webTitle: Make or break time for young talent discarded by Premiership

fields.headline: Fear in the air at the annual Shropshire cattle market
fields.standfirst: Make or break time for young talent discarded by Premiership
fields.trailText: After the euphoria of international victory, it's make or break time for young talent discarded by the Premiership. Stephen Bierley reports from the FA Premier League assessment trials.
fields.body:
The livestock markets of Shropshire are silent. No movement of animals and no auctions as the local farmers, so badly hit by the foot and mouth epidemic of 1967, go about their business with a stoic fatalism. Yet for the past three days, deep in the south-east of the county, those with an eye for a sturdy foot and a sound pair of lungs have been gathering from all parts of the country for their very own cattle market.

No bulls, cows or heifers, of course. Just footballers, that very peculiar animal much prone to foot in the mouth. For this has been the week of the annual late winter sales, more properly known as the FA Premier League assessment trials.

The euphoria of England's victory over Spain seemed even to have laid a golden hand on the national sports centre at Lilleshall yesterday morning, the bright March sunshine slowly releasing the frost-bound pitches and encouraging the birds into spring song. But there was tension in the air, tinged with fear.

Following the stud marks down the neat gravel paths that run between box hedges from the hall to the playing fields were a group of men, some young, some old, some battered, some neatly groomed, who held in their hands, along with their mobile phones and the names and numbers of all the players taking part, the power to break hearts and shatter dreams.

These were the scouts, an amorphous bunch who scour Britain on behalf of league and non-league clubs, searching out talent with a fanaticism born of many motives. "There are all sorts. Some can assess your oppositions and tell you precisely how they will play, their strengths and weaknesses. Others can fill your needs, like finding a reliable defender. Others can spot the stars of the future," said the former Aston Villa, Crewe and Swansea goalkeeper Geoff Crudgington, who now works as the community officer with Plymouth Argyle.

All the players at these three-day assessment trials - the under-18s and under-19s on Monday and Tuesday, the under-16s yesterday - had one thing in common. They had not been offered a contract, or a contract extension, by their Premiership club.

"You're looking at lads who have been used to success. The best at their school, or the best in their county. Now they are facing their first major knock-back," said Crudgington.

It does not make for an easy atmosphere. The unremitting energy and enthusiasm were abundantly obvious, but it was not pleasant, the strain of wanting to impress being all too obvious.

"I still love the game, but it can be wicked," said Tom Meachen, watching on behalf of Rotherham United. "The competition is huge, but I worry that not enough is being done at the grass-roots level. There isn't the quality of coaching in the schools. And you'd think, considering these lads here today have spent four or five years with a Premiership club, that I would be able to recommend half a dozen of them to Rotherham. But it just isn't like that."

Some will make it. Andy Parkinson, cast aside by Liverpool, was picked up by Tranmere Rovers here, and next week he will be hoping to help knock his old club out of the FA Cup. Plymouth, having seen Tottenham Hotspur spirit in another young striker, Ian Stonebridge, from the west country, were on hand to take him back when he was released.

But for all the success stories, there will be a plethora of disappointments. Many at Lilleshall insisted that the standard of those rejected by the Premiership is improving every year. Meachen is not convinced and others, though applauding England's victory against Spain, squirmed at the recollection of the Under-21s' humiliation by youngsters from the same country on Tuesday.

webTitle: Beckham should get on his bike to catch Barmby

fields.headline: Beckham should get on his bike to catch Barmby
fields.trailText: There were a lot of really encouraging signs in England's 3-0 victory over Spain. But if one thing disappointed me it was the fact that David Beckham again did not make the impact he is capable of.
fields.body:
There were a lot of really encouraging signs in England's 3-0 victory over Spain, not least the performances of Nick Barmby and Frank Lampard. But if one thing disappointed me it was the fact that David Beckham again did not make the impact he is capable of.

As against Valencia in Manchester United's recent Champions League matches, Beckham was below his best. And to my mind that's because he's often too deep and isolated rather than searching for the ball inside and doing damage in the final third.

His best moments on Wednesday night came when he dropped off the touchline, almost releasing Michael Owen at one point, and I would like to see him do that more frequently and get in more advanced positions.

That doesn't necessarily mean playing him as one of the two central midfielders. From the right he should be able to get in those great crosses while also coming inside to link up with the front players and threaten 30 yards from goal with shots and killer passes.

I know if I was managing a team faced with Beckham I would be happy to see him in those deeper areas or tied to the flank. It's far easier to pressurise him there, so he mustn't be obsessed with receiving passes from the back players and just hitting balls Gary or Phil Neville could do for him. He is at his best when he comes inside, makes a positive pass and then gets on his bike.

Hopefully Sven-Goran Eriksson will give him that licence to roam, look for the ball and dictate the play.

On the opposite flank there was a big plus point in Barmby, who I think is a better international player than he is for Liverpool. I had felt Steve McManaman would get that berth but he may find Barmby difficult to dislodge.

Barmby was very busy, did the simple things quickly and, having played as a striker, he has a nose for timing his runs and getting into the box. Those darts from midfield cause panic for defenders. He may not always receive a pass but it occupies opponents and can give the man on the ball better options.

The fact that Barmby will not swing over many crosses from the left doesn't bother me overly. When he comes inside the left-back can get forward to do that and, in any case, Barmby has the ability to spot a quick pass.

Plenty of others, such as Sol Campbell, Chris Powell and Gavin McCann, came out with credit. But it was young Lampard of West Ham who particularly caught my eye. He looked a lot stronger than on his last England appearance against Belgium, showed good authority, high energy and an ability to spot a pass. He may have staked a claim for a regular place, particularly if Steven Gerrard is not fit.

Michael Owen settled better than most would have expected into that withdrawn striker's position. One of the criticisms levelled at him is that he is not a good link-up man, but he was tidy, worked hard and he not only set up Barmby's goal but nearly provided another.

The fact remains, though, that he is at his best when he is driving at the near post or looking for threaded through-balls, and I'm not sure he has the vision of a natural link striker. Teddy Sheringham is so quick-thinking that he has the next pass sorted when the ball reaches him.

Yet Wednesday's performance was the best since the 2-0 win over Ukraine last May. There was great energy and, importantly, a good tempo. We will never be a patient international team because that doesn't suit us, but this showed that if we play at an English tempo and are positive we can be dangerous.

That means getting the ball into midfield and then into the front players quickly with penetrating passes. For all the Brazilians' great ability on the ball they play through people, and France do not take too long either to build an attack. I wonder whether it might help playing away from Wembley, which seemed to lend itself to a more studious game.

All in all I feel more positive than after the 1-1 draw in Paris, when a few people may have got a bit carried away. That was clearly a friendly and I fancy the French could have turned on the tap if they had wanted.

On Wednesday, England had to earn the right to play and, although I'm not getting carried away, as a start it was seven out of 10.

webTitle: Calls for ban on Lennon baiters

fields.headline: Calls for ban on Lennon baiters
fields.trailText:
Football authorities in Northern Ireland have been urged to ban the fans who booed Celtic's Neil Lennon during the 4-0 defeat against Norway on Wednesday night.
Northern Ireland 0 - 4 Norway
fields.body:
The fans who booed Celtic's Neil Lennon should be banned from all international matches in Belfast, the football authorities in Northern Ireland were urged last night.

Jim Boyce, the Irish Football Association president, joined the condemnation of the sectarian abuse directed at Lennon by a small section of fans during Wednesday's 4-0 defeat by Norway.

"I'm totally shocked by this," said Boyce. "I have no time for bigotry in any walk of life, let alone football. I have no time for sectarianism and I totally oppose it, as I've always done."

The IFA's community relations officer Michael Boyd said: "The time has come for the IFA to send out a strong message that this sort of behaviour cannot be tolerated. Banning these people is what the majority of decent supporters want."

A section of supporters at Windsor Park, a stadium situated in a Protestant stronghold, were unhappy that Lennon - a Catholic - opted to join Celtic in the summer.

Lennon was back in Glasgow last night considering his international future. "I want to talk this over with my family and manager [Martin O'Neill] before I make any comment," he said. "I don't way to say anything more."

The Northern Ireland manager Sammy McIlroy said after the match that he would select Lennon for the home World Cup qualifier against the Czech Republic on March 24 and expected him to play.

Meanwhile, Newcastle were dealt a fresh injury blow when it was revealed that their midfielder Kieron Dyer needs surgery. A scan on his long-standing shin injury yesterday showed that the cyst which is at the root of the problem is still present and doctors advised that it should be removed.

The operation will sideline him for several weeks and seems certain to rule him out of contention for England's crucial World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania on March 24 and 28 respectively.

Norwich's Darel Russell has had the red card he received at Crystal Palace last month annulled by the FA appeals committee after it viewed video evidence. His three-match ban has been lifted with immediate effect, freeing him for the First Division match at Huddersfield tomorrow.

Russell was sent off after a tackle on Jamie Smith had prompted an angry confrontation during the 1-1 draw at Selhurst Park.

Derby have snapped up the Icelandic international Thordur Gudjonsson from the Spanish club Las Palmas, initially on loan until the end of the season. Gudjonsson, whose father Gudjon Thordarson is manager of Stoke, where his younger brother Bjarni is a player, may make his debut against Tottenham tomorrow if his international clearance arrives in time. A permanent deal, for about £1.5m, has already been debated.

Two managerial appointments were made yesterday: Bristol Rovers appointed Garry Thompson, who had been in charge at the club since the sacking of Ian Holloway in late January, until the end of the season, and John Beck was confirmed as the manager of Cambridge United for a second spell.

webTitle: Wembley not my choice says Ken Bates

fields.headline: Wembley not my choice says Bates
fields.trailText: Ken Bates told MPs yesterday that the new national stadium should have been built in Manchester, and had a good go at the role of sports minister Kate Hoey.
fields.body:
Ken Bates, who was removed as chairman of Wembley National Stadium Limited last December following criticism over his handling of the project, told MPs yesterday that the new national stadium should have been built in Manchester.

Bates said: "In 1997 I said that this [Wembley] would be a total cock-up, let's go to Manchester or Birmingham. I advocated Manchester but also thought we could take the games around the country. But by that time the die was cast."

And Bates's replacement, Sir Rodney Walker, also giving evidence to the parliamentry select committee for culture, media and sport, said the stadium should perhaps have been built in Birmingham, which submitted the best proposal when bids for a new national stadium were invited.

Despite that, officials eventually opted for Wembley even though there were concerns about its location.

Bates also launched a blistering attack on the sports minister Kate Hoey. He told MPs her constant interference in the project and insistence that athletics should be included had delayed the rebuilding of Wembley by 19 months and increased costs by £30m. She had also been one of the main reasons that WNSL had failed to raise the £410m needed to finance the project.

The Chelsea chairman said she had constantly criticised the project and refused to attend meetings over issues such as how athletics could be included by constructing a platform that would carry a track.

He said: "Since Kate Hoey was appointed sports minister, there was nothing but criticism. We have had 19 months of knocking the project. We were supposed to be pulling together but all she did was undermine everything.

"She was leaking to the press all the time but what she was saying was based on total ignorance. One of the problems with the sports minister was that she never contacted me for a briefing to take her through the project. We only knew what she thought through the papers.

"Within two weeks of her taking office she had changed designs without any consultation. She was not qualified to do so and it is not the government's job to get involved in these sorts of things."

Bates denied he was responsible for the project's failure. "My biggest mistake was listening to the minister and her advisers."

Walker said Birmingham had submitted the best bid for the site of the new national stadium, although officials had been told Solihull council was unlikely to give planning permission because of concerns over traffic congestion.

He also informed MPs that he had been examining all aspects of the Wembley project and that even though athletics had been ruled out for the time being, the sport might return in the long run.

Walker added that Wembley officials were confident they would be able to raise the finance for the project. "I have become increasingly confident that when I return to the City having got an increased level of support from the FA we will get a more positive response."

Trevor Brooking of Sport England raised concerns about the Picketts Lock stadium after it emerged that the Greater London Authority would not underwrite the 2005 world athletics championships for which it is being built. Sport England has already given £1.3m of lottery funding to the project.

fields.headline: Sven's success comes Taylor-made
fields.trailText: Some of the gloss was taken off Eriksson's debut victory when Peter Taylor yesterday revealed that he and Steve McClaren had actually coached the players for the game.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson was yesterday basking in the plaudits for England's resounding success against Spain on Wednesday night, but some of the lustre was taken off his debut victory when Peter Taylor said that he and Steve McClaren had actually coached the players and that the Swede had not become involved until the day of the match.

"The first match was really about him getting to know the English players and vice versa," said Taylor, the Leicester City manager, who along with the Manchester United assistant McClaren is one of Eriksson's two senior coaches.

"The training was done by Steve and myself. Sven just wanted to sit back, observe and not change too much. He did not get involved in any training until the morning of the game, when he organised the team. That was how he wanted to do things."

Taylor, who took charge of England for their previous match against Italy because Eriksson was still contracted to Lazio, also implied that he had a large amount of input during the match, particularly the introduction of Emile Heskey in place of David Beckham.

"The coach asked me if Emile Heskey could play on the right of the midfield four," Taylor added.

"I knew from my days as England Under-21 coach that the former Leicester manager Martin O'Neill used to play him anywhere.

"I also remember from those days that I'd never seen anyone work as hard at closing people down as Heskey did. So I told Sven he'll play anywhere you want him, and that's what he did - that's what Emile's all about.

"He's such a good honest pro he will do anything anybody asks him. But I imagine he sees himself as a centre-forward because the way he played against Italy in Turin proved he can be a handful for the best defenders in the world."

Heskey may be restored to his favoured striker's role when Eriksson's proposed five-year reign begins in earnest this month with the World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania.

Then the experimentation will stop, but Taylor expects Eriksson to give all 31 members of his first England squad a chance to prove their worth.

"I think Sven was sorry he could not use more players against Spain. He was keen to play two teams against Spain because he wanted to see as many players in action as possible. There would have been value in that, because it would have helped him decide on the ones who were going to be involved in the two World Cup games.

"I don't think he will pick 31 players for those fixtures. I haven't got a clue as to the actual amount but I'm sure a squad of 24 will not be wide of the mark.

"That will mean some of the 31 being left out, but ultimately I'm sure everybody will be given the chance to show how they play at international level."

But I imagine he sees himself as a centre-forward because the way he played against Italy in Turin proved he can be a handful for the best defenders in the world." Heskey may be restored to his favoured striker's role when Eriksson's proposed five-year reign begins in earnest this month with the World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania. Then the experimentation will stop, but Taylor expects Eriksson to give all 31 members of his first England squad a chance to prove their worth. "I think Sven was sorry he could not use more players against Spain. He was keen to play two teams against Spain because he wanted to see as many players in action as possible. There would have been value in that, because it would have helped him decide on the ones who were going to be involved in the two World Cup games. "I don't think he will pick 31 players for those fixtures. I haven't got a clue as to the actual amount but I'm sure a squad of 24 will not be wide of the mark. "That will mean some of the 31 being left out, but ultimately I'm sure everybody will be given the chance to show how they play at international level."  You've read the piece, now have your say. webTitle: Just a start, but a good one

fields.headline: Just a start, but a good one
fields.standfirst: David Lacey finds Eriksson's smorgasbord appetising but not yet tested
fields.trailText: Eriksson's smorgasbord looks attractive, but all we have really had is a starter - the real taste-test is yet to come.
fields.body:
Ron Greenwood, when he was England manager, once remarked that "we knew that any team we picked would beat Spain". The point was echoed by Sven-Goran Eriksson at Villa Park on Wednesday night when in a game of 18-a-side his smorgasbord easily saw off Jose Antonio Camacho's paella 3-0.

The Swede's circumstances are somewhat different. Greenwood was speaking after his bench-warmers had defeated Spain 2-1 in a dead match in Naples, both sides having been eliminated from the 1980 European Championship. Eriksson needed an acceptable performance and an emphatic victory to persuade a few more doubters that appointing a foreigner to coach England was not the biggest insult to national pride since Errol Flynn liberated Burma.

He ended up with both, and since the new coach had introduced himself to the squad only two days earlier the country could hardly have asked for anything more. In fact, yesterday found the prime minister declaring that "like everyone else I think he's the best man for the job". If he changes his mind, it is a bit late to call the election before England meet Finland in a World Cup qualifier on March 24.

Predictably, Eriksson begged people not to get carried away by Wednesday's result. "When you win a friendly against Spain 3-0 you must try to keep both feet on the ground and not try to fly and say you have won the World Cup," he insisted.

Since no England supporter under the age of 40 will remember this particular airborne experience the caveat was hardly necessary. Wednesday's performance has merely raised the hope that England can qualify for the 2002 World Cup in the Far East despite taking only a point from their opening two qualifiers.

"I think we have a good chance," Eriksson said, "because there are still games to go and we can get 19 points. But if you have taken only one from two matches you really cannot afford to fail again."

In this context the brightest aspect of Wednesday's success was the general readiness of Eriksson's new charges to take responsibility for their performances. With a minimum of time to get across his ideas and having established little beyond the fact that he prefers a 4-4-2 formation, the coach played everybody except Emile Heskey in his club position and was rewarded by the swiftness with which various combinations found a rapport.

Eriksson made six changes at half-time and another when Gary Neville replaced his brother Phil at right-back. Amid the reshuffle the understanding and confident passing and movement of Nick Barmby, Michael Owen and Andy Cole was a constant factor.

Barmby, bright and busy, will hope that scoring England's first goal under Eriksson leads to greater things than his similar favour for Glenn Hoddle. For the first time Owen showed himself well capable of dropping deep off a front man, and Cole's best performance for England may well have won him pole position in Eriksson's thoughts ahead of Heskey.

The latter was brought on to operate from the right of midfield, a largely ineffective David Beckham having passed the captain's armband to Sol Campbell. Heskey spent much of the time on this flank when he impressed Kevin Keegan in the goalless friendly against Argentina a year ago and against Spain he took his goal, England's second, smartly enough.

Far from having to scratch around for a worthwhile England team, then, Eriksson would appear to have a luxury of choice. A healthy competition for places is never a bad thing and only Campbell, Scholes and Beckham are virtually certain of selection.

Barmby, Owen, Andy Cole, Butt and the Nevilles are high in the queue yet Kieron Dyer, Steven Gerrard and Steve McManaman and maybe Ray Parlour would all have appeared at some stage on Wednesday had they been fit. Even the goalkeeping position is wide open, Nigel Martyn's penalty save from Javier Moreno having put further pressure on David Seaman, who was not even on the bench.

In defence Rio Ferdinand in the first half and Ugo Ehiogu, who headed England's third goal, in the second gave Campbell sufficiently solid support to suggest that the side will somehow get by without the recently retired Tony Adams. And the response at left-back of Charlton's Chris Powell to winning his first cap at the age of 31 encapsulated the positive attitude of the side as a whole.

England teams invariably try their best for a new master before they find out more. It is a bit like Monty Python's lumberjack song in which the backing group sets off in hearty voice only to tail off in disgust when the hero reveals himself as a tree-chopping transvestite.

Eriksson is unlikely to confound his squad with dossiers, introduce them to faith healers or try to get results by cheerleading alone. But all he has really done so far is say hello. The imminent World Cup qualifiers will be the true test of the significance of Wednesday's victory.

webTitle: Blair woos farmers in price 'arm lock'

fields.headline: Blair woos farmers in price 'arm lock'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Tony Blair tried to woo rural voters last night when he accused supermarkets of "putting an arm lock" on British farmers and promised to find a long-term solution to the problem of low prices paid by the big five supermarket chains to farmers.
fields.body:
Tony Blair tried to woo rural voters last night when he accused supermarkets of "putting an arm lock" on British farmers and promised to find a long-term solution to the problem of low prices paid by the big five supermarket chains to farmers.

Face-to-face with farmers at a question and answer session in the Forest of Dean, Gloucestershire, where foot-and-mouth disease is only a few miles away, he made it plain that he wanted a reappraisal of agriculture once the crisis was over.

He told Martin Baber, a farmer who complained that he was getting 7p less for a litre of milk now than four years ago: "We all want cheaper food in the shops, but... the supermarkets have got you pretty much in an arm lock at the moment."

With Mr Baber warning him that "there would be no farmers left soon", he promised talks with supermarkets and farmers to get a new strategy. "Once these immediate problems are over, we need to go back to the table and try to work it out on a long-term basis."

Mr Blair went out of his way to reassure farmers that he sympathised with their problem. "We know you are feeling real difficulty and pain. We can't offer you solutions but we can offer a partnership to try to reach them."

Earlier he had a 15-minute meeting with the local National Farmers' Union which complained that the supermarkets are squeezing producers without passing on the low prices to consumers.

Mr Blair was also rallying support in some of the marginal rural constituencies Labour won in 1997. With party members anxious about apathy, Mr Blair had stopped first at GCHQ in Cheltenham to underline restoration of trade union membership.

webTitle: Government website whitewashes foot and mouth

fields.headline: Government website whitewashes foot and mouth
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
Special report: Internet news
fields.trailText: The Government came under fresh criticism this morning over the foot and mouth crisis when it was revealed that the Downing Street website on rural Britain makes no mention of the outbreak.
fields.body:
The Government came under fresh criticism this morning over the foot and mouth crisis when it was revealed that the Downing Street website on rural Britain makes no mention of the outbreak.

Despite nearly two weeks passing since the first reported case of foot and mouth, the "Backing Rural Britain" section of the prime minister's website ignores the epidemic which has now spread to every corner of the UK.

Indeed, it refers to the "forthcoming" rural white paper on the countryside - despite the fact that it was published last November.

The lack of up-to-date information has been criticised as "symbolic" by the Countryside Alliance.

A spokesman for the group said "The site is hugely outdated.

"This shows what we have been arguing  that politicians take no interest in rural concerns and have an absurd set of priorities."

The site even includes the disclaimer: "No-one is trying to pretend that problems dont exist", despite not mentioning the killer disease in more than six pages of text.

A Downing Street spokesman said: "There is so much information to upload we just haven't got around to it yet."

The pages  entitled Backing Rural Britain, within the factfiles of the Downing Street site  end with the comment: "Later this year the government will publish a rural white paper."

In fact, the document came out on November 28 last year.

But up to the minute information on the spread of the foot and mouth epidemic can be found on the ministry for agriculture, fisheries and food site.

Six new cases of the diseases, which affects sheep, cattle and pigs but not humans, were confirmed yesterday, bringing the total to 35 in the UK so far.

Two of yesterday's cases were in Dumfrieshire, the first outbreak of the disease in Scotland since the scare started on February 20 at an abbatoir in Essex.

fields.headline: Where to go snorkelling
fields.standfirst:
Where can a fairly weak swimmer go snorkelling over coral direct from the beach rather than from a boat?
Elizabeth Hopkins
fields.trailText: Where can a fairly weak swimmer go snorkelling over coral direct from the beach rather than from a boat?
fields.body:
 Even the most timid swimmers cannot fail to be tempted into the waters off the beach at the Iberotel Grand Sharm at Sharm-el-Sheik, in Egypt on the Red Sea. There is a floating walkway which leads out over the coral reef on to a large safe pontoon.You climb into the deep water and are surrounded by the most beautiful fish imaginable.Some even stood on the ladder or held on to the ropes around the edge and put their heads under water. You do not even have to swim if you are nervous.The hotel is bliss. It is in the Hayes and Jarvis Diving Brochure.

Clare Jones

 In September 1998 the Guardian did a big, irresistable, feature on Grenada. With my retirement coming up, my wife and I booked a four-week holiday at Coral Cove Cottages on the south of the island as a start to retirement bliss. It was paradise. The self-catering cottages are a few steps from the beach and a wooden jetty runs out over shallow water to a point where you can enter the sea without wading through seaweed and coral and over rocks. The water at the end of the jetty is only a few feet deep, generally very calm and there is a wooden ladder to lower yourself into the clear, blue water. We met Michael, who lives locally, when he brought us freshly caught crayfish (lobsters) and he arranged to take us to Hog Island in his boat later in the week. After mooring at Hog Island Michael and our son waded into the sea and went off snorkelling with a harpoon gun to catch our lunch. On their return, Michael made a fire and cooked the catch in a large iron pot, together with vegetables he'd brought with him. We enjoyed our meal which we washed down with bottles of cold beer and Michael's home-made drink which was like custard made with evaporated milk!

It's a long way to go, not cheap but very close to heaven. Go for it.

Gary Cornford

 If you can afford the airfare, I would highly recommend Heron Island on the Australian Barrier Reef. Heron Island is a coral island on top of it's own reef, so you only have to go for a paddle to see the fish and coral.The island is a resort only open to guests who stay for a few nights or more, so it is quiet and relatively unspoilt; it is also home to a university wildlife research station.

You can walk around the island in about half an hour and, as most of the guests spend their time diving, the beach is almost deserted when the dive boat is out. There is excellent snorkling and diving, with tuition available. When we visited in January the turtles were laying their eggs on the beach each night and birds were nesting in the trees. There is a semi-submersible boat trip so you get to see the further reaches of the reef even if you can't dive.

The accomodation and food is to a high standard, and there are plenty of opportunities to learn about the wildlife with guided island and reef walks and talks in the evenngs. When we went in 1997 it cost about £100 per person per night for a suite of rooms with a sea view and all meals, which was a bargain for such a slice of paradise.

I had never snorkeled before and as an average swimmer I did not feel I had missed out on anything during the trip.
Carol Norton

 From the Colonial Beach Hotel in Mauritius. It is ideal for snorkelling from the part sandy, part pebbly beach - only a couple of yards into the water there are a great variety of colourful fish. A few yards further in, the variety of fish increases. The hotel is small, informal and friendly and provides free snorkelling equipment. It can be booked through Kuoni and, while Mauritius is not cheap, this hotel is one of the cheapest (early to mid-September is a good time to go).

Frauke Sinclair

 The island of Maui in Hawaii offers many opportunities to snorkel over coral directly off gently shelving sandy beaches in water that is warm and mostly flat calm. Probably the best spots are in Kihei and Wailea. Right in front of the Mana Kai apartments on South Kihei Road is an extensive area of rocks covered with coral of all shapes sizes and colours with fish to match and a resident population of giant green sea turtles. You can swim over them straight off the beach, and from November to April if you swim under water you can hear whales singing. Dozens of humpback whales spend the winter in the bay and you can sit on the beach and watch then jumping. There are similar good snorkel spots all the way along this stretch and a turtle sanctuary at nearby Makena beach.
Andy Simpson

 The place to go is Sharm-el-Sheik on the Sinai peninsular in Egypt. I am 60, can just manage a width of the swimming pool provided I'm not at the deep end, and am too short sighted to see anyone more than a few feet away!

There is a fringe reef round most of this coast and the sea is so salty that floating is especially easy. We found a beach close to our hotel where you go down some steps onto a manmade platform over the coral and then launch yourself into the sea off a ladder (just like going into a pool) and there you were, amongst the fish and within a yard of the coral! Magic!

I found I could stay in the water for half an hour or so with no trouble. I concluded I'm a weak swimmer because I worry about not being able to breathe - the snorkelling tube eliminates that problem, and I really had a super time and would urge you to have a go.
Tony Krarup

 For snorkelling straight off the beach you can't beat the Coral View Resort in Pulau Besar, Perhentian Islands, Malaysia. The coral stacks right off the shore support hundreds of varieties of fish and an amazing range of animals from turtles to giant clams, and even black-tipped reef sharks (they're totally safe, honest, but guaranteed to cause palpitations on first viewing!)

The Perentian Islands are off the north east coast of Malaysia, a 20-minute speedboat ride from close to Kota Bharu, and amazingly accessible from Kuala Lumpar or Singapore by train or even plane.

Top tips for staying on Perhentian Besar are as follows. 1 Buy or borrow a mask, snorkel and flippers from a diving shop here in the UK before you go - you can hire them on the island but you'll want to be in the water for so long that the hire charges will work out more than the cost of purchase! 2 Buy a 'fish identification' sheet (one of the laminated ones) as you will want and need to know exactly what you have seen so you can brag about it for ages. 3 The islands are 'dry', so if it is important to you to have an evening bevvy, take your duty frees with you! 4 Stay at the Coral View Resort - it's got the best food, the best coral, excellent rooms, great staff, flying foxes and it's about £15 per night for ensuite aircon chalets.
Vicki May

 It's a long way to go, but Kauai fits the bill perfectly. We spent a week there in September and found the snorkelling was actually better from the beach than from a boat.

There are many spots to choose from.The best bet is to ask for advice in one of the snorkel hire shops when you arrive. Our favourite was Ke'e Beach, which is enclosed by coral apart from a narrow channel. You could swim among shoals of 3 foot long fish without getting out of your depth.
Martin Thomas

 Go to Villivaru Island in the Maldives which has it's own house reef a short foot-paddle from your beach bungalow. Wear a thin wetsuit for buoyancy, confidence and protection from the sun.
Dave George

 Last year we went from Mission Beach (Australia) to the coral reef. We were dropped on a small, beautiful sandbank, off an island, and I snorkelled over the reef from there. I am a weak swimmer but it was terrific. The skipper was environmentally sensitive and the whole trip - although it took a couple of hours to get to the reef - was friendly and enjoyable.
Roger Sim

 We discovered heavenly snorkelling for beginners in Curacao. I also hope that someone is going to suggest Rangali Island in the Maldives - we are about to go there for exactly that reason.
Christine Bibby

 You don't even need to swim at the Club Med in Moorea in the Pacific; simply wade out and poke your face into the water. Although they're small fry, you'll see lots of tropical fish. Our knees were even cleaned by a brilliant blue and black striped sucker fish! If you can swim about 10 metres further out, you may even see eels and tunafish.

Another alternative (much more expensive) is Bird Island in the Seychelles. There is a protected lagoon on one side of the island. Although it doesn't have the coral that you'll find in Moorea, it's a beautiful place to visit. If you're a real landlubber, check out the giant land tortoise. And stay awake at least one night to watch the night sky, where you'll see constellations not visible from the Northern Hemisphere. Brilliant!
John and Phyllis Murphy

 We traveled to Jordan last year and had some wonderful snorkeling in Aqaba. We stayed at the Alcazar Hotel, which has its own beach club adjacent to the coral reefs in the Red Sea. The hotel arranges free transport to the club, which is about eight kilometres south of Aqaba. The facilities are very good with restaurant, swimming pool and showers and you can hire snorkelling equipment. There is direct access to the reef from the beach.
Sue Banton

There are several places along the Kenya coast where the reef is quite close to the beach. My favourite is Tiwi, about 20km south of Mombasa, where at low tide you can get to the reef almost without getting your feet wet by using a sand bank that joins the beach to the reef. At high tide you have to wade a bit! There are no hotels there, and no package holidays, which for me is a major plus point, but there is self-catering accommodation and it is very easy to organise a holiday there yourself. If you don't like the cooking or cleaning part of self-catering, it is possible to employ people to do this for you.
Brian Thorogood

 My friend and I class ourselves as wimps, so Coral Bay on the west coast of Australia was ideal for us to snorkel. You are able to walk from the shore to the reef where the sea is gentle and we never felt out of our depth. Our visit here was the first time either of us had snorkelled and for us it was by far the best place to do it in Australia. You can hire the gear for about A$12.00. The resort is unspoiled and friendly, the campsites are great (hostel not so good), and after a day under the sea the happy hour at the pub is particularly welcome.
Angie Thompson

 We highly recommend the Royal Diving Centre, a 10-minure drive south of Aqaba, in Jordan. Here there is a short jetty from which you can lower yourself into four or five feet of water, and then observe not only corals, but also some beautiful fish and other colourful marine life. Do beware of stonefish on the seabed, and the occasional lion fish, though!
Jane and Pete, Bath.

 The Red Sea has some of the finest coral and marine life in the world, and is easily accessible from the UK. Last Christmas my partner and I spent a blissful week in the Egyptian resort of Na'ama Bay. Here you can simply walk into to sea from the beach and see spectacular fish and coral. Na'ama Bay is next to the larger (less attractive) resort of Sharm-el-Sheik, and there are direct flights to Sharm from the UK.

The beach is lined with mainly luxury hotels, but there are parts of it which are accessible to everyone. Most people arrange a package with a travel agent which will take them to one of these hotels, but it is just as possible to travel independently - we took the bus there from Cairo and found a very nice hotel near the beach at a reasonable price. However many of the tour companies seem to offer good value packages. An added attraction is that some of the hotels have piers going out over the coral so that you can easily get into the water without touching any coral in the shallows. From these piers you are still in safe, shallow, warm water and can snorkel easily over the beautiful coral reef.
Anita Ball

 Although you will still have to take a boat to get to the beach location, Dive Tulum (PADI registered) located near Tulum in Mexico, provide escorted snorkelling trips which include snorkelling in a pool where an underground freshwater river meets the sea. The reef that lies just off the Carribean cost of Mexico is extensive, and sits close to the shore, but I would still recommend that you take a boat out to it. It really is no problem even for a very weak swimmer as the boat and other swimmers are always nearby.
Quentin North
fields.bodyText:  Even the most timid swimmers cannot fail to be tempted into the waters off the beach at the Iberotel Grand Sharm at Sharm-el-Sheik, in Egypt on the Red Sea. There is a floating walkway which leads out over the coral reef on to a large safe pontoon.You climb into the deep water and are surrounded by the most beautiful fish imaginable.Some even stood on the ladder or held on to the ropes around the edge and put their heads under water. You do not even have to swim if you are nervous.The hotel is bliss. It is in the Hayes and Jarvis Diving Brochure. Clare Jones  In September 1998 the Guardian did a big, irresistable, feature on Grenada. With my retirement coming up, my wife and I booked a four-week holiday at Coral Cove Cottages on the south of the island as a start to retirement bliss. It was paradise. The self-catering cottages are a few steps from the beach and a wooden jetty runs out over shallow water to a point where you can enter the sea without wading through seaweed and coral and over rocks. The water at the end of the jetty is only a few feet deep, generally very calm and there is a wooden ladder to lower yourself into the clear, blue water. We met Michael, who lives locally, when he brought us freshly caught crayfish (lobsters) and he arranged to take us to Hog Island in his boat later in the week. After mooring at Hog Island Michael and our son waded into the sea and went off snorkelling with a harpoon gun to catch our lunch. On their return, Michael made a fire and cooked the catch in a large iron pot, together with vegetables he'd brought with him. We enjoyed our meal which we washed down with bottles of cold beer and Michael's home-made drink which was like custard made with evaporated milk! It's a long way to go, not cheap but very close to heaven. Go for it. Gary Cornford  If you can afford the airfare, I would highly recommend Heron Island on the Australian Barrier Reef. Heron Island is a coral island on top of it's own reef, so you only have to go for a paddle to see the fish and coral.The island is a resort only open to guests who stay for a few nights or more, so it is quiet and relatively unspoilt; it is also home to a university wildlife research station. You can walk around the island in about half an hour and, as most of the guests spend their time diving, the beach is almost deserted when the dive boat is out. There is excellent snorkling and diving, with tuition available. When we visited in January the turtles were laying their eggs on the beach each night and birds were nesting in the trees. There is a semi-submersible boat trip so you get to see the further reaches of the reef even if you can't dive. The accomodation and food is to a high standard, and there are plenty of opportunities to learn about the wildlife with guided island and reef walks and talks in the evenngs. When we went in 1997 it cost about £100 per person per night for a suite of rooms with a sea view and all meals, which was a bargain for such a slice of paradise. I had never snorkeled before and as an average swimmer I did not feel I had missed out on anything during the trip. Carol Norton  From the Colonial Beach Hotel in Mauritius. It is ideal for snorkelling from the part sandy, part pebbly beach - only a couple of yards into the water there are a great variety of colourful fish. A few yards further in, the variety of fish increases. The hotel is small, informal and friendly and provides free snorkelling equipment. It can be booked through Kuoni and, while Mauritius is not cheap, this hotel is one of the cheapest (early to mid-September is a good time to go). Frauke Sinclair  The island of Maui in Hawaii offers many opportunities to snorkel over coral directly off gently shelving sandy beaches in water that is warm and mostly flat calm. Probably the best spots are in Kihei and Wailea. Right in front of the Mana Kai apartments on South Kihei Road is an extensive area of rocks covered with coral of all shapes sizes and colours with fish to match and a resident population of giant green sea turtles. You can swim over them straight off the beach, and from November to April if you swim under water you can hear whales singing. Dozens of humpback whales spend the winter in the bay and you can sit on the beach and watch then jumping. There are similar good snorkel spots all the way along this stretch and a turtle sanctuary at nearby Makena beach. Andy Simpson  The place to go is Sharm-el-Sheik on the Sinai peninsular in Egypt. I am 60, can just manage a width of the swimming pool provided I'm not at the deep end, and am too short sighted to see anyone more than a few feet away! There is a fringe reef round most of this coast and the sea is so salty that floating is especially easy. We found a beach close to our hotel where you go down some steps onto a manmade platform over the coral and then launch yourself into the sea off a ladder (just like going into a pool) and there you were, amongst the fish and within a yard of the coral! Magic! I found I could stay in the water for half an hour or so with no trouble. I concluded I'm a weak swimmer because I worry about not being able to breathe - the snorkelling tube eliminates that problem, and I really had a super time and would urge you to have a go. Tony Krarup  For snorkelling straight off the beach you can't beat the Coral View Resort in Pulau Besar, Perhentian Islands, Malaysia. The coral stacks right off the shore support hundreds of varieties of fish and an amazing range of animals from turtles to giant clams, and even black-tipped reef sharks (they're totally safe, honest, but guaranteed to cause palpitations on first viewing!) The Perentian Islands are off the north east coast of Malaysia, a 20-minute speedboat ride from close to Kota Bharu, and amazingly accessible from Kuala Lumpar or Singapore by train or even plane. Top tips for staying on Perhentian Besar are as follows. 1 Buy or borrow a mask, snorkel and flippers from a diving shop here in the UK before you go - you can hire them on the island but you'll want to be in the water for so long that the hire charges will work out more than the cost of purchase! 2 Buy a 'fish identification' sheet (one of the laminated ones) as you will want and need to know exactly what you have seen so you can brag about it for ages. 3 The islands are 'dry', so if it is important to you to have an evening bevvy, take your duty frees with you! 4 Stay at the Coral View Resort - it's got the best food, the best coral, excellent rooms, great staff, flying foxes and it's about £15 per night for ensuite aircon chalets. Vicki May  It's a long way to go, but Kauai fits the bill perfectly. We spent a week there in September and found the snorkelling was actually better from the beach than from a boat. There are many spots to choose from.The best bet is to ask for advice in one of the snorkel hire shops when you arrive. Our favourite was Ke'e Beach, which is enclosed by coral apart from a narrow channel. You could swim among shoals of 3 foot long fish without getting out of your depth. Martin Thomas  Go to Villivaru Island in the Maldives which has it's own house reef a short foot-paddle from your beach bungalow. Wear a thin wetsuit for buoyancy, confidence and protection from the sun. Dave George  Last year we went from Mission Beach (Australia) to the coral reef. We were dropped on a small, beautiful sandbank, off an island, and I snorkelled over the reef from there. I am a weak swimmer but it was terrific. The skipper was environmentally sensitive and the whole trip - although it took a couple of hours to get to the reef - was friendly and enjoyable. Roger Sim  We discovered heavenly snorkelling for beginners in Curacao. I also hope that someone is going to suggest Rangali Island in the Maldives - we are about to go there for exactly that reason. Christine Bibby  You don't even need to swim at the Club Med in Moorea in the Pacific; simply wade out and poke your face into the water. If you're a real landlubber, check out the giant land tortoise. And stay awake at least one night to watch the night sky, where you'll see constellations not visible from the Northern Hemisphere. Brilliant! John and Phyllis Murphy  We traveled to Jordan last year and had some wonderful snorkeling in Aqaba. Our visit here was the first time either of us had snorkelled and for us it was by far the best place to do it in Australia. You can hire the gear for about A$12.00. The resort is unspoiled and friendly, the campsites are great (hostel not so good), and after a day under the sea the happy hour at the pub is particularly welcome. Angie Thompson  We highly recommend the Royal Diving Centre, a 10-minure drive south of Aqaba, in Jordan. Do beware of stonefish on the seabed, and the occasional lion fish, though! The beach is lined with mainly luxury hotels, but there are parts of it which are accessible to everyone. Most people arrange a package with a travel agent which will take them to one of these hotels, but it is just as possible to travel independently - we took the bus there from Cairo and found a very nice hotel near the beach at a reasonable price. However many of the tour companies seem to offer good value packages. An added attraction is that some of the hotels have piers going out over the coral so that you can easily get into the water without touching any coral in the shallows. From these piers you are still in safe, shallow, warm water and can snorkel easily over the beautiful coral reef. fields.headline: Head in the clouds
fields.standfirst: In her final week in Asia, Sue loses herself and then loses two days, climbs into the clouds  and goes dophin watching
fields.trailText: In her final week in Asia, Sue loses herself and then loses two days, climbs into the clouds and goes dophin watching
fields.body:
This week I say a sad goodbye to Asia and g'day Australia - a week spent enjoying more of Bali but ending with two missing days. First I must thank Gill for suggesting I go to Tirtagangga, where I spent a lovely few days. But my stay did not start too well. After visiting the water gardens where Bruce decided to be silly and hide among the statues, I went for a walk among the rice fields. I soon totally lost all sense of direction and found myself lost among tiny villages, surprising several women who were squatting in the dykes (no wonder the rice grows so well), I had forgotten the name of where I was staying and no one seemed to speak English.

Eventually two little boys pointed me in the right direction which involved walking through the compound of a ferocious looking woman, who made no attempt to call off her equally ferocious dog that was snapping at my heels.

Relieved to be back at the little restaurant at the losman (lodgings), the evening was spent with Jonathan, a young Canadian, two Japanese and the collection of young men who work there as guides, odd job men, taxi drivers and anything else they can think of to earn a dollar. They were lovely, anxious to improve their English and gain email contacts all over the world. The nearest computer was a 15-minute bus ride away - it was therapeutic to be away from them for a few days.

I fixed with Made, one of the lads, to take me to the bottom of Mount Lempuyang the next morning. He duly arrived with motorbike and a tin helmet for me to wear. So suitably saronged and helmeted (removed for the photo as I looked like a first world war soldier) I set off to the temple, Pura Telaga Mas, at the bottom of the mountain, arranging to be picked up four and a half hours later. The whole of Bali was preparing for a big festival in a few days and ceremonies were already underway. I climbed the stairs to the temple but was almost frogmarched back down by two official looking men in white. I was afraid I had committed some cultural faux pas, but no, they merely wanted me to take their photograph. Seeing the result in the back screen they were obviously not happy because they marched back in position for me to take another.

It was then a half hour walk up a very steep hill to reach the 1,700 steps that led up the mountain to the Pura Lempuyang Luhur at the top. This is one of the important directional temples of Bali that protect the island. I had flashbacks to my Nepal trek as my lungs and knees protested. There was a lot of sign-language mutual support as the local people struggled up too, some with small children or carrying large loads on their heads. I did not see another tourist all day.

The guide book had promised the most spectacular views of Bali and the huge volcano, Gunung Agung, but half way up we entered the clouds and the view from the top was white nothingness in every direction.

Back at the lower temple I rested, listening to the music, watching the men build shelters from bamboo and rushes and was invited to sit with the young men and girls all busy making offerings for the ceremonies. So no view, but an enjoyable experience, meeting the ordinary people of Bali, all in their best sarongs, everyone cheerful and nobody trying to sell you anything.

That evening in my losman there was a show of music, singing and dancing. Very different from the polished performances of Ubud, this was 15 men and boys from the village singing traditional songs. As the arak - the local spirit - flowed freely, they dragged up members of the audience to dance. My camera remained firmly zipped in its case. As I sat on my veranda afterwards I wished I could have recorded the sounds of the night here - a cacophony of bull frogs, cicada and various other twitterings. The morning sounds are less welcome, the dawn crowing of all the roosters that everyone in Bali keeps for their favourite sport - cockfighting.

Not wanting to make the same mistake twice, next morning I hired Made as my guide for a two-hour walk. We went through paddy fields and up a hill with a wonderful view of the mountain I had climbed. Bruce and I were impressed with our achievement. Made took me to his simple village with clay brick walls and rush roofs, showed me all the cooking equipment in the kitchen and his family temple. He asked if I wanted a swim in the dyke, but after what I had witnessed before and the fact that we were standing by a man washing his cows, I declined.

On Monday it was time to head off to Lovina in the north. Lovina has a black beach of volcanic sand. I booked into a lovely place with a swimming pool. Eating out that night with Jessica whom I had met on the bus, I mentioned catching my plane on Friday night to be in Darwin on the 1st. She assured me that the 1st was in fact Thursday, making my flight Wednesday night, and that Wednesday was a public holiday with no buses. Instant panic and bewilderment as to how I had lost two days somewhere. My big bag was still in Ubud, but luckily there was a bus going to Kuta and then on to Ubud at lunchtime the next day. So, not to be outdone by Sam, that left me just about time to do the dolphin trip at 6am the next morning.

This was a strange experience with a flotilla of small catamarans all charging about after any sightings of the dolphins half an hour or so out to sea. We did glimpse a couple in the distance, the flotilla broke up and we seemed to be heading back. But I was pleasantly wrong as with a few other boats we spent another hour in a different spot following a group of dolphins who then met up with others making a pod of 20 or so. They delighted us with their diving, a couple of show-offs doing fancy somersaults. Trying to catch them on camera was difficult as they seemed to dive under water every time I was ready, I was terribly excited when I eventually did get a shot. Presumably the dolphins could leave the boats well behind if they wanted to - I hope they do not mind this daily game of chase.

So it was virtually hello goodbye Lovina and back to Ubud for the evening. Time to negotiate an extortionate fee for a lift to the airport the following evening. Wednesday saw the whole of Bali dressed up for the first day of the Galungan Festival. All the streets were lined with 'penjor' - tall tapering bamboo poles intricately decorated and each with a box of offerings of fruit and food at the base. The family of the homestay where I was staying showed me their family temple with tall piles of fruit and other gifts. The children of my street gathered to dress up in a Barong costume and toured the streets with drums and gongs dancing for a small offering of money. I was sad to leave Bali, barely having seen half of the island. The more time I spent there the more I appreciated its unique talented people, and that it is much more than a tourist trap.

So yesterday, at 6am I arrived in Darwin and checked in to the YHA. The pampered youth of today - a YHA with a swimming pool - what happened to the cold showers and rota of chores of the hostelling days of my youth? The only minus is that the room smells awful - a mould, wet towels mixed with sweat smell - ugh. I questioned the receptionist who said all the rooms are the same, it is the humidity. I will stick it tonight as I am off to Kakadu tomorrow.

I have spent the day organising myself - swapping my Darwin to Sydney flight for Alice Springs to Cairns and buying an extra flight Cairns to Sydney, booking a four-day tour to Kakadu and another six-day trip to Ayres Rock (Uluru) and Alice Springs.

I decided to go the more popular south and east route as it is still very much the wet season and there are not many notices for car shares around. This is going to be an expensive month, tours seem to be the only option as I do not dare drive all the vast distances on my own. It will be a bit strange to be in groups after so long travelling alone. I'll let you know how I get on. It will also be strictly hostels here as accommodation is much dearer than I have been used to. No worries. G'day to you all.
Sue

fields.headline: The longest day
fields.standfirst: This week, Milly tests her staying power to new limits, bops to the Beatels, has a large dose of shorts, and prepares a few surprises for her mum...
fields.trailText: This week, Milly tests her staying power to new limits, bops to the Beatels, has a large dose of shorts, and prepares a few surprises for her mum...
fields.body:
Thursday is payday for me, woohoo! It somehow makes all the crazy hours worthwhile. Breakfast shift that morning was easy and I would almost say fun - we were done, cleared and out by 1pm, giving me a chance to enjoy the afternoon sun. Late afternoon I headed to Darling Harbour to see Jennifer Lopez (or J Lo as she calls herself) promoting her new album. I don't know why I didn't think many people would be there - in fact it came as a shock that crowds in their thousands had been waiting all day just to catch a glimpse of her as she did a mass autograph signing. I didn't stay long - staring at a celebrity doesn't really keep me happy for long, though she is as gorgeous as everybody makes out.

In last week's report I claimed I'd had my longest day ever. Well, Friday is a new record - and I don't think this one will be beaten. . . It began with a bus journey at 3.43am. Now the only time I've been awake that early before is because I'm yet to go to sleep - this isn't when normal people head off for work. Having somehow dragged my body through a morning of serving breakfast to a Japanese crowd I then had two hours' break before I started my next shift of the day - just enough time to curl up and sleep in the staff restaurant. The evening shift was for the same Japanese group, only they were quite different to how they had been that morning. I had the unfortunate job of handling beverages - unfortunate because they all went wild. There really were some big drinkers there, though at least it kept me busy.

There was a Beatles cover band - The Beatels - for their party, which was brilliant as I got to bop along to their tunes while I was working - one of my many job perks. I managed to get away at 1.15am, which meant I'd had a 17 hour working day, which is pretty impressive. More impressive was how I managed to stay in the pub for four hours after that (to celebrate still being alive). I returned home tired, less than sober, and over 24 hours later than I'd left. I think that day is going to take some beating.

On Saturday, unsurprisingly I found that moving had become a tricky task. Somehow I managed to leave my welcoming bed and return to the city for my evening at work (it really has become my second home). The function was an extravagant American do where the whole room had been decked out in underwater scenery complete with blue-painted dancers. It was another entertaining shift, especially near the end when they requested all staff to parade in wearing sombreros and carrying trays of tequila. A good night, and I even got to take home a ridiculously oversized flower arrangement which is now sitting on top of the telly in my room, making it look at least a bit homely.

The next day was my day off, and I was walking down the main Coogee Road when I met a guy who I've been at school with since I was five years old. I knew he was in the area so it wasn't a total shock to see him, but I still found it bizarre. We spent the afternoon chatting about travelling - which I find a lot of my conversations are about, and soon realised how surprisingly normal it was despite being the other side of the world. Having nothing better to do that evening, I went with Brian to a short film festival in the Domain. It turned out to be enormous - Tropfset no.9 - with a crowd of 85,000 gathered to watch. The evening was broadcast around the world and involved watching and then choosing winners from 16 films all less than seven minutes long.

There were some brilliant entrants - the winner was a tale of a man attempting to light a cigarette while driving, (I won't spoil the ending!) and I was incredibly glad I went. The next day I spent the whole day on the beach - which is incredibly lazy but felt wonderful so I'm not going to feel bad about it. In the evening me and Brian felt charged up for a second go at the pub quiz in Bondi. fields.headline: Obituary: John Diamond
fields.standfirst:
Writer John Diamond dies
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The journalist, writer and broadcaster John Diamond, who has died of cancer, aged 47, did not battle his illness bravely. Nor was he courageous in the face of death.
fields.body:
The journalist, writer and broadcaster John Diamond, who has died of cancer, aged 47, did not battle his illness bravely. Nor was he courageous in the face of death.

He developed cancer and, despite treatment, it killed him. As he wrote in his best-selling book, because cowards get cancer too, first published in 1998, "I despise the set of warlike metaphors that so many apply to cancer. My antipathy has nothing to do with pacifism and everything to do with a hatred for the sort of morality which says that only those who fight hard against their cancer survive it or deserve to survive it - the corollary being that those who lose the fight deserved to do so."

It was the kind of clear-eyed opinion, acutely expressed, which John's enormous circle of friends and colleagues had come to expect of him.

It was a horrible irony that the illness that eventually ended John Diamond's life was also, professionally, the very making of him. He was successful before, of course; he was well known around media London as the master of the quickly delivered newspaper opinion piece, first person or otherwise, to a tight deadline.

His career as a presenter on radio and television was burgeoning and he had earned enough money to indulge his fetish for electronic gadgetry, fine tailoring or overpowered motorbikes on which he rarely went further than the corner shop.

But the column he published in his regular slot in the Times, in which he announced that a lump on his neck had been diagnosed as a cancerous tumour, changed everything.

As he continued to chart the course of his illness, through treatment to terminal diagnosis and beyond, there was a growing realisation among both readers and editors alike that his immense facility for language, previously expended for the most part on the smallest of domestic issues, had disguised a writer of immense talent and skill.

His column won him a prestigious What the Papers Say award and his book was received with glowing reviews, both of which events gave him huge pleasure.

John Diamond was born in Stoke Newington , the son of a biochemist and a fashion designer and one of three brothers. He remained close to his family and he was particular proud of his secular Jewish upbringing, which informed almost all of his opinions.

Though he travelled far from his childhood in East London - a serious shlep by taxi to Hammersmith - he liked people to know that he had started a long way outside the media world of which he became such a part.

His tastes were essentially as eclectic as those of the editors who commissioned him. A member of the Labour party from the age of 16, he did write a column on politics for the Daily Mirror under the short-lived editorship of his friend Roy Greenslade but, for the most part, his work was on the softer side.

He wrote about everything and anything - from travel, cigars and cars, to the role of the fax machine in modern life and the importance of a good whisky in a man's life. He had the true hack's hunger for the by-line and he will no doubt have found it galling that his death would give a number of his friends and rivals the opportunity for one the day after.

Until his illness literally stole his tongue he was also a regular presenter on BBC radio, his talent for which was recognised by the judges in the Sony Radio Awards. A feverish interest in technology led to his presenting a series of Tomorrow's World and columns in computer magazines for which he won awards.

It was no accident that the summer parties he threw with his second wife, the journalist Nigella Lawson, were famous for being attended, in turn, by the famous whom he so enjoyed collecting around him and who, in return, so loved him.

In the summer of 1999, there was another John and Nigella party, this time thrown for them by the architect Lord Rogers and his wife Ruthie. It was, we were told, to mark 10 years of their relationship, though as John had only recently been informed that his condition was terminal it was clear we were celebrating an extraordinary life as well as a marvellous marriage.

A crowd of over 200 listened as John, now essentially mute, made an extraordinary speech of thanks to everybody for their support by writing on to an overhead projector beamed up on to the wall.

We can only, in turn, be thankful that the gap between that speech and his death was so much longer than any of us expected that warm summer's night.

 Read the full obituary in tomorrow's Guardian.

fields.headline: Fury as army attacks Buddhist relics
fields.trailText: The Taliban, Afghanistan's Islamic fundamentalist rulers, yesterday defied the international community by embarking on a campaign to destroy all the country's ancient statues.
fields.body:
The Taliban, Afghanistan's Islamic fundamentalist rulers, yesterday defied the international community by embarking on a campaign to destroy all the country's ancient statues - including two giant Buddhas carved into a mountainside which have survived since the second century.

The information minister, Qudratullah Jamal, confirmed that fighters armed with tanks and rocket launchers began yesterday to obliterate Aghanistan's Buddhist antiquities in accordance with an edict issued by the Taliban's spiritual leader, Mullah Mohammed Omar, on Monday.

Taliban fighters are carrying out the instruction in cities including the capital Kabul, Jalalabad, Herat, Kandahar, Ghazni and in Bamiyan, the mountainous Hindu Kush valley where the Buddhas are located, he said.

Buddhist pilgrims from across central Asia and India have visited Bamiyan for hundreds of years. More recently the statues had become Afghanistan's biggest tourist attraction. The bigger figure stands 55 metres tall and is said to be the world's largest Buddha statue. The smaller statue measures 38 metres.

Two years ago Taliban fighters blew off the smaller Buddha's face and fired rockets at the larger statue's groin, damaging the folds of his robes and destroying several ancient frescoes. They dumped burning tyres on the large Buddha's chin, blackening the face.

Troops have now sealed the valley, refusing requests by foreigners to inspect the site.

Rival Mojahedin factions fighting for control of Kabul looted most of the best exhibits from the city's museum in 1992, but the Taliban are now expected to destroy the 6,000 or so items which remain. "All of the statues all over the country will be destroyed," Mr Jamal insisted.

The destruction of the ancient artefacts has appalled an international community already wearied by Taliban outrages, even provoking condemnation from the hardline regime's closest ally, Pakistan. It called on the Taliban to protect historical sites, adding: "We hope the Afghan government will show tolerance ... as well as respect for international sentiment in this regard."

Buddhist countries such as Sri Lanka and Thailand registered their protests earlier in the week, and described the destruction of the two giant Buddhas as a "loss to humanity". They were joined yesterday by Egypt, which said the Taliban's actions could not be justified by appeals to Islam.

The German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, said his government was horrified by the "willful" destruction of the Buddhas. Russia and India have also protested.

The EU said the Taliban would "deprive the people of Afghanistan of its rich cultural heritage". Unesco, the UN's cultural organisation, said last night it was urgently appealing to the Arab world to exert pressure on the Taliban to reverse their decision.

Mullah Omar had earlier shrugged off western criticism. "All we are destroying are stones. I don't care about anything else but Islam," he said. The edict had been made in accordance with Islamic law following a meeting of senior religious leaders, he explained.

His decree can only be explained as an extreme response to the UN's decision last month to impose new sanctions against Afghanistan.

fields.headline: Blair promises to empower regions
fields.standfirst: The prime minister is laying the groundwork to devolve more power to the English regions
fields.trailText: Campaigners for regional government have received a massive boost after the prime minister announced that he was prepared to hand more power to the English regions.
fields.body:
Campaigners for regional government have received a massive boost after the prime minister announced that he was prepared to hand more power to the English regions.

Tony Blair is known to be cool on further devolution in the wake of the creation of the Scottish and Welsh parliaments.

Today, however, he told business leaders in Cardiff that the government is ready to go further, but only with the consent of people living in the regions.

"I have always taken the view that this is something that cannot be forced on people," said Mr Blair. "People have got to want it. You have to be sure that this is what I call a real people's desire and not a desire of the political class."

The statement hints that the government is preparing to move on the regional agenda, which has become a key issue for many activists in Labour's northern heartlands.

The speech comes just weeks after deputy prime minister John Prescott apparently promised a green paper on regional government.

He told delegates at Labour's spring conference: "I believe the time is right to take the next steps, to publish a green paper on empowering our regions to strengthen the accountability of regional chambers and where people vote for it, to move to directly elected regional assemblies."

Speaking at the same conference, chancellor Gordon Brown said Labour would devolve power to the regions and local communities in a second parliamentary term.

The party is committed to directly elected regional government by its 1997 general election manifesto. Those regions that voted for an assembly in a referendum would be allowed to have one, the document said.

Since then, there has been little movement on the issue, although ministers claim the nine regional development agencies and Ken Livingstone's Greater London Authority are a first step.

webTitle: Failing hopes for recovery of railway

fields.headline: Hopes for getting system back to normal disappear
fields.standfirst:
Easter deadline to free network cannot be met

Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: The Selby crash has wrecked any lingering hopes Railtrack had of returning the network to normal by Easter.
fields.body:
The Selby crash has wrecked any lingering hopes Railtrack had of returning the network to normal by Easter.

Railtrack sources admitted yesterday that it was working under considerable pressure to free the network of remaining speed restrictions after the Hatfield rail crash almost five months ago.

The company had already hinted that it might not be able to meet its self-imposed timetable, but the Selby crash has made it impossible to meet the Easter deadline. It is now working on the assumption that speed restrictions, rerailing and points maintenance will not be completed until well into the summer.

GNER hopes that the east coast mainline will be open again by Monday, but contracting engineers say it will be at least a week before the wrecked coaches and wagons can be removed after the police have finished sifting through the evidence on site.

Passengers travelling between London and Scotland can use an alternative service on the west coast mainline, provided by Virgin Trains, or break their journey at Doncaster and be taken by coach to York, where they will be able to continue by train. Passengers have been told that this will delay their journey by at least an hour. But travellers said yesterday that the delay was much longer.

Those who did brave extended journeys yesterday expressed their fears about safety. Martin O'Brien, 46, an enterprise manager from Ashford, Middlesex, who was travelling from London to Doncaster, said: "The rail network has been quite bad for a number of years and it will take a long time to reach a decent standard of safety. Ultimately, the railways need long-term investment. You can't just have quick fixes. The government needs to put more money in and I can't see things improving for at least 10 years."

Tim Brown, 37, of Fulham, west London, a venture capitalist travelling on business to Cambridge, added: "I travel a lot in Europe because of the work that I do and it still amazes me that I can get from London to Paris in a quicker time than it takes for me to get from King's Cross to Leeds."

Speed restrictions of 20mph are still causing delays on many parts of the network, particularly the busy inter-city routes between north and south and London and the west.

Railtrack faces fines by the rail regulator, Tom Winsor, for failing to carry out normal maintenance work on the network. Independent consultants are examining Railtrack's books to see how far the company has fallen behind on its commitments.
