webTitle: Polly Toynbee: Labour and the leftwing

fields.headline: Coalition of dreamers
fields.standfirst:
These leftwingers are a bit like that scene from The Life of Brian: 'What did the Romans ever do for us?'

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: These leftwingers are a bit like that scene from The Life of Brian: 'What did the Romans ever do for us?'
fields.body:
The noble portals of the St Ermine's hotel, a stone's throw from the Palace of Westminster, have witnessed much of the tug of war on the left over the past few decades. Yesterday, inappropriately renamed the Jolly St Ermine's, it played host to a voice from yesteryear - Dave Nellist, former Militant Labour MP, now Socialist Alliance chair, launching their general election campaign. It was he, in his wry and charming way, who referred to this as the spot where rightwing Labour plotters used to gather two decades ago - the founders of the social democratic party, splitters on the other side. (Like me.)

This coalition of Militant and the Socialist Workers party is putting up 100 candidates in England and Wales, one in all 72 Scottish seats, enough to guarantee them a party political broadcast. But unity on the left is still tricky. Arthur Scargill, standing in Hartlepool for his Socialist Labour party, will not answer their letters, but despite that, in a brotherly gesture the Alliance will not put up a candidate against him (and Peter Mandelson). The first questioner to leap to her feet at the press conference was from Worker's Tannoy, demanding to know why the Socialist Alliance had supported Ken Livingstone, "who is not a socialist!" Next up was someone demanding to know whether Socialist Alliance had abandoned Troops Out of Ireland and revolution as the path to socialism? Nellist was evasive on both, saying they hadn't quite decided yet, but he'd let her know. "Oh, I see, answer's in the post, eh?" she snorted. Those too young to remember scenes such as these from the 70s and 80s might get the general flavour from the Judaean People's Liberation Front in The Life of Brian. (We will come to what the Romans did for us later.)

Their policies? Take a blank piece of paper, think blue sky and green field and dream of a world that is a better place than this, unfallen angels in an Eden of goodness where all manner of things shall be well. Every child and adult will be immediately lifted out of poverty, benefits will be restored to 16-year-olds, pensioners will not be means tested so all get the minimum income guarantee, free nurseries and childcare for all, rail and buses renationalised, abolish the monarchy, legalise cannabis, open the borders to free immigration, abandon Nato and the European Union, increase foreign aid, bring in a 35-hour week, a minimum wage of £7 an hour, abolish private schools, free breakfast and lunch for all children, free grants for all students, freeze council rents, renationalise water and make it free and a whole lot more besides.

How will it be paid for? There was some confusion about whether or not the budget was included in the press pack. (It wasn't, it would be following in a few days.) But the rough outline called for swingeing wealth and property taxes, socking great income tax rises for the rich and companies, slashing military spending, plus using the giant surplus the miserly chancellor is sitting on. No pain, all gain. Nellist is no Scargill, a sincere and decent man - but more vicar than politician.

Who are their target voters? "The working classes, the millions not the millionaires". They are after the disillusioned, disenfranchised, disenchanted, going for the "won't vote" vote. Psephologist Professor Paul Whiteley, writing in the Guardian yesterday, predicted that voting may drop at the next election to levels unseen since 1918 - down from 1997's already low 72% to a projected 65% this time. Many more Labour supporters say they won't vote this time than disaffected stay-at-home Tories. Among these there are potential rich pickings for a Socialist Alliance offering instant nirvana. Votes will be counted in saved deposits, not seats won - but the real aim is to shift Labour policies. There are plenty of MPs and indeed some ministers in peril of losing their seats where Alliance intervention might be a killer. By Whiteley's calculation, some 52 Labour MPs stand to lose through Labour voters' apathy. It may be better to hope the young might at least vote Alliance than not vote at all. But those 52 threatened MPs might prefer to try winning them over with a bit more visionary inspiration.

For us old troopers, there is no romance on the dotty left. The bad old days when these folk were inside the Labour tent fighting like rats in sacks are still a raw memory. A majority of Labour members may secretly yearn for many Socialist Alliance policies in their hearts: cannabis, monarchy, no privatising tube or air traffic, 35-hour week, universal nurseries and more. They are quite wrong to suggest Labour's heart is not with the poor, when all the first money has poured towards them - pensioners, children, minimum wage and all. In fact the more vigorously the Alliance campaigns, the better it may be for Labour, so unjust and outrageous is their refusal to admit Labour is one iota better than the Tories.

Critical friends have a hard time steering between admiration for New Labour's success and urging it on to do better. Militant et al represent the politics of 18 years of failure, but that does not mean that every one of their policies is unthinkable. Look at the Institute for Public Policy Research (IPPR) and the Fabians, Labour's two closest think-tanks - sane, wise and clever political realists. Both are now pressing Labour to be bolder, more radical - yes, more leftwing in a modern context. The Fabian's great tome on tax and spending, the result of long deliberation by a commission chaired by Lord Plant, came up with excellent plans for a fair wealth tax and higher income tax for earnings over £100,000. It does not take raving loony lefties to propose such a thing, for the IPPR also wants the rich taxed more in national insurance and pension perks.

The IPPR has just produced its own manifesto calling for a "more ambitious agenda" for the next election, questioning why one of the most prosperous countries in the world is still so un equal, something the government ducks. webTitle: Opposition pledge to cull ministerial jobs

fields.headline: Opposition pledge to cull ministerial jobs
fields.standfirst: Special report: Election countdown
fields.trailText: William Hague has told Whitehall's most senior official that an incoming Conservative administration would cut three places off the 22-strong cabinet, reduce the number of junior ministers - now around 80 - by up to 10 and slash the overall running costs of government by 10%.
fields.body:
William Hague has told Whitehall's most senior official that an incoming Conservative administration would cut three places off the 22-strong cabinet, reduce the number of junior ministers - now around 80 - by up to 10 and slash the overall running costs of government by 10%.

The Conservative leader also informed Sir Richard Wilson, the cabinet secretary, that he would make it a legislative priority to create secure reception centres for asylum seekers, privatise Channel 4, and permit only English MPs at Westminster to vote on English-only matters.

Like much of his programme that is controversial - unworkable according to critics - English voting has a markedly rightwing flavour.

If elected, he also intends to move quickly to end the early release of prisoners, impose "honesty in sentencing" and ensure that - contrary to reports that he has backed off the policy - any future Tony Martin, who killed a burglar, has better legal protection in defending the home.

Mr Hague's meeting last week was the traditional one granted to leaders of the major opposition party as election day looms. It will be followed by meetings between shadow ministers and permanent secretaries in each department.

"It demonstrates that we are serious about government," one Hague aide said last night as the Tory leader headed for his weekend spring conference in Harrogate.

fields.headline: Islamic anger at 'terrorist' list
fields.trailText: Islamic groups yesterday responded angrily to the government's decision to brand 21 organisations as terrorist under a new act which for the first time enables the home secretary to proscribe those targeting foreign states.
fields.body:
Islamic groups yesterday responded angrily to the government's decision to brand 21 organisations as terrorist under a new act which for the first time enables the home secretary to proscribe those targeting foreign states.

More than half the 21 groups on the list of banned groups, announced on Wednesday, are of Muslim origin, though it also included the Kurdistan Workers Party (the PKK), which has thousands of supporters in Britain.

The London-based Islamic Human Rights Commission complained that Britain was effectively siding with friendly or "occupying regimes" responsible for oppression of Muslim populations. "Struggles in Palestine and Kashmir, for instance, are undertaken by the indigenous population against illegal occupation. International law accepts that such struggles are perfectly just," said Massoud Shadjareh, the group's chairman.

Yasser al-Serri, an Egyptian who runs the London-based Islamic Observation Centre, said the act would "poison relations between Britain and Islamists". Kurdish spokesmen who asked not to be identified criticised the inclusion on the list of the PKK.

The act defines terrorism as "the use or threat of action", including serious violence against property in Britain or abroad, to advance a political, religious or ideological cause. It also includes a new offence of "incitement".

Critics of the measure, including the civil rights group Liberty, claim it is so draconian as to make it an offence to help to organise a meeting to be addressed by someone who professes to belong to a proscribed organisation, even if the person is not really a member, and says nothing about the organisation.

Charles Clarke, the Home Office minister, said that what action might be taken against the proscribed groups was up to the police.

Simon Hughes, the Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, said: "We must ensure that decisions to ban organisations take fully into account their democratic aims."

fields.headline: Ministers face far-left challenge
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Election countdown
Special report: Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was yesterday warned that senior ministers will face "credible" head-on election challenges from non-Labour leftwingers determined to give the "disenfranchised working class" a socialist alternative to vote for.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was yesterday warned that senior ministers will face "credible" head-on election challenges from non-Labour leftwingers determined to give the "disenfranchised working class" a socialist alternative to vote for.

The former Labour MP for Coventry South East, David Nellist, chaired a London press conference to unveil a "David and Goliath" challenge from the Socialist Alliance, an umbrella organisation for far-left groups which expects to field at least 100 candidates throughout Britain's 659 seats.

Mr Nellist, a veteran member of the Militant Tendency, now a Coventry councillor, and his allies in other small leftwing parties believe they can rally voters "whose hopes have been cruelly dashed" since Mr Blair's landslide win in 1997.

Issues being highlighted include minimum wages and pensions, tuition fees and student loans, public control of the NHS and the railways, and resistance to further council houses sales.

Among the ministers who face challenges are Jack Straw in Blackburn, David Blunkett in Sheffield Brightside, Stephen Byers in Tyneside North, Chris Smith in Islington South, and Charles Clarke in Norwich North.

The SA campaign claims that it will attract disenfranchised voters who would oth erwise not vote at all - at least 100,000 overall. "We intend to be the major minor party in this election," Mr Nellist said.

But there are divisions on the Trotskyite left between those who want to create a centralised party and those inclined to stick to a loose tactical alliance between such groups as Militant, the Socialist Workers Party (SWP), and the Workers Revolutionary Party.

fields.headline: Labour homes in on marginals
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Life in parliament
Special report: Election countdown
fields.trailText: Labour's high command is attempting to disrupt Tory election preparations by allowing MPs in Britain's most marginal constituencies to skip votes at Westminster, forcing the Conservatives to divert resources away from more needy seats.
fields.body:
Labour's high command is attempting to disrupt Tory election preparations by allowing MPs in Britain's most marginal constituencies to skip votes at Westminster, forcing the Conservatives to divert resources away from more needy seats.

MPs in Labour's 30 most marginal seats have been ordered to increase their profiles in their constituencies to spread fear among their Tory opponents who are largely being left to their own devices by Central Office.

Labour strategists issued the orders after discovering that Conservative Central Office is putting comparatively few resources into the 30 most marginal seats, assuming that they should bounce back to the party.

Such constituencies have been classified by the Tories as "stand alone" seats.

The new Labour strategy became clear in recent weeks when the government's majority fell noticeably in a series of Commons votes.

MPs in former Tory strongholds, such as Kettering and Gillingham, which the Tories will win back on a swing of less than 2%, have been told to attend high-profile events in their constituencies.

The disclosure of Labour's latest spoiling tactic highlighted renewed confidence at Millbank in the face of dire Tory poll results.

An ICM poll for yesterday's London Evening Standard showed that Labour has jumped to a 24-point lead in the capital, representing a three point swing since the last general election.

Labour stands at 52% in London, up three points on 1997, with the Tories on 28%, down three, and the Liberal Democrats staying on 15%.

The Conservatives' poor poll results will cast a shadow over the party's spring conference which begins in Harrogate today.

fields.headline: Hague considers Millbank spy post
fields.standfirst: Special reports: Election countdown
fields.trailText: For William Hague it may well turn out to be a case of 'If you're not able to beat 'em, at least join 'em' ... The Tories are poised to storm Millbank, Labour's HQ and home of the party's spin machine.
fields.body:
For William Hague it may well turn out to be a case of 'If you're not able to beat 'em, at least join 'em' ... The Tories are poised to storm Millbank, Labour's HQ and home of the party's spin machine.

Conservative officials have been offered a base in the Thames-side tower during the election campaign by a sympathetic company.

Mr Hague is considering the invitation to use office facilities made available on the 22nd floor, allowing him to peer down on Mr Blair and his new Labour troops 21 floors below.

The unexpected move raises the prospect of Mr Blair and Mr Hague bumping into each other in the gents or the lifts.

Millbank strikes fear into Conservatives after Labour masterminded its 1997 massacre from the block. Occupying space above Labour would boost Tory morale, and Chris Lewis, chief executive of hi-tech consultancy Lewis UK, made the offer last month in a letter to Mr Hague.

The bulk of the Tory forces will remain in Conservative Central Office in nearby Smith Square, but a Tory spokesman made clear that Mr Hague saw the tactical value of infiltrating some personnel into Millbank.

Clive Booth, a Lewis spokesman, said: "We are completely apolitical but we thought we would make the offer to the Conservatives. It's not creating mischief."

fields.headline: 'Loopholes' in Scottish bill on information
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: Campaigners have given a cautious welcome to the Scottish executive's draft freedom of information bill, published yesterday. By Kirsty Scott.
fields.body:
Campaigners have given a cautious welcome to the Scottish executive's draft freedom of information bill, published yesterday.

The justice minister, Jim Wallace, said the proposals put Scotland ahead of the rest of the UK in promoting a culture of openness, but campaigners said the document still had too many loopholes.

The proposals centre on an independent information commissioner, who would enforce the legislation and would be appointed by the Scottish parliament.

The bill would ensure for everyone a legal right of access to information held by a broad range of Scottish public authorities, including, under some circumstances, the executive. The legislation would also apply to government departments, local authorities, the NHS, educational institutions and the police.

Information would not have to be disclosed where it would "substantially prejudice" matters such as the effective conduct of public affairs, law enforcement, national security or defence. The test in the rest of the UK is simply "prejudice".

The bill was launched in the executive's Edinburgh warehouse, which holds eight miles of files. It has been touted as one of the most important pieces of legislation to emerge from the executive.

"Today we are setting out a right of access to public information which promises to transform the culture of Scottish public life," Mr Wallace said. "This will be a right exercisable by anyone. A right to know that does not rely on establishing a need to know. We need to change the mindset of Scotland's public authorities from that of a culture of secrecy to a culture of openness."

However, the Campaign for Freedom of Information said some of the bill's exemptions were still too widely drawn. It was concerned that the first minister could veto disclosure in certain cases, and believed the costs of access could be unacceptably high north of the border. But it welcomed the "substantial prejudice" test for non-disclosure.

"The substantial prejudice test which applies to many, though not all, exemptions in the draft bill is an important step forward and a tougher test for authorities to meet than the simple 'prejudice' test in the UK act," a campaign spokesman said. "It will require Scottish authorities to operate more openly than similar bodies elsewhere in the UK.

"However, in certain cases, the first minister would still be able to veto the commissioner's decisions, and we are opposed in principle to any veto."

Mr Wallace, meanwhile, said the power to override the commissioner would rarely be used. "We want to strike the right balance, but I believe it is tipped in favour of openness."

Chris Bartter of the public service union, Unison, which had urged the executive to create a robust and radical piece of legislation, said the legislation had not gone as far as the union would have wished, but he gave it a cautious welcome.

"In some areas it goes further than the rest of the UK, but there are other areas where there may be problems, particularly the question of payment. Looking at this you may end up paying more for information under Scottish legislation than you would in the rest of the UK."

The draft bill is open to consultation until May 25. The UK Freedom of Information Act reached the statute book in November last year but will not come into force until 2002.

The first questioner to leap to her feet at the press conference was from Worker's Tannoy, demanding to know why the Socialist Alliance had supported Ken Livingstone, "who is not a socialist!" Next up was someone demanding to know whether Socialist Alliance had abandoned Troops Out of Ireland and revolution as the path to socialism? Nellist was evasive on both, saying they hadn't quite decided yet, but he'd let her know. "Oh, I see, answer's in the post, eh?" she snorted. Those too young to remember scenes such as these from the 70s and 80s might get the general flavour from the Judaean People's Liberation Front in The Life of Brian. (We will come to what the Romans did for us later.)

Their policies? Take a blank piece of paper, think blue sky and green field and dream of a world that is a better place than this, unfallen angels in an Eden of goodness where all manner of things shall be well. Every child and adult will be immediately lifted out of poverty, benefits will be restored to 16-year-olds, pensioners will not be means tested so all get the minimum income guarantee, free nurseries and childcare for all, rail and buses renationalised, abolish the monarchy, legalise cannabis, open the borders to free immigration, abandon Nato and the European Union, increase foreign aid, bring in a 35-hour week, a minimum wage of £7 an hour, abolish private schools, free breakfast and lunch for all children, free grants for all students, freeze council rents, renationalise water and make it free and a whole lot more besides.

How will it be paid for? There was some confusion about whether or not the budget was included in the press pack. (It wasn't, it would be following in a few days.) But the rough outline called for swingeing wealth and property taxes, socking great income tax rises for the rich and companies, slashing military spending, plus using the giant surplus the miserly chancellor is sitting on. No pain, all gain. Nellist is no Scargill, a sincere and decent man - but more vicar than politician.

Who are their target voters? "The working classes, the millions not the millionaires". They are after the disillusioned, disenfranchised, disenchanted, going for the "won't vote" vote. Psephologist Professor Paul Whiteley, writing in the Guardian yesterday, predicted that voting may drop at the next election to levels unseen since 1918 - down from 1997's already low 72% to a projected 65% this time. Many more Labour supporters say they won't vote this time than disaffected stay-at-home Tories. Among these there are potential rich pickings for a Socialist Alliance offering instant nirvana. Votes will be counted in saved deposits, not seats won - but the real aim is to shift Labour policies. There are plenty of MPs and indeed some ministers in peril of losing their seats where Alliance intervention might be a killer. By Whiteley's calculation, some 52 Labour MPs stand to lose through Labour voters' apathy. It may be better to hope the young might at least vote Alliance than not vote at all. But those 52 threatened MPs might prefer to try winning them over with a bit more visionary inspiration.

For us old troopers, there is no romance on the dotty left. The bad old days when these folk were inside the Labour tent fighting like rats in sacks are still a raw memory. A majority of Labour members may secretly yearn for many Socialist Alliance policies in their hearts: cannabis, monarchy, no privatising tube or air traffic, 35-hour week, universal nurseries and more. But if they had sat listening yesterday to the trashing of Labour's achievements, they would spit with fury. What did Labour (the Romans) ever do for us? A lot, and a lot more to come. How dare Dave Nellist and Mark Steel talk of "Labour cuts" just as more money than ever before comes on stream? They are quite wrong to suggest Labour's heart is not with the poor, when all the first money has poured towards them - pensioners, children, minimum wage and all. In fact the more vigorously the Alliance campaigns, the better it may be for Labour, so unjust and outrageous is their refusal to admit Labour is one iota better than the Tories.

Critical friends have a hard time steering between admiration for New Labour's success and urging it on to do better. Militant et al represent the politics of 18 years of failure, but that does not mean that every one of their policies is unthinkable. Look at the Institute for Public Policy Research (IPPR) and the Fabians, Labour's two closest think-tanks - sane, wise and clever political realists. Both are now pressing Labour to be bolder, more radical - yes, more leftwing in a modern context. The Fabian's great tome on tax and spending, the result of long deliberation by a commission chaired by Lord Plant, came up with excellent plans for a fair wealth tax and higher income tax for earnings over £100,000. It does not take raving loony lefties to propose such a thing, for the IPPR also wants the rich taxed more in national insurance and pension perks.

The IPPR has just produced its own manifesto calling for a "more ambitious agenda" for the next election, questioning why one of the most prosperous countries in the world is still so un equal, something the government ducks. Quality of life is the true measure of a successful society, not mere economic progress, they say. They call for turning Railtrack into a non-profit trust, reducing prison numbers, proportional representation to re-engage voters, a new deal for refugees and work/life balance rights.

None of this is wild stuff. This is the new boldness of Labour party thinkers realising that in a strong second term, a great leap forward is now thinkable. There is an important difference between Labour's sworn enemies and its friends who sometimes criticise its timidity and lack of ambition. Growing numbers in the Commons and on the inner loops fear Labour's next manifesto will lack new vision. Why, they ask, is Labour always happier to disappoint its own ranks than offend those interests who will never support Labour anyway?

webTitle: Tory peer's '£2m plan to buy off election challengers' revealed

fields.headline: Tory peer's '£2m plan to buy off election challengers' revealed
fields.trailText: Senior Conservatives last night distanced themselves from claims that a "renegade peer"           was willing to raise up to £2m from wealthy backers to pay the UK Independence           party not to put up candidates against Eurosceptic Tories at the general election.
fields.body:
Senior Conservatives last night distanced themselves from claims that a "renegade peer" was willing to raise up to £2m from wealthy backers to pay the UK Independence party not to put up candidates against Eurosceptic Tories at the general election.

Using an ex-Tory colleague and peer who defected to the UKIP as a go-between, the peer - said to be Lord Pearson of Rannoch, a close friend of Lady Thatcher - is reported to have engaged in lengthy negotiations with Nigel Farage, one of the UKIP 's three MEPs elected to Strasbourg in 1999.

After mulling over the Tory dilemma with his friend and Scottish neighbour Lord Neidpath, now a UKIP voter, Lord Rannoch is said to have remarked that it would be "an awful tragedy" if the UKIP knocked out sound anti-EU Tories, and "vaguely" broached the possibility of raising between £1m and £2m to keep the UKIP out of 30 key Tory seats.

The talks, details of which were leaked last night to the Times, were triggered by fears that UKIP candidates could repeat the kind of damage that they and supporters of the late Sir James Goldsmith's Referendum party did to John Major at the 1997 general election.

But according to the account confirmed by Mr Farage - though by no other source outside the UKIP - the talks broke up in December, allegedly because Tory HQ got wind of them and took the view that such an offer would inflate the UKIP 's importance and damage William Hague by linking him, however remotely, to the perceived extremism of a party that wants Britain to leave the EU. A source close to Mr Hague said last night: "It's got nothing to do with the Tory leadership, it's just a renegade Tory peer."

Oliver Letwin, one of the shadow cabinet members whose West Dorset seat would have been spared a UKIP challenge had the deal gone through, was also dismissive. Mr Letwin, whose UKIP opponent took 1,590 votes in 1997 -slightly fewer than his 1,840 majority - said he had heard nothing of the claims. "They may or may not put up a candidate against me. I am not going to pay anyone anything," he told the Guardian.

John Redwood, another MP already targeted by a UKIP nominee in Wokingham, a much safer seat, was also unaware of any talks - which had little confirmation outside Mr Farage's own account.

One veteran of the strife-torn UKIP warned: "I would treat anything Nigel says with suspicion. He's always been a blathermouth."

Among the senior Tories who would also have been spared by the deal were David Heathcoat-Amory and Angela Browning, whose anti-European manifesto in Tiverton last time won her support from Paul Sykes's Democratic Movement. David Davis, another Eurosceptic and potential leadership challenger, is also under threat. So is Iain Duncan Smith, the ambitious shadow defence secretary.

Mr Farage told the Times that talks broke down after word of them got out. He claimed it showed how worried the Tories were by the UKIP , though in reality Mr Hague has gone a long way to win back disaffected Eurosceptics by taking a much tougher line than did Mr Major. Almost 1m voted for the Referendum party and UKIP in 1997, costing Mr Major up to 20 seats. Between them they got 3% of the vote.

Lord Pearson, a life peer who made a fortune in insurance, is an enthusiastic amateur in politics terms who came to politics late and became a Tory whip. He is a friend of the former cabinet minister Jonathan Aitken.

webTitle: Cook acts against Mugabe as top judge clings on

fields.headline: Cook acts against Mugabe as top judge clings on
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Britain last night expressed growing anger at the government of Zimbabwe by announcing the withdrawal of a peacekeeper training team at the end of this month.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal  in Harare and  Michael White
fields.body:
Britain last night expressed growing anger at the government of Zimbabwe by announcing the withdrawal of a peacekeeper training team at the end of this month.

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, increased pressure on President Robert Mugabe as tension rose in Zimbabwe over the plight of the chief justice, Anthony Gubbay.

Mr Cook expressed concern at the "deteriorating situation" in Zimbabwe, which expelled two foreign journalists last week.

Meanwhile, Mr Gubbay, 68, defied a government deadline to quit yesterday, throwing into disarray Mr Mugabe's attempts to purge the courts of judges who ruled against his seizure of white-owned farms.

He arrived at his supreme court office despite government claims that he had already been replaced by a Mugabe supporter.

The justice minister, Patrick Chinamasa, claimed his defiance made no difference. "We now refer to him as former chief justice," he said. "If he embarks on any games, which I believe he is trying to do, he only has himself to blame ... He is disrespectful and not worthy of being a chief justice."

The information minister, Jonathan Moyo, said Mr Gubbay would be dealt with "in a humane way".

Mr Gubbay and other supreme court judges have been under pressure to quit - with open threats to their safety - since handing down a series of rulings declaring the wholesale occupation of white-owned farms illegal.

Mr Gubbay made no comment yesterday but his lawyers said he would resist any attempt to remove him or bring him before a tribunal.

"Any attempt to force our client to vacate his chambers or house will be challenged. There is no basis to appoint a tribunal and any such action will be challenged by our client," they said.

The justice minister told parliament on Wednesday that a former attorney general and prominent Mugabe supporter, Godfrey Chikausikyu, would shortly be sworn in to replace Mr Gubbay.

The government wants Mr Chikausikyu to oversee a disciplinary panel it intends to use to dismiss other senior judges it accuses of having a "Rhodesian mindset".

As the crisis over land reform and Mr Mugabe's resistance to growing opposition has escalated, Britain has suspended help with the land reform programme, switched aid to non-governmental organisations and ended sales of parts for military aircraft.

This week the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, returned from Zimbabwe demanding its suspension from the Commonwealth and a freeze on assets.

fields.headline: Prescott 'at compromise limit' over tube
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Sources close to John Prescott insisted last night that the deputy prime minister had gone to the "outer limit" of compromise over the London tube, after the board of Ken Livingstone's Transport for London body authorised a legal challenge to his plans for partial selloff.
fields.body:
Sources close to John Prescott insisted last night that the deputy prime minister had gone to the "outer limit" of compromise over the London tube, after the board of Ken Livingstone's Transport for London body authorised a legal challenge to his plans for partial selloff.

The decision to allow the transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, to seek judicial review, which was moved by the Liberal Democrat Susan Kramer and backed unanimously by board members, is likely to be activated in the next few days unless agreement can be reached with the government.

Legal advice to Transport for London, which was set up to run the city's bus and underground system, suggests that the challenge has "good prospects of success" and should be pursued "as soon as possible".

But government sources countered last night that legal action would only delay necessary investment in the fast-deteriorating tube network, and said that Mr Kiley, who is seeking "unified management control", would "have to make his mind up".

The government confirmed that a package of concessions over its scheme to break up and partially privatise the tube was a formal offer, but it has already been rejected by Mr Kiley as failing to meet his central objective.

Mr Prescott is offering Mr Kiley a special share with veto rights in the private companies due to be awarded 30-year contracts to run track, signalling and stations; a power of direction over the companies' order of work; and a right of veto over their chief executives and key managers.

A final concession would make half the members of their boards "partnership directors" with legal public interest responsibilities, a quarter to be appointed by Mr Kiley and a quarter by the private consortiums - the other half, made up of ordinary directors, would also be appointed by the consortiums.

webTitle: Grants to universities show wide variance

fields.headline: Grants to universities show wide variance
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Some under-pressure former polytechnics in England have been hit with real-terms cuts in their budgets in a funding settlement announced today.
fields.body:
Some under-pressure former polytechnics in England have been hit with real-terms cuts in their budgets in a funding settlement announced today.

The Higher Education Funding Council for England is providing grants for universities to cover the equivalent of an extra 20,400 full-time places and 32,300 part-time places. They include about 20,000 that remained unfilled in this academic year.

Hefce's £4.76bn settlement for teaching and research shows wide variations. Some 51 institutions missed their targets for attracting students by more than 2%.

The universities at Luton, and Lincolnshire and Humberside, have received 0.5% increases - below the 2.5% needed to deliver a budget standstill - because they are failing to attract enough students.

Hefce has given extra money to both universities to cushion the blow of the drop in rolls. Luton, where 98 jobs are at risk in a cost-cutting exercise, is receiving an extra £2.6m this year and was given £3m extra last year.

Lincolnshire and Humberside, which is closing its Hull campus has also received an extra £1.8m this year and £2.4m last year.

But some institutions have done much better from the council's £4.76bn settlement for 2001-2. The average increase is 4%.

The rapidly expanding Nottingham University wins an 8.9% increase, as does the Open University, and Essex University wins a 7.9% increase.

The University of Teesside is among new universities to do well, with a 9.6% increase.

 Students at further education colleges end up getting little more than half of the qualifications they set out to achieve, the government's spending watchdog reveals today. The national audit office describes the level of achievement in the £3bn sector as "disappointing".

fields.headline: Row ignites as Blunkett hits at Woodhead
fields.standfirst:
Ex-education chief 'wanted to cut pay' of less efficient teachers

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The always uneasy relationship between David Blunkett and Chris Woodhead, the former chief inspector of schools, exploded into an acrimonious public row yesterday as the education secretary returned fire on a damning and personal attack on his policies.
fields.body:
The always uneasy relationship between David Blunkett and Chris Woodhead, the former chief inspector of schools, exploded into an acrimonious public row yesterday as the education secretary returned fire on a damning and personal attack on his policies.

Beginning his new career as a columnist for the Daily Telegraph, Mr Woodhead assailed Mr Blunkett for a "depressing, narrow and utterly misguided" approach to education which had betrayed a generation. He also laid into the prime minister, his former ally, who he said lacked the drive to see through the reforms of the education system he wanted.

In retaliation, Mr Blunkett disclosed that Mr Woodhead once proposed cutting the pay of poor-performing teachers - a move which would have sparked a strike of "universal proportions".

While the education secretary insisted he would not emulate the "vitriol and abuse" heaped on him by the former Ofsted chief, he did allow his department to release a dossier of previous remarks by Mr Woodhead praising both Mr Blunkett and Tony Blair.

Mr Woodhead's article had some "very strange" contradictions, Mr Blunkett told BBC Radio 4. "I think he's diminishing his credibility in what he's saying this morning, not least because so many of the things he is now criticising he was either in favour of, or wanting us to go further."

Mr Blair stood back and used the education secretary as his lightning conductor. "The prime minister's view remains he [Mr Woodhead] did a good job and it's for him to explain himself in whatever way he wants," said his official spokesman, Alastair Campbell.

Many in the education world puzzled over Mr Woodhead's characterisation of Mr Blunkett as an old-style liberal who "encapsulated the worst of the discredited ideology that has done so much damage since the 1960s".

The education secretary was clearly stung by the assault from a man who three months ago was the most powerful independent figure in English education. "I haven't transformed the education service yet in the way I would wish, but I have laid the foundations and the seeds and I'm very sorry indeed that Chris has chosen to abuse us in this way," Mr Blunkett said.

Theresa May, the shadow education secretary, said: "It is obvious that Mr Blunkett and his colleagues just do not understand that teachers want to be free to teach and children want to learn. No amount of slick presentation can disguise the simple fact that the government has failed children and teachers and the prime minister's pledge of 'education, education, education' being his priority has a completely hollow ring."

Mr Woodhead wrote in the Telegraph that he came up against a "stone wall" when he told the education secretary of his frustration with the government over the slow introduction of performance related pay for teachers, the contracting out of local government services and cutting red tape.

Mr Blunkett had been "reluctant to challenge" the vested interests of the education authorities and the unions.

While Labour had spent money and delivered more than 60 initiatives in four years, they amounted to "very little" other than the national literacy and numeracy strategy, he wrote.

"On the occasions when we talked, I felt the prime minister shared my views on the kind of schools our children deserved, and the kind of action needed for standards to rise," Mr Woodhead wrote.

But he added: "I smile whenever I read that the most feared words in Whitehall are 'Tony wants'. In my experience, there is an inverse correlation between what Tony wants and what Tony gets."

The two men only had one conversation away from Mr Blair's "coterie of advisers" - when they bumped into each other at a Buckingham Palace party.

When Mr Woodhead told him "the unvarnished truth", Mr Blair said he should talk to David Miliband, head of the Downing Street policy unit.

"I talked to Mr Miliband - and absolutely nothing. Since then I have often wondered why Tony Blair seemed so sympathetic and yet turned out to be so incapable of seeing anything through.

"The real problem, I believe, is that he has failed to focus with sufficient rigour on what he repeatedly declared to be his number one priority."

One Downing Street adviser said last night the prime minister had always been very careful to avoid making specific promises in private to Mr Woodhead.

His column prompted wide criticism yesterday. Labour MPs complained in the Commons Mr Woodhead should have been sacked earlier.

"If you feed wild dogs, you deserve to be savaged by them," said Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers.

Peter Smith, general secretary of the Association of Teachers and Lecturers, said Mr Woodhead's attack was "no more than nauseating cant".

The Secondary Heads Association general secretary, John Dunford, said: "Chris Woodhead was part of the policy-making process he now criticises."

The Liberal Democrat education spokesman, Phil Willis, said: "Chris Woodhead's all too predictable political and personalised attacks have lost him any last vestiges of respect."

Mr Woodhead is planning to work for the Telegraph and in public relations, though the Conservatives are keen for him to join their benches in the Lords.

"There are no conversations that I'm having about Tory peerages," he told BBC Radio 4. "Heaven knows, in the future I might do anything, but that is not an issue that is on the agenda."

fields.headline: Two enemies: both wrong
fields.trailText: The kindest thing that critics say of David Blunkett is that he knows he's wrong - he's just forced to implement daft policies by the bullies in Downing Street. There's nothing so kind to be said about Chris Woodhead: his error is fabulous, his thinking is fatuous. But the poor boy really believes it.
fields.body:
The kindest thing that critics say of David Blunkett is that he knows he's wrong - he's just forced to implement daft policies by the bullies in Downing Street. There's nothing so kind to be said about Chris Woodhead: his error is fabulous, his thinking is fatuous. But the poor boy really believes it.

Mr Woodhead's central thrust, repeated in yesterday's Daily Telegraph, has always been that children are being betrayed by "trendy teaching methods from the 1960s" - child-centred learning which abjures discipline and bans criticism and reduces all pupils to the lowest level of expectation. He believes this to be true because (and it is important to admit this) there is some truth in it.

Our schools did suffer from some bad teachers, some bad techniques and some bad management. More than that, there was an extraordinary and deeply undemocratic presumption that this was none of anybody else's business. Local education authorities allowed their schools to be accountable to just about no one. Headteachers could be as secretive as they pleased, concealing their results and disguising their problems.

In the hands of Mr Woodhead, however, this truth has been treated in a way which William Blake would have understood: "A truth that's told with bad intent is worth all the lies you can invent."

The bigger truth, which is denied in Woodhead's world, is that when schools fail, the most important single factor is the intake of children who go there, and the most important single aspect of intake is poverty. There is a skyscraper of evidence to show the link between poverty and educational attainment. (One taste: at the age of 22 months, children from affluent families are already 14% higher up the educational-development distribution than children from poor families.)

And the most important single statistic in contemporary Britain is this: when the Tories came to power in 1979, 7% of our children lived in poverty; by the time they left in 1997, that figure had risen to 30%. One-third of our children! And they are all supposed to go to school.

You have to understand that this poverty is not just about material hardship. Those children are growing up in communities that have collapsed, families that have broken; more than any other social class, they are exposed to drug abuse, alcohol abuse and to physical, emotional and sexual abuse. Miraculously, many of them survive. But a great many of them are deeply damaged and turn up in class with all kinds of emotional and behavioural disorders.

The next crucial part of the bigger picture is that the effects of that poverty on schools have been enormously aggravated by the reforms which were introduced by Kenneth Baker in 1989. This is a complicated story, but essentially, he set up a market in school places, and that market has created a terrifying polarisation. Schools with an intake of well motivated, middle-class children do well in the league tables and attract extra children who bring extra funds with them. Schools with an intake of troubled poor children struggle in the league tables, lose children and lose money. It is these schools with a concentration of damaged children which are held up as failures.

When Mr Woodhead then blames "trendy teachers" for that failure, he inflicts a gross injustice on those teachers who have survived a 20-year purge of a kind unseen in any other profession. But, more than that, he uses the power of his position to collude in the camouflaging of the truth. With the energetic support of newspapers like the Daily Telegraph, this entirely bogus analysis has been used to generate a set of entirely bogus solutions.

Confronted now with the abject failure of schemes such as special measures and Fresh Start, Mr Woodhead might have admitted his fault. But no. Perhaps he feels too trapped by his history of bold error to turn back. Perhaps he is simply an extremely brittle personality, driven more by anger than by reason. Whatever the explanation, he clings to his illusions and now attacks Mr Blunkett on the basis that all would have been well if only Mr Blunkett had been even more extreme in building on Mr Woodhead's flawed foundations.

Mr Blunkett should ignore him. Which is not to say that the education secretary should not be attacked. Indeed, he should be hounded around the clock from the opposite point of view - for his cowardly refusal to take on the political battle which had to be fought to reverse Baker's market-driven reforms and put our education system back on to a rational footing. It may well be that he knows that what he is doing is wrong. That is not enough. It leaves the rest of us in the deeply uncomfortable position of watching a debate in which we are invited to choose between a liar and a fool.

 The School Report by Nick Davies, is published by Vintage, £ 6.99.

fields.headline: 10,000 teacher posts shown vacant
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Nearly 10,000 secondary school teaching posts are unfilled in England and Wales, according to a survey published today.
fields.body:
Nearly 10,000 secondary school teaching posts are unfilled in England and Wales, according to a survey published today.

Evidence collected from 876 secondary schools - about a quarter of the total - reveals there were 2,410 vacancies for permanent teachers last month. Across the secondary sector that would mean 9,969 unfilled posts.

A similar survey last September concluded there were 4,000 posts unfilled.

According to the analysis, carried out by the Secondary Heads Association and Times Educational Supplement, the most serious problems are still in London and the south-east, but the situation is also worse than before in the midlands and the north-east.

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "For too long the government has underplayed the extent of the teacher recruitment crisis."

The Recruitment and Employment Confederation said that at least 20,000 temporary vacancies in England and Wales remained unfilled every week because of a lack of supply teachers.

This week the two biggest teaching unions, the National Union of Teachers and the National Association of School Masters Union of Women Teachers, announced they would refuse to cover unfilled, permanent posts and staff absences of longer than three days in London and Doncaster after strike ballots.

"This survey shows the true depth of the crisis facing our schools," said Phil Willis, the Liberal Democrats' education spokesman.

David Blunkett, the education secretary, told the TES: "The word crisis is the kind of word you use when you have foot and mouth disease destroying an industry.

"It is not a word that you use when you want to resolve a problem by recruiting or bringing back more professionals. "

fields.headline: How Labour's big moves measure up
fields.standfirst:
From literacy to dealing with failure

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Chris Woodhead accused David Blunkett of presiding "over a set of initiatives that has wasted taxpayers' money, distracted teachers from their real responsibilities and encapsulated the worst of the discredited ideology that has done so much damage since the 1960s". He said there had been more than 60 initiatives since 1997, including the following:
fields.body:
Chris Woodhead accused David Blunkett of presiding "over a set of initiatives that has wasted taxpayers' money, distracted teachers from their real responsibilities and encapsulated the worst of the discredited ideology that has done so much damage since the 1960s". He said there had been more than 60 initiatives since 1997, including the following:

Literacy and numeracy

These alone were singled out for praise by the former chief inspector, who added that they were inherited from the Tories.

But Labour has systematically built on them to ensure that the structure is in place to teach the "3 Rs" - reading, writing and arithmetic - in all 18,000 primary schools.

A new daily "literacy" hour was followed by a daily maths lesson, backed by extra resources and specialist training for teachers. The National Year of Reading and Maths Year 2000 came next.

Teachers were initially worried about extra workload, as well as the challenges of ambitious new targets. But in tests for 11-year-olds standards have risen sharply. Further investment of £190m for each of the next three years is planned. Progress in primary schools has laid the foundations for the drive to raise standards in secondary schools, announced last month.

Education action zones

Described as "educational test beds" to encourage innovation through partnerships between local education authorities, businesses and parents, the scheme was designed to provide imaginative approaches to raising standards in disadvantaged urban and rural areas.

Each zone typically includes a cluster of two or three secondary schools with their supporting primaries and special educational needs provision.

Since September 1999, 73 "large" zones have been set up, where results for 11-year-olds have improved by more than the national average and rates of truancy have gone down.

The idea began with promises of an annual sum of £750,000 from the Department of Education and Employment, matched by £250,000 from private sponsorship. But firms have not been as keen to get involved as had been hoped.

Two recent reports highlighted the failure to attract the target figure for business sponsorship.

But ministers are pressing ahead with city academies, where they are finding similar sponsorship problems, and an expansion of specialist schools.

Excellence in cities

Launched in March 1999, it is a wide-ranging scheme to give state schools in tough urban areas extra funds to help struggling pupils or those in danger of being expelled and to develop the talents of children with particular gifts.

By September it is expected to cover a third of all secondary pupils in 1,000 schools. Already schools in EiC areas have shown faster improvement than schools elsewhere, in terms of the proportion of pupils achieving 5 or more A* to C grade GCSEs and those getting at least one GCSE.

Headteachers do not have to bid for the money - resources are diverted to wherever they are needed, and heads have queued up for funds. Key to the scheme is a programme for "gifted and talented" pupils, which provides extra resources, such as summer schools, to allow them to fulfil their potential.

National grid for learning

Launched in late 1998, the NGfL was created to become the national focal point for learning on the internet, and a resource for all schools in England.

The challenge was to boost the use of information and communications technology (ICT) in primary schools, where four years ago fewer than 20% were connected to the internet.

Now that figure is 86% (98% in secondary schools), with improved ratios of one computer to every 13 pupils. By next year, over £650m will have been spent in equipping and networking schools. The initiative is backed by £230m funding from the new opportunities fund, to help train teachers in the use of ICT in the classroom. But many schools are still struggling to pay for basic equipment, while teachers often lack the time for training.

Fresh start and failing schools

Labour said it inherited a "disgraceful" situation with hundreds of failing schools left to drift. Its approach was that schools could not be left to their own devices. But the brutal "naming and shaming" policy introduced early in its term was unpopular and divisive, and was later toned down. In total, 653 failing schools have come off special measures since Labour took power, with 120 closed and 25 put into a controversial "fresh start" scheme. The latter led to a school re-opening under a new name, new headteacher and new staff, but some schools made no progress and their high-profile heads quit.

fields.headline: You'd really need a heart of stone not to laugh at this man
fields.standfirst:
The chief inspector's latest tirade gets some marks out of ten

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Ted Wragg: If you have tears, prepare to shed them now. They rolled liberally down my cheeks when I read the first episode yesterday of Chris Woodhead's account in the Daily Telegraph of why he resigned as chief inspector of schools.
fields.body:
If you have tears, prepare to shed them now. They rolled liberally down my cheeks when I read the first episode yesterday of Chris Woodhead's account in the Daily Telegraph of why he resigned as chief inspector of schools.

Unfortunately, the tears were of mirth. I love surreal comedy. The storyline goes something like this. Heroic Wooders tries to take on the world's evils: progressive teaching methods, "misguided" teachers, bureaucracy, the teacher unions, the Labour government, local authority leaders such as Tim Brighouse, professors of education, Vlad the Impaler.

Unfortunately our hero is frustrated by a prime minister and a secretary of state who have betrayed a generation of children, so he rides off on his white horse to become a highly paid writer for a rightwing newspaper and employee of a rightwing public relations firm, as you do when you're upset.

He chooses his targets carefully: "I no longer knew what to say when head-teachers stood up at conferences to complain that bureaucratic interference was making it impossible for them to lead their schools in a properly autonomous, professional manner." Most headteachers at conferences were asking each other when Woodhead would bog off, but bureaucracy is a safe windmill at which to tilt, because everyone agrees that it is excessive. He forgets to mention is that it was launched by the Conservatives, driven by the same lack of trust with which he viewed teachers and heads, and worsened by the very organisations of which he was head, namely the National Curriculum Council and the Office for Standards in Education.

Other well chosen targets are: penalising schools financially for excluding pupils, and the surfeit of initiatives, both of which are perfectly fair to criticise. These unexceptionable points, however, are merely the leaven that produce the gas to lighten the dough. It was the dough itself that caught my attention.

Tony Blair's greatest sin was that he was not "prepared to force David Blunkett to act on my advice". The prime minister has just gone up several notches in my estimation, but what takes the breath away is Woodhead's sheer cheek. The prime minister should "force" a minister to do what Wooders tells him? Who does he think he is - Aristotle? So what would this astonishingly insightful advice have been? Look no further than an article he wrote in the Times Educational Supplement in April 1998 in which he said it was "dangerous" for teachers to work out their own best professional practice. They should teach the Ofsted way.

Dangerous? Striking a match in a gas-filled room, sipping a glass of vodka and strychnine, that's what I call dangerous. Using your professional judgment, not merely doing as Woodhead tells you, is what teachers are paid for. Good on Blair for not "forcing" his ministers to implement such twaddle.

Some of the account is just bizarre. Listen to this description of a meeting with David Blunkett: "It was important to be honest with each other, I said, given that this might be our last meeting. 'So you've made up your mind, then,' he replied brusquely. Actually I hadn't." From this he concluded that Blunkett wanted him to go.

If you say to someone, having revealed that you are contemplating resigning your post, "This might be our last meeting", then, unless the other person is quitting, or an asteroid is heading towards Earth at high speed, the assumption must be that your mind is made up. It is all part of the "hero forced out" scenario.

Woodhead as cultural defender, today's Matthew Arnold, is another heroic role he adopts, quoting Oakeshott for the umpteenth time (find another quote, Chris, there's a good chap) about education being a conversation between generations. Blunkett is portrayed as a philistine "who does not appear to understand this". I have always thought it was the Ofsted view of education as a mechanical process that eliminated sweetness and light.

One of his missions, he states, was "to publish reports written in plain English". There speaks the man who presided over Ofstedspeak, the language of "generally sound", "evidence base", "well below the national average", plain enough, but what on earth did it mean to people struggling to improve their teaching?

The Daily Telegraph has marketed the Woodhead articles aggressively, with banners across the front page. "Woodhead: the final report" is the dramatic headline, followed by "Day 1. Blair and Blunkett have not delivered. The children have been betrayed". Ooh, I say. Thrilling, or what?

Let me guess the titles of the rest of these saloon bar reflections: "Day 3. Labour are clueless, vote Conservative"; "Day 6. William Hague, untrammelled genius"; "Day 10. Why I would be bloody brilliant in the House of Lords"; "Day 99. 'Ere guv, I once had that Prince Charles in the back of my cab".

The articles are designed to inflict damage on Labour, but I doubt that they will. Who wants to read indefinitely about a saint surrounded by fools? After an initial flurry interest will subside, only resurfacing briefly if our hero becomes Screaming Lord Woodhead and enters the political arena.

webTitle: FE students achieve only 50% success rate, says audit office

fields.headline: FE students achieve only 50% success rate, says audit office
fields.trailText: Students at further education colleges end up getting little more than half of the qualifications they set out to achieve, the government's spending watchdog reveals for the first time today.
fields.body:
Students at further education colleges end up getting little more than half of the qualifications they set out to achieve, the government's spending watchdog reveals for the first time today.

The national audit office describes the level of achievement in the £3bn sector as "disappointing", and warns that the Department for Education and Employment has some way to go if it is to meet national learning targets for 2002 for older teenagers and adults.

The NAO's report, Improving Student Performance: How English Further Education Colleges Can Improve Student Retention And Achievement, also expresses concern about the wide variation in performance between colleges.

It urges colleges to work harder to help students to choose the right course, and identify and support students who are at risk of dropping out. Those having to cope with long hours of part-time work in parallel with their studies, for example, are particularly vulnerable.

For the first time, the NAO publishes a new "success rate", which shows that students achieve just over 50% of the qualifications they set out for. This is brand new data, as the government only publishes achievement figures which does not include the 15% of students who drop out of courses along the way. Broken down further, the figure is 56% for 16-18-year olds and 51% for older students.

The further education sector provides a wide range of part-time and full-time education and training opportunities to people from school leaving-age upwards. There are some 400 FE colleges in England, attended by 3.8m students (more than twice as many as the higher sector), who study for some 17,000 different qualifications.

Sir John Bourn, head of the NAO, said: "Further education colleges, with the support of the funding council and the department, have done well over the past five years to increase the proportion of students who achieve their qualifications. In particular, we were pleased to see that the number of colleges with overall achievement rates below 50% has reduced dramatically".

But he warned: "Overall success rates remain disappointing Ð and the gap between the best and worst performing colleges is still too wide. Poorer performing colleges need to adopt the good practices of the best if they are to help the government meet the national learning targets".

The influential public accounts committee responded yesterday by saying it would grill the outgoing permanent secretary at the DfEE, Sir Michael Bichard, on the issue at a hearing next month.

David Davis, chairman of the PAC, said: "FE has for too long been viewed as the poor relation of the education sector. What is most stark about today's report is the significant variation in the level of student achievement between colleges. This must represent an unacceptable waste of student potential".

fields.headline: Pretend you know all about
fields.standfirst: Rellik
fields.trailText: Rellik
fields.body:
You may not have noticed, but a long-overdue reappraisal of Vivienne Westwood is starting to take place. Some say it began with Katie Grand's styling in the current issues of The Face and Pop, others say it was Kate Moss who kicked it off, being photographed last autumn shopping with Stella and Sadie in vintage Westwood boots. But west Londoners know it's a shop called Rellik, which has been flying the Westwood pirate flag for the past couple of years now, that is the Year Zero of this welcome revival.

The store, at the base of the landmark Trellick Tower, is a partnership between three businesses, each of which works in both vintage and new clothes. Steve Philips is the Westwood specialist, with a massive on-site archive of work from throughout her career. In addition to well-known pieces from her pioneering early 80s collection, which saw her break free from Malcolm McLaren and into a whole new romantic look, Philips has in stock rare and unseen pieces made especially for Japan.

His two colleagues, Fiona Carenza and Claire Stansfield, concentrate on recycling vintage fabrics and trimmings to make some fantastically current pieces. The store can also be set search projects if you can't find something out-of-stock for yourself. (One of their current missions? Visors.) You get the feeling this treasure trove will last easily beyond the sell-by date of whatever retro fever it helps stir up.

 Rellik is at 8 Golborne Road, London W10, 020-8962 0089.

fields.headline: Clearing up the crime plan
fields.standfirst: Richard Garside, head of communications for the crime reduction charity Nacro,  examines the home secretary's 10-year crime plan
fields.trailText: Richard Garside, head of communications for the crime reduction charity the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders examines the home secretary's 10-year crime plan.
fields.body:
There is no doubt that crime will prove to be a crucial campaign issue in the general election and, assuming the farming crisis does not knock the election schedule into late summer, we will be hearing much more from our politicians on this subject over the next few months.

The government's 10-year crime plan Criminal Justice: The Way Ahead, launched this week, is its latest attempt to seize the initiative on what is considered to be a key election battleground. The plan is primarily aimed at the core of 100,000 persistent offenders estimated to be responsible for half of all serious crime in England and Wales.

It makes sense to target those offenders who commit a large slice of crime. After all, who wants a criminal justice system that treats everyone the same regardless of patterns of criminality? An offender who has committed a number of increasingly unpleasant assaults represents a different risk to one who uncharacteristically gets into a fight after downing too many pints on a Friday night.

But the real challenge is in implementing this principle. On some measures, the government's plan looks good. There are plans to increase funding for prison-based offender behaviour programmes and to improve prisoner education and training opportunities. No one is likely to oppose better supervision on release for prisoners serving short sentences while plans for more flexible community sentences should increase sentencers' confidence that they will work.

But on other measures, there must be some question marks over the government's strategy. Take their plans for an extra 2,660 prison places and the commitment to longer prison sentences for persistent offenders.

The courts have always had powers to hand out longer sentences to persistent offenders than to first timers, but the sentence must be proportionate to the seriousness of the offence. Otherwise there is a risk of sentencing the repeat burglar more harshly than the first time rapist. They may both be unpleasant offences but society rightly considers sexual offences to be more serious than crimes against property and sentencing should reflect this.

It is increasingly recognised that the "prison works" mantra is nonsense. Most crime is committed by young men, typically under the age of 21, yet more than two-thirds reoffend on release from prison. Even if improved supervision and resettlement support help to reduce offending, the continued reliance on prison to achieve this is doomed to failure.

Many of the 100,000 hardcore offenders suffer from homelessness, drug abuse, poor education and unemployment. It is difficult to see how a spell in prison will solve these problems. In fact, prison often compounds these problems by wrenching them out of the communities to which they will have to return on release. Intensive community supervision based on evidence of what works would be a better bet for many offenders.

This all comes down to basic questions about how crime can best be tackled and the role of the criminal justice system in that process. Out of all the crime reported by the police, convicted offenders make up only 9%. One Sunday newspaper reported that the government hopes to end another 100,000 crimes in convictions, cautions or taking incidents "into consideration" by 2004. Though an admirable aim, this would still not dramatically improve clear up rates.

The criminal justice system alone will never tackle crime because so much of it is tied up in unemployment, poor housing, education and drug abuse. Though this is tacitly acknowledged by the government's plan, it is a long way from rising to prominence in political rhetoric on crime reduction.

webTitle: Royal Bank prepares for mercy killing

fields.headline: Royal Bank prepares for mercy killing
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Fred Goodwin, chief executive of Royal Bank of Scotland, warned yesterday he would be prepared to embark on a mission of "mercy killings" of underperforming rivals as he announced a 31% rise in pre-tax profits of £4.4bn.
fields.body:
Fred Goodwin, chief executive of Royal Bank of Scotland, warned yesterday he would be prepared to embark on a mission of "mercy killings" of underperforming rivals as he announced a 31% rise in pre-tax profits of £4.4bn.

Reporting the first end of year profits since taking control of NatWest after a brutal hostile takeover last year, Mr Goodwin described any future acquisitions as "tactical".

"Frankly the time is not now. The prices are still high. In the future there's going to be opportunities for mercy killings of institutions which no longer have a long term future in the UK," Mr Goodwin said.

He made clear that any acquisition was not imminent and refused to be specific about the type of organisation which he expected to fall into his category.

The bank, which is planning to brighten up the NatWest brand, said it had made faster than expected progress in integrating the two operations.

More than 13,000 staff - 90% of whom worked for the former NatWest - had been made redundant by the end of the year, compared with original targets of 9,000 job cuts. Another 9,000 jobs are to be lost by March 2003.

The bank reported higher than expected cost savings in the first year of £653m. This bolstered the bank's pre-tax profit by £448m - more than the £290m originally estimated. However, Mr Goodwin did not alter his forecast for £1.3bn cost savings by 2003.

The last of the major banks to report its results for last year, Royal Bank's shares jumped almost 10% to £16.59 as analysts took heart from the bank's insistence that its profit margins were not being eroded by competitive pressures in the market.

The profits were also higher than many analysts had been expecting and among the highest reported by any company in the FTSE 100 during the last year.

As a result of taking over NatWest, Royal Bank has already been singled out by the competition commission as having a "scale monopoly" in the small business market with a share of more than 25%.

It could find out as soon as next week what remedies the commission might seek to address any public interest concerns raised by the continuing competition review of the business banking market.

More than half the bank's profits last year were generated by the corporate banking and financial markets division. The group also owns Direct Line insurance group, which doubled its profits to £201m. It also owns the up-market Coutts operation.

Citizens, its bank in New England which has made 17 acquisitions in recent years, also reported a rise in profits to £349m as it played down the impact of any downturn in the US economy, feared by some of its rivals.

After searching for a buyer for NatWest's former corporate headquarters in the City for almost a year, Mr Goodwin revealed yesterday that a purchaser had been found. He declined to name the buyer.

In Europe, where the Royal Bank has a close relationship with Spanish bank BSCH, Mr Goodwin played down any idea of a full-scale merger to expand. He said joint ventures and small acquisitions were more likely.

The bank will pay a 33p dividend to investors.

webTitle: Gena Rowlands on the work of her husband, John Cassavetes

fields.headline: ''Why would anyone want to see a movie about a crazy, middle-aged dame?'
fields.standfirst: Since his death in 1989, Gena Rowlands has been notoriously reluctant to discuss the work of her husband, John Cassavetes. To mark a new retrospective of his films, she makes an exception for Duncan Campbell
fields.trailText: Since his death in 1989, Gena Rowlands has been notoriously reluctant to discuss the work of her husband, John Cassavetes. To mark a new retrospective of his films, she makes an exception for Duncan Campbell
fields.body:
It’s hard to imagine two of Hollywood’s most admired actors running into trouble with the police for slapping up posters of their latest film in the middle of the night. But that was the only way that John Cassavetes and Gena Rowlands could rustle up interest in the films that were shunned by the mainstream industry.

John Cassavetes died in 1989 at the age of 59, still battling to get his films shown because he was still the maverick, edgy director whose work people either loved and treasured as part of the canon of great American cinema or hated and mocked as self-indulgent ramblings. Now the National Film Theatre is screening all of his films, from the very first, Shadows, made for next to nothing in 1961, through his best-known work such as the award-winning A Woman Under the Influence in 1974 and The Killing of a Chinese Bookie in 1976. A new generation who may never have had a chance to see his work on a cinema screen will now be able to judge for themselves.

Posters for two of his films, Gloria and Love Streams, hang on either side of the log fire in the home he shared with Gena Rowlands high in the Hollywood Hills, a home that doubled as their studio. Other posters, small works of art in themselves, frame the door to the sitting room where Rowlands is talking about her late husband’s work. “These were in John’s office when he died and I was going to put them in storage and then I thought no - heck, that’s our whole life there - I’m going to put it up so I can be reminded of it. Looks dangerously like Sunset Boulevard...”

When people mention Cassavetes’s work they refer to him mainly as the great improviser, a misconception with which Gena Rowlands is familiar. “Many people feel that all of John’s scripts were improvised and that just isn’t true. There are a lot of different opinions of what improvisation means - a lot of people think it means you just say anything you want to, whereas usually it’s based on a storyline: you know what the thrust of the scene is, then it’s rehearsed and turned into something. That is the way they worked in Shadows. When John screened it for the first time he didn’t like part of it so he went back and shot some more. I think he would have kept reshooting and editing for the rest of his life!”

A Woman Under the Influence, widely regarded as Cassavetes’ finest film, won an Oscar nomination for him as best director and for Rowlands for her haunting portrayal of a woman on the very edge. “That was totally scripted. John had written it as a play - he wrote two plays and they were both wonderful - but I said: ‘John, I would be dead in two weeks if I played this on stage every night.’ So he said: ‘I’ll put it into a movie.’ And that’s what he did.” But while the cast may have been working from a script, there was always room for their own improvisations, whether it was Seymour Cassel riffing in Faces (1968) or Ben Gazzara, Peter Falk and Cassavetes rambling drunkenly in Husbands (1970). So how did the actors feel about working in that way? “Peter [Falk, along with Rowlands, Cassel and Gazzara, part of the loyal Cassavetes ensemble] was a little hesitant at the beginning. Peter used to say: ‘I dunno, I don’t know what he’s talking about.’ Then he saw the results and he became a believer.”

Esme Chandlee, who has worked as a publicist with Rowlands and Cassavetes since the early days, is sitting in on the interview on this oddly grey LA afternoon. She recalls that Joan Blondell, one of the great names of old Hollywood who played a playwright in Opening Night not long before she died, was also initially puzzled by Cassavetes’ way of working. “She had been brought up in the studio system and she said: ‘You know, Esme, I have never worked this way before. I don’t know if I’m doing the right thing.’ I said: ‘Whatever you feel is right, just talk to John about it and that will be that.’ About a week later, she said: ‘I feel so free, everything I ask him, he listens. I never had an experience like this.’”

“It takes a while to get used to freedom,” says Rowlands, who was a successful actress before participating in her husband’s films. Cassavetes had made his name playing the title role in the television detective series Johnny Staccato and went on to act in nearly 30 films including Rosemary’s Baby and The Dirty Dozen, mainly to finance his own movies. “My idea of the future was of us acting together like the Lunts [America’s most famous theatrical couple, Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne]. It took me by surprise when he became interested in directing and writing, but once he had started, he didn’t have the interest in acting he had had before; he looked at it simply as a way to make money so we could make our films.”
