I cite the lines of Lynn Carlin, the embattled wife in Faces: “I’ve got lots to say - you want to try me.” But as Rowlands responds: “You hear both sides - many feminists attack him. He had a great interest in women and a great sympathy for them. His opinion was that society made women quite crazy - and not just the men. It was their mothers making them crazy half of the time. He said men got all the blame but their mothers told them which way to act and to pretend things that they didn’t feel and say things they didn’t mean, to inflate a man’s ego . . . I just thought he saw through a lot of games.

“He had an insatiable curiosity and compassion for just regular people, very often working-class people or artists or women. In Faces, there were older women who expressed their desires and frustrations and that was just not seen at the time. It was considered embarrassing for an older woman to have anything to say about anything emotional.”

So difficult was the business of distribution that one night Cassavetes went to a late-night newsstand and bought all the out-of-town papers, from St Louis and Toronto and Chicago, to see which cinemas were playing the sort of films they liked; he would then ring them and ask if they would take his movies. Sometimes it even worked.

“John was totally fearless, almost unnaturally so. I never saw him depressed, I saw him angry, which they say is the other side of depression, but he was very sure and not particularly influenced by anything anybody said. Our pictures made people feel very uncomfortable much of the time. The characters were very emotionally exposed and people weren’t used to it. Everything was not spelled out. The old tradition was that you prepared the audience but with our films you had to just sit there and hold on to your seats. Some people like that and some don’t.”

Cassavetes was often called the “European American” director because his work seemed similar to some of the new wave cinema of the period in Europe. His own taste in films and directors incorporated American masters such as John Ford, Orson Welles and Frank Capra. Rowlands remembers that he once said: “Maybe there wasn’t an America, maybe there was just Frank Capra.” He also admired closer contemporaries like Martin Scorsese, who often praises Cassavetes’ work. When Rowlands and Cassavetes first met as students at the American Academy of Dramatic Arts in New York, he admired Roberto Rossellini and Vittorio De Sica.

So which of his own films was he proudest of? “When he was ill, we were talking one day and he said: ‘Well, I made three pictures I would live or die for.’ Now wouldn’t you think that I would say: ‘Which pictures were those, John?’ But I felt I knew. Now I don’t know and I can’t say for certain because I don’t want to speak for John.” She hopes that A Woman Under the Influence was one and suspects that Faces and his first, Shadows, may have been the others. Their last film together was Love Streams in 1984: “Jon Voight was supposed to do it but at the last minute he couldn’t - one of those commitment things - and John said: ‘Oh, hell, I’ll do it.’ I’m so glad that he did, not that I don’t love Jon Voight, but because that was our last picture together.”

Does she ever watch the films she made with Cassavetes? “ I don’t really have to - when I want to, in my mind, I can roll them from the first frame right to the very end.”

The John Cassavetes season runs at the National Film Theatre, London SE1 (020-7928 3232), until March 30.

webTitle: On the edge CD of the week: Keith Tippett: Linuckea

fields.headline: Spontaneous combustion
fields.standfirst: John L Walters  sees pianist Keith Tippett and a string quartet blurring musical boundaries
fields.trailText: John L Walters sees pianist Keith Tippett and a string quartet blurring musical boundaries
fields.body:
Keith Tippett Linuckea
(FMR/Harmonia Mundi)
****
£14.99

Plenty of CDs that come out on small labels in the creative music field are decidedly low-density and low in ambition: they may be worthy attempts at documentation, or as a declaration of intent, but they are hard to value as a repeatable musical experience. Linuckea is different. The music made by Tippett and his colleagues rewards careful listening, resulting in one of the best-value CDs I've heard for a while.

The title track is a 36-minute continuous piece for piano (played by Tippett himself) and string quartet. It exemplifies the freedom and fluidity possible for a composer who is also a great improviser - the boundaries between the two are blurred and in many cases insignificant. Tippett explains his intentions as follows: "One of the differences between preconceived composition and spontaneous composition is that the former is solidified by ink on paper. Within pre-conceived architecture, the opportunity to improvise enables the performers to be creators not just curators."

There's nothing new about jazz pieces with lots of writing or classical pieces with improvisation, but it is still remarkably difficult to put together a skilled creative group that can successfully perform in this way. Or perhaps I should say that the alternatives are so much more easy and straightforward that they are what gets funded and rehearsed for most of the time.

The opening passage of the piece states all its musical concerns from the outset, with assertive ensemble phrases, a long piano figure that drills its way into your memory, a slower, more elastic theme and some intricate unisons that test the string players' ability to hook into a rhythmic feel that is neither jazz nor contemporary classical, but has the qualities of both. Linuckea is riddled with melodies, and both piano and strings exhibit some of the fractured spikiness associated with Tippett since his young band erupted on the British jazz scene three decades ago.

The full line-up is Tippett, playing inside and outside the piano (plus occasional bells and woodblocks), Philip Sheppard (cello), Malcolm Allison (viola) and violinists David Le Page and Christopher George. One of the joys of their performance is that they sound at once like a band jamming and like an assured chamber group. It's Tippett's piece, but it was the string players (or at least three of them) who initiated the commission. Their commitment to Linuckea shines throughout the recording, which is engineered by Steve Lowe and produced by Daryl Runswick.

fields.headline: On the edge releases
fields.trailText: Maelström: Labyrinth | Mel Torme: In the Lounge With...
fields.body:
Maelström Labyrinth
(Hat Art/ Harmonia Mundi)
***
£14.99

There is a theory that pop creativity runs out after the age of 27. A corollary to this is that jazz and classical musicians (with a few notable exceptions) don't really get going until well after this age. So it is interesting to hear this lovingly performed album of eight works for percussion written by Lou Harrison while he was in his early 20s. Much later, Harrison (born in 1917) developed a deep interest in Indonesian music and built and wrote music for gamelans, but these pieces show that his compositional personality was well established long before he began exploring other cultures seriously.

As a teenager, Harrison studied with Henry Cowell and Arnold Schoenberg, from whom he learned simplicity - how to strip a piece to its salient points. The Viennese composer apparently also told him: "Study only Mozart." Admittedly, it is hard to detect a Mozartian influence in pieces such as Fugue (1941), with its wild and complex polyrhythms and wailing, siren-like flexatones. In fact, many musicians of the time considered the scores "unplayable", and Harrison has never achieved either the notoriety and influence of John Cage or the multi-performance ubiquity of composers such as John Adams and Elliott Carter. His three-part Suite (1942), Canticle (1940), and the Fifth Symfony [sic] (1941) are full of invention and thoroughly enjoyable, though I would recommend listening to this album in segments rather than sitting down to 70 minutes of percussion music in one go.

Labyrinth No 3 (1941) employs a larger ensemble, full of gongs, tam-tams and shakers, organised with the same good-natured sense of purpose as his pieces for smaller forces. Harrison can't help writing melodies (he calls his motifs "melodicles"), even when he only has unpitched instruments at his disposal. It would be interesting to programme these ambitious early pieces alongside Harry Partch's work from the same era. (Harrison didn't discover Partch and his music until the late 1940s.)

The players of the Maelström Percussion Ensemble, directed by Jan Williams, attack Harrison's scores with just the right balance of delicacy and funky gusto, and the recording is immaculately recorded and mixed with a clear stereo image - which is essential for a sound-world created entirely from percussion.

The album's outstanding piece is the six-minute Double Music (1941), a co-composition by Harrison and his friend John Cage. It has many of the sneaky rhythmic and timbral hooks you hear in Cage's later Sonatas and Interludes for prepared piano, but its shape, structure and junk-yard orchestration seem more Harrison-like. Moreover it's a young man's piece, out to impress and seduce and make a bit of noise - and there's nothing wrong with that, as Craig David might tell you.

Mel Torme In the Lounge With . . .
(Columbia)
***
£8.99

Though Torme never sang a duff note in his life, his jazz fans might be embarrassed by some of the tracks on In the Lounge With . . . , a canny follow-up to a repackaging job of the same name for Andy Williams. The singer has now been claimed as a loungecore hero, for whom the details of phrasing and musicality are incidental to the pursuit of a pinkly decorated, animal-print world of 1960s camp. Secret Agent Man is John Barry-inspired boogaloo fluff, while Dominique's Discotheque and Ciao Baby are pure soap opera (as Bing or Frank might have said). The hit Coming Home Baby, which became a kind of fusion anthem, balances the fine line between retro cool and the real thing.

Some of the kitsch artefacts and music claimed by the lounge gang barely work out of context - their laminated, multicoloured awfulness needs a strong dose of ironic detachment. But whatever you think about the loungification of Torme, he couldn't help being good, even in the cheesiest surroundings. In the company of jazz musicians (all uncredited, of course) he shone: the arranger of Swinging on the Moon slips in a reference to Godchild (from Birth of the Cool), and the repertoire includes tunes by Duke Ellington and Cole Porter, and a groovy reinvention of 42nd Street - not quite in the Alasdair Nicolson league, but witty nevertheless.

Whether you sip your Manhattan in a Barcelona chair or a Verner Panton womb with a view, there's a strong argument for craft and skill in your consumer goods. Mel Torme always phrased every line with innate tastefulness - pitch-perfect and on the right nanosecond of the beat.

webTitle: Selby rail crash: Crew among first named victims

fields.headline: Crew among first named victims
fields.standfirst:
More bodies may be trapped under wreckage

Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: The identities of the 13 known victims of the Selby rail disaster began to emerge last night as police warned that it may be several days before the final death toll is established.
fields.body:
The identities of the 13 known victims of the Selby rail disaster began to emerge last night as police warned that it may be several days before the final death toll is established.

As specialist police teams completed the task of removing bodies from the wreckage, GNER named the driver of the Newcastle to London King's Cross service as John Weddle, from Throckley, on the outskirts of Newcastle.

The company said the train's chef, Paul Taylor, from the Newcastle area, had also died. The third member of the crew, Raymond Robson, 43, a customer operations leader from Whitley Bay, was also "unaccounted for".

Freightliner, the company which ran the goods train, confirmed that one of its drivers, Stephen Dunn, 39, had been killed. The married father of two young sons lived in the North Yorkshire area.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.trailText: Rob Mackie looks at The Luzhin Defence, Me, Myself & Irene, There's Only One Jimmy Grimble and E - Eminem
fields.body:
The Luzhin Defence
Rental and DVD rental EV Cert 12
***

Kubrick's Lolita apart, Vladimir Nabokov has not translated well to the screen, but this is an honourable attempt to reproduce his book's feverish obsessiveness. John Turturro is the chess fanatic incapable of any other life. He is tongue-tied when he meets Emily Watson, until she asks him how long he's been playing chess. "Nine thousand, two hundred and sixty-three days, four hours" is the response. Will Watson become a pawn in his game or vice-versa? The two relationships in Turturro's life, with his new girlfriend and his embittered ex- mentor (Stuart Wilson) mirror those of difficult talents in Shine and The Color of Money. Turturro is a master of oddball roles, and his pale, distracted bundle of nerves is another believable creation, as is Watson's protective lover. It's elegantly filmed by Dutch director Marleen Gorris, though Boaz Yakin's Fresh still beats it to the title of best chess-as-metaphor-for-life film.

Me, Myself & Irene
Rental and DVD rental Fox Pathé Cert 15
**

The Farrelly brothers' comedies show no sign of progression and the law of diminishing returns is setting in fast. Dumb & Dumber and Kingpin had cherishable moments, but these came from ensemble playing . Here, to all intents and purposes, Jim Carrey's co-star is himself, which is a lot more Carrey than is good for the film. His official co-star is Renée Zellweger, a good dramatic actress who shows no flair for comedy (which doesn't bode well for her forthcoming Bridget Jones). Carrey is the Rhode Island policeman "trapped behind a wall of politeness" who discovers his other self. In other words it's The Mask without a mask, and much less fun. The comedy is based, as ever, on scatology and mental illness, but it is also the most sentimental Farrelly outing yet. It was condemned by mental health groups for muddling schizophrenia and split personality. It should also offend cows, chickens, black and short people: about par for the course, then.

There's Only One Jimmy Grimble
Rental Fox Pathé Cert 12
*

As believable as Billy the Fish and as convincing as the Bradford City attack, this is one more dismal British football film. Robert Carlyle is an ex-Manchester City striker who once scored a hat-trick against United but goes unrecognised as a local school football coach. If you can believe that, you are asked to swallow Ray Winstone as a diehard City fan. Mancunian, my arse, as the great philosopher Jim Royle might say. It's full of sentimental homilies and clunky scripting. I felt most sorry for Lewis McKenzie, very likable as the aspiring kid footballer of the title.

E - Eminem
Retail (£12.99) Universal Cert 15
***

Now that it's illegal not to have an opinion about Eminem, this collection of seven of his best-known numbers could help push you one way or the other. Oddly, the videos are in reverse chronological order, starting with the impressive Stan and working towards the blatant misogyny of his early stuff. But in today's shockingly bland pop universe, Eminem's music is at least about something and, for anyone who has been to Detroit, his raps fit the post-industrial setting like an iron glove.

webTitle: Police say Selby death toll may be lower

fields.headline: Police say Selby death toll may be lower
fields.standfirst: Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: The death toll in the Selby train crash may be 10 and not 13 as first stated, police revealed today.
fields.body:
The death toll in the Selby train crash may be 10 and not 13 as first stated, police revealed today.

The confusion has arisen because the violence of the crash had caused human remains to be scattered over a considerable area.

The wreckage of the GNER passenger train will not be removed from the Selby train crash site until the personal effects of all passengers have been recovered, police coordinating the clearance operation said.

A police spokesman said that the painstaking operation to clear the site of Wednesday's tragedy was likely to take the recovery teams many more hours, but could prove vital in identifying the dead.

He said: "After the Ladbroke Grove crash, more than 2,000 different items belonging to the passengers had to be recovered. This gives some idea of the task we are facing here."

Meanwhile, the company that insures Gary Hart -, the driver whose Land Rover careered off the road and triggered the disaster - has confirmed that claims from crash victims could run into "tens of millions of pounds," Alan Sendall, claims director at Fortis Insurance, said: "I confirm that this insurance policy provides unlimited liability in respect of third party claims.

"At this stage it is impossible to estimate the total cost of claims, although we expect it to run into tens of millions of pounds."

Human remains from 13 different locations around the crash site have already been recovered and it is feared more could be found once the heavy lifting equipment is used to drag the wreckage clear of the track.

Some of the survivors of the disaster, which killed 13 people and wounded 76, were today still fighting for their lives in hospital. Thirty-three of the people injured were being treated in several hospitals in Yorkshire and Newcastle. Six people were in intensive care, two of them in critical condition.

Relatives of those feared dead have been offered the chance to visit the crash scene and some were expected to make the pilgrimage.

Superintendent Tony Thompson, of British Transport police, said that the relatives might find it useful to visit the site to help them come to terms with the tragedy.

He said that only by viewing the devastation would it be possible for the families to understand why the operation to recover the bodies had taken so long.

Overnight, rescue workers continued construction on a road that will allow heavy equipment to be brought in. They also began to assemble a giant crane to lift the carriages of the passenger and freight trains.

Confirmed among the dead were the driver of the GNER train John Weddle, a divorced father-of-two from Throckley, near Newcastle, and one of the drivers of the goods train, Stephen Dunn, a 39-year-old father-of-two from Brayton, Selby.

A chef on the GNER train, Paul Taylor from the Newcastle area, was also confirmed dead and the company said that a third member of its crew, customer operations leader Raymond Robson, 43, from Whitley Bay, was "unaccounted for".

Freightliner, the company running the goods train, said its second driver Andrew Hill, 39, from South Yorkshire, was in a satisfactory condition in hospital.

The wife of Mr Hart has denied that he was asleep at the wheel when his Land Rover left the road.

webTitle: CD of the week: Experimental Pop Band: The Tracksuit Trilogy

fields.headline: The glorious return of Britpop
fields.standfirst: At last - a band who encapsulate the ridiculousness of being English. By  Dave Simpson
fields.trailText: At last - a band who encapsulate the ridiculousness of being English. By Dave Simpson
fields.body:
Experimental Pop Band The Tracksuit Trilogy
(City Slang)
****
£12.99

Glancing at the list of Brits winners this week, you could be forgiven for thinking we live in a country populated by cheeky chappies (Fatboy Slim, Robbie Williams) and bedsit miserabilists (Coldplay). Add the slick, oily commercialism that increasingly pervades the music industry, and it feels as though British pop hasn't much, if anything, to do with Britain any more. Sure, Coldplay articulate the feelings of a certain type of twenty- or thirtysomething male, but they make little comment on wider society, while Robbie purveys a wry triumphalism - Sing When You're Winning - that record buyers aspire to but can't share.

And yet, never has "Great" Britain been more ripe for affectionate mockery. The trains don't run on time, the animals are - ahem - a little off-colour, and the streets are littered with shysters with bad moustaches selling two-quid "designer" gear. We are becoming a nation of pub bores, wannabe celebs, wankers who soak passers-by with their BMWs and, most terrible of all, unhealthy people wearing tracksuits. However, you won't find this in pop music, since the last group to gloriously encapsulate the ridiculousness of being British (the Fall) have disappeared from the airwaves, and may well have been run out of the country.

This sorry state of affairs has inspired Experimental Pop Band, who have experienced plenty of life at the absurd end of blighty.com. For years, mainman Davey Woodward toiled in the Brilliant Corners. Audiences ignored them in favour of bands who sounded more glamorous and American. Critics ridiculed them as the definitive example of everything loser, shambling and indie (for their fans, five at the last count, these were pluses). In 1995, motivated by musical ambition and revenge, Woodward formed Experimental Pop Band. Then bassist Chris Galvin died of cancer. Those sort of experiences can make or break a band, and here, on their third album (their first songs since Galvin's death), EPB have delivered. Produced by PJ Harvey collaborator John Parrish, The Tracksuit Trilogy is a marvellously sardonic, pithy record, rooted in classic, spiky British pop.

Narcotic Daze and the eerie The Bereaved echo Roxy Music and Wire. Hard Enough could have come from the run of classic Stranglers singles of the late 1970s. However, EPB's musical reach goes worldwide, mixing styles from Velvets rock to War funk to jazz. It all hangs together because of their hooklines. Emotion is just one potential single, a stunning electronic soundscape somewhere between Giorgio Moroder-era Sparks and Blur's Girls & Boys (in fact, EPB most often conjure up a more jaundiced, bittersweet Blur). Then again, a song such as Somethingsaremoreimportantthanmusic, a mid-1970s disco being flattened by a Martin Hannett industrial groove machine, is so adventurous it's virtually uncategorisable.

With the band revelling in this role as deranged jukebox, Woodward establishes himself as the most potent Brit social commentator since Jarvis Cocker. Emotion finds him staring at the TV, numbed by the bombardment of everything from Madonna to genocide ("I've got a lot of emotion, but it don't seem that way"). The brilliant, Kinks-y All Hang Out harangues lad culture, with its "vomit down the trouser leg" giving way, with unconcealed delight, to "maisonettes crumbling down to ragga sounds". Woodward's Mark E Smith sneer is even more withering when he is pondering Britain's facade of tacky glamour, from the thrill-less modern Bristol in Casual Sex to Hard Enough's "It's hard to dance in your Kookai nylon pants. Won't show any passion. Things like that are out of fashion."

However, Woodward never comes across as a moaner, because his acerbic eye for human nature is couched in the blackest of humour (example: "It's hard enough being a Siamese twin, always doing the say-ay-ame things"). Some may find this a little too caustic, or lacking warmth, but it's fundamental to his appeal. Like Victor Meldrew or Basil Fawlty, this is a person crushed by the notion of a stiff upper lip, his feelings disguised behind wit, irony and grim resignation and lashing out at everybody when they erupt. A typical 2001 Englishman, in fact, fronting a quintessential, fantastic, modern English band.

webTitle: Phones still ring in Selby rail wreckage

fields.headline: Phones still ring in the wreckage as mourning for the dead goes on
fields.standfirst: Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: The eerie sound of mobile phones ringing could still be heard in the wreckage of the Selby rail disaster yesterday, as police and firemen slowly dismantled the awful metal jigsaw.
fields.body:
The eerie sound of mobile phones ringing could still be heard in the wreckage of the Selby rail disaster yesterday, as police and firemen slowly dismantled the awful metal jigsaw.

Every forlorn jingle was checked as the team, in yellow tabards and white boiler suits, painstakingly freed the bodies of the 13 known fatalities, including four railway workers, and prepared for a final search once cranes have hoisted an unstable pyramid of coaches out of the way.

The dead who were named last night included the driver of the 4.45am Newcastle-London express, John Weddle, and the train's chef, Paul Taylor, both from Tyneside.

A third member of the crew, Raymond Robson, 43, a customer operations leader from Whitley Bay, was "unaccounted for".

One of the two drivers of the Freightliner coal train from Immingham docks to Ferrybridge power station, Stephen Dunn, 39, was also killed. His co-driver Andrew Hill, also 39, is still in hospital but in a satisfactory condition.

Last night, on either side of the smashed carriages at Great Heck, North Yorkshire, bulldozers dug away part of the local Bridgeside Nurseries' garden and two paddocks to double, overnight, the number of roads in the railway hamlet and allow heavy lifting tenders to take the crane parts for assembly by the tracks. Specialists meanwhile started to tackle the effects of 3,000 gallons of spilt diesel from the broken-backed freight engine and tonnes of power station coal tipped out from upended bunker wagons.

Fears that there might be more bodies in the wreckage are focused on part of a first class carriage, stamped flat as another coach rolled over it, and on a chaos of broken wheels and undercarriage below another first class carriage and the buffet car.

The head of the recovery operation, Chief Inspector Martin Hemingway, said small voids in the twisted metal had not yet been been physically searched, though sound and thermal detectors had swept the train four times.

Careful removal of scores of personal possessions and split-open luggage was also underway to help with identification, he said, including tracking down the mobiles. "Their rings are quite unnerving," he said. "You naturally think they may be from people trying to ring their loved ones to see if they are all right."

Gary Hart, 36, the driver whose Land Rover careered down the M62 verge and on to the main line, triggering the disaster, was released by British transport police without charge yesterday. He will face further questioning following a recovery period, after being described by officers as "inconsolable" and at one stage having difficulty in speaking about the terrible sequence of events.

Police confirmed that the possibility of driver error, including dozing at the wheel, was one line of inquiry being considered, but only along with motorway conditions, the state of the Land Rover and the possibility of a tyre blowout.

The last is understood to be Mr Hart's belief, but forensic checks on the Land Rover's sheered-off front section will take several days to complete.

Mr Hart's wife Elaine, 38, said reports of him falling asleep at the wheel were "rubbish." She was in tears as she told reporters at Withern, Lincolnshire, where the couple live with their four daughters, that Mr Hart was undergoing counselling and was suffering a lot of pain.

Crash investigators were examining whether the 30-tonne driving car on the GNER express had sufficient weight to be leading the train and whether the train would have remained on the rails if the 80-tonne locomotive had been leading, instead of being at the back.

Villagers in Great Heck laid flowers on the bridge which takes Heck and Pollington Lane directly above the derailed second wagon of the coal train and the last coach of the doomed express.

The Bishop of Doncaster, Rt Rev Cyril Ashton, joined a rota of volunteers at the mission chapel of St John the Baptist, after conducting a special service in the nearby market town of Snaith.

He discouraged attempts to moralise or be "too pious" about the tragedy, saying: "It is important to be realistic, so that people know where we are coming from. Sadly, most people know that accidents do happen."

The vicar of Selby, the Rev Keith Jukes, added: "The disaster will touch every community which is home to a dead or injured person."

She was in tears as she told reporters at Withern, Lincolnshire, where the couple live with their four daughters, that Mr Hart was undergoing counselling and was suffering a lot of pain. Crash investigators were examining whether the 30-tonne driving car on the GNER express had sufficient weight to be leading the train and whether the train would have remained on the rails if the 80-tonne locomotive had been leading, instead of being at the back. Villagers in Great Heck laid flowers on the bridge which takes Heck and Pollington Lane directly above the derailed second wagon of the coal train and the last coach of the doomed express. The Bishop of Doncaster, Rt Rev Cyril Ashton, joined a rota of volunteers at the mission chapel of St John the Baptist, after conducting a special service in the nearby market town of Snaith. He discouraged attempts to moralise or be "too pious" about the tragedy, saying: "It is important to be realistic, so that people know where we are coming from. Sadly, most people know that accidents do happen." The vicar of Selby, the Rev Keith Jukes, added: "The disaster will touch every community which is home to a dead or injured person."

fields.headline: Parents beware
fields.standfirst: A terrifying compilation from John Digweed and some die-hard vinyl fans help  Frank Tope to rediscover the underground
fields.trailText: A terrifying compilation from John Digweed and some die-hard vinyl fans help Frank Tope to rediscover the underground
fields.body:
Various Sampled 2 - Digging Deeper
(Virgin)
****
£16.99

John Digweed Los Angeles
(Global Underground)
*****
£16.99

Various Nu Progressive Era
(Hooj Choons)
***
£15.99

Tayo Y4K - Further Still
(Distinctive Breaks)
****
£13.99

Questions, questions. What is the future of dance music? Is the lure of vinyl dying? Are clubbers still interested in old records, in musical history? And what the Tong are nu-skool breaks? At least one thing's for sure: vinyl isn't about to die. Any number of 12-year-olds clamouring for the latest garage white labels in London's record shops could tell you that.

Starting in the capital and spreading outwards, the ravers' constant companion - the "spotter" - is having his revenge. Yes, tune trainspotting is back, back, back, so put aside those glowsticks, dahling, and reach for that notebook. This year's dancefloor trend seems to be a desire on the part of both DJs and their fans to "go back to their roots" and rediscover a sense of the underground. Too little, too late, you might cry, from the safety of your Ericsson-sponsored VIP rooms. But that ain't gonna stop them trying.

Do The Kids care about the origin of samples? It seems they do, with bells on. Virgin's Sampled series neatly turns perceived wisdom on its head. It's a musical Timewatch that rounds up the source material for hits from Fatboy Slim, Basement Jaxx, the Chemical Brothers et al. Volume one sold by the bucketload. Volume two should surpass it easily. There's the Did You Know factor, for one thing, that will have you playing tracks such as Lalo Schifrin's Mission Impossible offcut Jim's on the Move to fans of the Wiseguys' Ooh La La, and comparing Locksmith's Far Beyond to Basement Jaxx's Red Alert. Plus, most of the chosen tracks still cut it as songs in their own right, making this far superior to most half-cocked retro-disco round-ups. Recommended for all future historians.

Back in the modern era, Hastings's John Digweed is firmly in the driving seat of the new underground train. His latest Global Underground compilation, Los Angeles (most likely segued in the comfort of his home rather than the Viper Rooms, but who's quibbling?), is exactly the kind of music that should terrify parents with children of clubbing age: throbbing rhythm tracks with no hummable melodies and a whole lot of sexually charged percussion and drug-bamboozled sound effects. Buy it for your mum and you'll never be allowed to leave the house again. Even if you are 34.

Global Underground itself is one of dance music's biggest success stories. Behind it are two self-confessed Geordie wideboys who have worked their way up from under-the-counter mix tapes to a series that is now, if anything, bigger in Asia and America than it is here. And a quick glance at the Global Underground website (www.cluboxed.co.uk) should tell you everything you need to know about the kind of maladjusted target market that buys their immaculately designed double-CD packages. They're a bunch of nerdish wannabe DJs who hog the message board discussing DJ Sasha's most recent set, and the best way to mix minimal house records. My kind of people.

And they love John Digweed, one of the most technically accomplished DJs in Britain. It's probably all a big front, but the ever-humble John gives the impression that a big night out for him involves a few pints down the local before heading home to recategorise Techno A to E. Not for him the glamorous, private-jet trappings of stardom. Because of this, he isn't just the wannabe DJs' idol - he is them, writ large.

Digweed's sound has long been categorised as "progressive house", but it goes much further than that these days, a dark vision that takes in the whole genre crossword puzzle - from techno to trance and deep house. He offers a worthwhile lesson in not getting hung up on meaningless musical categories. Which is why his Los Angeles mix just edges it over Hooj Choons' Nu Progressive Era. Hooj is a daft name for a record label, but they've been riding the cutting edge since the rave days of 1990, when silly names were all the go, so you have to cut them a little slack. And as regular providers of 12in vinyl DJ fodder, their latest album remains unimpeachable. It collates recent minor classics from new heroes such as New York DJ don Danny Tenaglia, Germans Timo Maas and Sven Vath and, er, Hayes's Peace Division. All good, solid stuff, but like Al Gore, lacking "the vision thing".

So what alternatives to the thumping metronome of house music are out there in the ever-confusing category jungle? Now chart-topping hip-hop acts such as Outkast and Dr Dre are rapping about getting on one at raves, there aren't many boundaries left to break. The closest links between old-skool hip-hop beats and acid-house attitude are being forged on the London-based micro-scene known by the press as "nu- skool breaks" and by the cognoscenti as simply "breaks". For a swift education, check out Distinctive's excellent Y4K mix from up-and-coming DJ Tayo. In a world of sub-Digweed, shaven-headed, parka-wearing journeymen, at least he has the grace to hit the decks in full pimpadelic garb. The music, of course, is distinctly un-retro: future megastars such as the Stanton Warriors and Matthew "Bushwhaka" B provide a jerky, bass-heavy soundtrack that falls somewhere between Kraftwerk, Cameo and the Chemical Brothers. The future of dance music is looking safe in these hands.

fields.headline: Death to the classic rock song
fields.standfirst: In the red corner - an invigorating compilation from Rough Trade. In the blue corner - violent guitar solos from Clapton and Turin Brakes
fields.trailText: In the red corner - an invigorating compilation from Rough Trade. In the blue corner - violent guitar solos from Clapton and Turin Brakes
fields.body:
Various 25 Years of Rough Trade Shops
(Mute)
*****
£20.99

If Rough Trade hadn't opened in 1976, Nick Hornby would probably have invented it. It's spent a quarter of a century as London's premier alternative record shop, supplying what Jon Savage, in this celebratory 4-CD set's booklet, calls "beyond-the-minute recorded information capable of surprising even the most jaded". CD1 covers punk's immediate aftermath, when the maligned genre "indie" encompassed anything that strove to be intelligent and exciting: the brainy pop of the Go Betweens, Cabaret Voltaire's threatening electronica, Joy Division mining introspective depths. It's an endlessly startling opener. At what point did indie stop sounding like this? Who let the boring blokes with "classic rock" songbooks take over? Not Rough Trade. The other three CDs cover the past 20 years and cheeringly ignore indie music's drift to the mainstream, becoming more wilfully eclectic. The Smiths and Pixies give way to Cornershop and Clinic; feisty women abound (from shouty Huggy Bear to rapper Peaches); dance music creeps in via Plastikman and the Chemical Brothers. The effect is less historical document than friend's compilation tape: made with love, packed with wonderful music. (AP)

Eric Clapton Reptile
(WEA)
***
£14.99

While he is bogged down in bluesy self-indulgence live, Eric Clapton's recording career is more disciplined. His first solo studio album since 1998's Pilgrim chugs along in unhurried, pleasing fashion. As with many solo artists, Clapton's wares are voice, songs and guitar. Unlike his peers, Clapton's voice and songs are obscured by his baggage. His voice is much underrated, long mistaken for mere window-dressing. The difference between the warmth and anguish of Broken Down and the clinical hollering which lets Come Back Baby down so badly is that voice. The casually offensive I Wanna Little Girl aside, the songs pass muster: Travelin' Light resembles an up-tempo JJ Cale shuffle, before it skips daintily into Leo Kottke territory, and Stevie Wonder's Ain't Gonna Stand for It is pushed in intriguing piano-led new directions. And the guitar? Well, it's there, although too frequently employed as hubristic bluster. Yet the gorgeous instrumental title track almost shows why misguided fools once equated him to god. (JA)

Turin Brakes The Optimist
(Source)
**
£13.99

It's no surprise that Turin Brakes are being tipped as one of this year's Coldplays: they too plough a conservative furrow already traced by a thousand other male bands. Their debut album is littered with rampaging guitar solos (Save Me, The Door and more), and dire lyrics such as: "All my colours bleed for you/ can't you see them running/ my hazy hills glow green for you/ you can just call me on my mobile number" (Emergency 72). Of course, these are early days for singer-guitarists Ollie Knights and Gale Paridjanian, but let's hope that their music in future veers closer to the territory of By TV Light, easily the stand-out track here. The music is far more experimental, a shimmering wash of sloping bass, dusky guitar notes, clinking glass and the weird static sounds of TVs clamouring for attention. And Knights's voice sounds significantly less strained, even beautiful. This, at least, is music to be optimistic about. (MC)

Tim Finn Say It Is So
(Hypertension)
***
£11.99

Were Tim Finn not forever toiling in the shadow of his more gifted, more successful kid brother Neil, he would be regarded as exactly what he is: a fine singer-songwriter with a handsome pedigree. Say It Is So should redress the imbalance a little. These are sturdy, literate songs, brimming with neat little twists such as Finn's echoey vocals, which add eeriness to the already atmospheric Need To Be Right and the Prefab Sprout-esque chorus to Twinkle. He lacks sufficient flashes of genius to elevate him into songwriting Valhalla, but he comes close on the Byrdsy Some Dumb Reason: the sort of rollicking, chorus-heavy anthem baby brother has never quite been able to master. (JA)

Elf Power A Dream in Sound
(Shifty Disco)
***
£11.99

With A Dream In Sound, Elf Power have captured a golden moment in pop - the slow melting of the British Invasion into the sunny psychedelic sounds of 1967. Here are stories that make you smile, capturing the sense of excitement at the advent of something strange and new but holding close to the belief that a short, sweet pop song is perfection. In Jane, about a day-dreaming girl, the bass and lilting keyboards resonate against the winsome lyrics. It's a lovingly crafted mix of cleverness and wonder. Andrew Reigers's vocals, while sometimes sounding too high for his own good, are almost breathless with awe. Old Tyme Waves sounds like the Rutles and We Dream in Sound stomps along good-naturedly, with a noisy drum part that's surprisingly fierce. It's a mad but sweet-smelling breath of fresh air. (BC)

Snow Patrol When It's All Over We Still Have To Clear Up
(Jeepster)
****
£14.99

Snow Patrol take lo-fi charm, add some dirty riffs and buckets of regret and passion, yet still sound innocent. Maybe it's the casual vocals, gliding over the sassy synth and swooning guitars. It could be the trumpet and backward drum loops. Or perhaps it's how personal these songs are. Listening feels intrusive, with On Off - an open letter of remorse - particularly special, accepting responsibility where Coldplay's Trouble blames everyone else. The theme of the death of a relationship reappears throughout the album, the sense of disbelief tangible. "Even if we shouldn't be here, I cannot help myself with you," a tiny voice full of fear sings on Black and Blue, before it turns into a frenzied New Wave guitar epic. The fragile Make Love to Me Forever hints at a desperate clinging onto something that's fading away. Sad, sexy and simply great. (BC)

Giant Sand Selections Circa 1990-2000
(Loose Recordings)
****
£11.99

There are a lot of people under the delusion that they're playing authentic American desert roots-rock. Most of them wouldn't be fit to lick the dust off JJ Cale's boots, but Howe Gelb's Giant Sand are a magnificent exception. Gelb sounds as authentically sun-baked as a lizard basking on a rock in his native Tucson, and his leathery croak of a voice is impeccably matched with music that drifts out of your speakers like tumbleweeds at sundown. This decade's worth of Giant Sand music, including a few related items such as a Tex-Mex version of Lee Hazelwood's Sand featuring Lisa Germano, amounts to a plausible manifesto for Gelb as a true American classic. Whether he's trekking through a painfully ragged take of Neil Young's Music Arcade or evoking a heat-haze in The Inner Flame, his music makes you want to mop your brow and trot wearily towards the next watering-hole. Giddy-up! (AS)

My Vitriol Finelines
(Infectious)
***
£13.99

You'll search in vain for anything especially vitriolic about either this debut or its Anglo-Sri Lankan creators. Despite the odd rumble of thug-metal, My Vitriol seem to be as mild-mannered as kohl-eyed mainman Som Wardner's old buddies, Coldplay. Wardner sweetly sings of "falling at your feet", and mourns a relationship that is "just as empty as it seems", and what vitriol he harbours is expressed only in small, manicured bursts of distorted guitar. Those bursts, though, have seen them adopted as leading lights of the British nu-rock fraternity, a tag that doesn't suit their melodic pop proclivities. Perhaps that's why they titled one 30-second screech of white noise Critic Orientated Rock. Mostly, they tread a catchy path delineated by imploring vocals and shiny choruses that owe something to both Irish guitar-pups Ash and the Manic Street Preachers. They perfect their technique on the wildly infectious Always Your Way and Cemented Shoes, which are as good a place as any to start on this diverting album. (CS)

The Clicking Stick Mocrophone
(Rictus Recordings)
***

At first, Mocrophone seems to be one of the oddest records ever made. Titles such as I've Got the Blues Because My Hands Are Flowing Red conceal an apparently sprawling mess of trombone grunts, "head in clay urn chanting" and a rhythm section that sounds like a broken typewriter. However, get past the shock of such avant-garde leanings and the Birmingham's band's experiments become thoroughly addictive, although not for the faint-hearted. There's a perverse logic here that recalls the pioneering spirit of 23 Skidoo and Captain Beefheart, and even the deranged jazz segments of Bowie's Heroes and Outside albums. However, Martin Longley's impassioned and barmy vocals ("Dead trousers, airing up the legs" indeed) - give Mocrophone unique character. Quite where the warped piano magic of Hand Leather Regurgitator ("blazing masturbator . . . ") will take them is anyone's guess, but at this has all the hallmarks of a minor, peculiar cult. (DS)

webTitle: Selby rail crash: police to investigate Land Rover

fields.headline: Driver denies being asleep at wheel
fields.standfirst:
Police say every possibility will be examined to find out why vehicle left road

Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: Police say every possibility will be examined to find out why vehicle left road.
fields.body:
The wife of the driver of the Land Rover that careered off the M62 and travelled more than 50 metres along a steep grass verge before ending up in the path of an express train yesterday dismissed suggestions that he might have fallen asleep at the wheel.

Gary Hart, 36, from Lincolnshire, is understood to have told police that a blown tyre caused his vehicle, which was towing a low trailer carrying a Renault car, to slew off the motorway a few metres before the start of crash barriers.

Supt Tony Thompson of British transport police said all aspects of why the vehicle went off the road were being covered. Asked if that included looking at whether Mr Hart fell asleep, Mr Thompson said: "Yes, absolutely, that is obviously one of the conclusions that might be drawn. That is one of them, as well as obviously the technical aspects of the vehicle, and the road surface."

Elaine Hart, 38, said her husband had stressed that the crash was a tragic accident. At a news conference in Withern, Lincolnshire, where Mr Hart's parents live, his wife said: "Gary is a very traumatised and is suffering a lot of pain. He is more than willing to cooperate with the police, but he has been asked not to comment at this stage. It was definitely an accident. He is very distraught. It is rubbish that he fell asleep at the wheel."

Embankment

Yesterday an inspection of the grass verge showed two sets of tyre marks veering off the motorway about 45 metres before a bridge that carries the road over the railway track and before the crash barrier starts. The Land Rover appears to have continued in a straight line, traversing the steep embankment parallel to the M62 before rolling over and crashing through two wooden fences at the corner of a field. It then seems that the vehicle tumbled down the steep railway cutting, where it was brought to a halt by gravel and railway tracks. If the vehicle was travelling at 50mph as is believed, the time from its leaving the motorway until it landed on the railway line would have been little more than five or six seconds.

Investigators carrying out a search of the scene will have looked for signs that would help them to determine the cause of the accident, including whether or not there were any skidmarks on the carriageway, indicating if the vehicle had tried to brake.

Once the Land Rover has been removed from the site it will be inspected by a vehicle examiner trained to piece together the precise state of a vehicle immediately before an accident. This will be a delicate job because the entire front of the vehicle was ripped off by the impact with the train. More than 40 pieces of wreckage, marked by poles and spread out over a large area, will also be examined.

Police are being assisted by an accident investigation team from the transport research laboratory in Crawthorne, North Yorkshire. In their first big operation, the team of six specialists in road and rail crashes, accident investigation and weather effects will be equipped with laser-surveying technology.

The equipment is able to quickly survey and reproduce the crash scene. This will give investigators access to an exact, three-dimensional representation of the scene - complete with the trains, the wreckage of the Land Rover and other debris - even after the site has been cleared.

Yesterday Mr Hart, who works in the building industry, was said to be inconsolable with grief. Martyn Taylor, his father-in-law, said: "He can't comprehend what has happened. How could you? We are trying to cope, but to see all those people killed in that way.." Mr Taylor said Mr Hart, who has four daughters, had been on business in Wednesday morning. He had not talked about what happened, apart from to say that it was an accident.

Robert Tilley, a lifelong friend who sold him the Land Rover County two years ago, said Mr Hart was a "very competent" driver who always kept the vehicle well maintained. "He is a very level-headed, decent bloke," said Mr Tilley. "He works really hard and often gets up at 4am or 5am to drive to work many miles away. I think he was on his way to a job in Wigan when the accident happened and he was delivering the Renault for a buyer up north. He is used to driving long distances."

Mr Hart's mother, Margaret, said: "He is very lucky to escape but I am very worried about him being at the centre of such a terrible tragedy."

fields.headline: News Corp denies DirecTV takeover crisis
fields.trailText:
5.15pm: Rupert Murdoch's News Corp has denied takeover talks for DirecTV are on the verge of collapse, reports Dan Milmo.
March 2: Merger on the verge of collapse
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation has angrily denied takeover talks for DirecTV are on the verge of collapse.

Sources close to the negotiations claim DirecTV owner General Motors is trying to "sweeten the pot" by offering the US satellite broadcaster to News Corp's rivals.

However, a News Corp spokesman today denied reports the talks had stalled completely because GM was not getting enough value out of the deal.

"The talks are ongoing and they are progressing slowly. Any suggestion of a stalling in the process is plainly wrong," said the spokesman.

The competitors in the frame are understood to be media giant Disney, cable operator Comcast and General Electric, owner of the NBC TV network.

"It looks as if GM's bankers are trying to get others interested and increase the value from a deal," said one source.

The source added talks between News Corp and GM were at a delicately balanced stage, and the £49bn deal could go either way.

A spokesman for Hughes Electronics backed up the claims when he admitted the company was "reviewing the other interested parties".

This further dampens speculation that Mr Murdoch was on the verge of snapping up DirecTV and its holding company Hughes Electronics.

If Mr Murdoch pulls off the DirecTV takeover, he will give his Sky Global Networks subsidiary a much needed foothold in the US.

fields.headline: Foot and mouth restrictions eased
fields.standfirst:
• Animal movement ban relaxed
• UK cases reach 37
• Ireland fears the worst
• Blair angers supermarkets
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: A relaxation of the nationwide ban on the movement of animals, imposed to stop foot and mouth disease from spreading, was announced today to help farmers and boost the country's dwindling meat supplies amid fears of panic-buying.
fields.body:
A relaxation of the nationwide ban on the movement of animals, imposed to stop foot and mouth disease from spreading, was announced today to help farmers and boost the country's dwindling meat supplies amid fears of panic-buying.

The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, said animals in disease-free zones will be licensed to go to slaughter directly to approved abattoirs, possibly by Tuesday of next week.

Four more cases of foot and mouth disease were confirmed today in Worcestershire, Wiltshire, Dumfries and Cumbria, taking the total to 37 for the UK.

Irish police today also sealed off a farm in County Louth and a meat factory in Kildare amid mounting fears that the disease may have spread to the Republic of Ireland.

Officials moved into the premises, around 20 miles south of the border with Northern Ireland, in the early hours. Reports indicated the farm may have received sheep from north of the border which had come into contact with the disease.

The operation was centred close to the main Belfast-Dublin road and about 30 miles from the farm at Meigh, south Armagh, where 20 sheep were discovered with the disease. They had been bought in a market in Carlisle before the outbreak was discovered.

The Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, today said the disease represented a "once-in- a-generation" threat to his country.

News of the latest confirmed cases came as the prime minister, Tony Blair, became embroiled in a row with supermarkets after he accused the country's biggest stores of having farmers in an "arm-lock" to produce cheap food.

Asda, which yesterday announced it had already run out of pork and lamb at one of its stores and warned of shortages elsewhere, accused Mr Blair of looking for a "scapegoat" as concerns were raised that falling farming standards might have contributed to the outbreak and spread of foot-and-mouth.

Mr Blair also said that the government were working on a compensation package for farmers and looking at measures to protect the long-term future of farming in Britain.

He said the licensed slaughter scheme was "enormously important" to get some British meat back into stores, which have been increasing their demand for imports.

Concerns over the safety of foreign meat imports have also been raised as the Food Standards Agency (FSA) disclosed that consignments of beef from Germany and Holland imported to East Sussex were found to contain remnants of spinal chord.

The chief veterinary officer, Jim Scudamore, said that a total of 37,000 animals were having to be destroyed and that 67,000 needed to be tracked down and tested.

A farmer is to be prosecuted for allegedly breaching special regulations introduced to curb the foot-and-mouth disease outbreak by allegedly moving cattle, trading standards officials said today.

Colin Hebson, of Chapel farm, Cotehill, near Carlisle, Cumbria, will appear before the town's magistrates court on Monday accused of breaking the Foot and Mouth Declaratory (Controlled Area) Order 2001.

Vets are continuing to try to untangle the web of trades in sheep in the two weeks before the outbreak was confirmed. The number of cases is expected to rise at the rate of six to eight a day for the next week.

Meanwhile, the outbreak has prompted scientists to place the world's first cloned sheep, Dolly, in quarantine.

Dolly has been isolated from other animals at the Roslin Institute, near Edinburgh, and the research centre has been closed to visitors until the disease is under control.

Professor Ian Wilmut, of the institute, said the precautions were the same as those being taken at other farms, but acknowledged that Dolly was a special case.

Called off

 Crufts dog show, due to start on March 8, postponed

 The Reading marathon

 Forestry commission closed all forests to public

 East and West Sussex closed all footpaths

 National Trust closed almost all properties in England, Wales and Northern Ireland

 National shire horse show, due to take place at Peterborough, cancelled

 National Botanic Garden of Wales closed

 Army training stopped and helicopters grounded

 Britain's oldest horse race, the Derby, faces cancellation for only second time in its 480-year history

Online debate
Guardian columnist George Monbiot was live online discussing the foot and mouth crisis on Thursday March 1 - see what he had to say

webTitle: March 2: diary of a monitored social services department

fields.headline: Laying the foundations for an improved service
fields.standfirst: Lisa Christensen returns from holiday to a stack of graphs and a schedule full of meetings, but finds evidence that the department is starting to achieve its goals
fields.trailText: Lisa Christensen returns from holiday to a stack of graphs and a schedule full of meetings, but finds evidence that the department is starting to achieve its goals.
fields.body:
Returned from holiday to commence a week largely focused on money and performance. In fact, thinking about it, most weeks are.

I am turning into a sad type who gets her thrills from seeing ever more accurate graphs and pages of figures which are the evidence that 1,000 people's effort is getting harnessed with increasing effectiveness towards achieving some well defined goals.

Having luxuriated in glow of the graphs, I spent two-and-a-half mornings and half an afternoon thrashing through what they are really telling us. Firstly, with spokespeople on social services from the three political parties. Next day, with the management team; that afternoon with the leader, and finally with the social services inspectorate (SSI) at my monitoring meeting on Friday.

The dataset is now impressive and covers everything from sickness absence, staff turnover, telephone performance, client-related activity (which forms the bulk), complaints, and member inquiries.

We include targets for all the indicators and are trying to get a range of benchmark authorities to compare ourselves with - strangely many seem to be rather coy about getting into an arrangement with us.

A key concern for us - which we discussed at length with our SSI colleagues on Friday - was to establish what level of performance we will have to hit to avoid further ministerial directions when our current set expire on August 31. We are being completely transparent and realistic about where we think we will be and need to know how we will be judged.

We believe that sustainable progress and performance levels that compare reasonably with other similar authorities are the key.

Whatever the final judgment on this, we must devote our main energies now to establishing our foundations to get a firm footing for the service we are rebuilding - if we do that the performance will improve and the figures will reflect the improvement.

Had a great meeting with the now virtually complete management team in children's services. I count my blessings to have got such a good team who are so enthusiastic about the challenge - and are brimming with confidence. They'll certainly make a difference.

 Lisa Christensen is social services director for Lambeth council

fields.headline: Passing the buck
fields.standfirst:
Britain's park authorities want to protect deer from foot and mouth - but according to some, they are villains not victims
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Britain's park authorities want to protect deer from foot and mouth - but according to some, they are villains not victims, writes Derek Brown.
fields.body:
There is a great irony in today's announcement that three Royal parks are to remain closed to the public.

The park authorities want to protect the deer herds in Richmond Park, Bushy Park and Hampton Court Home Park from the ravages of foot and mouth. But according to farmers - and government agencies - deer could be the villains rather than the victims.

They not only suffer from the disease, but are almost certainly spreading it far and wide among other wildlife, and domestic animals.

The deer population in Britain has increased hugely in recent years, to an estimated one million. They are present in all counties of England, vast tracts of Scotland, and are increasing steadily in Wales.

As ungulates, or cloven-footed, animals they are susceptible to foot and mouth - but they cannot be isolated and destroyed, like cattle, sheep and pigs. Indeed, when the latest eruption of foot and mouth was reported, one of the government's first responses was to slap a ban on deerstalking.

That was a logical extension of the official policy of restricting human and animal movement in outbreak areas. But it has also temporarily removed from the countryside the deer's only significant predator - men with guns.

Each year, some 80,000 deer are killed by hunters in Britain. A relative handful are hunted by dog-packs, and shot when cornered. The great majority are stalked and shot, either for sport or in habitat-protection schemes by conservation bodies.

The annual cull may seem enormous, but it is having little impact on the flourishing numbers of deer. Of the six species which live in the wild, only two - the Red and the Roe - are indigenous to Britain.

The others are the Fallow, thought to have been imported by the Romans, the Sika, the Muntjac and the Chinese Water Deer. The last three were introduced in the late 19th century, as ornamental park animals. (A seventh species, the reindeer, was reintroduced in the 1950s to the Scottish Highlands, where a small herd exists in semi-domestication).

Without natural predators, deer are expert survivors. Naturally secretive, they spend most of the day and night in woodland, usually emerging only at dawn and dusk to graze and browse. (The exception is the majestic Red, which has adapted to moorland conditions. It is abundant in northern Scotland, where there are estimated to be 300,000 of them, and is also flourishing on Exmoor, the New Forest and the Lake District).

For many farmers, deer are a pest - and a rapidly growing one. In many parts of the country where deer were unknown a generation ago, they have become a common sight, on farmland and even in gardens. The recent fashion for woodland planting has extended their range.

Most conservationists agree that deer numbers have to be controlled, not least to protect their own habitats. In large numbers they can cause extensive damage to young trees as well as to crops. Now the threat they pose is more immediate - but there is likely to be a massive outcry if a major cull is mooted.

The problem, to put it brutally, is that deer have big brown eyes and attractive young. There wouldn't be a fuss if the authorities attempted large-scale extermination of rats - also potential transmitters of foot and mouth - but the animal 'rights' lobby is likely to froth with fury if deer are threatened.

The problem, to put it brutally, is that deer have big brown eyes and attractive young. There wouldn't be a fuss if the authorities attempted large-scale extermination of rats - also potential transmitters of foot and mouth - but the animal 'rights' lobby is likely to froth with fury if deer are threatened. webTitle: In brief: Eminem offered $4m to be movie bad guy

fields.headline: Eminem offered $4m to be movie bad guy
fields.standfirst: Plus: ITV picks up 14 Hollywood blockbusters; Affleck and Damon name competition winner; Jamie Theakston dreams of movie stardom; Film Council lights the way for future film-makers
fields.trailText: Plus: ITV picks up 14 Hollywood blockbusters; Affleck and Damon name competition winner; Jamie Theakston dreams of movie stardom; Film Council lights the way for future film-makers
fields.body:
 Eminem has been offered more than $4m (£2.74m) to join fellow rap artist DMX in the film Lazarus. But Michael Fleming reports in Variety that the controversial rapper, who has turned down other projects including one opposite Denzel Washington, is unlikely to be tempted by the movie. The film will tell the story of two young men who die and are then brought back to life. As one is good and the other evil, they do battle for dominance in the hip hop world. Eminem has, unsurprisingly, been offered the role of the bad guy.

 Matt Damon and Ben Affleck have announced the winner of their search for a new Hollywood star (see earlier story). According to Reuters, Damon and Affleck have given their own version of a film studio "green light" to unknown writer-director Pete Jones, who will now have the chance to make his own film, Stolen Summer, with a $1m (£686,000) budget and the two stars as executive producers. Miramax Films will distribute the movie. "Really, this is the first time I've had a chance to get anything out," said 31-year-old Jones. "I've never even gotten as far as film development hell, and if I had, well that would have been heaven." Affleck and Damon say they plan to hold a second contest next year.

 More on the contest.

 ITV2 has picked up 14 feature films from a new deal with Columbia TriStar. According to Variety, ITV's digital TV channel has signed a deal for a package of films which include Sleepless in Seattle, Philadelphia and The Last Action Hero.

 Jamie Theakston is the latest TV star to harbour ambitions of becoming an actor. Peoplenews reports that the former children's television presenter has been offered a role as a surfer in a low-budget British film set in Cornwall. The part is being described as an ideal springboard role, as it is expected to be shown at this year's Cannes Festival. It is thought that Theakston's interest in acting has been rekindled by his relationship with Joely Richardson.

 The Film Council is launching a new scheme to give children the opportunity to make short films on digital video. Screendaily reports that the Council has partnered with Hi8us Projects for the £1m scheme, dubbed First Light. It will enable children aged from eight to 18 to make films up to ten minutes long, using a range of low-cost digital technology. Children will work with film industry mentors and advisors and experience all aspects of film production. First Light is expected to be open for applications from May.

fields.headline: My Uncle George
fields.standfirst:
How does all-American clothing company Tommy Hilfiger prove its patriotism once and for all? Hire the president's niece, of course. Emma Brockes meets her
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: How does all-American clothing company Tommy Hilfiger prove its patriotism once and for all? Hire the president's niece, of course. Emma Brockes meets her
fields.body:
Tommy Hilfiger was always in the running for label of choice of America's first family. With its slightly creepy re-rendering of 1950s US, in which grown-ups wear sailor suits and the sun always shines, it is to leisurewear what George Bush is to politics. Nevertheless, it came as a surprise this week when an invitation to the launch of Hilfiger's new collection laid down as its trump card Lauren Bush, niece of the president, who would act as "ambassador" for the clothing company. (Twenty minutes later, a second invitation arrived, this time with "niece" spelt correctly.)

Sixteen-year-old Lauren, daughter of the president's brother Neil and his wife Sharon, was brought up in Houston, Texas, and has recently been signed to the Elite model agency. The promotional material put out by Hilfiger didn't disguise its intentions. "Last week her uncle discussed world politics with Tony Blair - this week London welcomes Lauren as an ambassador for Tommy Hilfiger." The non sequitur was as shameless in its implication as it was tenuous: to wear Hilfiger isn't a fashion statement any more, it's an act of patriotism.

By marrying the company name to that of the president, the American clothing giant has pulled off a fantastic ambition: to make good the heavy-duty symbolism it has for years used to market itself as a branch of the establishment. The Hilfiger logo is a reconstitution of the US flag; its ad campaigns feature girls and boys who look as if they have been assembled by a committee chaired by Senator Joe McCarthy.

In Britain the label is better known for adorning spoof rapper Ali G -not, one suspects, an accidental choice. Sacha Baron Cohen's appropriation of the whitest, preppiest of American labels is in the same spirit of mockery that 10 years ago saw sixth- form girls vulgarise Laura Ashley skirts by wearing them with Doc Martens.

In the Sloane Street store, the candy-striped deck shirts and camel sweaters are even more fanatically folded than in Benetton and models slink about like Egyptian cats.

"Yeah, Louise - or was it Laura? - was, er, nice," says one, Simon. "She's only young, though, and during the photo-call she got a bit - " he pulls a face. "It's not easy having 40 men yelling at you to take your coat off."

Lauren Bush is a somewhat pitiful figure in all of this, exhausted by jet lag and flagging under the over-bright lights of the store's basement. Her mother Sharon, a traditional southern belle (it is still the 1980s at make-up counters in Houston), is positioned a little way off like a scrum-half, ready to protect her daughter from impertinence and prompt her if she falters.

I ask Bush Jnr what it means to be an ambassador for Tommy Hilfiger. "Er, it means you, um -" she shoots at her mother the first in a series of desperate looks. "It means you come to London... and you wear the clothes. Um." Does she like Hilfiger fashions? "Yeah. You know, 'all-American' and that." The arrow of adolescent sarcasm peters out and she goes back to looking tired and bewildered. "Their styles are clean and classic, which is what I like."

Her music tastes, Bush says, are "mainly alternative bands, not too much rap, some punk". Yes, she likes Eminem - another glance at Mom - but hasn't bought the albums yet.

The three-paragraph biography released by Tommy Hilfiger seeks to establish Bush as a modish but politically aware young thing who, like the brand itself, is both of the people and above them. "Not since Jacqueline Kennedy has an American girl wowed the French as Lauren did when she was presented on the arm of a prince at the Bals de Debutantes at the Hotel Crillon in Paris," it pants, before informing us that "Lauren is busy with the regular demands of homework and after-school activities that any high school student in Texas faces".

Given her age and kinship to the president, her political convictions are understandably vague. What issues does she feel passionate about? "Um, anything with children and animals." She and the family are proud of her uncle, she says, and looks embarrassed, before brightening at the mention of the charity work she has done for an organisation called Dress for Success. "It gives clothes to women who are going back into the workforce. Also, my friends and I are collecting prom dresses to give to girls who can't afford them for their proms."

When she finishes high school, she says, she wants to go to business school. Who has she been most excited about meeting since her uncle was made president? Mom jumps in. "Colin Powell," she yells from the sidelines. Her daughter looks mortified. "Oh," she says, "oh, well, he was awesome and all, but let me try to think of someone younger."

There follows a short, excruciating silence. The ambassador for Tommy Hilfiger looks anxiously around the store for inspiration. "I'm sorry," she says, weakly. "My mind's gone blank."

fields.headline: Microsoft unveils online media initiative
fields.trailText: 4.15pm: Microsoft Network is setting up a pan-European online media planning facility to encourage corporate advertising. By Wale Azeez.
fields.body:
Microsoft Network is attempting to rejuvenate a flagging online advertising sector by setting up a pan-European online media planning facility to encourage corporate advertising on the portal.

The MSN Media Centre will enable advertisers to plan online European-wide campaigns by supplying them demographic data to target surfers, and hopefully provide an incentive to spend more on online marketing.

"The idea is to provide advertisers planning information at their fingertips," said Matt Whittingham, UK business marketing manager at MSN, and provide them with tools other than banner advertising to devise campaigns.

"Banner ads are not the only things out there. We also hope to encourage online branding and the distribution of retail content," he said.

Information available will range from case studies of other advertisers on the portal, to demographic data such as age, gender and occupation of the target audience. The data will be provided by researcher Nielsen.

Mr Whittingham said the site would eventually enable advertisers to tailor campaigns across each of the 33 European countries and 17 languages in which MSN operates.

The MSN Media Centre will go live in the UK from March 12 and will mirror a similar initiative launched in the US in April last year.

webTitle: Foot and mouth affects supermarket's supplies

fields.headline: Supermarkets struggle to keep pace as sales rise
fields.standfirst:
Shoppers stock up during wait to move livestock from disease-free areas

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Signs that shoppers are stocking up in case meat becomes scarce were seen yesterday. Tesco said a steep increase in meat sales meant that branches were having trouble keeping fridges filled, even though they have good stocks in depots.
fields.body:
Signs that shoppers are stocking up in case meat becomes scarce were seen yesterday. Tesco said a steep increase in meat sales meant that branches were having trouble keeping fridges filled, even though they have good stocks in depots. Customers were also buying more milk, dairy products, fish and pasta, but so far the company had not seen the panic buying that took place during the fuel crisis.

A similar picture emerged from Sainsbury's, Asda, Safeway and Waitrose. How well they cope with demand will depend on whether the public keeps its nerve, they said. Supermarket buyers were hoping to cover shortages in British meat with imports from the Republic of Ireland but if foot and mouth is found there, they will bring meat in from further afield, which will be more expensive.

The British Meat Federation, which represents slaughterers and whole salers, said British pork would be in short supply from this weekend, home-grown lamb would last until the middle of next week and beef supplies were reasonable.

Small independent butchers were finding it harder get hold of supplies, however, and Graham Bidston of the National Federation of Meat Traders, said they were depending on the Ministry of Agriculture allowing some movement of livestock soon.

The junior agirculture minister, Lady Hayman, said measures to introduce limited movement under licence of livestock from uninfected areas could start on Monday.

webTitle: Former prisoner wins damages for attacks

fields.headline: Former prisoner wins damages for attacks
fields.standfirst: Policing crime
fields.trailText: Danny McNamee, whose conviction as an IRA terrorist was quashed, today won £5,000 High Court damages for injuries suffered as a result of unjustifiable attacks by prison officers in the wake of an unsuccessful breakout.
fields.body:
Danny McNamee, whose conviction as an IRA terrorist was quashed, today won £5,000 High Court damages for injuries suffered as a result of unjustifiable attacks by prison officers in the wake of an unsuccessful breakout.

Mr McNamee, 40, whose conviction for playing a part in the July 1982 Hyde Park bombing was quashed in December 1998, needed stitches to two head wounds after the escape bid from Whitemoor prison, Cambridgeshire, in September 1994.

Today, Mr Justice Crane, in London, allowed a claim against the Home Office by Mr McNamee and by fellow escapee, armed robber Andrew Russell, for assault and battery or misfeasance of public office.

Russell, 38, who is still serving a 20-year term for an armed robbery and for hijacking a helicopter for a jailbreak at Gartree, was awarded £2,500.

A similar claim by 37-year-old Liam McCotter, who was also jailed as an IRA terrorist and has completed a sentence imposed in June 1988 or conspiracy to cause explosions, was dismissed.

The judge said that Mr McNamee's evidence that he was hit twice on the head with some object was clearly supported by the medical evidence.

"Although Mr McNamee did not see what object struck him, prison officers had drawn staves at the time.

"The conclusion that he was hit twice with a stave is inescapable."

The judge accepted Mr McNamee's evidence that after he was restrained on the ground by officers and handcuffed, without struggling, other blows were delivered, whether by fists, feet or batons.

He ruled that the blows struck, particularly the two with a stave, were not "justified or reasonable".

The judge accepted Mr McNamee's evidence that there were some blows and one kick on his arrival back at the prison's segregation unit.

He described the failure to obtain more urgent medical attention for Mr McNamee's head as "inexcusable", although it did not lead to any lasting aggravation of his condition.

In Russell's case, the judge said that the medical evidence about the injuries on his face led him to the inescapable conclusion that he was punched and kicked in broadly the way he described while on the ground, handcuffed and effectively restrained.

He also accepted Russell's evidence that an officer stamped on his hand.

None of the three, who were legally aided to bring the action - which is likely to cost the taxpayer more than £500,000 - were in court.

The judge said that he was conscious that the principal unlawful activity that evening was the unlawful escape of six prisoners serving long sentences for dangerous crimes, in which guns were carried and fired - one shot injuring a prison officer.

"Some people may take the view that, if a group of armed prisoners escape from a prison, they should not be entitled to complain about any violence to them in the course of their recapture.

"Some people may say that the present action should not have been publicly funded.

"However, the duty of the court is clear: to ascertain the facts and to judge the issues that arise.

"Those who break the law do not forfeit its protection."

Director general of the Prison Service, Martin Narey, said: "We will consider the judgment of the court very carefully.

"But I welcome the recognition by the judge that the actions taken by the staff in dealing with a highly dangerous incident involving the use of firearms was very courageous and that officers were in fear of their lives.

"Fortunately, only one officer was shot and he recovered after treatment.

"Staff involved in the recapture of the prisoners put their own lives at risk in ensuring the protection of the public."

Former Whitemoor prison officer John Kettleborough was shot in the ribs as he investigated a hole in the perimeter fence on the night of the escape bid in September 1994.

He received £14,000 compensation for his injuries and now works at a prison in the Cayman Islands.

fields.headline: New Media Markets
fields.standfirst: Publication date: March 2
fields.trailText: March 2: Liberty Media is seeking to dominate distribution and content in Germany.
fields.body:
Liberty Media is planning to dominate distribution and content in Germany following last week's surprise deal.

Pay-television piracy is becoming increasingly sophisticated and threatening, costing an estimated £2.5bn a year in lost subscription revenues.

Canal Satelite Digital, the Spanish digital satellite service, has taken a bold decision to almost double the price of its basic package.

ONdigital has launched interactive enhancements to key programming on its own channels and those of ITV.
