fields.headline: VAT move would encourage green housing
fields.standfirst: It is currently cheaper to build a new home than to do up an old one. But the Budget could change all that, reports Simon Parker
fields.trailText: It is currently cheaper to build a new home than to do up an old one. But the Budget could change all that, reports Simon Parker.
fields.body:
The biggest story for the housing sector in last year's Budget was what the chancellor did not say. Dashing the expectations of social landlords, Mr Brown failed to announce the equalisation of VAT for new and refurbished properties.

That meant that the process of building a new home attracts no VAT, while that of refurbishing an old one is charged at the full 17.5% rate.

The policy flies in the face of the government's goal of rejuvenating the country's inner cities by discouraging the recycling of old homes and business premises.

Ministers were discussing the move in the run-up to last year's Budget, and this fuelled expectations that the two rates would be equalised at 5% or 7.5%.

The chancellor is likely to partly address the issue in this year's Budget by extending the zero rate of VAT to cover renovating buildings that have been derelict for more than 10 years, and promising a 5% rate for converting residential properties into flats.

This does not go as far as organisations such as the Chartered Institute of Housing and the Confederation of British Industry would like. They are still pushing for an equalisation.

The most significant announcement that Mr Brown did make in last year's Budget was a plan to raise £1bn for economic development through a network of regional venture capital funds, set up in partnership with the regional development agencies and the small business service.

Registered social landlords (RSLs) won a widening of stamp-duty exemptions to cover their property transactions with other housing associations and local authorities. This move was designed to smooth the continuing transfer of thousands of council homes into the hands of the RSLs.

In an announcement aimed at cutting the number of winter deaths in the UK, the chancellor also announced a cut in the VAT rate to 5% on energy saving materials, such as insulation, installed in homes.

There was little for local government, although education, roads and public transport all received significant boosts.

On top of all that, Mr Brown provided a package of measures to combat poverty, with an extra £4.35 a week per child for low-income families; an extra £50 on the winter fuel allowance for pensioners; and the promise by 2003 of a new employment tax credit, based on the working families tax credit, but available to those without children.

fields.headline: Blair pays tribute to Diamond
fields.trailText:
3.30pmTony Blair has led a flood of tributes to the columnist John Diamond, who died today writes Jessica Hodgson
John Diamond loses battle against cancer
fields.body:
Tony Blair has paid tribute to the columnist John Diamond, who died today.

The Blairs had known Mr Diamond and his family for some time, and the writer's family had visited the Prime Minister's country residence, Chequers.

A statement from Mr Blair's press secretary said "The Prime Minister and Mrs Blair were saddened to hear the news of John's death. Their thoughts and prayers are with Nigella and the children, who have lost a much-loved husband and father."

The prime minister led a stream of tributes that poured in from different sections of the media.

The editor of the Times, Peter Stothard, said Mr Diamond's work had "shed light on a dark disease. That light will be his greatest legacy."

Roger Alton, editor of The Observer, another newspaper to which Diamond had been a regular contributor, added his tribute.

"He was one of the most lovable people I have ever known. No-one could meet him without having their spirits lifted.

"Despite knowing that he had a terminal illness for three years it is still hard to believe that he is dead.

"He was a wonderful, generous, kind, funny friend and a superb professional journalist," Mr Alton said.

The new editor of the Daily Express, Chris Williams, who described Mr Diamond as "a gifted writer and columnist who will be sadly missed. He was also a charming gentleman, who faced his illness with incredible courage."

Diamond's regular columns outlining his battle with the disease were praised by cancer charities for shedding light on the illness.

Sir Nicholas Young, chief executive of Macmillan Cancer Relief, said his work did much to remove the taboo surrounding the disease.

"John's work to raise awareness of cancer, through his column and his support of cancer charities such as ourselves, did a huge amount to remove the taboo that is still felt by many people living with this illness," he said.

"This sad loss will be keenly felt, not only by those of us who had the privilege of meeting him, but also the legion of readers who followed his column.

"John was a positive example of someone who had cancer and continued to live life to the full. Our thoughts are with Nigella and his family."

Dominic Lawson, editor of The Sunday Telegraph, where Diamond was a columnist for three years, praised his professionalism.

"Somehow he never failed to turn out immaculate copy even though throughout that period he was undergoing, the most intensive and unpleasant treatment for his throat cancer.

Diamond's book, C: Because Cowards Get Cancer, was adapted for stage by journalist Victoria Coren.

The play entitled A Lump In My Throat was shown in London and at the Edinburgh Festival.

The BBC recently commissioned a television adaptation in which Diamond was due to appear.

"John was a sparkling, lovable, huge hearted man and a quite brilliant journalist. "It was incredible privilege to be one of his friends and a greater privilege still to be one of his readers," said Ms Coren.

"A natural broadcaster, he lost his voice in the cruelest of circumstances, but his millions of readers heard him loud, clear and compelling to the very end.
John Diamond loses battle against cancer

fields.headline: Oz-owned publisher up for sale
fields.trailText:
3.30pm: Australian-owned publishing company Attic Futura is up for sale, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Mar 1: Attic abandons good health
fields.body:
Attic Futura, the Australian-owned publishing company that publishes B, Sugar, Shine and CD:UK, is up for sale.

Parent company PMP has announced it will merge with Independent Print Media Group, which owns the Australian Courier Newspaper Group.

Attic will resume control of its joint-venture titles B and Sugar from North South, the UK and German-based publisher with whom it shares the titles.

Attic Futura's managing director Vivien Cotterill is being briefed about the sale of the company.

PMP will also sell its UK publishing interests for £56m. This will be used to reduce its debt to £144m.

The Australian newspaper has reported the merger as an "effective takeover" of PMP.

The merger "will be the culmination of a strategic review of the company which began late last year and which clearly concluded that bringing in a partner like IPMG was the best way out for the company and its long-suffering shareholders", it said.

webTitle: How the great NHS cash bonanza melted away

fields.headline: How the great NHS cash bonanza melted away
fields.standfirst: Gordon Brown silenced the government's critics last year by announcing record spending on health. But staff shortages and strict performance targets mean that more funds are needed, argues Patrick Butler
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown silenced the government's critics last year by announcing record spending on health. But staff shortages and strict performance targets mean that more funds are needed, argues Patrick Butler.
fields.body:
As far as the NHS is concerned, one thing is certain about this year's Budget: it will not match the 2000 budget for sheer surprise and stunning impact.

In March last year, Gordon Brown gave the health service its biggest cash increase in its 52-year history. Spending was raised by 35% in real terms by 2004, or around £19bn extra.

It was a political strike of incredible potency. In a single afternoon the chancellor swept aside nearly three months of corrosive sniping at Labour's stewardship of the health service in the wake of a near-disastrous winter flu crisis.

Despite Tony Blair's vague promise that he would raise NHS spending to the European average, the Tories had begun to make headway with calls for an expansion of private health insurance, and the Liberal Democrats had won support for tax increases to boost NHS coffers.

In addition, the British Medical Association had launched a "fundamental review" of health service funding - prepared, it said, to "think the unthinkable" and consider options such as charges, and private and social insurance.

But in just 51 minutes Mr Brown demolished the Tories, trumped the Liberal Democrats and humbled the BMA. At a stroke he had appeared - as the government would later boast - to have kicked the bitter debate over NHS finance into touch.

The 2000 Budget was also seen as a clear sign that the government was planning a May 2001 election. In theory, it gave sufficient time for the cash to trickle down and begin to make a visible difference to the NHS and other public services.

Politically, it outflanked the Tories by forcing them to choose between matching NHS spending or making tax cuts. The Tories have since promised to match Labour promises on NHS spending.

The headline targets announced in the Budget last year were 10,000 extra nurses, better intensive care facilities, and a package of "modernisation" reforms that would be later crystallised in the NHS Plan, published in July 2000.

Whether the cash has yet fed though into frontline services in a way likely to make a difference to voters' perceptions is doubtful. There was no repeat of the 1999-2000 winter crisis this year, but nurse shortages are still an acute problem, and the 10-year NHS plan has yet to bear fruit.

The Treasury's condition for agreeing to the multibillion-pound handout for the NHS was to impose a strict, wide ranging framework of performance targets - from clean wards to clinical outcomes to balancing budgets - that the NHS must meet.

However, this welter of centrally imposed initiatives has left the NHS groaning under renewed financial pressure. While it will end this current financial year with balanced books, it is unsure whether it can do so again in 2001-02, and still meet the performance targets.

Last month the NHS quietly slipped an extra £140m out into health authority budgets to tidy things over. But it has not been able to dampen the renewed debate over NHS funding, which has returned rather more quickly than ministers would have liked.

Unless Mr Brown announces more cash for the NHS this time round - and there was little suggestion in the pre-budget statement last autumn that he will - the NHS will just have to stick with its "historic" increases for the next three years, despite evidence of spiralling wages and modernisation costs.

It is likely that in the event of a May election, the NHS will end this term of government as it started: wondering how it will find the cash to make ends meet.

webTitle: Charities feeling the benefit of Brown's tax changes

fields.headline: Charities feeling the benefit of Brown's tax changes
fields.standfirst: A package of measures to help voluntary organisations were announced in the chancellor's 2000 Budget. They are having an impact, reports Patrick McCurry
fields.trailText: A package of measures to help voluntary organisations were announced in the chancellor's 2000 Budget. They are having an impact, reports Patrick McCurry.
fields.body:
Charities have reported significant benefits to their income because of changes announced in last year's Budget.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, announced a package of changes to encourage charitable donations, as well as some minor reforms to VAT.

"The donation reforms are having an impact, but the VAT changes were relatively peripheral," said Nick Kavanagh, marketing accountant at Save the Children and chairman of the Charity Tax Reform Group, a lobbying organisation.

Among the changes in last year's Budget were simplifying the Gift Aid system, which allows charities to claim the income tax on individual donations. The government also extended Gift Aid to all donations, not just those over £250.

Gordon Brown also agreed to add 10% to all donations from employer-based payroll giving schemes and introduced new tax relief on donations of shares.

On the VAT side, the most important changes were improving tax relief for fundraising events and advertising.

Christian Aid spokesman Michael Griffiths said the changes to Gift Aid had led to a major boost in income for the charity. "In our annual doorstep collection we put a Gift Aid tax declaration on the back of the donation envelope and that brought us in an extra £600,000," he said.

Mr Kavanagh agrees that the Gift Aid changes have been effective. He said: "The sector has been doing a lot of work in areas such as seeing if people can Gift Aid the proceeds of sponsored events."

Some changes have also been noticed in payroll giving, although this is an area where significant improvements are likely to take longer to bear fruit as it involves building relationships with employers.

A spokeswoman for the Charities Aid Foundation, which runs one of the main payroll giving schemes, said income from its Give as You Earn scheme increased to £40m last year compared with £30m the year before.

Part of that increase was due to the Children's Promise appeal but some was probably also due to changes announced in the Budget, she said.

Share donations have also increased at some charities. "At Save the Children we've had a number of large share donations in recent months, which suggests supporters are taking advantage of the tax relief," said Mr Kavanagh.

He added that the Charity Tax Reform Group was examining ways that would allow individuals donating shares to first sell them and then donate the proceeds to the charity.

But the VAT changes have had only a limited impact, he said. It is estimated that the sector will lose £400m a year after the phased abolition of the tax credit on share dividends introduced by the government in 1997.

Mr Kavanagh said: "There have been some benefits from the VAT changes. But many have turned out to be complicated - and sometimes charities get conflicting advice from the Inland Revenue or Customs and Excise on one side and the charity commission on the other."

For example, when it came to income from fundraising events, the tax authorities want it put through the main charity while the charity commission advises it be put through the trading subsidiary, he said.

webTitle: Moscow dispatch: Holy row divides relatives of Tolstoy

fields.headline: Holy row divides relatives of Tolstoy
fields.standfirst:
Attempts to recommunicate Tolstoy to the Russian Orthodox church look likely to fail. Amelia Gentleman reports

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Attempts to recommunicate Tolstoy to the Russian Orthodox church look likely to fail. Amelia Gentleman reports.
fields.body:
Leo Tolstoy's controversial religious convictions incensed the Russian establishment during the last years of his life. A century later, his capacity to infuriate the Russian Orthodox church has not abated.

On the 100th anniversary of the writer's excommunication last week, his great-great grandson Vladimir Tolstoy called on the head of the Russian church to readmit him to the fold. This mild request for tolerance has prompted enraged controversy among Tolstoy descendants and an exasperated response from the church.

Vladimir wrote to the Russian Orthodox Patriarch Alexei II to request that the excommunication decree be revoked, appealing for posthumous forgiveness on the grounds that Orthodox believers were thrown into confusion by the church's rejection of the Russian writer. "Russian people are forced to choose between a national genius and the national religion. This is a very complex contradiction in society and within every person," he explained.

"Russians cannot renounce their nation's prophetic genius who is our culture's pride and honour," his letter stated. "Now that humanity has reached a new level of spiritual tolerance, I'm entitled to hope that my great ancestor's role in history can be reconsidered."

His appeal has not received the approval of the Tolstoy clan throughout the world - many of whom have pointed out that the writer maintained a strongly-felt distaste for the Orthodox church until his death, rejecting numerous attempts to reconvert him and dismissing the church's rituals as meaningless sorcery.

Tolstoy formulated his own version of Christianity towards the end of his life, emulating a Russian peasant's unsophisticated faith in God. He developed his belief - known as Tolstoyanism - in a series of works, most of them considered too heretical to be published in Russia. He advocated chastity, abrogated all forms of killing, and challenged most teachings of the church - questioning the concept of the Holy Trinity, the divinity of Christ and the immaculate conception.

He made no attempt to disguise his contempt for the ceremonial rites of Orthodox church, portraying priests as villains and shocking readers with viciously critical descriptions of church services. The church denounced much of his later work as unacceptably blasphemous.

Vladimir, who runs the Tolstoy museum at his estate outside Moscow, has been overwhelmed by a stream of emails from relatives this week, complaining about his campaign.

Fyodor Svetana, a distant relative who works at another Tolstoy museum in Moscow, said the pardon campaign was pointless and irrelevant, adding that Tolstoy died in 1910 "unrepentant, without any intention of seeking a reconciliation".

An official response from the patriarch has not yet been delivered, but judging from preliminary remarks made by Alexei II, the chances that the excommunication will be overturned look remote. "He brought this upon himself when he wrote his study of the Gospels and a series or works wholly oppposed to the Orthodox church. We cannot review this decision because a review is only possible when the individual changes his position," the Patriarch said on Wednesday.

Father Vsevolod Chaplin, one of the Patriarch's representatives, clarified these remarks adding that it would be unusual to reverse the decision now, particuarly given the clarity of the original case.

"It is possible that Tolstoy was on the path to repentence, but he didn't get there. One should remember that after the excommunication ruling was made, Tolstoy said himself that he was in agreement with this decision and did not consider himself a member of the Orthodox church," he said.

Seeking to reassure Orthodox believers about the writer's afterlife prospects, he added cheerfully that excommunication was by no means a sentence to hell. "Excommunication does not represent damnation as many seem to think; it is simply the recognition that the author's views were wholly incompatible with those of the Orthodox church," he said.

webTitle: Social services seem safe from Budget shock

fields.headline: Social services seem safe from Budget shock
fields.standfirst: The chancellor's plans for social services are expected to deviate little from the pattern of means-tested grants and tax credits set out in last July's comprehensive spending review.
fields.trailText: The chancellor's plans for social services are expected to deviate little from the pattern of means-tested grants and tax credits set out in last July's comprehensive spending review, writes Seamus Ward .
fields.body:
When the chancellor stands up to deliver his Budget on March 7, MPs will be on the edge of their seats. Will he stick with his favourite word, prudence, and target a series of tax breaks and spending increases at the poorest? Or will he deliver an election-winning coup by producing a bumper give-away for all?

As far as spending on social services is concerned, Labour has already set out its stall. Last July's comprehensive spending review (CSR) outlined spending plans between April 2000 and March 2004. Social services will get an increase of almost 30% over the same period. By 2004, the social services budget will be £12.2bn.

Despite the extra cash, social services departments claim they do not have enough money to go round. The CSR figures are not set in stone and, with a surplus which some economists put at £18bn, they will argue that Gordon Brown can afford to top up their budgets.

Councils, which are said to have run up a debt of £30m looking after asylum seekers, will be hoping for funds to address these people's needs.

Though the national asylum support service now looks after new asylum seekers, issuing vouchers and placing them in accommodation, councils have complained that additional costs are not being met, particularly in education and social services. The latter includes foster care for the growing number of unaccompanied children entering the country.

Even if Mr Brown ignores the claims of social services regarding asylum seekers, other social care clients could benefit from the Budget. The chancellor may boost spending on pensioners and the poorest families and their children. Help for these groups through direct grants and complex tax relief schemes has been an ongoing theme of his Budgets.

Last March, he relaxed the rules governing income support for pensioners. Those with savings of up to £6,000 can now claim income support, double the previous limit. On average, 500,000 pensioners gained £250 a year from this measure.

He also ensured that six million pensioners would no longer pay income tax by raising personal allowances to £5,790. The tax-free band was increased to £6,050 for the over-75s, who also benefit from free TV licences.

This year's Budget could include more information on the pensioner's credit, a new means-tested benefit aimed at pensioners with income of less than £100 a week or couples with less than £150. This will replace the minimum income guarantee, set in last November's mini-Budget at £92.15 a week and £140.55 for couples.

Embarrassed by publicity over the previous year's 75p a week increase in state pension, Mr Brown has increased pensions by £5 a week for single pensioners and £8 for couples, starting this April. Next year will see rises of £3 and £4.80 respectively. He also increased the winter fuel payment by £50 to £200.

Raising the standard of living of children in the poorest families ranks among the chancellor's top priorities. In his Budget last March, he announced child benefit for the first child would rise to £15.50 a week and £10.35 for subsequent children from April this year.

But the overriding principle behind the chancellor's thinking is to give the children of the poorest families the same chances in life as those with better-off parents. While child benefit can be collected by all families, the working families tax credit is aimed at the less well off. This credit now stands at £25.60 a week.

From April, a family with one child and one parent working full time will be guaranteed a minimum income of £214 a week. The new children's tax credit will take effect from April, reducing basic rate taxpayers' liability by £520 a year. Parents will be able to apply for the credit once their child is born.

People will be waiting to see how large a boost he will give to these initiatives. At the moment, experts are split about the likely extent of his largesse.

The chancellor has also ploughed money into organisations and schemes that support underprivileged children. Sure Start is a government programme that aims to improve the health and wellbeing of vulnerable children before and from birth, through local services, as part of the drive to tackle child poverty and social exclusion. There's now a £300 grant to less well-off parents to buy essential items for their new baby. Other programmes aim to cut the number of children registered as at risk by 20% and to cut smoking by pregnant mothers by 10%.

The new children's fund is also part of the anti-poverty strategy, funding preventive work as well as small community initiatives. Its budget is currently £100m, rising to £200m by 2003-04 (£450m over three years). An advisory service called Connexions will aim to tackle truancy, drug abuse and educational under-achievement in teenagers.

The chancellor has clearly set out his stall. The poorest in society will be helped through a combination of means-tested grants and tax credits. There is little doubt that he will maintain this approach on March 7, whatever he does in the rest of his Budget.

fields.headline: Modern baroque
fields.standfirst: Britten's cello suites can be played with lean briskness or rich drama - but which approach is preferable?  Andrew Clements  investigates
fields.trailText: Britten's cello suites can be played with lean briskness or rich drama - but which approach is preferable? Andrew Clements investigates
fields.body:
Britten: Cello Suites Nos 1-3 Truls Mork
(Virgin Classics)
****
£14.99

Britten: Cello Suites Nos 1-3 Rohan de Saram
(Naive Montaigne)
*****
£13.99

Britten wrote five works for Mstislav Rostropovich - the three suites for cello followed the Cello Sonata (1961) and the Cello Symphony (1963). The original plan agreed between the cellist and the composer was apparently that Britten should write a set of six such suites, following Bach's example, but whether or not Britten really envisaged completing such a scheme, his increasing ill-health in the 1970s meant that he wrote no more after the third, composed in 1971.

Yet the model of Bach is ever-present in what he did write. This is true not only in the sequences of short movements that characterise each work - six in the First (1964), five in the Second (1967), and no fewer than nine in the Third (1971) - but in the kinds of musical form that he employed. All three suites contain a fugue, while there is a chaconne in the Second and a Passacaglia to end the Third.

In every movement of these pieces, there are nods towards the baroque - to Purcell as much as to Bach. The way in which figuration is used constantly to decorate a single melodic line is a re-conception of baroque practice in Britten's own, strictly 20th-century terms. There's nothing neoclassical about these pieces, no sense of recycling the past, but an absorption of certain received forms and ideas. This creates an idiom that, in its spareness and rhythmic freedom, is of a piece with the language of Britten's church parables, which were being written in the same period - the first of them, Curlew River, was composed in the same year as the first Cello Suite.

It's inevitable that Rostropovich's performances and recordings of the suites continue to haunt all other interpretations, though he has never recorded the Third, perhaps because its premiere at Snape Maltings in 1974 was the last occasion on which he saw Britten. Yet neither of the two fine new versions, by the Norwegian cellist Truls Mork and the British-based member of the Arditti Quartet, Rohan de Saram, seems at all overawed by Rostropovich's readings. They both take their own, distinctly different perspectives on these works.

Both of the players are totally in command of the technical challenges that Britten sets - the guitar-like strummed chords, the arpeggiated harmonics, the use of the bow's wood - but Mork is undoubtedly the more expansively expressive player. His tone is bigger and richer than de Saram's, and his rubato more ample; he is more inclined towards making rhetorical gestures. His performances, too, are consistently the slower, and he generally gives more latitude to the sections in which the score allows the performer to set his own tempo.

There is something about de Saram's accounts, on the other hand, that is fascinatingly compelling. Despite his brisker approach, he never skimps on detail, or on subtleties. Because his sound-world is leaner, his playing sometimes seems more direct, carrying less historical baggage.

Hearing de Saram, you really feel you are being provided with fresh insights into all three suites, whereas Mork offers beautifully conceived and delivered performances that never really alight upon anything new. Yet many listeners will prefer his approach, and there's nothing wrong with that either.

fields.headline: Classical CD releases
fields.trailText: Finzi | Josquin | Barber | Mozart
fields.body:
Finzi: In Years Defaced; Prelude; Romance; Violin Concerto Ainsley/Little/City of London Sinfonia/Hickox
(Chandos)
****
£13.99

For Gerald Finzi enthusiasts, the main interest of this centenary tribute will be the first recording of the Concerto for small orchestra and violin, a modest three-movement work from 1927 that was his earliest attempt at an extended instrumental score. Its fusion of neoclassicism and English pastoralism is uneasy; there is none of the ecstatic lyricism that informs Finzi's best works. That, though, pervades the six songs that have been brought together as In Years Defaced, for which five composers were commissioned to orchestrate settings by Finzi to mark his 100th birthday. The results are eloquently sung by John Mark Ainsley. The finest are Colin Matthews's version of To a Poet a Thousand Years Hence, and Judith Weir's At a Lunar Eclipse, though all of them sparkle alongside Finzi's own penny-plain scoring for When I Set Out for Lyonnesse.

Josquin: Motets Orlando Consort
(Archiv)
****
£13.99

Josquin Desprez (c1455-1521) was one of the greatest of renaissance polyphonists, and the Orlando Consort's scrupulous performances of some of his most magnificent achievements, using new and specially prepared editions of the motets, do full justice to his invention and imagination. In works such as the four-voice Ut Phoebi Radiis and the lament for Ockeghem, Nymphes des Boys, the singers generally take a neutral interpretative line, allowing Josquin's own sense of musical architecture to determine the rate at which the music unfolds, without adding any extra articulation of their own. Some might prefer a more interventionist approach, but the intrinsic beauty of the Orlando's singing disarms most criticism. The clarity of the recording, which keeps every voice distinct even in the densest six-part textures, is a huge asset.

Barber: Cello Concerto; Medea; Adagio for Strings Warner/Royal Scottish National Orchestra/ Alsop
(Naxos)
***
£4.99

Volume two of the Naxos survey of Barber's orchestral music includes the inevitable Adagio for Strings, but both the Cello Concerto and the suite from his ballet Medea are much less well known. They are immediately post-war works, both premiered in 1946, when the ripe neo-romanticism that Barber had use so effectively in works such as the Adagio and the Violin Concerto was beginning to acquire a more astringent, neoclassical edge. In the concerto the cello is given some typically rangy, expressive lines, but the orchestral backdrop is less plush, and the seven extracts from the ballet score, composed for Martha Graham's company, develops that line of Barber's musical thinking still further, with a much more dissonant, hard-edged sound world, even if he still cannot resist the occasional juicy melody. Marin Alsop's performances proclaim her belief in the music, while Wendy Warner is a characterful cello soloist. But in the Adagio especially, the playing of the RSNO lacks just a bit of tonal richness.

Mozart: Arias from Die Zauberflöte; Lucio Silla; Ascanio in Alba; Zaide; Die Entfuhrung; Idomeneo Dessay/Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment/Langree
(Virgin Classics)
***
£15.99

Natalie Dessay has yet to be seen on stage in Britain, but there is no better coloratura soprano around at the moment. Yet though this Mozart showcase displays her fabulous technique and even, forward tone very effectively, the results are not quite as beguiling as they could be, and ultimately the whole disc seems lacking in real excitement. Dessay is in her element in the Queen of Night's two arias from Zauberflöte that bracket the disc, attacking the top Fs without a hint of strain. She is fine, too, in an engaging rarity from the early Ascanio in Alba. But she is less commanding in the great Martern aller Arten from Entfuhrung, even though she is on top of every technical challenge the music throws at her, and she doesn't quite bring the necessary emotional depth to the numbers from the unfinished Zaide. Admirers of great voices, however, will certainly want to hear what she does.

Szymanowski: Concert Overture; Symphony No 2; Songs of the Infatuated Muezzin; Slopiewnie Kilanowicz/London Philharmonic/Botstein
(Telarc)
***
£14.99

The two purely orchestral works here are early Szymanowski, composed in the years before the first world war when he was still assimilating the massive influences of Wagner and Richard Strauss. The song cycles are later - the gorgeously coloured Songs of the Infatuated Muezzin from 1918 open up an orientalist world that mixes in elements of Debussy and Ravel that Szymanowski explored even more ravishingly in his First Violin Concerto, while the 1928 Slopiewnie transfers that exoticism to the folk sources of his native Poland. As a compact survey of Szymanowski's development it is thoughtfully planned, but the performances under Leon Botstein lack a bit of zip, presence and tonal allure. Meanwhile, the songs ideally need a fuller-toned, more characterful soprano than Zolia Kilanowicz.

fields.headline: Havas defies advertising downturn
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: Havas has brushed off the global slump in advertising revenues by posting a 64% rise in profits, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Havas Advertising has brushed off the global slump in advertising revenues by posting a 64% rise in profits.

The French company, which is the fourth largest advertising agency in the world, said pre-tax profits for last year had risen to £57m.

"The outlook for Havas Advertising for 2001 and beyond looks very positive," said Havas chairman Alain de Pouzilhac.

The results were boosted by a contribution from Snyder, the US advertising group which Havas bought in September last year.

Mr de Pouzilhac's bullish statement comes despite a marked fall in advertising revenue growth for media companies, which has hit their key source of income.

However, advertising agencies have been protected from the downturn because they are involved in a broad range of sectors including market research and public relations.

On the other hand, broadcasters are trapped in a narrower and more cyclical advertising market, which is more susceptible to the economic downturn affecting the US economy.

The near-recession across the Atlantic has filtered through to companies in the UK, sparking a drastic slump in ITV advertising revenues.

Related stories
Feb 21: Martin Sorrell predicts tough year
Jan 22: Havas to take 100% control of media planning

webTitle: Tories face curb on state funds

fields.headline: Tories face curb on state funds
fields.standfirst:
£3.5m parliamentary grant 'not for use in election'

Special report: election countdown
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The Conservative party is to be asked to stop using £3.5m of annual state cash to fund its election campaign and party propaganda, according to a leaked report agreed by the public administration select committee.
fields.body:
The Conservative party is to be asked to stop using £3.5m of annual state cash to fund its election campaign and party propaganda, according to a leaked report agreed by the public administration select committee.

The cash, known as Short money, is supposed to be deployed solely to further the Conservative's "parliamentary opposition" to the government.

The committee report, agreed on Wednesday, states: "There is an urgent need for stricter regulation as to what Short money may be spent on and more transparency as to how it has been spent."

The committee proposes that leader of the house, Margaret Beckett, should "take an early opportunity to table an amended resolution so that the house can agree, more precisely, on what Short money may be spent and how exactly it is to be accounted for".

The report also proposes that it would be appropriate for political parties to publish accounts of how they spend their Short money.

It notes that the Conservative party and its auditors, PricewaterhouseCoopers, "were unable to give a categorical assurance that its Short money funding was used exclusively for parliamentary business".

The committee also expresses concerns that the Conservatives, after approaching the parliamentary fees office, agreed a description of how its Short money could be spent "which seems to allow more latitude in how this money is spent".

It points out that this definition was agreed privately between the Tories and the fees office "without consideration by parliament".

The committee was split over its findings, with Tory members claiming the inquiry went beyond its remit. Sources suggested that Tory MPs on the committee made as many as 18 attempts to remove any reference to Short money in the report.

The inquiry discovered that the Conservatives had renegotiated the definition of legitimate use of the Short money in a private negotiation with the fees office in May 2000.

The wider definition proposed by the Conservatives was accepted apparently without change by the house authorities. Conservative leaders had gone to the fees office after they were urged to do so by PricewaterhouseCoopers.

The wider definition stated the Short money covered "research associated with front bench duties, developing and communicating alternative policies to those of the government of the day, and shadowing the government's front bench. It does not include political campaigning and similar partisan activities, political fundraising, membership campaigns or personal or private business of any kind".

The select committee in its report, to be published next week, states: "We are not clear how 'communicating alternative policies to those of the government of the day' which is permitted under the expanded definition is different from political campaigning which is not".

However, Labour claimed the Tories were not using the money to further their efficiency as a parliamentary opposition, but to fund their election war room and communicate their policies to a wider electorate. Labour's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, called for the Short cash to be audited separately.

In a memorandum to the committee, the fees office admitted the new definition was circulated for comment and final approval only to the official opposition, the accounting officer and the national audit office. The other parties were informed in August 2000 only when the new definition was included in the "notes for the auditor" which form part of the rewritten audit certificate.

During the inquiry, David Prior, Conservative chief executive, repeatedly insisted the wider definition did not extend to partisan activity or propaganda. Mr Prior told the committee: "I have increasingly come to the view that a large measure of state funding is something that I would be in favour of."

The committee proposes that leader of the house, Margaret Beckett, should "take an early opportunity to table an amended resolution so that the house can agree, more precisely, on what Short money may be spent and how exactly it is to be accounted for". The report also proposes that it would be appropriate for political parties to publish accounts of how they spend their Short money. It notes that the Conservative party and its auditors, PricewaterhouseCoopers, "were unable to give a categorical assurance that its Short money funding was used exclusively for parliamentary business". The committee also expresses concerns that the Conservatives, after approaching the parliamentary fees office, agreed a description of how its Short money could be spent "which seems to allow more latitude in how this money is spent". It points out that this definition was agreed privately between the Tories and the fees office "without consideration by parliament". The committee was split over its findings, with Tory members claiming the inquiry went beyond its remit. Sources suggested that Tory MPs on the committee made as many as 18 attempts to remove any reference to Short money in the report. The inquiry discovered that the Conservatives had renegotiated the definition of legitimate use of the Short money in a private negotiation with the fees office in May 2000. The wider definition proposed by the Conservatives was accepted apparently without change by the house authorities. Conservative leaders had gone to the fees office after they were urged to do so by PricewaterhouseCoopers. The wider definition stated the Short money covered "research associated with front bench duties, developing and communicating alternative policies to those of the government of the day, and shadowing the government's front bench. It does not include political campaigning and similar partisan activities, political fundraising, membership campaigns or personal or private business of any kind". The select committee in its report, to be published next week, states: "We are not clear how 'communicating alternative policies to those of the government of the day' which is permitted under the expanded definition is different from political campaigning which is not". However, Labour claimed the Tories were not using the money to further their efficiency as a parliamentary opposition, but to fund their election war room and communicate their policies to a wider electorate. Labour's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, called for the Short cash to be audited separately. In a memorandum to the committee, the fees office admitted the new definition was circulated for comment and final approval only to the official opposition, the accounting officer and the national audit office. The other parties were informed in August 2000 only when the new definition was included in the "notes for the auditor" which form part of the rewritten audit certificate. During the inquiry, David Prior, Conservative chief executive, repeatedly insisted the wider definition did not extend to partisan activity or propaganda. Mr Prior told the committee: "I have increasingly come to the view that a large measure of state funding is something that I would be in favour of."

webTitle: Rise in grant rate keeps rents down

fields.headline: Rise in grant rate keeps rents down
fields.standfirst: The proportion of public grants to housing association homes up since mid-1990s, won't mean more homes, but lower rents
fields.trailText: The proportion of public money allocated to new housing association homes has reached its highest level for seven years, reflecting the increasing focus on keeping rents low. Matt Weaver reports
fields.body:
The proportion of public money allocated to new housing association homes has reached its highest level for seven years, reflecting the increasing focus on keeping rents low.

Housing associations, which now provide the vast bulk of new social housing, fund new development from a mixture of public grant administered by the Housing Corporation, their own resources and private loans.

In the mid-1990s the proportion of public grant allocated to new schemes decreased as housing associations became more reliant on private finance. This allowed the associations to build more homes but at the cost of higher rents to repay loans. The proportion of public grant used on schemes is therefore seen as a key barometer of the trade off between building more homes and ensuring that rents are affordable.

The Housing Corporation announced yesterday that public money will make up 58.5% of next year's housing association building programme. This is a sharp increase on last year's rate of 50.7%. It is also the highest proportion of grant approved for an annual building programme since 1993-94.

However, because the element of grant has increased the overall amount of money available to the Housing Corporation will buy fewer homes. Last year the agency had £750m to spend when the grant rate of 50.5% produced 22,000 homes. Next year it has more than £1bn to spend, but it expects to produce the same amount of homes because of the higher portion of grant going into each scheme on average and increased development costs.

The grant increase comes after housing minister Nick Raynsford increased to 60% the headline rate or maximum amount of grant with which the housing association can fund schemes. It follows tough new rent restraints announced in last year's housing green paper.

In the mid-1990s the Housing Corporation was under pressure to fund housing associations which bid for the least grant as a way of making grant go further. Housing associations responded by bidding well below the headline rate, in what lead to a downward spiral. Since after each year they undercut the grant rate, the next year ministers would cut the headline rate.

Fiona Cruickshank, assistant director of investment at the Housing Corporation, said: "When housing associations were undercutting the grant rate the money had to come from somewhere and this usually meant higher rents."

She said the new rate reflected "the desire to keep rents down".

fields.headline: Bright Station outfit axes third of staff
fields.trailText:
1.15pm Internet technology group Bright Station took a further pounding today as a subsidiary cut a third of staff. By Wale Azeez.

Mar 2: Smartlogik flotation shelved
fields.body:
The fortunes of internet technology group Bright Station took a further pounding today as one of its subsidiaries shed a third of its staff.

WebTop, Bright Station's search engine unit, has axed 15 sales and marketing jobs in a bid to make savings of up to £2m a year.

The blow comes a day after Bright Station announced it would indefinitely postpone the flotation of Smartlogik, its knowledge management software division, on the back of operating losses of £16.8m for the year ending December 2000.

According to a statement issued by the holding company, which last year bought the technology of high-profile dot.com failure Boo.com, a review of staffing requirements had to be carried out "based on present marketing conditions".

"Regrettably we have decided to reduce total staff numbers employed in this subsidiary business. Those staff who are not being re-employed within the group will be provided with redundancy packages and every assistance in finding new positions. WebTop, with its unique web searching technology, remains an important part of our group," the statement continued.

Related story

webTitle: Author and broadcaster John Diamond dies

fields.headline: Author and broadcaster John Diamond dies
fields.trailText: Writer and broadcaster John Diamond has died aged 47 after a long battle against cancer.
fields.body:
Writer and broadcaster John Diamond has died aged 47 after a long battle against cancer.

The disease was diagnosed in 1997 when Mr Diamond was a self-described "sometime smoking, unexercised and overweight man of fortyish". He went on to write C: Because Cowards Get Cancer Too as "an attempt to write the book I was looking for the night I got the bad news".

An unrelenting look at the disease, it offered a blow-by-blow account of the progress of his cancer and his various treatments together with his thoughts and reflections on what the illness meant for him and his family. A moving BBC documentary which followed his progress was also made.

Writing became his therapy, and the disease his subject; dying from cancer, as he said, had ironically become his living.

Both the book and his long-running column in the Times about his illness were acclaimed for their humour and courage, and their practical advice for cancer sufferers. In his column last weekend, Diamond joked about a new round of chemotherapy: "Strangely, I don't much mind about losing the hair on my head for a while, but I'm annoyed that I'll be bald-chested."

He was married to the food writer and Observer columnist Nigella Lawson, with whom he had two children.

fields.headline: John Diamond dies
fields.trailText: Columnist and broadcaster John Diamond, whose compelling accounts of life with cancer drew a large and sympathetic following, has died.
fields.body:
Columnist and broadcaster John Diamond, whose compelling accounts of life with cancer drew a large and sympathetic following, has died.

Mr Diamond, 47, died at Royal Marsden Hospital, said Peter Stothard, editor of The Times newspaper.

He won critical acclaim for his entertaining contributions to the public understanding of the disease.

"He shed unique light on a dark disease. That light will be John Diamond's greatest legacy." Mr Stothard said.

Diamond was diagnosed with throat cancer in 1997, and his weekly lifestyle column for the Times became an intimate diary blending everyday experiences with thoughts on radiotherapy, surgery and mortality.

In his column last weekend, Mr Diamond joked about a new round of chemotherapy: "Strangely, I don't much mind about losing the hair on my head for a while, but I'm annoyed that I'll be bald-chested."

He found writing therapeutic.

"It certainly helps me deal with what's happening ... It's as valid and useful for me to do this as it would be to go into complete denial or to spend my days at some centre for positive thinking," he wrote one week.

Other cancer patients, or their friends and relatives, felt the same, finding solace in his work. No longer able to taste food, he would lock himself in his bedroom while his wife, Nigella Lawson, presented a cookery show downstairs.

The former broadcaster lost his voice after an operation to remove most of his tongue, and he wrote about hearing his old voice on a repeat broadcast.

"He was the one who didn't realize what a boon an unimpaired voice was, who ate his food without stopping to think about its remarkable flavour, who was criminally profligate with words, who took his wife and children and friends for granted - in short, who didn't know he was living," Mr Diamond wrote.

As well as his weekly column, he wrote a book, "C: Because Cowards Get Cancer Too," and a play. He was tracked by television crews for more than a year for a documentary, culminating in a poignant embrace with his wife as he was wheeled in for life-threatening surgery.

"Stories like his, available to all every week in the papers, have helped bring cancer out of the closet in Britain," said Kate Law, a spokeswoman for the Cancer Research Campaign.

"By describing his life - for example how he continued to attend dinner parties even though he could no longer swallow - he helped show others that they too must try and continue life as normally as possible," Law said.

Dying from cancer, he said, had ironically become his living.

Nevertheless, some readers accused Diamond of morbid sensationalism, and there was abuse among thousands of letters and e-mails he received each week.

A stranger once saw him drowning his sorrows in a bar and berated him for not taking better care of himself and for ignoring his readers' feelings. Another reader accused him of cowardice and "not wanting to get better; a week after he'd described the joy of lighting his cigarettes.

"There you were, cheering me onto the line," he wrote the following week. "And in gratitude all I could do was cock a smoky snook at your encouragement ...Thanks for the thought. But you're wrong. I - or my body, at least, have called tobacco's bluff by being beyond its threat."

Mr Diamond is survived by his wife and two children. Funeral arrangements were not immediately announced.

webTitle: First glimpse of Harry Potter movie

fields.headline: First glimpse of Harry Potter movie
fields.standfirst:
Watch the trailer (RealPlayer)
Watch the trailer (WindowsMedia)
Watch the trailer (QuickTime)
fields.trailText: Join the rush to catch a first glimpse of Harry Potter on celluloid in a trailer posted on the internet.
fields.body:
Cinemagoers are well accustomed to being told a film is "the most eagerly awaited movie of the year" - but the tired claim seemed as if it might actually be justified yesterday as thousands of internet users rushed to catch a first glimpse of Harry Potter on celluloid in a trailer posted on the internet.

But the movie will not be coming to a cinema near you soon.

Audiences will have to wait until November to see it - making the trailer the most premature that Warner Brothers has ever released.

The studio plans to schedule the 110-second snippet for exhibition in cinemas, where it will serve less as an advertisement than as a temporary sedative for already hyperventilating fans.

A Warner spokeswoman said there had been "overwhelming interest" in the trailer, posted yesterday afternoon on the official website www.harrypotter.co.uk.

It follows the trainee wizard from his enrolment in Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry to his discovery of the full extent of his magical powers, via special effects-laden scenes depicting the broomstick-piloting game of Quidditch.

Numerous enthusiasts, sounding suspiciously like adults, flocked to the site's discussion forums yesterday to analyse the brief clip in detail.

It is hard to draw many conclusions about the quality of the acting - 11-year-old Daniel Radcliffe, playing Harry, does not speak once.

However, the scenes drip with evidence of the £80m that has been poured into shooting of the film at the Leavesden studios in Hertfordshire.

Directed by Christopher Columbus, whose credits include Mrs Doubtfire and Stepmom, the film stars Alan Rickman, Maggie Smith, Robbie Coltrane and Ian Hart - plus a flock of computer-animated owls. These figure heavily in the online trailer.

The sneak preview should provide Warner with some respite from a spate of bad publicity surrounding the movie. It has left the studio risking looking as much of a representative of the forces of evil as Potter's diabolical nemesis Voldemort himself.

Within days of signing a $103m merchandising deal with Coca-Cola, Warner announced a partial cessation of hostilities in its bid to force several young fans operating websites to surrender internet domains which include the name Harry Potter.

fields.headline: Mackintosh to 'do a Burberry'
fields.trailText: 1pm: The traditional British raincoat manufacturer is hoping to turn itself in to a trendy, luxury brand, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Traditional British raincoat manufacturer Mackintosh is aiming to "do a Burberry" and turn itself in to a trendy, luxury brand.

Mackintosh sells clothing ranges in upmarket department stores in London and Edinburgh and also makes garments for luxury labels including Hermes and Louis Vuitton.

The company is planning to open its first standalone store in London's West End next year. It will sell outerwear, luggage and accessories.

Mackintosh also has long-term plans to extend move into furniture design and manufacture.

It is understood the company will look for design and advertising agencies to help transform the brand into a fashionable label.

Burberry drafted in Saks Fifth Avenue chief Rose Marie Bravo as chief executive to help shed the brand's frumpy image.

Supermodel Kate Moss and minor royal Lord Frederick Windsor appeared in a series of ads that established the Burberry bikini as one of last summer's must-have items.

Men's suit retailer Moss Bros and English luxury goods company Alfred Dunhill have both announced plans to rebrand in attempts to tap in to the luxury goods revival.

fields.trailText: Sven-Goran Eriksson will "spring another shock" by naming Sol Campbell as England captain to face Finland ahead of David Beckham, reports the Mirror.

Sven-Goran Eriksson will "spring another shock" by naming Sol Campbell as England captain to face Finland ahead of David Beckham, reports the Mirror.

Arsene Wenger has denied rumours linking him with a move with Barcelona at the end of the season. "All that talk is rubbish. I have a contract until the end of the 2002-03 season," he told Teamtalk. "I have never broken a contract and I have no intention of doing so now."

webTitle: Tax plan may boost poorest areas

fields.headline: Tax plan may boost poorest areas
fields.standfirst: A proposed tax break could see £1bn pouring in to the UK's least well-off neighbourhoods, reports Simon Parker
fields.trailText: A proposed tax break could see £1bn pouring in to the UK's least well-off neighbourhoods, reports Simon Parker.
fields.body:
A new government tax credit could put £1bn of extra private investment into the country's most deprived areas, Gordon Brown has claimed.

The chancellor's proposals would hand investors back a quarter of the value of their money over five years in an attempt to encourage businesses, individuals, banks and charities to put more funding into areas blighted by high unemployment.

In return, investors would have to put their money into local community development companies, which provide finance for small and medium business start-ups and social enterprises that cannot get full funding from the banks.

The proposals, currently out for consultation, are a response to the social investment taskforce, whose report last year said that such a tax break could create £1bn of extra funding.

Launching the scheme, Mr Brown said: "To tackle the causes of unemployment and low economic activity, we need a radical new approach to encourage enterprise and stimulate business-led growth in our most challenged communities. We want to put in place the best possible incentive structure to open up enterprise and employment opportunities to all."

Under the proposals, the government will set a total value for the tax credit. The so-called community development finance providers would bid for a share using their business plans and evidence of their capabilities to raise and handle the money.

One such body, the Aston Reinvestment Trust, welcomed the new tax credit. Since setting up in 1997 to encourage people to "invest in their own backyard", it has made 65 loans worth over £1m to local social enterprises and businesses. The loans have levered in an extra £1.7m of other funding.

The trust's spokesman, Steve Walker, said the scheme was "really positive". "It looks like great news," he added.

The consultation period on the tax credit will last three months, making it unlikely that the measure will be introduced before the next session of parliament.

The credit is part of a government push to encourage enterprise and regeneration in the country's most run-down areas. Mr Brown has already signalled that next week's Budget will aim to create an "enterprise culture" in the parts of the country with the highest unemployment.

The chancellor has signalled that the Budget might include cuts in stamp duty on property transactions in high-unemployment areas and business rate relief for companies across the country.

fields.headline: Players and their pages
fields.trailText: Foot-and-mouth: Why the government must do more, by Gilles Grimandi
fields.body:
Foot-and-mouth: Why the government must do more, by Gilles Grimandi

"I must say that I've become very concerned about the foot-and-mouth crisis in recent days. You may not be aware of this, but when I grew up I was close to a lot of farming folk and so I can imagine what a terrible strain this must be to them.

"Watching the television footage of all those burning carcasses is extremely upsetting and alarming. This is a time of low confidence in the safety of meat, I feel. There have been other crises recently and it's becoming hard to know whether to feel safe about what you eat.

"I think the trick at this time is that the government must give us proper, clear information on what's going on. That's the only way to rebuild confidence and avoid alarm."

For more Gilles Grimandi click here.

Dennis Bergkamp: why the foot-in-mouth crisis is good for my father-in-law

"The foot-and-mouth crisis is certainly catching the headlines at the moment and I see it's even beginning to effect sport with rugby matches and horse racing events cancelled. We've had outbreaks of this in Holland in the past and also problems with mad cow disease.

"For me, it's interesting because my father-in-law is in the fish selling industry so he did really well out of these problems in the past. Obviously he's as upset as anyone about these matters but financially it helps him because it gives fish extra importance in the food chain. Suddenly, when things like this happen everyone wants to buy more and more fish."

Want to hear more of what Dennis Bergkamp has to say? Then click here.

Mario Melchiot: I'm gutted Craig David didn't win at the Brits

"My week has been taken up with the injury but I did notice that Craig David, who I really admire, missed out on getting an award at the Brits ceremony. I couldn't believe that.

"Obviously, he was up for so many awards that the votes for him were spread too thinly. It's like fancying too many women in one club and ending up with none of them.

"But it's still unbelievable that someone with so much talent, who's had so many good songs, missed out. It just shows you that the music business is like football: unpredictable. You think you're favourites to win a game and you can end up coming away with nothing."

For more of Mario's views go to his personal website.

fields.headline: Mail offers payouts to websites
fields.trailText:
1pm: The Daily Mail and the Mail on Sunday have made pay offers to settle copyright disputes with two websites, writes Amy Vickers
Useful link: theregister.co.uk
theweekly.co.uk
Mil Millington's story
Media Monkey: Guilty of plagiarism
fields.body:
The Daily Mail and the Mail on Sunday have made pay offers to settle copyright disputes with two websites.

British IT news site the Register has been promised a cheque for £250 by way of an apology for the Mail using one of its stories verbatim.

And Mil Millington, who runs a website called the Weekly, which is fast gaining cult status, has been offered £1,600 by the Mail on Sunday to settle the copyright spat.

The copyright disputes were brought to public attention when the Register ran a story detailing Mr Millington's plight.

It was a follow-up to a longer piece about the similarities between a Register story on anti-Plaid Cymru messages and an article that appeared in the Mail a few days later.

According to the Register's editor Drew Cullen, the Mail had believed it was getting the piece from a freelance journalist, and claimed it had never heard of the site.

"If you plagiarise you will be found out. Especially if you rip stuff off the web," said Mr Cullen.

"The Register may be an obscure publication so far as most print journalists are concerned.

"But we have more than a million readers a month. And they tell us when our stuff is reproduced elsewhere."

He added that the £250 would be donated to Shelter when it arrives in the post.

Register reporter Kieren McCarthy, who wrote both pieces for the site, questioned the ethics of taking alleged freelance work without checking sources.

"Why is the political editor of a national newspaper putting his byline on an article he has had very little (or nothing) to do with? Isn't that a bit lame?" he asked.

Mr Millington has been out of the country, but he has posted his version of events onto his website.

fields.headline: John Diamond dies
fields.trailText: 1pm: Columnist and broadcaster John Diamond has died after a long battle against cancer, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Columnist and broadcaster John Diamond has died after a long battle against cancer.

Mr Diamond, who wrote a column about his disease in the Times, received critical acclaim for his contributions to the public understanding of the illness.

He was a prolific writer for many papers including The Guardian and before he lost his voice was a regular on Radio 4 and Radio 5.

He was married to the food writer and Observer columnist Nigella Lawson, with whom he had two children.

fields.headline: Gillette strengthens ties with Eurosport
fields.trailText:
12.30pm: Gillette is have its own football news mini-TV programme as part of a sponsorship deal with Eurosport, reports Julia Day.
Jan 31: TF1 pays £220m for Eurosport
fields.body:
Gillette is have its own mini-TV programme focusing on football news as part of a sponsorship deal with Eurosport.

The razor and toiletries giant has extended its football broadcast sponsorship deal with the pan-European channel, signing a two-year deal.

The agreement includes a new, two-minute show called Gillette Football News, which features the latest news from around the world.

Weekly magazine programme Eurogoals will be sponsored by Gillette and the company will also receive prime spot advertising in Eurosport's major events.

Also included in the deal is online sponsorship of the Winamax Game, which appears in the World Cup 2002 section of eurosport.com.

In addition, Gillette will be the broadcast sponsor of Dream Team, a series of programmes that picks out the best players taking part in the World Cup in Korea.

"Gillette and Eurosport have built up a close partnership over the past four years," said Dominic Burns, Eurosport director of sales.

"This partnership has developed and moved up a gear with each deal."

Eurosport is available in 54 countries and broadcasts to 92m households in 18 different languages.

Related story

fields.headline: Harry Potter joins Barbie on the toyshelf
fields.trailText:
2pm: Harry the book, Harry the movie and now the inevitable has happened - Harry Potter is to be made into a doll, writes Julia Day.
Feb 26: Mattel conjures up Harry Potter game

Feb 20: Coke to cash in on Harry Potter
fields.body:
Harry the book, Harry the movie and now the inevitable has happened - Harry Potter is to be made into a doll.

And he will be accompanied by a toy version of his flying broomstick, the Nimbus 2000.

But Mattel, holder of the main licence for Harry Potter toys and maker of the Barbie dolls, will limit production and supply of the toys to keep children hooked on collecting new products.

The move is an attempt to avoid the market being flooded with Harry merchandise in a repeat of the 1999 Star Wars backlash when consumers left much of the movie's merchandise on the shelves.

Mattel, for example, will make only about 3,000 copies of a clear plastic action figure of Harry wrapped in his invisibility cloak.

There will also be fashion dolls wearing wizard robes with hair that can be brushed and action figures with trolls to fight and an electronic dragon called Roarin' Snorin' Norbert.

But the toy that most children would love to own a real version of, is the Nimbus 2000, Harry's flying broomstick on which he plays the wizard's version of football, Quidditch.

Disappointingly, the toy broomstick does not fly. It only makes flying sounds.

The toys will be launched to coincide with the release of Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone on November 16.

webTitle: Ireland dreads foot and mouth outbreak

fields.headline: Ireland dreads foot and mouth outbreak
fields.standfirst:
 Farm and meat factory closed in Republic
 36 cases in UK
 Scotland and Northern Ireland confirm outbreaks
 Fear of panic-buying
Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText:
 Farm and meat factory closed in Republic
 36 cases in UK
 Scotland and Northern Ireland confirm outbreaks
 Fear of panic-buying
Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.body:
As the 36th outbreak of foot and mouth disease was confirmed in the UK, fears that the crisis has spread to the Republic of Ireland were heightened today as police closed down a farm and a meat factory.

However, in the UK, a relaxation of the nationwide ban on the movement of animals, imposed to stop the disease from spreading, is expected to be announced to help farmers and boost the country's dwindling meat supplies amid fears of panic-buying.

Today, a major supermarket launched an attack on the prime minister after he accused the country's biggest stores of having farmers in an "arm-lock" to produce cheap food.

Asda, which yesterday announced it had already run out of pork and lamb at one of its stores and warned of shortages elsewhere, accused Mr Blair of looking for a "scapegoat" as concerns were raised that falling farming standards might have contributed to the outbreaks.

The prime minister had said at a meeting last night: "We all want cheaper food in our shops, but on the other hand the supermarkets have pretty much got an arm-lock on you people at the moment."

In Ireland, officials moved into the premises of a farm in County Louth, around 20 miles south of the border with Northern Ireland, early today and later into the Kildare Chilling company meat factory in Kildare.

Authorities are worried that sheep from Northern Ireland - where the disease was confirmed yesterday - may have been processed at the plant earlier this week.

The operation was centred close to the main Belfast-Dublin road and about 30 miles from the farm at Meigh, south Armagh, where 20 sheep were discovered with the disease. They had been bought in a market in Carlisle before the outbreak was discovered.

The affected sheep were part of a consignment of 291 which had been issued with a certificate for immediate slaughter on their arrival in Northern Ireland. They never arrived at the slaughterhouse and a man from Banbridge, County Down, where the livestock importer lived, was arrested yesterday.

Another 250 sheep, thought to be from the same consignment, appear to have been taken to an abattoir in the centre of the republic at County Roscommon.

Vets were trying yesterday to establish whether they were part of the Carlisle batch and police were trying to find 21 sheep unaccounted for.

The Irish deputy prime minister, Mary Harney, said: "This has the potential to do enormous damage to this country. This could stop the Celtic Tiger in its tracks. There are 47,500 people employed in this sector."

In Britain, six more cases of the disease were confirmed yesterday and four more today, taking the total number of outbreaks to 36. Scotland and Northern Ireland both recorded their first cases as animals at two farms in Dumfries and Galloway, and the farm in south Armagh, tested positive.

However, despite the growing numbers of outbreaks, a system is expected to be introduced where farmers in unaffected areas are given licenses to take animals directly to abattoirs for slaughter.

The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, and chief veterinary officer, Jim Scudamore are due to give an update on the latest position at midday and confirm some of the details of the plan.

Concerns over the safety of foreign meat imports were also raised last night as the Food Standards Agency (FSA) disclosed that consignments of beef from Germany and Holland imported to East Sussex were found to contain remnants of spinal chord.

Today, Mr Blair said that the immediate ban on animal movements has meant that the current outbreak is not yet progressing in the same way as the disease did in 1967.

The 1967 outbreak "was a very serious outbreak which went on for many months", he said during a question and answer session with business leaders in Cardiff, south Wales.

Vets are continuing to try to untangle the web of trades in sheep in the two weeks before the outbreak was confirmed. The number of cases is expected to rise at the rate of six to eight a day for the next week.

Called off

 Crufts dog show, due to start on March 8, postponed

 Forestry commission closed all forests to public

 East and West Sussex closed all footpaths

 National Trust closed almost all properties in England, Wales and Northern Ireland

 National shire horse show, due to take place at Peterborough, cancelled

 National Botanic Garden of Wales closed

 Army training stopped and helicopters grounded

 Britain's oldest horse race, the Derby, faces cancellation for only second time in its 480-year history

fields.headline: Murdoch's merger: a print-out-and-keep guide
fields.standfirst: A print-out-and-keep guide to News Corp's planned takeover of DirecTV
fields.trailText: A print-out-and-keep guide to News Corp's planned takeover of DirecTV
fields.body:
What is Sky Global Networks?

At the moment it's just a holding company in Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, but it is the potential jewel in his media empire's crown. It contains the Aussie tycoon's satellite TV stations, which include BSkyB in the UK, Star TV in Asia and Sky Latam in Latin America. Mr Murdoch had planned to float it in New York but he has put that on hold due to volatile market conditions. He sees satellite as the global media platform of the future. He believes it will prove as good as cable or broadband phone lines for delivering television images and accessing the internet.

What is DirecTV?
The apple of Mr Murdoch's eye. For the last decade he has wanted to replicate his BSkyB success in America. Like BSkyB, DirecTV operates its own network of TV stations and acts as a "shop window" for other channels. It beams programmes to nearly 10m subscribers and could give Sky Global the US presence that allows it to live up to its name. It is part of the Hughes Electronics empire, which is in turn owned by car giant General Motors.

How are the companies joining together?
It's a complicated "reverse" takeover, which involves Mr Murdoch transferring his Sky Global companies into Hughes Electronics, leaving News Corporation as a 35% shareholder. However, Hughes shareholders will slowly sell off their holdings, leaving News Corp as the dominant company in a group that will be renamed Sky Global Networks.

What happens if Mr Murdoch doesn't pull off the deal?
News Corp's shares will be summarily savaged by the stock markets in Australia and the US, where they are listed, and Mr Murdoch will turn to another target. The most likely is EchoStar, which has 4.3m subscribers and is valued at around £15bn. Analysts are excited by the idea of a Sky Global containing DirecTV, but will not take kindly to a global satellite broadcaster without a US presence.

What are Mr Murdoch's other options?
News Corp insiders have said they will float Sky Global anyway. This new-look Sky Global would be nothing more than a dolled-up BSkyB and Star TV, and the volatile markets will almost certainly give it short shrift. The consequences of this option underline the importance of the DirecTV deal.

Any impact on BSkyB?
BSkyB is 37%-owned by News Corporation, and chief executive Tony Ball has said it will retain its London listing no matter what happens. The most important event in BSkyB's near future is Vivendi Universal's handling of its 22% stake in the company. The French media giant must offload its £4bn holding due to a competition watchdog ruling, and this is weighing down BSkyB's share price as well as confidence in Sky Global.
