webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week twenty-seven

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week twenty-seven
fields.standfirst: Come with us as we squander the Blue Square millions
fields.trailText:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £175.54
Sean Ingle = £34.82
Paul MacInnes = £30.01
The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £19.08
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £175.54
Sean Ingle = £34.82
Paul MacInnes = £30.01
The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £19.08

Scott Murray: Manchester City v Southampton - James Beattie to score first goal £5 @ 13/2

Mistakes in the bookies. We've all made them. We've all convinced ourselves to bet on one horse before changing our minds at the last minute. And we've all seen our original selection romp home by ten lengths, while the nag whose name we frantically scribbled on our slip just before the off stops awhile to graze and, perchance, to urinate.

So if Dundee are beating St Johnstone at half-time (11/4), I am going to regret this.

But James Beattie has scored the first goal in nine of the 26 matches he's played in this season. Which is just under one in three. The price for him doing so against City's slack defence is nearly sevens.

Why do I already rue the day?

Sean Ingle: £10 treble - Celta Vigo v Real Oviedo: Celta to win @ 4/7; Stockport v Wimbledon: Wimbledon to win @ 11/8; Bristol City v Oxford: Bristol City to win @ 1/3

It's all well and good scanning foreign leagues looking for 4-1 single bets, but when they fail week after heartbreaking week, it's hard to take. So to welcome our new betting analyst The Camel on board, I've decided to go for a "value treble".

Is this a contradiction in terms? Probably. But I do think the bets I've picked would come off more than one time in five, which is what the odds of 3.95-1 would suggest.

Celta Vigo, despite their lowly position in the Primera Division, are unbeaten in four matches and have only lost once at home all season. Meanwhile their opponents, Real Oviedo, are gunning for the most hapless away record in Primera Divison history: so far their record reads played 11, drawn 1, lost 10. So you would expect Celta to come through.

The same goes for Wimbledon, who have won eight times away all season - the fifth-best record in the First Division - and still have an outside chance of a play-off place. I'd back them more often that not to beat Stockport, who have won at home only three times all season and lie 20th in the First Division.

Finally, Bristol City have won their last five at Ashton Gate, while Oxford haven't picked up a point on their travels since early November. And while the odds of 1/3 aren't exactly profligate, I think they are fair.

The Prince of Punts: Parma to beat AC Milan £5 @ 11/4

"It's difficult to know what we can do, but changes certainly need to be made. We must now prepare for the arrival of Parma. This will be a tough match, because they are playing well this season."

Not the words of the Prince of Punts, although with such a sophisticated analysis they could be, but those of Franco Baresi, former AC Milan legend and World Cup final limper. Baresi knows that the mighty Milan are in troubled waters right now, in 7th position and 12 points behind third-placed Lazio. They got pumped by Juve last week, and only scraped a draw with Bologna at home the Sunday previous.

Parma meanwhile are on a (ham) roll. They've only lost once in their last seven matches - to Roma - and put five past Perugia last week. Perugia, incidentally, also beat Milan 2-1 at home earlier this season. So that means Parma should win 10-5. Quite a comprehensive margin, I'm sure you'll agree.

Martin Lawson of the Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective: Derby to draw with Tottenham - £5 @ 9/4

I was tempted by the 5/1 offered on a West Ham win at Highbury, but Arsenal are bound to be a little tighter this week, so turned my attentions to Leicester. The Foxes might have been worth a shot to beat the surely-tired-by-now Liverpool at home. However, a price of 13/8 isn't that generous, so I settled on Derby's home tie with Tottenham.

Much as I'd love to see the Spurs notch up an amazing third-consecutive away win, I am dissuaded by the fact that Derby haven't been beaten at home in the Premiership since Manchester United scored three in November. I'll take my chances on the 9/4 price for a draw. The winnings won't pay off the debts, but the true glory is in taking money off the bookie. Blue Square, hand it over!

webTitle: The main findings of the inquiry

fields.headline: The main findings of the inquiry
fields.trailText: The main findings of the inquiry:
fields.body:
The main findings of the inquiry:

 Health trust should carry out an urgent review of lead roles in relation to child protection cases
 Clear and rapid channels of communication should be set up between hospital staff, GPs and health visitors for children at risk
 Social work staff in positions of responsibility should have adequate training and experience
 Social workers should be trained in risk assessment, decision making and legal processes
 Child protection committee should have a formal stage of initial referral discussion to ensure background information is effectively shared
 An audit of child protection processes across Scotland should be carried out to look at consistency and quality of practice.

webTitle: Inquiry finds death of murdered girl 'could have been prevented'

fields.headline: Inquiry finds death of murdered girl 'could have been prevented'
fields.trailText: Social workers and health professionals failed to recognise the risks that led to the murder of a three-year-old Dumfries girl, an independent inquiry has found. David Mitchell reports
fields.body:
Social workers and health professionals failed to recognise the risks that led to the murder of a three-year-old Dumfries girl, an independent inquiry has found.

Kennedy McFarlane died from brain and spinal injuries on 17 May last year after a blow from her mother's boyfriend sent her crashing into the leg of a bed. Last November Thomas Duncan, 33, was sentenced to life for the murder at the high court in Edinburgh.

An inquiry by consultant paediatrician Helen Hammond, a leading child protection expert, concluded that although Kennedy's death could not have been predicted, it could have been prevented.

Dr Hammond said: "I do not believe that anyone could have predicted the sudden and violent death which occurred. However, a number of opportunities to identify the extent of the risks to Kennedy and for effective intervention had arisen as the case unfolded."

Concern was first raised in January last year, when social workers received a referral from local playgroup staff, who noted a marked decline in Kennedy's physical appearance and her mother's very negative attitude towards her bedwetting. A family social worker visited the family but no formal assessment was carried out.

Early last March, Kennedy was admitted to hospital with serious eye injuries. A referral was passed to the social work team manager but he did not think it was necessarily a child protection case and no formal assessment was begun.

Later that month, playgroup staff again voiced their concerns about bruising to Kennedy's face, back pain and her general wellbeing but no formal investigation was initiated.

Then in April, Kennedy was again admitted to hospital with bruising, ataxia and drug ingestion. A child protection referral form was started by the paediatric social worker but not typed up until after Kennedy's death.

After Kennedy was discharged from hospital on 5 May, there was no further social work or health contact. Social workers had begun to arrange a case conference but Kennedy had already died before this could take place.

"By the time of her discharge, despite the repeated concerns, referrals and admissions, a formal child protection investigation had not been triggered and no-one had put all the pieces of the puzzle together creating a total picture of escalating harm within the context of a family in need," said Dr Hammond.

"I have no doubt that if a joint investigation into all the circumstances around this little girl from the end of 1999 to early May had been instituted there would have been enough evidence already available to satisfy a sheriff of the need to protect her in a place of safety whilst a risk assessment was completed."

Director of social services Keith Makin said the inquiry's recommendations had been taken fully on board.

"No child protection system is 100% protective as they rely at some point on the judgment of members of staff. We have made some mistakes, we want to learn from them and we never want this to happen again. Everybody can be absolutely assured that we are hiding nothing and digging into every corner of activity to make sure that we are safe."

Mr Makin confirmed that disciplinary action was being brought against staff at management and practitioner level as a result of the inquiry but refused to identify them or say what numbers were involved. One person had been moved to a post where they were not making "operational decisions".

In a joint statement, Dumfries & Galloway council, the local NHS trust and local child protection committee said all agencies accepted the inquiry's recommendations and fully acknowledged the child protection framework did not operate effectively to protect Kennedy.

Janet Birks, chairman of the child protection committee, said: "The agencies involved have already done a lot of work to put the recommendations in place. It is the role of the child protection committee to monitor that work and we take that responsibility very seriously."

fields.headline: Pass notes: Shakespeare's drug habit
fields.standfirst: Was the Bard a cocaine user?
fields.trailText:
Name, age, occupation, all that stuff:
I think we can assume we all know who we're talking about here. But a startling new fact about him has come to light: Will may have had a secret love of charlie.
fields.body:
Name, age, occupation, all that stuff:
I think we can assume we all know who we're talking about here. But a startling new fact about him has come to light: Will may have had a secret love of charlie.

Oh, that one about him being gay is decades old.
Not that one. A really strange and sinister new fact.

Surely you don't mean he was a spy/Christopher Marlowe/Belgian (delete according to whichever underpaid literary scholar is trying to garner free publicity for their next book)?
No, no, no. It turns out that the bard may have been a secret drug-taker.

Who says?
Researchers analysing fragments of pipes in the collection of the Shakespeare Birthplace Trust, found traces of cocaine, cannabis and a hallucinogen derived from nutmeg.

I hope this theory isn't going to go the way of the one that said the bard's plays were really written by Richard Whiteley, or whoever it was.
Well, let's say they're not crack pipes, exactly - just pipes. And we can't be certain they belonged to Shakespeare, so we can't be sure Will spent his Saturday nights staggering round Stratford or Southwark trying to score nutmeg. But consider all the clues in the plays and the sonnets!

Such as?
The "noted weed" and "compounds strange" in Sonnet 76, for a start. And anyone who says they refer to clothes and odd grammatical constructions is just being a spoilsport, frankly.

And the whole of A Midsummer Night's Dream.
Yes. And Othello's line: "O thou weed who art so lovely fair and smell'st so sweet that the senses ache at thee." And the bit in the Taming of the Shrew where someone calls someone else a "crack-hemp". And...

I get the picture. Next you'll be telling me that Coleridge took opium.
No, no, no. All that stuff about Xanadu was based on a package holiday he took at Center Parcs. Why do you always have to look for a negative interpretation of the facts?

webTitle: Suspension of talks brings Hollywood strike closer

fields.headline: Suspension of talks brings Hollywood strike closer
fields.trailText: The Hollywood writers' strike has moved a step closer after talks between writers and studios broke down last night
fields.body:
The much-feared Hollywood strike is still on after talks between writers and studios broke down last night.

Variety reports that, although both sides tried to dampen fears of a strike in the summer, there are still massive gaps on financial issues, which include demands for increased residuals for video and DVD. There is also no date set for the resumption of negotiations.

"While the suspension of these talks will not inevitably lead to a strike, we are deeply concerned. No one is anxious to strike," said John Wells of the Writers Guild of America West.

Nick Counter, president of the Alliance of Motion Pictures and Television Producers said: "We are so far apart on the economics that there was no way to bridge the gap."

The collapse of the talks after six weeks will intensify fears that the Writers Guild will strike when its contract expires (May 2) and that the Screen Actors Guild will follow when its contract ends on June 30.

 The Writers Guild website reports on the suspension of the talks.

 The Alliance of Motion Pictures and Television Producers website has a different view on the suspension.

webTitle: Why we fell out  of love with Waterstone's

fields.headline: Books were us
fields.standfirst: It was a new kind of bookshop - and it seduced Britain into a new love affair with books. But when the browser's paradise ballooned into an empire, it all started to go horribly wrong.  Stephen Moss  on the rise and fall of Waterstone's
fields.trailText: It was a new kind of bookshop - and it seduced Britain into a new love affair with books. But when the browser's paradise ballooned into an empire, it all started to go horribly wrong. Stephen Moss on the rise and fall of Waterstone's
fields.body:
At last week's British Book Awards there were two targets for compere Tony Hawks's scabrous wit: Anthea Turner and Waterstone's. Anthea Turner, whose autobiography was the dodo of 2000, had sensibly given the evening a miss, but Waterstone's staff were out in force.

"There have been four changes of management since the start of dinner," said Hawks, who at that moment was standing a few feet away from Brian McLaughlin, successor to David Kneale as managing director of the ailing book chain, which has 220 outlets and some 20% of the UK book market. Kneale, who was sacked earlier this month, had become the bete noire of publishers with a series of measures intended to put the squeeze on Waterstone's suppliers: increasing the store's take on each book sold; lengthening credit terms; even trying to make publishers pay for window displays. Those may be the rules of engagement in baked bean retailing, squealed the suppliers, but books are different.

Few tears were shed when the abrupt departure of Kneale was announced. That is not strictly true: tears were shed, but they were tears of joy. Hawks said at the book awards that small publishers had asked for the date of Kneale's sacking to be declared a national holiday. That got a huge cheer from the publishers and booksellers massed in the Hilton's ballroom. Waterstone's staffers, meanwhile, slumped a little further in their chairs.

What gives this everyday story of corporate intrigue a deeper resonance is the cultural status of Waterstone's: it's the bookshop that made Britain enjoy books again. When the charismatic entrepreneur Tim Waterstone launched the company in 1982 with his first store in Old Brompton Road, London, it was revolutionary - large, well-designed, well-stocked shops run by people who loved books. One former executive explains what defined the Waterstone's ethos: "Liberality, shared enthusiasm, shared passion, generosity." It was a potent combination that left the opposition for dead and led to a rapid expansion of the chain during the 80s.

Waterstone's was an unlikely success story of the Thatcherite boom years: yuppies, it seemed, had an abiding interest in the more esoteric corners of modern literature. Waterstone's opened more than 80 stores in eight years, employing managers (often young graduates) who were allowed to promote the books they favoured. The shops opened long hours, offered their own recommendations, prided themselves on generating excitement through author events, and made good books enjoyable and accessible. Waterstone's transformed bookselling, and the voluble, jug-eared founder of the chain was happy to claim the credit. "The whole Waterstone's thesis was built on me," he insisted. "We ordered heavily, piled them high, and publishers backed us with extended credit. We jettisoned the received wisdom of bookselling, and proved that stockholding bookshops really can work financially."

It all seemed too good to be true, and it was. The 80s were boom and bust. By the end of the decade, expansion had left the chain deeply in debt and in need of a saviour. WH Smith, which ironically had sacked Waterstone in 1981 and prompted him to go it alone, stepped in: it bought the chain for £49m, £10m of which went to the founder.

In retrospect, the problems of static sales, falling profits and low staff morale which have beset Waterstone's in the past two years had their origins in that deal. Waterstone's loyalists saw the move as a betrayal: they were the vanguard of the movement to shake up British bookselling, yet here was their general selling out to fusty old Smith's. Waterstone's was henceforth deprived of its freedom of operation, and its entrepreneurial spirit was gradually eroded.

Tim Waterstone, who had never lost his proprietarial interest in the business, was outraged and countered with a bid for Smith's, saying: "I just know I can pull Smith's back within six months. I know I can Waterstone it." He had turned himself into a verb, and everyone knew what it meant: huge stock, pleasant shops, good locations, knowledgeable managers, and relaxed book lovers idly thumbing through slim volumes of poetry. Waterstone returned as chairman of the group, apparently happy with a hands-off role and extolling the virtues of the chief executive, Alan Giles. But the relationship quickly turned sour. Waterstone made it clear that he felt the stores were being dumbed down and the brand diluted as the chain cut stocks, reduced store managers' independence and sought to concentrate on bigger-selling titles in the face of competition from new chains such as Borders. By the middle of last year, he had lost patience with Giles and Kneale, and said he wanted to buy the business back.

Kneale had been an ineffective defender of his managerial revolution at Waterstone's, and was roughed up by Jeremy Paxman on Newsnight when small publishers complained to the office of fair trading about their reduced margins. This was at a time when Waterstone's managers were in open revolt over the sacking of Robert Topping, manager of its Deansgate store in Manchester, for refusing to accept Kneale's instructions to accept centralised buying.

Topping became a cause célèbre : he had been with Waterstone's since 1983 and represented its golden age, when every store had a distinct identity and buying was devolved to each manager. Experienced, articulate and be sotted with books, Topping's philosophy was widely quoted: "Any bookshop can sell the fourth Harry Potter. It's the bookshop which sells the first Harry Potter that matters." He appealed against his dismissal; there were pickets outside the Deansgate store, and the press rounded on his allegedly dictatorial boss. A decade of positive public relations for Waterstone's went out of the window.

Topping, who started at the Old Brompton Road store, had witnessed the changes at Waterstone's with growing disquiet. "There was a gradual dilution of the original energy, vision and belief in books," he says, "a bit-by-bit replacement by a new approach, from allegedly professional management, which has resulted in lower sales and less profitability. It was a gradual process starting with the acquisition by Smith's. That was the beginning of a managerial culture with an emphasis on selecting managers with managerial, rather than bookselling, skills. To make a career with the company, you had to get out of books and move into the office."

Topping, who now runs the Pan Bookshop in Fulham Road, London, says Tim Waterstone must return to breathe new life into the chain he created. "Back in 1982, he had the foresight to create what was in effect a 21st-century company - a company based on the idea of empowering the staff. He was way ahead of his time. Waterstone's needs him to restore that original vision."

Others are less sure: a straw poll at the book awards suggested that the fact he had never quite been able to let go had not helped the chain over the past decade, and one former senior colleague wondered whether, if he returned, he would be able to undertake the bout of store closures that will be necessary.

The chain has battened down the hatches in the face of the current storms. Small publishers may have been premature in their celebrations of Kneale's sacking, because McLaughlin is promising to be even tougher than his predecessor, ordering managers to sharpen their "stock turn".

In other words, books that aren't selling should be returned to publishers, and stores should promote what sells. McLaughlin wants a chain that caters for buyers rather than browsers, but critics say that further undermines the Waterstone's ethos. "It will damage their reputation and business in the long term," poetry publisher Hamish Ironside told the Bookseller magazine.

The flagship store near Piccadilly Circus, opened in a blare of publicity 18 months ago, symbolises many of the things that have gone wrong.Despite its size, there is no buzz about the place. It doesn't even seem to be very busy. As at the V&A, the cafe appears more successful than the institution it is meant to support.

The immediate question is whether Tim Waterstone can manoeuvre himself back to centre stage. "I won't give up. I won't let this die," he said at the time of his battle with Smith's in 1997. "If you start something, you must finish it." That resolve led to his second coming. A third coming really would be something.

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: Quick bites | Cheapskate
fields.body:
Quick bites... Where to eat out in 15 minutes

Bradley's, 63 Ledbury Road, London W11. Tel 020-7727 1121

Well, yes, you can actually eat here. There are two tables in the window for the coffee and croissant/pain au chocolat merchants in the morning, and superior sarnies, but the real point about Bradley's is their fabulous prepared dishes - carrot and rocket soup, frittata with pancetta and goats' cheese, lasagna with eggplant and courgette, bitter-sweet chocolate cake, lemon polenta cake, rhubarb fruit compote. They also sell some of the raw materials. All very clean, nouvelle vague Notting Hill chic.

Cheapskate... Where to eat out for under £15

The Mandola, 139-141 Westbourne Grove, W11. Tel: 020-7229 4734

Every neighbourhood should have a Sudanese restaurant as the food is much more interesting and varied than some other highly touted national nosh. It sort of sits happily between the lightness and spice of North Africa and the greater heft of Ottoman and Turkish food, what with salata aswad (a splendid aubergine goo), salata daqua (a salad of white cabbage in peanut sauce), chicken halla in a potent tomato sauce, and date mousse.

The interior bounces with colour, toned down by subtle lighting at night. Service can be seductively languid. Very popular. Booking essential.

webTitle: G2: The curious story of the rabbi and the popstar

fields.headline: Family values
fields.standfirst:
They make an odd pair: the world's strangest pop star and a rabbi who once outraged the Jewish community with a book called Kosher Sex. But now the two have joined forces to tell us how to get closer to our children. Can they be serious, asks Hadley Freeman

Talk about it
fields.trailText: They make an odd pair: the world's strangest pop star and a rabbi who once outraged the Jewish community with a book called Kosher Sex. But now the two have joined forces to tell us how to get closer to our children. Can they be serious, asks Hadley Freeman
fields.body:
Parenting, they say, is the new rock'n'roll, and next week we will be treated to some improbable evidence for the claim. On Tuesday night Michael Jackson will appear before a packed Oxford Union to discuss his newest project: a charity aimed at "bringing parents closer to their children". The following evening the entertainer and philanthropist will appear at a star-studded tribute show at the Hammersmith Apollo in London, proceeds from which will go to the charity, Heal the Kids.

If the idea of a man once very publicly accused of abusing a teenage boy launching himself as an authority on parenting seems bewildering, the aims of Jackson's new charity remain distinctly hazy. According to a brief statement on his fan club website, "the aim of Heal the Kids is to encourage adults to reprioritise children, trusting that, by bringing our children from the periphery of our attention to the centre of our daily consciousness, we can imbue them with the love and devotion which they so badly need and break the cycle of neglect."

The statement elaborates briefly that "Major studies show that children who experience no tactility, no tenderness or hugging in their formative years, bear emotional scars that will not heal later in life. However, parents nowadays have often been replaced by television, computers, and home video games."

The charity is not short of heavyweight backing. Among its listed board members are former Israeli prime minister Shimon Peres, Nobel laureate Elie Wiesel, and Denise Rich, the Democrat socialite at the centre of the Clinton cash-for-pardons row. No one knows precisely how Jackson plans to pursue his lofty goal of re-enthusing the world's parents about their progeny, but we know that he is very serious about it: despite breaking his foot in a fall at his Neverland ranch this week he insisted he would honour his Oxford engagement. "The message of Heal the Kids is far too important to me to allow a broken foot to keep me from this commitment," he declared.

Jackson's partner in parental proselytising is Shmuley Boteach, the rabbi best known for writing a bestselling book encouraging Jews to have more sex. He and Jackson decided to launch Heal the Kids after being introduced in September by their mutual friend, Uri Geller. ("Uri said, 'I think you'll really like Michael Jackson, I got to get the two of you together,' and I said, 'Well, if you're twisting my arm!' Ha ha ha!")

The deliciously improbable troika will be getting together on Wednesday when Geller renews his wedding vows in a traditional Jewish ceremony at which Jackson will be best man. Boteach concedes that the trio may seem unlikely, but says: "We do have a lot of common characteristics. Michael started work when he was five, Uri was a big celebrity in his early 20s, and me, I was a rabbi at Oxford at the age of 21. Also, we got a lot in common in that we're all misunderstood."

First, however, there is the small business of promoting Boteach and Geller's latest joint venture, a book with the unsurpassably bargain-basket-friendly title of Confessions of a Rabbi and a Psychic. In the best tradition of the epistolary novel, it consists of a series of letters between Boteach and Geller as they help each other to come to terms with Personal Growth and What it's All About ("Did you feel your dog's warm breath and cold nose against you that day?" the Rabbi asks his friend, "... Perhaps you tapped into a higher reality.")

We meet in his hotel room in Piccadilly, London. He is running a little late as he is having difficulties with his caterers. He is younger and shorter than one would expect, and his American twang booms off the marble walls. Five copies of his and Geller's book rest tidily above the minibar.

Rabbi Boteach was very much the golden boy of rabbinical society at Oxford. However, after the publication of Kosher Sex - and its serialisation in Playboy - he was publicly reproached by the president of the United Synagogues and was forced to resign from the synagogue in Willesden where he preached. On top of all this, L'Chaim, a Jewish society at Oxford University of which Boteach was president, was embroiled in controversy when it was reported in the national press that some of the funds from donors had gone towards Boteach's second home in London ("This is a totally normal process in the United States," he insists. "And why should I have to pay for another home?")

Since then, he has moved back to the US with his wife and seven children and is writing books with Geller and Jackson. Once the great young hope of the Jewish community, he now seems to be banished to his bizarre celebrity sub-sect. Unlike many friends of celebrities, Boteach is absolutely delighted to talk about "my friend, Michael Jackson". "When he's in New York, we see each other or talk on the phone almost every day," he says, reclining in his armchair. "We go to kosher restaurants together, we go shopping for our kids' clothes together, sometimes after hours..." The Boteach family recently stayed at Jackson's ranch to celebrate Jackson's birthday. They had cake and everyone wore little paper hats. The two men have written a book about how to rediscover your inner child. It will be published in December.

"Michael really is a very traditional guy," he barks. "He lived at home until he was 27 years old because he had the traditional belief that you live at home until you're married, which is cool! I like people with traditional values. His daughter has gorgeous little dresses, his son is dressed like a real little gentleman. It's just beautiful, I tell you." And what are their names? "Prince and Paris," he replies hurriedly, taking another puff on a fat cigar.

Jackson is not an obvious candidate to become a parenting authority. His two children - born by a dermatology nurse from whom he is now divorced - are cared for by a battalion of more than a dozen nurses. Then there was the small matter of the 13-year-old boy who claimed in 1993 to have been sexually abused by the singer - only for his parents to drop the charges after allegedly receiving a payment of $26m (£18.5m) from Jackson. Boteach, however, is dismissive of suggestions that his new friend's relationships with children have been anything other than wholesome.

"Why would anyone believe those charges?" He answers his own question before I can try: "For two reasons: Michael settled. He fought the case for four months, but then his lawyers said, 'Forget it, man, you don't have a chance.' He had no choice. Two, they said anyone who spends that amount of time with kids has to be sick. Well, that's not an indictment of Michael Jackson, that's an indictment of our society!"

British parenting groups and experts have so far been decidely guarded about Jackson and Boteach's new venture. "You couldn't say that the aims are anything other than laudable," says Barry Mason, director of the Institute of Family Therapy, "but I don't notice any mention of any ethical guidelines, which is absolutely vital for any organisation working with children. If you're working with children and if you're promoting ideas about working with children you must be seen to have clear ethical guidelines. One of the most important things for this kind of organisation is to establish your credibility, and that depends on your record in the past. For any organisation that is setting itself up, it needs to convince people that it is credible."

Boteach, meanwhile, is confident that the public perception of Jackson will not be an impediment to their new venture. "And anyway, look at how public perception changes - just look at Bill Clinton!" The rabbi gives equally short shrift to cynical suggestions that his collaboration with Jackson is only the latest of a long line of publicity-courting stunts. "No. No. Well, sure, publicity is nice, and at first Michael Jackson was like this big pop star, but now we're just intimate friends. No one knew of our friendship for six months. And anyway," he says smiling, taking the cigar out of his mouth. "I've got plenty of other celebrity friends."

 Additional reporting by Esther Addley.

He had no choice. Two, they said anyone who spends that amount of time with kids has to be sick. Well, that's not an indictment of Michael Jackson, that's an indictment of our society!" British parenting groups and experts have so far been decidely guarded about Jackson and Boteach's new venture. "You couldn't say that the aims are anything other than laudable," says Barry Mason, director of the Institute of Family Therapy, "but I don't notice any mention of any ethical guidelines, which is absolutely vital for any organisation working with children. If you're working with children and if you're promoting ideas about working with children you must be seen to have clear ethical guidelines. One of the most important things for this kind of organisation is to establish your credibility, and that depends on your record in the past. For any organisation that is setting itself up, it needs to convince people that it is credible." Boteach, meanwhile, is confident that the public perception of Jackson will not be an impediment to their new venture. "And anyway, look at how public perception changes - just look at Bill Clinton!" The rabbi gives equally short shrift to cynical suggestions that his collaboration with Jackson is only the latest of a long line of publicity-courting stunts. "No. No. Well, sure, publicity is nice, and at first Michael Jackson was like this big pop star, but now we're just intimate friends. No one knew of our friendship for six months. And anyway," he says smiling, taking the cigar out of his mouth. "I've got plenty of other celebrity friends."  Additional reporting by Esther Addley. Talk What do you think? fields.headline: Shortcuts
fields.trailText: Overexposed | Overheard | Oversubscribed
fields.body:
Wonky skirts
Never mind Ant 'n' Dec and their Wonkey Donkey (and if you don't know what I'm referring to, get a life and start watching Saturday morning TV, for goodness sake); the real wonkiness to which we should all aspire is more of a sartorial one. A wonky skirt, to use the scientific definition, notable for the inexplicable extra long pleat hanging down one side against the wearer's leg.

At London fashion week, the wonky skirt became not so much a leitmotif as a repeated-ad-nauseam motif. It made its wonky little appearance in the shows by Scott Henshall, Hamish Morrow, Maria Grachvogel, Boyd and Julien Macdonald, to name but a few. Maria Chen took this asymmetry mania to unnecessary extremes with her wonky pedal pushers, which must be the worst of all possible worlds. The true indicator of what we will all be wearing by next week, Top Shop is fit to burst with wonky skirts.

Whereas your garden variety fishtail (extended pleat hanging at the back of the skirt) makes you look like you have a sexy little wiggle, this fishtail-to-the-side malarkey makes you appear to have a wonky walk.

Designers, darlings, take note: making wonky skirts does not make you look like cutting-edge fashion students, nor is it particularly original. Learn to sew your hems properly, there's good lads.

Overheard

"Mint"
As minty green is one of The Colours of the Season, the word has become yet another fashion adjective for something cool or really jolly good. For example: "Your polka-dot ankle socks and gold stilettos are totally mint, man!"

Oversubscribed

The Cesar Philip Treacy Collection
We all know what happens when the ridiculous meets the sublime: you get Craig David, the bobble-haired pop star with the gorgeous voice. But what about when the extravagant meets the downright silly? You get Philip Treacy joining forces with a dogfood company, that's what.

Treacy, hat designer to the rich and extroverted, has teamed up with Cesar dogfood to create one couture range (£90-£150) and one pret-a-porter collection (£54-£64) of ponyskin and goldleaf accessories for dogs, inspired by Treacy's own beloved Mr Pig.

This unusual idea reflects, the press release says, "Cesar's claim to have a unique understanding of small dogs". Unique does not begin to describe it. And the fact is, this little marriage has warmed my heart. Think how proudly Fifi will strut through Kensington Gardens with a Philip Treacy collar round her neck, and you with a Philip Treacy hat. The label in one's hat should always match the label on one's dog's accessories, as I've always said.

webTitle: Warm welcome for hot pants in a cool climate

fields.headline: Warm welcome for hot pants in a cool climate
fields.trailText: Alessandro dell'Acqua has a penchant for hotpants. His Milan catwalk shows are seldom without a pair - even when, like yesterday, the presentation is supposedly to showcase winter clothes. However, they did at least come in wool.
fields.body:
Alessandro dell'Acqua has a penchant for hotpants. His Milan catwalk shows are seldom without a pair - even when, like yesterday, the presentation is supposedly to showcase winter clothes. However, they did at least come in wool.

At 37 years old and with a label of five years standing, dell 'Acqua is a relative newcomer to the Milan fashion scene. He is little known in Britain, but popular in Italy and in the US, where Winona Ryder and Gwyneth Paltrow are fans of his designs, his sharp style having earned him comparisons to the Austrian born, New York based Helmut Lang.

His profile has recently been raised by the enthusiasm for his designs of the semi-retired model Helena Christiansen, who has featured in dell'Acqua's advertising campaigns and last season took a turn on his catwalk.

Many of the clothes on display yesterday were aimed at a winter spent indoors. Alongside the hotpants came endless whirls of semi-transparent chiffon, a fabric that is hardly the mainstay of most winter wardrobes. But worn over vest tops and tucked into leather pencil skirts, chiffon blouses managed to look fairly convincing for the season; meanwhile, wispy chiffon ballerina wrap skirts were warmed up with snug ribbed sweaters.

Even more practical were a soft cream wool trousersuit, and a short, belted camel trench coat featuring a sprinkling of pearls along each side seam.

Once he had reassured his customers that he was not going to let them freeze next autumn, the designer indulged in a series of layered chiffon dresses that were the highlight of the show.

Some colours had an autumnal flavour: a clinging slip of glossy bronze sequins smouldered under floaty black chiffon, while an asymmetric chiffon dress, tied at one shoulder, featured burnt orange worn over ivory. There were bright ice cream colours too, with a flippy dress in bubblegum pink, and a mint green batwing knit top teamed with matching chiffon wrapskirt.

The flower corsage, currently fashion's hippest accessory, also made an appearance: an overblown "rose" made from brown and white pheasant feathers was pinned at the hip of a coffee tinted chiffon dress.

fields.headline: Obituary: Arturo Uslar Pietri
fields.standfirst: Writer who was Venezuela's national conscience
fields.trailText: The death of Arturo Uslar Pietri, at the age of 94, has deprived the Spanish-speaking world of one of its leading intellectuals, and his native Venezuela of a man who had come to be regarded as the nation's conscience.
fields.body:
The death of Arturo Uslar Pietri, at the age of 94, has deprived the Spanish-speaking world of one of its leading intellectuals, and his native Venezuela of a man who had come to be regarded as the nation's conscience.

Government minister, journalist, senator, prizewinning novelist - but, above all, an acute and lucid commentator on history, culture and current affairs - Uslar Pietri was possibly the best president Venezuela never had. He stood for the office in 1963, but despite winning an impressive 39% of the vote in the capital, Caracas, only managed to poll 16% nationwide.

"I come from a family that was very much involved with history, and I've always been enormously interested in my country," he said in one of his last interviews. His ancestors included two presidents and an aide-de-camp to independence hero Simon Bolívar.

A dedicated - and published - writer since his early teens, Uslar obtained a doctorate in political science in 1929. With the death of dictator Juan Vicente Gómez in 1935, he began to combine journalism with political activism. But he was soon called on to play a series of important roles in the post-Gómez governments of generals Eleázar López Contreras and Isaías Medina Angarita, and, over the next few years, occupied successively the posts of minister of education, secretary of the presidency, finance minister and interior minister.

It was while holding the education portfolio that Uslar wrote the article whose title was to become his most famous quote. Entitled Sowing the Oil, the piece outlined, with uncanny prescience, the dangers of over-reliance on the commodity that was already beginning to transform his country from a rural backwater into "Saudi Venezuela".

"His was always a warning voice," said the current defence minister, José Vicente Rangel. "If he had been listened to, we'd have avoided many failures." A veteran journalist, Rangel was a contributor to the newspaper El Nacional, which Uslar Pietri edited from 1969-74.

The coup that ousted Medina Angarita in 1945 marked the end of Arturo Uslar Pietri's days in government. For much of the rest of the century, Venezuela was dominated by Acción Democrática (AD), the party behind the coup - and thus no friend of Uslar's. His first move was to New York, where he taught at Columbia University and wrote fiction and essays. "October 18 [1945]," he remarked, "took me out of politics, and returned me to what I am - a writer." But Uslar was never able to separate the two for long.

His most famous literary works include the historical novel Las Lanzas Coloradas (Red Lances), whose subject is the military campaigns of Bolívar. He also wrote poetry, short stories and plays. In 1990, he was awarded Spain's prestigious Principe de Asturias prize in recognition of his role as one of the founders of modern Latin American literature.

Several times nominated for the Nobel prize, Uslar never won; partly, he believed, because of the government's lack of interest in his candidacy. Had he confined himself to writing historical novels, perhaps they would have forgotten his political past. But, still torn between politics and writing, Uslar stood for the senate in 1959, on the leftist URD (Democratic Republican Union) ticket. It was not until 1973 that he gave up party politics for good.

He remained, however, a constant reference point among those concerned about the course the nation was taking. In 1989, Venezuela - already in economic and social decline - was shaken by widespread riots, which were bloodily suppressed by the army and national guard. The following year Uslar Pietri joined the so-called "group of notables" pressing for reform of the increasingly moribund political system.

In 1992, the demand for reform was more dramatically expressed in the form of two failed coups, the first led by Lt Col Hugo Chávez who, after a spell in prison, would later be elected president. Uslar, however, had little time for Chávez. "He's a man with a messianic view of himself," he declared a few months after the inauguration. "He thinks that just by being there he can solve our problems."

Venezuela, he believed, had completely lost its way. "I had hoped to grow old and die in a country beginning to have some sense of reality," he mused. "But it is crazier than ever." Chávez repaid the compliment by studiously ignoring the great man's passing.

At Uslar Pietri's funeral, however, figures from Chávez's government mingled with representatives of the discredited two-party system. Both sides had felt the lash of Uslar's tongue, but none spoke of him with anything less than reverence. He had long since acquired a stature well above the mire of politics.

Uslar's wife died in 1996. He is survived by his son, Fernando Uslar Braun.

 Arturo Uslar Pietri, politician, writer, intellectual, born May 16 1906; died February 26 2001

fields.headline: GNER pulls adverts in wake of Selby tragedy
fields.trailText: 10.45am:GNER has dropped a national advertising campaign at the 11th hour following the rail disaster, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Great North Eastern Railways has been forced to abandon a national advertising campaign at the 11th hour following the train disaster at Selby.

The campaign, promoting the company's new flat-rate pricing structure, was due to break on Monday in national and regional newspapers.

A spokesman for GNER confirmed the move and said it had not yet been decided when the campaign would run.

GNER, which recently hired a new advertising agency, had been planning to spend £5m on a substantial brand-building campaign that could have included TV advertising.

But those plans have now been put on ice pending an investigation into the crash, which involved a GNER train.

GNER, one of the UK's biggest train operating companies, runs high-speed rail services between London, the east midlands, Yorkshire, the north-east and Scotland.

fields.headline: Murdoch's merger on verge of collapse
fields.trailText:
10.45pm: Rupert Murdoch's £49bn takeover of US satellite broadcaster DirecTV appears to be in deep trouble, writes Dan Milmo.
Feb 28: Murdoch merger delayed
Media Monkey: How long has the digger got to live?
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch's on-off takeover of US satellite broadcaster DirecTV appears to be in deep trouble.

The £49bn deal is on the verge of collapse because DirecTV owner General Motors wants more cash from Mr Murdoch's News Corporation empire, according to the online edition of the Wall Street Journal.

Although the takeover has been trumpeted as a done deal, people close to the negotiations said Mr Murdoch needs to come up with a more lucrative offer for DirecTV and its holding company Hughes Electronics, owned by US giant General Motors.

The deal is being seen as Mr Murdoch's last big flourish - but earlier this week he joked he didn't want to spend too much of the time he has remaining on earth in "useless meetings" or in "negotiations with General Motors".

Mr Murdoch, who revolutionised TV viewing in the UK with the launch of Sky 12 years ago, has made it a personal mission to launch similar services in all the most lucrative markets around the world.

He already has a foothold in China with StarTV and DirectTV - the biggest direct-to-home satellite service in the US - would have cemented access to millions of US homes.

At a New York conference this week Mr Murdoch tried to play down the significance of the deal.

Asked if DirecTV was the final piece of his global satellite vision, he said: "Hell no. There are 6 billion people in the world. There are 250 million here. Don't let's get too excited about it."

But the deal has been fraught with problems.

News Corp insiders have repeatedly scoffed at General Motors' claims that it is holding negotiations with other parties, and analysts say Mr Murdoch may try to find a cash-rich partner to sweeten the deal.

"The DirecTV takeover is too complicated. Perhaps GM wants more cash and less shares, so you could imagine News Corporation finding another partner who can offer cash, such as Vivendi Universal or even AOL Time Warner," said Marc Loneux, analyst at Commerzbank.

The "reverse" takeover involves Mr Murdoch merging his Sky Global Networks satellite TV companies into Hughes. Hughes shareholders would then exit the company over time, leaving News Corp as the major shareholder.

If the link-up falters, News Corp could turn its attention to DirecTV rival EchoStar, which has 5m satellite subscribers compared with DirecTV's 9m.

"News Corporation has already tried twice for EchoStar, and the subscriber numbers show it would not be as good as the DirecTV deal. But it still fits in with News Corporation's US Strategy," added Mr Loneux.

Mr Murdoch needs a US satellite broadcaster to ensure his Sky Global Networks company can live up to its name.

Without a US operation, Sky Global would be nothing more than BSkyB in the UK, Star TV in Asia and a few interests scattered across Europe and South America.

Analysts and chief executives at rival media groups have registered their approval of the DirecTV merger, but plans to float Sky Global without a US presence have met with outright scepticism.

"If the DirecTV deal collapses and Murdoch cannot get EchoStar, then it is clear that Sky Global is too small," said one analyst.

fields.headline: 15m witness EastEnders shooting
fields.standfirst: EastEnders: top 20 rating shows
fields.trailText:
11.45am TV overnights: More than 15m tuned in to watch Phil Mitchell's shooting on last night's EastEnders on BBC1, writes Jason Deans.
EastEnders: top 20 rating shows
fields.body:
More than 15m viewers tuned in to BBC1 to watch last night's EastEnders episode that climaxed with Phil Mitchell's shooting.

The cliffhanger instalment of the soap, which began with Mel and Steve's wedding and ended with EastEnders regulars including the newlyweds, Mark Fowler and Ian Beale potentially implicated in Phil's shooting, took 15.4m and a 58% share, according to unofficial overnights.

The interest in this special extended EastEnders from 7.40-8.20pm helped BBC1 record its best Thursday peaktime for a year.

But after all the hype, which included promotions across peaktime on BBC1 and countless press interviews and photospreads, the episode won't be going down in soap history.

Tuesday night's episode got more viewers with an audience of 15.6m and it was nothing compared with "Sharongate" in 1995 - when Grant Mitchell, played by Ross Kemp, discovered his wife had been having an affair with his brother Phil. That was watched by a colossal 25.3m viewers.

And it lagged millions behind the soap's other big cliffhangers such as Michelle Fowler telling family she is pregnant which was watched by 24.9m.

Nevertheless it was a big night for BBC1.

A Weakest Link special featuring EastEnders stars turned in the quiz show's best ever ratings.

Anne Robinson's fearsome inquisition of actors including Todd Carty, Wendy Richard and eventual celebrity Weakest Link winner Adam Woodyatt pulled in 10.7m viewers and a 44% audience share.

ITV opposition Emmerdale was beaten down to what is believed to be its worst ever rating. The ITV soap had just 7.3m and a 29% share.

Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? also suffered from 8-9pm against the second half of EastEnders.

Millionaire took 8.6m viewers and what is thought to be its lowest audience share - 33%.

At 8.20pm, Ballykissangel returned to BBC1 with a new Aussie priest and 7.7m viewers.

Ellen MacArthur: Sailing Through Hell followed at 9.10pm. The 50-minute documentary about the 24-year-old who became the fastest yachtswoman to circumnavigate the globe last month had 6m and a 25% share.

It was beaten by ITV's Holiday Airport 2, which drew 8m viewers.

But BBC1 won its third 10pm news battle on the trot, with the Ten O'Clock News pulling in 5.9m to News at Ten's 5.4m.

Overall last night, BBC1 had a 37% share of peaktime viewing from 6-10.30pm, up from 33% last Thursday.

ITV had 33.3%, down by three percentage points compared with a week ago.
fields.bodyText: More than 15m viewers tuned in to BBC1 to watch last night's EastEnders episode that climaxed with Phil Mitchell's shooting. The cliffhanger instalment of the soap, which began with Mel and Steve's wedding and ended with EastEnders regulars including the newlyweds, Mark Fowler and Ian Beale potentially implicated in Phil's shooting, took 15.4m and a 58% share, according to unofficial overnights. The interest in this special extended EastEnders from 7.40-8.20pm helped BBC1 record its best Thursday peaktime for a year. But after all the hype, which included promotions across peaktime on BBC1 and countless press interviews and photospreads, the episode won't be going down in soap history. Tuesday night's episode got more viewers with an audience of 15.6m and it was nothing compared with "Sharongate" in 1995 - when Grant Mitchell, played by Ross Kemp, discovered his wife had been having an affair with his brother Phil. That was watched by a colossal 25.3m viewers. And it lagged millions behind the soap's other big cliffhangers such as Michelle Fowler telling family she is pregnant which was watched by 24.9m. Nevertheless it was a big night for BBC1. A Weakest Link special featuring EastEnders stars turned in the quiz show's best ever ratings. Anne Robinson's fearsome inquisition of actors including Todd Carty, Wendy Richard and eventual celebrity Weakest Link winner Adam Woodyatt pulled in 10.7m viewers and a 44% audience share. ITV opposition Emmerdale was beaten down to what is believed to be its worst ever rating. The ITV soap had just 7.3m and a 29% share. Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? also suffered from 8-9pm against the second half of EastEnders. Millionaire took 8.6m viewers and what is thought to be its lowest audience share - 33%. At 8.20pm, Ballykissangel returned to BBC1 with a new Aussie priest and 7.7m viewers. Ellen MacArthur: Sailing Through Hell followed at 9.10pm. The 50-minute documentary about the 24-year-old who became the fastest yachtswoman to circumnavigate the globe last month had 6m and a 25% share. It was beaten by ITV's Holiday Airport 2, which drew 8m viewers. But BBC1 won its third 10pm news battle on the trot, with the Ten O'Clock News pulling in 5.9m to News at Ten's 5.4m. Overall last night, BBC1 had a 37% share of peaktime viewing from 6-10.30pm, up from 33% last Thursday. ITV had 33.3%, down by three percentage points compared with a week ago.

webTitle: Cruise leapfrogs Julia to go top of Forbes list

fields.headline: Cruise leapfrogs Julia to go top of Forbes list
fields.trailText: Forbes magazine puts Tom Cruise at the top of the list of the world's most powerful celebrities, ahead of Bruce Willis and Julia Roberts
fields.body:
Tom Cruise has been named the most powerful celebrity in the world by Forbes magazine.

Despite being "only" 13th on the list when it comes to pay, raking in a mere $43.2m (£29.67m), Cruise comes out on top because of so-called "star power" which includes factors such as media attention. The movie star, who recently announced that he was splitting from his wife Nicole Kidman, was on the front of 11 magazines and had 136 television or radio hits in the last year.

According to Reuters, Cruise leapfrogs Julia Roberts, last year's number one, who has dropped to 16th position.

The next most powerful film star after Cruise is Bruce Willis, who earned a remarkable $70m (£48m) in 2000, to make fifth place on the list. Between Cruise and Willis are golfer Tiger Woods, the remaining Beatles and popstar Britney Spears.

"Not only did Cruise earn much more money in 2000 than in 1999 ($27 million/£18.54m) but his media exposure increased dramatically," Forbes reports. "In 1999 Cruise only managed one cover story and around 27,000 web hits, as opposed to 139,000 hits last year."

Somewhat macabrely, some of the most lucrative names are dead celebrities from Hollywood's past, including Marilyn Monroe with $4m (£2.74m) and James Dean on $3m (£2.06m).

webTitle: Dome contents sale falls short of target

fields.headline: Dome contents sale falls short of target
fields.standfirst: Special report: Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Proceeds from the ongoing auction of Millennium Dome contents are likely to fall around £2m short of target following the last-minute withdrawal from sale of more than 1,000 items, it was revealed today.
fields.body:
Proceeds from the ongoing auction of Millennium Dome contents are likely to fall around £2m short of target following the last-minute withdrawal from sale of more than 1,000 items, it was revealed today.

Organisers had hoped that the four-day sale, which ends today, would raise around £5m. However, catalogued items, including hi-tech display screens and TV broadcasting equipment, were removed from the auction.

Dome organisers, the New Millennium Experience Company, said it was now thought the sale would raise between £2.5m and £4m.

NMEC and auctioneers Henry Butcher had included the items in the sale believing that the Legacy company would end its interest in the dome following the decision by the government to strip the company of its preferred bidder status.

But Legacy, which wants to turn the Greenwich site into a hi-tech business city, has not yet pulled out, so items it had originally requested could not go under the hammer.

The timekeepers of the millennium exhibition and the home planet zone were among items that had been excluded from the sale from the start following a request from the former NMEC chief executive, Pierre-Yves Gerbeau.

The Frenchman is bidding to keep the dome open as a visitor attraction.

The first day of the auction, on Tuesday, raised around £200,000, with a 6ft-tall plastic hamster, complete with slab of cheese, fetching £3,000.

The second day realised around £800,000. Details of yesterday's sale - which did not end until midnight, were not available today, but Mr Butcher was hoping to give a total figure for the auction tonight.

fields.headline: Charities braced for £97m water levy
fields.standfirst: The Scottish parliament is to debate new rules for water charges which have sparked 'panic' among the country's voluntary organisations. Clare Horton reports
fields.trailText: The Scottish parliament is to debate new rules for water charges which have sparked 'panic' among the country's voluntary organisations. Clare Horton reports.
fields.body:
Scottish charities have warned that new rules for water charges could cost them up to £97m over the next three years.

Umbrella group the Scottish Council for Voluntary Organisations (SCVO) says the voluntary sector in the country is "increasingly feeling panic" as the date for introducing the changes approaches.

The SCVO is demanding that the Scottish executive intervenes and forces the country's water authorities to back down on their plans.

Registered charities currently receive up to 80% relief on their water bills. From next month, however, the water authorities will be phasing out that support.

SCVO spokeswoman Lucy McTernan said: "We have been negotiating with the water industry for some time over this and thought we had reached an agreement.

"But now the industry has announced that all relief for water and sewerage charges will be removed, completely overturning what we had arranged in consultations. The net effect on the voluntary sector will be enormous."

The SCVO, which speaks for 10,000 voluntary sector organisations, calculates the change would cost its members £27m in the next financial year, doubling the following year and, because of water charge rises, totalling £97m by the end of 2003-04.

Charities are particularly concerned about the impact of the charges during the next financial year. Budgets had already been drawn up for 2001-02 - assuming the charge relief would be available - and grant making bodies have already decided how they will allocate funding next year.

Scottish National party water industry spokesman Richard Lochhead has tabled a motion to the Scottish parliament calling for the water authorities to withdraw their plans. The SCVO hopes MSPs will debate the motion next week.

"This will be a double whammy for Scotland's charities," Mr Lockhead said. "It makes a mockery of the government's stated objective of tackling social exclusion, given that the victims of this policy are the very bodies that are trying to help more vulnerable members of society."

The water authorities' plans will bring Scotland into line with England and Wales, where charities are not entitled to relief on water rates.

Ms McTernan added: "The announcement coming so late means it could not be planned or budgeted for. Now, because of the way the water industry made its announcement, we are faced with no alternative but to debate the issue in the press and the chamber of the Scottish parliament, rather than face-to-face.

"Nevertheless, charities feel quite confident that this ludicrous situation can be sorted out."

The SCVO has previously successfully campaigned against government plans to force charities to pay for checks on the criminal records of volunteers.

A spokesman for the north of Scotland water authority said every effort would be made to help charities affected as relief was phased out, including the free installation of water meters.

webTitle: One in 10 suffers knock-on harm in hospital

fields.headline: One in 10 suffers knock-on harm in hospital
fields.trailText: More than one patient in every 10 admitted to hospital for treatment will suffer some sort of harm while they are there, according to the first study of its kind in the UK.
fields.body:
More than one patient in every 10 admitted to hospital for treatment will suffer some sort of harm while they are there, according to the first study of its kind in the UK.

The toll of what are known as "adverse events", ranging from picking up a minor infection on the ward to the recent tragedies when patients have died through drugs being injected in the wrong part of the body, costs the NHS around £1bn a yearin extra treatment, says the study, published today in the British Medical Journal.

That is besides the high cost of litigation - £77m compensation was paid to patients last year - and the human cost in suffering for patients and their relatives.

Although there have been studies in the US and Australia to establish how many patients suffer unexpected harm in hospital, the exercise by Charles Vincent, professor of psychology, and colleagues in the clinical risk unit of University College London has never been undertaken before in the UK.

They found that the rate of adverse events in their pilot study of 1,014 patients in two London hospitals was 10.8%. Since some patients suffered more than one event, the percentage of medical misadventures was still higher, at 11.7%.

This is considerably higher than the 3.7% recorded by a Harvard study in the US, but lower than the Australian figure of 16.6%. The team found that half the adverse events in the UK were preventable. "I strongly suspected there was a problem of this magnitude," said Professor Vincent. "I don't think we have faced up to the scale of it or the economic consequences of it."

Prof Vincent was a member of the panel put together by the chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, which last year launched a blueprint for the NHS to report mistakes and learn from them.

The document, An Organisation With a Memory, promised confidential phone lines for medical staff to report mistakes anonymously and central databases which would reveal common and preventable mistakes.

But little appears to have happened so far, and without precise data for the rates and numbers of mistakes being made by doctors and nurses, it will be impossible to tell whether the confidential reporting system is aware of more than the tip of the iceberg.

"Reporting is not going to tell you what is going on where, and how much it is costing," Prof Vincent said.

He and his team want to carry out a large-scale study to provide a picture of the rate and cost of adverse events nationwide.

In an editorial in the BMJ, Sir George Alberti, president of the Royal College of Physicians, concurs. "Only a full-scale study can substantiate this estimate, and if the NHS is serious about learning about and reducing errors it should fund such a study," he writes.

But Prof Vincent has tried without success to get financial backing for the work, which raises questions as to how eager the NHS is to know the truth about medical error.

The mistakes that are made in hospital were "much more often an accumulation of small things rather than one big blunder, such as problems in record-keeping and delays", he said. Some were barely preventable, such as bedsores, but others could certainly have been avoided, such as infections picked up after surgery by patients who should have been given antibiotics as a preventative measure.

In his editorial, Sir George points out that there are things that can be done to prevent errors happening, once it is clear what is going on. Better surgical training is needed.

"Fewer operations and procedures during the night may also help," he says.

Drugs errors remain a problem, but Birmingham has a computer linked pharmacology system, which sends out warnings when drugs that could be dangerous in combination are prescribed.

"The introduction of such a system nationwide could prevent hundreds, indeed thousands, of errors," he writes.

There may be more mistakes made by doctors than even this study suggests, Sir George says, because not every error leads to harm to the patient. "A pilot study by the Royal College of Physicians into deaths after admission for medical emergencies suggests that some error occurred in as many as one in five cases.. These data should be interpreted cautiously, but do suggest that actual recorded adverse events are the tip of the iceberg."

fields.headline: ITV2 revives Northern Exposure
fields.trailText:
10.15am: Cult Canadian drama Northern Exposure is set to make a comeback on British TV, writes Jason Deans.

Dec 20: New focus planned for ITV2
fields.body:
Cult Canadian drama Northern Exposure is set to make a comeback on British television after ITV decided to boost the schedules of its sister station.

The little-watched ITV2 digital service has bought 110 episodes of the Universal show, which will go out from Monday at 11.50pm after the David Letterman Show.

Northern Exposure, which went out on Channel 4 in the UK during the early 1990s, starred Rob Morrow as a New York doctor sent to be the GP of a remote Alaskan town peopled by a cast of eccentrics.

ITV2 has also bought 85 episodes of 1970s sci-fi series the Incredible Hulk from Universal for transmission in the spring in a new action adventure slot.

From late March, ITV2 will get a chance to watch award-winning US animation Dr Katz on Saturdays.

The channel has acquired 81 instalments of the cartoon from US cable broadcaster Comedy Central.

In addition, ITV2 has recently bought a package of 14 movies from Columbia Tristar, including Sleepless in Seattle, Philadelphia, Last Action Hero and In the Line of Fire, to run in its 9pm Saturday night film slot from mid March.

The broadcaster has also acquired four Columbia Tristar TV shows, including 55 episodes of Tea Leoni sitcom the Naked Truth.

fields.headline: Del Boy in TV comeback
fields.trailText: 10am: The much-loved BBC comedy Only Fools and Horses is returning after five years, write Claire Cozens and Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Lock up your valuables, Del Boy is back. The much-loved British comedy Only Fools and Horses is returning to the BBC after an absence of five years.

Writer John Sullivan has already written three hour-long specials, which will go out as the centrepiece of this year's Christmas schedules.

The new shows will feature the Peckham pair living it up in exotic locations such as Barbados after they became millionaires at the end of the last series.

Mr Sullivan, who wrote all 61 original episodes, said the original stars, including David Jason and Nicholas Lyndhurst, were eager to appear in the new shows. Buster Merryfield, who played Uncle Albert, died in 1999.

The award-winning scriptwriter has been talking of reviving the hit sitcom for years but he has been busy on other projects.

In 1999 the prospect of another series was in jeopardy after Mr Sullivan clashed with the BBC over a £4m adaptation of Charles Dickens novel David Copperfield.

The row was so bad he walked out of the BBC, ending a 25-year relationship.

But Mr Sullivan's gripe was with drama chiefs who didn't like his script for Copperfield - it had been commissioned by the entertainment department who had asked him to write a humourous script with a modern slant.

Today Mr Sullivan told the Sun newspaper: "We're on. All the studio dates have been pencilled in. The stars are up for it and I have the bones of the story in place."

Only Fools and Horses has been one of the crown jewels of the BBC's comedy schedules. They will be the first new episodes since the 1996 Christmas show, which drew an audience of 24m.

Old repeats of the show have drawn in huge audiences and the sales of the videos have reached the millions.

The show ran for 15 years from 1981. By 1986 it had reached cult status and "right plonker" had become part of the nation's vocabulary.

Every episode of the 1986 autumn run challenged EastEnders and Coronation Street. By the end of the year it had overtaken the ITV soap, ranking as the third most popular programme of the year after EastEnders and Just Good Friends with an audience of 18m viewers.

webTitle: Foot and mouth spreads all over UK

fields.headline: Outbreak spreads all over UK
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The impact of foot and mouth disease reached every corner of Britain yesterday as the first cases were confirmed in Scotland and Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
The impact of foot and mouth disease reached every corner of Britain yesterday as the first cases were confirmed in Scotland and Northern Ireland.

The disease is also thought to have spread to the Republic of Ireland. A sheep dealer was arrested in County Down and troops deployed on the Irish border after police allegedly discovered 250 sheep that had been smuggled from an infected market in England.

The number of outbreaks in the UK rose to 31 after five more cases were confirmed yesterday with several more "highly suspicious" cases expected to be added overnight. Jim Scudamore, the government's chief vet, said he expected the numbers to go on increasing for another week.

The two Scottish cases were both in Dumfries - one at Netherplace farm, Lockerbie, the home of a major cattle and sheep dealer, and the other at Parkhouse Farm near Canonbie on the Duke of Buccleuch's estate. More Scottish cases are being investigated.

The case in Northern Ireland was at Meigh, South Armagh, on the border with the republic. The 20 sheep discovered with the disease had been bought in Carlisle before the outbreak was discovered. They were part of a consignment of 291 which had been issued with a certificate for immediate slaughter on their arrival in Northern Ireland. They never arrived at the slaughterhouse and a man from Banbridge, County Down, where the livestock importer lived, was arrested yesterday.

Another 250 sheep, thought to be from the same consign ment, appear to have been taken to an abattoir in the centre of the republic at County Roscommon.

Vets were trying yesterday to establish whether they were part of the Carlisle batch and police were trying to find 21 sheep unaccounted for.

The Irish deputy prime minister, Mary Harney, said: "This has the potential to do enormous damage to this country. This could stop the Celtic Tiger in its tracks. There are 47,500 people employed in this sector and it is £7bn industry, half of it in exports. It would have a catastrophic affect on our economy if we were to get it."

In the UK vets continued to try to untangle the web of trades in sheep in the two weeks before the outbreak was confirmed. The number of cases is expected to rise at the rate of six to eight a day for the next week, Mr Scudamore said. If the measures put in place by the government are working then numbers should then start to tail off.

Hundreds of potential cross infections took place in the few days before the ban on movement was introduced on February 23. So far 25,200 animals have been affected.

Lambs with foot and mouth were known to have been mixed with healthy sheep and sold in batches from markets in Hexham in Northumberland, Darlington in County Durham, Longtown in Cumbria, Welshpool in Powys and Holsworthy in Devon.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, told the cabinet yesterday that arrangements were being made for special licences that would allow British meat back into the food chain. The first could be issued on Monday.

There are also serious animal welfare problems looming, with thousands of sheep needing to be brought down from higher ground for lambing, and cattle due to be moved for calving. Mr Brown said this problem was being investigated and special arrangements would have to be made to make sure vulnerable animals were protected.

Called off

 Crufts dog show, due to start on March 8, postponed

 Forestry commission closed all forests to public

 East and West Sussex closed all footpaths

 National Trust closed almost all properties in England, Wales and Northern Ireland

 National shire horse show, due to take place at Peterborough, cancelled

 National Botanic Garden of Wales closed

 Army training stopped and helicopters grounded

 Britain's oldest horse race, the Derby, faces cancellation for only second time in its 480-year history

fields.headline: Tate appeals to football fans
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The Tate gallery has created a football-themed CD-rom featuring a very familiar voice, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
John Cavanagh, the voice of the football results, has been signed up to provide the voiceover to a football-themed product from the Tate gallery.

Mr Cavanagh has teamed up with UK artist Simon Patterson to provide the voice for a screensaver that will appear on the gallery group's website.

From May, vistors to the website or galleries will be able to buy a CD-rom of the 12-minute screensaver called Colour Match.

Colour Match features Mr Cavanagh reading the Scottish football results as hundreds of Pantone colours flow across the screen.

The CD has been designed to look like a red card and comes packaged within a foam football held inside a net bag.

This week, the Tate launched a range of paints with DIY retailer B&Q.

webTitle: Nurses head for first union action

fields.headline: Nurses head for first union action
fields.trailText: The Royal College of Nursing was last night heading for its first industrial action after staff at the John Radcliffe hospital in Oxford said overcrowding of the accident and emergency department was putting patients' lives at risk.
fields.body:
The Royal College of Nursing was last night heading for its first industrial action after staff at the John Radcliffe hospital in Oxford said overcrowding of the accident and emergency department was putting patients' lives at risk.

A union committee agreed to recommend a ballot of the 70 nurses working in the unit. Industrial action could include working to rule, a ban on overtime or refusing to treat patients in places nurses consider unsuitable.

The full RCN council is expected to support the proposal within the next 10 days. If the hospital does not move quickly to solve the problem, it could be the first to be targeted since the RCN changed its rules in 1995 to permit limited industrial action that did not affect patient care.

Patricia Marquis, the union's regional officer, said: "For several years, conditions have become more and more difficult [at John Radcliffe]. There have been increasing numbers of patients and, partly because of the nurse shortages, fewer beds."

It was common for every corridor to be full of people waiting on trolleys, but the overcrowding reached crisis proportions 10 days ago when the unit held three times the approved maximum number of patients. "This means the nurses cannot give patients the best care, or even privacy and dignity, and safety is being compromised."

Last year the nurses made a formal complaint to the trust management and a panel upheld their complaints, Ms Marquis said. But an action plan was not fully implemented and problems continued. "The nurses are at the end of their tether and now feel this ballot is their only course," Ms Marquis said.

David Highton, the hospital's chief executive, said: "I understand the frustrations of our accident and emergency staff and am deeply concerned about the difficulties they face.

"It is no great secret that the emergency care system in Oxfordshire has been very stretched recently.

"I will continue to talk to the RCN and to our own staff about how we can work together to relieve some of the pressures and improve the system as a whole."

The hospital serves more than 600,000 people in the Oxford area. A report last year on its heart unit criticised a "culture of cronyism" that left the centre in chaos. Personality clashes between doctors left the unit "on its knees" and threatened its future, the report said.
