webTitle: Americans yearn for end to crisis

fields.headline: Americans yearn for end to crisis
fields.standfirst: The latest Clinton scandal rumbles on, but people are weary of it, writes Martin Kettle
fields.trailText: The latest Clinton scandal rumbles on, but people are weary of it, writes Martin Kettle.
fields.body:
As the 15 months of the Monica Lewinsky crisis unfolded, two things became increasingly clear. The first was that the longer the argument about it continued, the more exasperated the American people became.

The second was that the more they thought about it, the more the people wanted Bill Clinton to remain as president.

Six weeks into Clinton's post-presidential crisis, the first of these two responses is already beginning to repeat itself once again. Most people have had enough. Democrats have wanted the whole issue to go away almost from day one. Now, George Bush's wing of the Republican Party, anxious to shape the headlines, shares that impatience.

The polls show that most Americans have done with the pardon scandal. The only people who haven't are the same people who got impeachment wrong too, the conservative congressional Republicans.

On Capitol Hill yesterday, one almost sensed the moment when the Marc Rich story crossed the boundary between political scandal and partisan ritual.

Though Dan Burton, the House government reform committee chairman, had earlier announced: "I know that members on both sides here don't want to spend the rest of their lives investigating Bill Clinton," it was clear from the way that Congressman Bob Barr laid into the witnesses that there was nothing the Georgia Republican would like better than to do just that.

The behaviour of the committee Democrats suggested that a line had been crossed too. Henry Waxman, the senior Democrat on the committee, made a long introductory speech that was full of denunciations of Clinton's conduct on the Rich pardon.

But then he moved into full attack mode against the Republicans, asking why their indignation was so selective. Why had the committee never raised questions about George Bush Sr's pardon of the old pro-Soviet oil crook Armand Hammer in 1989?

Or about Jeb Bush's lobbying of his father for the release of the anti-Castro terrorist Orlando Bosch? Or about who had given money to the Ronald Reagan or Bush presidential libraries, and what they had got for it?

Many on both sides have judged, one senses, that the Rich pardon and the other pardon scandals have outstayed their welcome on the political stage.

The whole matter is under legal investigation by a federal prosecutor in New York. The Burton committee in the House of Representatives and the parallel inquiry under Arlen Specter in the Senate are both aiming at the headlines rather than at any more substantial end.

Very few people are suggesting that the presidential power of pardon be removed from the constitution, for example.

No one, either, seems to want another attritional grind through Clinton's misdeeds. Though Barr may like his chance to reprise his role as congressional Republican pitbull from the impeachment crisis, the Clinton machine has been very slow to crank itself into full defence mode this time round.

John Podesta, Clinton's ex-chief of staff, clearly did not have his heart in it when he gave long hours of evidence to the Burton committee yesterday. Even Bruce Lindsey, normally the ultimate Clinton consigliere, lacked his usual combative spirit. If there's a Clinton war-room this time round, it is keeping itself well hidden.

And yet there is one big difference between this affair and the impeachment crisis. In the Lewinsky crisis, most Americans drew a line between what Clinton did in private with the gullible, star-struck intern and what he did in public as the nation's leader.

The Rich pardon, on the other hand, was an action that messily blurred the private and the public spheres. Clinton may well have pardoned Rich as a favour to the Israelis rather than as a quid pro quo for donations rendered. However, Podesta and Lindsey argued yesterday, the fact remains that most Americans, like Podesta himself (though perhaps not Lindsey), think he did the wrong thing in the wrong way at the wrong time.

They also, I am certain, think that Republican politicians would have done almost exactly the same thing for their friends as Clinton did for his Democratic ones.

Just as in the impeachment crisis, no one has emerged very well from the pardon scandal. Not the Clinton loyalists, not the Clinton haters, not the press. This time, though, Clinton and his apologists do not have the consolation of favourable public opinion. In some respects, Clinton may even be more damaged by Rich than by Lewinsky.

The fact that most Americans now want to move on, just as they did two years ago, cannot obscure the fact that, this time, the Clintons have done themselves some truly lasting damage.

webTitle: The night Moira got it wrong and was almost killed

fields.headline: The night Moira got it wrong and was almost killed
fields.trailText: Moira has been working the streets of Glasgow for four years to feed her drug habit. She has had her share of bad clients but last Friday she met the worst yet and she pulls back her hair to show the bruises on her forehead.
fields.body:
Moira has been working the streets of Glasgow for four years to feed her drug habit. She has had her share of bad clients but last Friday she met the worst yet and she pulls back her hair to show the bruises on her forehead.

"I almost got killed. I went down the alley with a guy and I was just about to do business when he put his arm round my neck and tried to choke me. It was like he was trying to break my neck. He was shouting, 'someone's going to get killed tonight and it's going to be you'.

"He got me on the deck and started banging my head off the ground. I thought I was going to black out. He had his hand over my mouth and I bit his finger. Then I got him by the balls but he kicked me back down and started banging my head again and I was just out of it then. I think I was concussed. He kicked me again, then he ran off.

"I reported it and the police liaison team were quite good. I had his blood on my cheek and I got some of his hair. But a couple of nights before that a wee lassie got done and they think it's the same guy. After he did me he ran straight past one of the CCTV cameras, but they're false ones so they won't have the picture of him. You've really just got to look out for yourself. No one else is going to do it for you."

Ann works from a flat in Edinburgh with another girl. She thinks its the safest way, even though it does not guarantee protection. She has had experience of saunas and she knows girls who have been forced into "carnal interviews" with sauna owners and others forced to forgo condoms.

"We've been lucky. Flat clients and sauna clients are completely different. In the flats we have a nicer client. It's done discreetly. Yes, there are clients that leave a lot to be desired, who get verbally abusive. But we have a security camera and a very good back-up. If a girl is in a room and it's not going right it's easy for her to let us know. A lot of the saunas don't have enough security. If you are in a cabin and a client turns on you what chance do you have?

"Flats are the safest way to go. The police are good in Edinburgh too. They know where every one of the flats is and they are approachable.

"Even with the violence, girls are scared to come forward. People still imagine that prostitutes are terrible, the scum of the earth, but I know some nice office workers that come up the town every weekend and drop their knickers, and you wouldn't say they don't deserve the same protection as everyone else, would you?"

fields.headline: Prostitutes 'left at risk of attack'
fields.standfirst: First study into sex industry violence calls for overhaul of social and legal attitudes with 80% of street workers suffering assaults
fields.trailText: Two-thirds of all prostitutes experienced violence and more than a third were attacked within the last six months, according to new research. Only 34%, however, had ever reported the assaults to police.
fields.body:
Two-thirds of all prostitutes experienced violence and more than a third were attacked within the last six months, according to new research. Only 34%, however, had ever reported the assaults to police.

The findings, in the first study in the UK, have led to calls for a major overhaul of social and judicial attitudes towards prostitution in the UK.

More than 80% of street prostitutes had experienced violence while they were working and half of them had been attacked within the last six months. Street prostitutes in Glasgow were six times more likely to have been attacked than those working indoors in Edinburgh. Indoor workers were not immune to violence, however. A total of 48% had been attacked, 26% within the last six months, says the study which focused on prostitutes in Glasgow, Edinburgh and Leeds and will be published today in the British Medical Journal.

The most common assault was punching and kicking, but 37% of street prostitutes had been robbed, 24% threatened with a weapon, 25% held against their will, 20% had been kidnapped and 22% raped. A total of 15% of indoor workers had been held against their will, 17% subject to attempted rape and 10% robbed.

The author, Marina Barnard of Glasgow University's centre for drug misuse research, said the findings were alarming and suggested that nothing short of legislation and a major shift in public attitudes would make prostitution safer.

"This study is the first look in this country at the levels of violence that women are confronting," she said. "If you are going to address it you need to look at ways of making sex work safer and ultimately there seems to be no way around legal change.

"We need to look at ways of minimising the risk of attack that are not just about pushing prostitution indoors. We need to encourage the perception that client violence against prostitutes is wrong and clients who perpetrate this violence will be brought to book."

The problem is particularly acute in Glasgow where six prostitutes have been murdered and a seventh has died violently since 1991. There are around 1,000 women working the streets and roughly 90% are on drugs, mostly heroin. The city recently adopted a radical scheme to take women off the streets and stop others entering the profession.

"We see prostitution as survival, not sexual behaviour," said Liz Curran of the Routes Out partnership. "At a social and political level, prostitution, like slavery and apartheid, is unacceptable. We had an option to try and manage it better but we wanted to dismantle it as something that is damaging to women."

Since October, 30 women have been persuaded to enter the programme, but street workers say more are starting every week.

In Edinburgh, city officials operate a policy of liaison and "discretionary prosecution", which prostitutes say offers better protection. There are 23 licensed saunas and 90% of prostitutes work in them.

"What we have done in Edinburgh is not rocket science," said Tom Wood, deputy chief constable of Lothian and Borders police. "We have recognised that the sex industry will always be there and that it is dangerous and we have worked along with the local authority and the health authority to reduce the risk as far as we can."

Ruth Morgan-Thomas, a leading campaigner for prostitutes, said the study was highly significant. "I think this shows up some very serious issues that society should look at about the sex industry and how it operates.

"The Scottish parliament and the UK parliament need to start examining the reality. Too often we pretend it does not exist because people are uncomfortable about looking at this. We need to look at it in all its complexities.

"We need a cultural shift because our attitude at the moment continues to disempower those working as prostitutes and make them extremely vulnerable."

The night Moira got it wrong and was almost killed

Moira has been working the streets of Glasgow for four years to feed her drug habit. She has had her share of bad clients but last Friday she met the worst yet and she pulls back her hair to show the bruises on her forehead.

"I almost got killed. I went down the alley with a guy and I was just about to do business when he put his arm round my neck and tried to choke me. It was like he was trying to break my neck. He was shouting, 'someone's going to get killed tonight and it's going to be you'.

"He got me on the deck and started banging my head off the ground. I thought I was going to black out. He had his hand over my mouth and I bit his finger. Then I got him by the balls but he kicked me back down and started banging my head again and I was just out of it then. I think I was concussed. He kicked me again, then he ran off.

"I reported it and the police liaison team were quite good. I had his blood on my cheek and I got some of his hair. But a couple of nights before that a wee lassie got done and they think it's the same guy. After he did me he ran straight past one of the CCTV cameras, but they're false ones so they won't have the picture of him. You've really just got to look out for yourself. No one else is going to do it for you."

Ann works from a flat in Edinburgh with another girl. She thinks its the safest way, even though it does not guarantee protection. She has had experience of saunas and she knows girls who have been forced into "carnal interviews" with sauna owners and others forced to forgo condoms.

"We've been lucky. Flat clients and sauna clients are completely different. In the flats we have a nicer client. It's done discreetly. Yes, there are clients that leave a lot to be desired, who get verbally abusive. But we have a security camera and a very good back-up. If a girl is in a room and it's not going right it's easy for her to let us know. A lot of the saunas don't have enough security. If you are in a cabin and a client turns on you what chance do you have?

"Flats are the safest way to go. The police are good in Edinburgh too. They know where every one of the flats is and they are approachable.

"Even with the violence, girls are scared to come forward. People still imagine that prostitutes are terrible, the scum of the earth, but I know some nice office workers that come up the town every weekend and drop their knickers, and you wouldn't say they don't deserve the same protection as everyone else, would you?"

webTitle: Labour ignoring north-south divide, says MP

fields.headline: Labour ignoring north-south divide, says MP
fields.trailText: A former Labour defence minister last night accused the government of advancing a regional development policy akin to a local raj, imposing Whitehall's will. Peter Kilfoyle, the MP for Liverpool Walton, told a Guardian North debate that Whitehall saw the regions through a departmental prism.
fields.body:
A former Labour defence minister last night accused the government of advancing a regional development policy akin to a local raj, imposing Whitehall's will. Peter Kilfoyle, the MP for Liverpool Walton, told a Guardian North debate that Whitehall saw the regions through a departmental prism.

Pockets of extreme deprivation and unemployment continued to separate the north from the south, despite the hundreds of millions of pounds spent on renewal schemes. The only way to stop them was with regional devolution.

Speaking in Salford at the debate, The Regeneration Game: Are Northern Cities Losing Out? he said: "I view the government officers as local raj set out to impose Whitehall's will. They have departmental agendas.

"They do not look holistically at the region. The government has to develop policies with local people. It has to establish local ownership of these projects." Tenants associations might have better ideas for their development than civil servants.

A report commissioned by the Guardian this week found economic divisions between north and south had widened over the past four years and showed little sign of narrowing despite government money on urban schemes.

Brian Robson, head of the centre for urban policy at Manchester University and a government adviser who wrote the report, highlighted the extent of deprivation on Humberside and in the north-west.

"There have been dramatic changes in the centre of Manchester and Liverpool but unless we bridge the gulf between the centres of cities and the doughnut ring of deprivation around the edge, we haven't solved the problem."

Tom Bloxham, whose Urban Splash group, has made millions by renovating decaying areas of Manchester and Liverpool, said money from central urban development had not reached the peripheries of the cities.

Anthony Wilson, founder of Factory Records and the Hacienda club, said the success of French cities like Lille proved regional cities could be regenerated with devolved government.

fields.headline: Olympic merchandise gets protection
fields.trailText: The first official Athens 2004 Olympic Games merchandise is being launched with heavy security, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
The first official Athens 2004 Olympic Games merchandise is being launched with heavy security tagging to protect its official status from bootleggers.

Casual and sporty clothing, swimwear, accessories, housewares and jewellery will be marketed internationally and the income will help fund the games.

The products will go on sale initially in Greece later this month.

The authenticity of the goods will be protected by sophisticated anti-counterfeit security systems. These include holograms and lasers, bar codes, specially marked clothes hangers and embroidered or self-adhesive name-tapes placed in obvious and inconspicuous places.

The products will be sold in authorised shops.

In Greece, the matter is being taken so seriously police will patrol shops, confiscate counterfeit items and prosecute people who sell unauthorised goods.

The organising committee has also issued a tender document calling for designs for the mascot of the games.

The deadline for tenders is April 20 and between three and 10 designs will make it on to a shortlist.

The popularity of Olympic mascots is always a hit-and-miss affair.

The Sydney 2000 games had three mascots - "Ollie", a Kookaburra, "Syd", a Platypus, and "Millie", an Echidna - representing air, water and earth.

fields.headline: Campbell to front Watchdog
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Nicky Campbell is to take over from Anne Robinson as the presenter of BBC1's Watchdog, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Nicky Campbell is to take over from Anne Robinson as the presenter of Watchdog, insiders have confirmed.

It is believed he agreed the contract on Wednesday.

The former Wheel of Fortune presenter and BBC Radio 1 DJ was offered the job after Ms Robinson decided to end her eight-year association with the programme.

Mr Campbell is thought to have been chosen in preference to Charlotte Hudson, the chief reporter on Watchdog.

Adrian Chiles, the presenter of BBC 2's Working Lunch, was also a contender.

The Scottish presenter has been eager to establish himself in a regular current affairs primetime slot on the BBC.

He has presented a topical talk show on ITV and 18 months ago landed a short stint as a location presenter on Newsnight.

Ms Robinson is leaving the programme to present her hit series the Weakest Link in the US.

webTitle: RIM builds itself up for flotation

fields.headline: RIM builds itself up for flotation
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Regional Independent Media, the newspaper group which owns the Yorkshire Post, is looking for acquisitions to build the business ahead of a planned stock market flotation in 18 months.
fields.body:
Regional Independent Media, the newspaper group which owns the Yorkshire Post, is looking for acquisitions to build the business ahead of a planned stock market flotation in 18 months.

The company - which rejected a takeover approach from a consortium led by the US media group, Gannett, at the start of the year - said it had full backing for its strategy from Candover, the venture capital firm which is its largest shareholder.

Chris Oakley, RIM chief executive, said: "We aim to move toward flotation - possibly in autumn next year - depending upon market conditions, our performance and ability to grow by acquisition. It would be useful if we were a little bigger than we are now."

Mr Oakley said the company would pursue targets in regional newspapers, albeit that there are few independent groups left of any significant size. RIM will also be looking for acquisitions in business magazines and for further expansion in radio.

RIM has £10m in cash, plus borrowing in place amounting to a further £25m. "Candover has made it clear that more cash would be made available for acquisitions," he said.

RIM yesterday reported a 22% rise in operating profit to £40.9m and an 8% increase in revenues to £169m for 2000.

The Gannett consortium, which included Johnston Press and the Guardian Media Group, is understood to have lodged an indicative offer of between £450m and £550m for RIM just before to Christmas. The approach, which would have led to the break-up of RIM, was the second the consortium had made.

"We are a venture capital-backed company, and venture capital firms are obliged to go into a deal thinking about an exit which means they can never rule out a trade sale," Mr Oakley said.

"But there is a real difference between that and a company seeking a trade sale. And we are not seeking a trade sale."

fields.headline: BBC man 'linked to coup plot'
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The government of Bangladesh has called on the BBC to sack the head of its Bengali service after accusing him of colluding in the bloody 1975 coup. By Luke Harding and Arshad Mahmud.
fields.byline: Luke Harding and Arshad Mahmud in Dhaka
fields.body:
The government of Bangladesh has called on the BBC to sack the head of its Bengali service after accusing him of colluding in the bloody 1975 coup which led to the murder of the country's independence leader, Sheikh Mujibur Rahman.

Bangladesh's prime minister, Sheikh Hasina, - Sheikh Mujibur's daughter - has demanded a formal investigation into the role played by Syed Mahmud Ali in her father's death. Mr Ali joined the BBC 11 years ago after a career as a senior officer in the Bangladeshi army.

Officials in Dhaka have hinted that unless the corporation swiftly "removes" Mr Ali from his editor's post, the government will consider terminating the BBC's transmission facilities. They added that the "existing fraternal and cordial relations" between the UK and Bangladesh might also be in jeopardy.

In an interview last week with a London-based Bangladeshi journalist, Mr Ali said he had initially fought on the side of the Pakistan army during Bangladesh's war of independence in 1971.

He also described how on the day of the coup, in August 1975, he turned up at the radio station in Dhaka where the coup leaders had triumphantly assembled after shooting to death Sheikh Mujibur and 11 members of his family.

Last night Mr Ali would not discuss his earlier career in the Bangladeshi army. But the BBC World Service said he had been "misrepresented" in the interview. "The BBC has full confidence in the impartiality and objectivity of the Bengali section and its head," a statement said. It added that he denied all involvement in the plot against Sheikh Mujibur.

fields.headline: Save loses the forecourt fight
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Save Group, Britain's biggest independent petrol retailer, was yesterday in the hands of administrators as the battle for supremacy of the country's forecourts claimed its largest victim to date.
fields.body:
Save Group, Britain's biggest independent petrol retailer, was yesterday in the hands of administrators as the battle for supremacy of the country's forecourts claimed its largest victim to date.

James Frost, the chairman and chief executive, has resigned, leaving open to question the future of 4,000 staff employed indirectly by Save on its 465 sites.

The company, with a turnover of £400m, is continuing to operate under the control of accountant Ernst & Young; the search is on for a potential buyer to save the operation. Save shares were suspended at 47.5p.

Shell, Texaco and Esso have in the past been linked with a takeover but other independent retailers blamed the large integrated companies for driving Save to the wall.

An Ernst & Young spokeswoman confirmed Save had been damaged by intense competition from oil companies and supermarkets. These difficulties were exacerbated by bad weather and the fuel crisis.

Aylesbury-based Save complained in January that the autumn blockade had scared off potential purchasers. Save warned at the time that "recent pump price reductions and product price rises [were] reducing margins in some areas to unsustainable levels".

Mr Frost's anger was directed mainly at the banking consortium made up of Barclays, Royal Bank of Scotland and Lloyds TSB. "They gave us a series of short-term facilities which were never quite enough," he said.

The banks argued that they had spent two years talking to Save, and an offer was on the table which the company felt unable to accept.

"The banks are obviously disappointed at this outcome," a spokesman for market-leading bank Barclays said.

Another independent retailer, SSL, said the real culprits were the oil groups. SSL's financial director, Anthony Salvidge, said: "This underlines our view that oil companies are trying to drive independents out of business."

In the first six months of last year, Save produced after-tax profits of £1.9m on turnover of £236m. But it failed to make money in the September to October fuel crisis.

Save has a capitalisation of around £47m, compared with the billion-pound values of most of its competitors on the forecourt.

The oil majors, such as BP and Shell, recently announced record annual profits but argued that they were earning very little on the forecourt because of the strong competition. They too have been closing stations.

Taxes are blamed for Britain having the highest petrol prices in Europe, and Save's troubles will heighten the debate days before the Budget.

The City was taken by surprise by Save. Analysts at ING Charterhouse rejected suggestions that some of Save's problems were self-inflicted.

One analyst said: "Given the size of the group [Mr Frost] did well to stay afloat as long as he did."

Mr Frost, who owns 5% of Save, said he would take his fight with the banks to the office of fair trading and the financial services authority.

 Motor dealership HMG Holdings has fallen into administrative receivership, it was announced yesterday. The group, based in Sevenoaks, Kent, employs 1,800 staff in 40 sites in the UK, trading under the names Henlys, Stormont and Hancock.

webTitle: Brussels dispatch: Europe resists gloating over foot and mouth

fields.headline: Europe resists gloating over foot and mouth
fields.standfirst: The EU's main concern is still BSE, but the latest livestock crisis could yet make a pariah of the UK, writes Andrew Osborn
fields.trailText: The EU's main concern is still BSE, but the latest livestock crisis could yet make a pariah of the UK, writes Andrew Osborn
fields.body:
Foot and mouth disease has yet to reach Europe, but its fallout is already taking its toll on the continent's demoralised farmers who are being forced to slaughter thousands of apparently healthy animals on the altar of precaution.

Sheep, goats, pigs and deer imported from the UK in the past month have already gone under the knife in France, Germany, Belgium and the Netherlands, and large cattle markets across the continent have suspended trade for the time being.

Europe's farmers are understandably starting to ask who will foot the bill for the huge loss of earnings they will undoubtedly suffer, but an expected wave of anti-British feeling has, perhaps surprisingly, not yet materialised.

Militant farmers are more than ready to heap opprobrium on "perfidious Albion" but most European countries have so far failed to take advantage of what many might regard as a golden opportunity to make a pariah out of the UK.

The recent spread of the disease to Northern Ireland has, however, heightened fears that foot and mouth will rear its devastating head in Europe. What if what is being billed as a doomsday scenario does come to pass? It is unlikely European politicians and the media would be able to hold back any longer.

That is not to say the outbreak of foot and mouth in the UK has not reinforced an already deep-rooted sense of distrust of all British food products. It has - but Europe's consumers have not visibly taken any satisfaction in being proven right.

In the UK, foot and mouth may have topped news bulletins for days, but in Europe the country's woes are reported like any other foreign news story.

Europe is still obsessed with the other British outbreak - mad cow disease. Its spread across the continent has already provoked a genuine crisis in European agriculture and the thought that foot and mouth might follow on its heels is, for many, too much to bear.

BSE has already strained the European Union's £25m-a-year agricultural budget to bursting point, thanks to compensation payouts for the destruction of millions of older cattle across Europe that cannot be proven to be BSE-free. And EU farm supremo Franz Fischler has warned his pockets are empty.

Not a day seems to go by without farmers from somewhere in Europe coming onto the streets to demand greater compensation for BSE and giving vivid expression to their angst that nobody wants to eat their animals anymore.

Pre-foot and mouth, European agriculture has already been plunged into crisis and the EU's infamous common agricultural policy is visibly creaking under the strain.

This week thousands of disgruntled farmers fought pitched battles with riot police in the centre of Brussels as EU farm ministers deliberated behind closed doors over how to tackle BSE in Europe.

Britain's agriculture minister, Nick Brown, flew in to update his colleagues on the foot and mouth situation in the UK, but that was not the focus of the meeting. It was mad cow disease, old news in the UK but hot news in Europe.

Europe teeters on the brink as far as foot and mouth disease is concerned. If it does spread to the continent, disaster will ensue and it could deliver the coup de grace to the common agricultural policy and European farming as a whole.

If that happened Britain would, as in the case of BSE, once again find itself labelled a pariah state. But if foot and mouth can be contained within the UK and perhaps Ireland, European farmers could actually do quite well out of Britain's woes, as supplies of meat dry up and they step in to take up the slack.

webTitle: Horse racing: Festival fears over new outbreak

fields.headline: Festival fears over new outbreak
fields.standfirst:
Cheltenham in turmoil as foot and mouth is suspected at nearby farm
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The Cheltenham Festival was dealt a potentially fatal blow last night when it was announced that a suspected case of foot and mouth disease was being investigated at a farm five miles from the racecourse.
fields.body:
The Cheltenham Festival was dealt a potentially fatal blow last night when it was announced that a suspected case of foot and mouth disease was being investigated at a farm five miles from the racecourse.

The news followed days of speculation about the fate of the three-day meeting, which the organisers insist will go ahead if possible. They face an anxious wait over the weekend to see whether the farm, at Woolstone, is infected.

Tests began at the sheep farm 48 hours ago. Last night the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (Maff) confirmed that Woolstone had not been linked to any previous outbreaks, and Cheltenham's clerk of the course Simon Claisse said there was "only a 5% chance" it would prove positive. But time is pressing and investigations could take days.

A final decision about the Festival, which is due to start on March 13, will rest with Maff and the Jockey Club, which intends to press ahead with an announcement today on a code of practice intended to allow a resumption of racing nationally next Wednesday.

Even if the showpiece event survives it will not do so unscathed, after yesterday's decision by the Irish trainers not to send their runners to the meeting. This ruled out any chance of Istabraq attempting to win the Champion Hurdle for a record fourth time.

"We made soundings with our members before the committee convened and not one of them said they disagreed with our stance," said Willie Mullins, the chairman of the Irish Race Horse Trainers Association. "When you see people losing their livelihoods in a day, nobody in our association wanted to take the chance of that happening over here."

Edward Gillespie, Cheltenham's managing director, was "very disappointed" at the decision taken by Irish trainers, who also urged the public not to travel to the meeting.

Cheltenham had received a boost hours earlier when French authorities gave the green light for their horses to travel to Britain. They include the strong Gold Cup fancy First Gold, owned like Istabraq by the big-time Irish punter JP McManus.

Professionals in the sport are divided about the Jockey Club's attempt to bring racing back next week. "I honestly cannot believe it, just don't understand it," said Ferdy Murphy, who trains 100 horses at Middleham in north Yorkshire. "All we are doing is alienating a lot of people who already think we are nincompoops."

But his fellow Middleham trainer Mark Johnston, who is also a vet, is in favour of a quick resumption. "The Ministry of Agriculture does not see racing as a threat and the seven-day stoppage has been a reaction to public pressure.

"There has been a fair amount of scaremongering. The perception seems to be that horses hang on to the infection and then pass it on. In fact they are no more likely to carry it than a hare."

Racing is not the only sport in a quandary over how to proceed. Rugby's Six Nations committee will today come under pressure to ensure that the championship is played to a conclusion this season despite the foot and mouth outbreak.

The international between Wales and Ireland, which should have been played tomorrow, is likely to be rearranged for April 29, but Irish and English rugby officials are conceding that the meeting between their countries in Dublin on March 24 is almost certain to be called off.

Allan Hosie, the chairman of the Six Nations committee, said last night that he was confident France would play Wales at the Stade de France two weeks tomorrow as scheduled. "As things stand, only one match has been postponed and it will be rearranged," said Hosie. "We hope that the rest of the programme will be played according to schedule, but we would be negligent if we did not discuss a course of action should worst come to worst."

However, the Welsh Assembly's agriculture minister Carwyn Jones yesterday called for sports fields and golf courses that are adjacent to fields where animals graze to be closed until further notice.

fields.headline: Rethink on cheap food policies
fields.standfirst:
Excess 'should be discouraged'

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The government last night signalled that the foot and mouth epidemic is prompting a move away from policies promoting the over-production of food.
fields.body:
The government last night signalled that the foot and mouth epidemic is prompting a move away from policies promoting the over-production of food.

Speaking at the launch of an action plan designed to implement the principles of the rural white paper announced last year, the agriculture minister, Elliot Morley, said the crisis underlined the need for a rethink over the principles of the common agriculture policy.

Mr Morley said: "The political priorities and drivers for agriculture was set in 1947 under the Agriculture Act. And the number one priority was intensification. It was production of food and that meant destruction of wildlife features, larger agriculture units, intensification of livestock. It was a cheaper food policy".

He said the policy was "designed at a time of post-war austerity and it is now time to review the objectives of agriculture. There is a new role for quality as well as quantity".

He pointed out the proportion of the family budget de voted to food had declined dramatically. "Consumers are better educated. There is much more interest in organic food and regional food".

He claimed that "there had been a policy of production subsidies in which food is produced almost at any cost regardless of whether or not there is a market or not".

Mr Meacher backed Mr Morley in calling for a re-think in intensive farming policy and said the foot and mouth outbreak "may well accelerate that trend".

He said the government is trying to prevent the closure of small abattoirs, but added the ultimate cause of the epidemic had not yet been found. There was no evidence that regulatory regime had failed. He said the closure of these slaughterhouses had led to increased movements of animals across the country.

The countryside agency also warned that unless the foot and mouth outbreak was brought under control, the face of the countryside would change. It warned that as much as as £1bn was at stake through the risk to rural tourism.

The agency pointed out that the cancellation of the Cheltenham racing festival would wipe out profits of the whole region and have a massive effect on the rural economy.

fields.headline: Last outpost falls to virus
fields.standfirst:
No part of UK safe as disease crosses border

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Yesterday, the men from the Ministry of Agriculture told Scotland's farmers that foot and mouth had crossed the border and no corner of the UK was now safe.
fields.body:
It was the news they had been dreading but knew would almost certainly come. Yesterday, the men from the Ministry of Agriculture told Scotland's farmers that foot and mouth had crossed the border and no corner of the UK was now safe.

Farmers' leaders had been warning the Scottish farming community to brace itself for bad news as the virus cut a swathe through England and Wales.

The first confirmed Scottish case came at Netherplace farm in Lockerbie, in the south-west of the country.

The farm, belonging to a big sheep and cattle dealer, sits in the centre of the town, surrounded by houses, bordered by the M74 and bisected by the main west coast rail line.

Veterinary officials say containment and slaughter at the site, which had links with Cheale Meats abattoir in Essex, will be a nightmare.

Less than 20 miles away, infection notices were also being posted at Parkhouse farm near Canonbie.

Part of the Duke of Buccleuch's estate, the farm leases out grazing land to other farmers and had been visited by a lorry from an infected area of Devon.

"We don't see this as just two farms and we don't see it as just having to safeguard the whole livestock of Dumfries and Galloway, but the whole of Scotland," said Andrew Campbell, convener of Dumfries and Galloway council and himself a farmer. "You can't see this virus and you can't smell it, but for heaven's sake use common sense and take advice from the veterinary department," he said.

Forty other farms across Scotland are under supervision and the results of tests on a third suspected case at a sheep farm at Polmont, central Scotland, will be released today. The livestock trade is worth £721m annually to Scottish farmers and Dumfries and Galloway is one of the richest areas for the industry.

The trade and the general public have already been constrained by the UK-wide restrictions on livestock movement, but as news broke yesterday of the first confirmed cases of foot and mouth north of the border, the barriers came down in earnest.

Farmers' leaders had been warning the Scottish farming community to brace itself for bad news as the virus cut a swathe through England and Wales. The first confirmed Scottish case came at Netherplace farm in Lockerbie, in the south-west of the country. The farm, belonging to a big sheep and cattle dealer, sits in the centre of the town, surrounded by houses, bordered by the M74 and bisected by the main west coast rail line. Veterinary officials say containment and slaughter at the site, which had links with Cheale Meats abattoir in Essex, will be a nightmare. Less than 20 miles away, infection notices were also being posted at Parkhouse farm near Canonbie. Part of the Duke of Buccleuch's estate, the farm leases out grazing land to other farmers and had been visited by a lorry from an infected area of Devon. "We don't see this as just two farms and we don't see it as just having to safeguard the whole livestock of Dumfries and Galloway, but the whole of Scotland," said Andrew Campbell, convener of Dumfries and Galloway council and himself a farmer. "You can't see this virus and you can't smell it, but for heaven's sake use common sense and take advice from the veterinary department," he said. Forty other farms across Scotland are under supervision and the results of tests on a third suspected case at a sheep farm at Polmont, central Scotland, will be released today. The livestock trade is worth £721m annually to Scottish farmers and Dumfries and Galloway is one of the richest areas for the industry. The trade and the general public have already been constrained by the UK-wide restrictions on livestock movement, but as news broke yesterday of the first confirmed cases of foot and mouth north of the border, the barriers came down in earnest. webTitle: Foot and mouth in Northern Ireland

fields.headline: Missing sheep spark anger at the border
fields.standfirst:
Complaints over controls around farm close to republic

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Hours after Northern Ireland's first outbreak of foot and mouth disease was officially confirmed yesterday, there was little sign of the stringent restrictions promised by the Ministry of Agriculture.
fields.body:
Hours after Northern Ireland's first outbreak of foot and mouth disease was officially confirmed yesterday, there was little sign of the stringent restrictions promised by the Ministry of Agriculture around the south Armagh farm at the centre of the crisis.

Around 40 sheep, just a few hundred yards from the village of Meigh, right on the Irish border, had to be destroyed after they showed symptoms of the virus. Part of a flock of almost 300, purchased in a Carlisle market a fortnight ago, they were meant to have been slaughtered.

But a frantic search is now on to locate the remaining 250 sheep, which, it is feared, could have been taken south of the border. The Meigh farmer issued a statement last night, saying he had done all he could to cooperate with the authorities, and the RUC have arrested a man in Banbridge, Co Down.

Farming is Northern Ireland's largest business, with more than 30,000 farmers and 30,000 more employed in agri-food related industries, which export 80% of their produce, accounting for hundreds of millions of pounds a year.

Worry

In Meigh, the worry and fear that all this was in jeopardy was all too clearly etched on local faces, but there was criticism too of the Ministry of Agriculture for not acting faster, and anger that the disease might have been brought to the area through the illegal movement of animals. A large warning sign, red and white tape and disinfectant mats blocked the entrance to the farm where the infected sheep were discovered.

Three or four miles away, frustrated motorists, some of whom had taken five hours to make journeys of less than 20 miles, waited at a Garda checkpoint to be allowed to enter the Irish Republic. Cartons of milk were confiscated and drivers had to cross more disinfectant mats. "I know why we have to do this, but surely there must be a more efficient way," said one woman, travelling from Warrenpoint, Co Down, to Dundalk. "By the time I get to work it'll be time to go home again."

However, just beside the Meigh farm, traffic and pedestrians trundled up and down a busy road it all day, neighbouring farmers drove tractors in and out, and sheep and horses grazed peacefully in nearby fields.

Restrictions

A tighter exclusion zone was in place by evening, but some residents were furious the restrictions had not been enforced earlier. "What's the point of bolting the gate after the horse has gone?" said one man. "Why did they have to wait til it was confirmed? Surely they should have done all they could when they first suspected this?"

Local people had no doubt what this could mean for their livelihood - devastation. "There's only one topic of conversation here," said Miceal McCoy, president of the Northern Ireland Agricultural Producers Association, who has a farm nearby. "I haven't heard anyone mention the train crash in England or any other item of news. This could mean absolute disaster for the economy, not just in south Armagh, but for the whole of Northern Ireland.

"Already, the Middle East and South America are refusing UK milk. The dairy industry could be crippled. We reckon it could lose £5m a month through the ban. The government and the European Union must help us. "Every family round here is asking themselves what they are going to do. They could be in a situation where they're imprisoned on their farms with no income."

"Everyone has held their breath hoping we wouldn't hear the worst, but now there's a real sense of dismay," said Sinn Fein assemblyman, Conor Murphy, who also lives close by. "People thought there was very little future in farming after the BSE crisis but we were just turning round and picking up after that when this comes along. This will put a lot of people out of business.

Patrols

"It's ironic though, the army virtually closed this road for 25 years and yet when there's a real crisis, the authorities are incredibly slow at getting restrictions in place."

He said he was also concerned that army helicopters and foot patrols were still active in the area. "This is a very virulent, easily spread disease and this activity must stop," he said, adding that people would be furious if they found out that smuggling had brought the virus into Ireland.

Local farmers were determined to do all they could to stop the outbreak spreading, but there was a resigned sadness that it was perhaps already too late.

"I had to destroy cattle before through brucellosis," said Henry McElroy. "I just fear this is us finished. We might as well bring in the planks and the coal and get on with it. It'll get worse before it gets better and it's heartbreaking."

fields.headline: A very, very nice man
fields.standfirst: My week: Paul King, 29, AA patrolman in the Aberdeen area
fields.trailText: My week: Paul King, 29, AA patrolman in the Aberdeen area
fields.body:
The weather this week has been some of the worst I have experienced in three years as an AA man. The conditions have definitely made my work much more difficult. In the mornings I start from home and usually have to dig my own and my partner's car out before I can go anywhere. I usually get a call in the first few minutes. The vehicles that we drive are equipped with a satellite global positioning system which means that as soon as a call comes in, the system plots the closest AA man. The area I cover is large and the countryside can be quite desolate, so it is important that we get to members as quickly as possible.

Everything slows down when there's snow on the roads - especially on the smaller ones, which have trouble with heavy drifts coming off the fields and hills. On top of cars breaking down more often, people are more likely to call you out for things they could normally sort out themselves. Normally members wouldn't call you out for something like a flat tyre, but when there's weather like this about, people tend to panic. This means that people have to wait longer for support than they normally do.

Generally, though, drivers are quite well prepared because the weather tends to get pretty bad at this time of year in Scotland. People often take extra clothing and hot drinks when they go out.

Others have been caught on the hop. On Tuesday night there were 35 people stranded at Whiterashes on the A947, which is one of the main roads out of Aberdeen. They were frightened and very cold. They needed all the help that they could get. It is at times like this that you feel your job is an important one, as there are very few other people who can get out to situations like that.

On Wednesday I also had to go and help a young woman who had been stranded with her two small children in a small village for three days. She was starting to run out of food and so decided to try to drive to her local shops. Unfortunately her car wouldn't start and it took me a while to get it fixed. I ended up defrosting her drive, too.

At the moment I am doing 10-hour shifts, which means I do get very tired, especially as I am spending a lot of my time in the freezing cold. We are all looking forward to the summer now, which is when our jobs become a lot easier. It'll be nice to put away my shovel.

webTitle: Flying high Extreme sports lift Popstars producer

fields.headline: Flying high Extreme sports lift Popstars producer
fields.trailText: Popstars, the hit television show, has also proved a success off screen by contributing to a sharp improvement in the fortunes of Sportsworld Media, which shares the worldwide rights to the programme format.
fields.body:
Popstars, the hit television show, has also proved a success off screen by contributing to a sharp improvement in the fortunes of Sportsworld Media, which shares the worldwide rights to the programme format.

The show was picked up in 13 countries, including the US, Canada and India.

Sportsworld, which began life producing extreme sports programming, yesterday reported an operating profit of £4.8m for the six months to December 31 against a loss of £90,000 in the previous year.

Extreme sports programming, sponsorship and me dia sales account for 90% of the group's revenues. Chief executive Geoff Brown said he expected the percentage to fall as the group's success encourages it to develop further light entertainment formats.

Its next hope is Search for a Supermodel, a programme following the annual trawl by the Ford agency for the next Kate Moss or Naomi Campbell.

Shares in Sportsworld closed 2.5p higher at 475p.

fields.headline: Redbus seeks buyer's payment
fields.trailText: A UK film distribution company backed by entrepreneur Cliff Stanford has issued a $16m (£11m) writ against a German distributor which it says withheld payments after taking a majority stakeholding in the business.
fields.body:
A UK film distribution company backed by entrepreneur Cliff Stanford has issued a $16m (£11m) writ against a German distributor which it says withheld payments after taking a majority stakeholding in the business.

Mr Stanford, who made a fortune on the sale of his Demon internet service provider, has claimed that Helkon ignored a number of agreed deadlines for the completion of a deal for 51% stake in Redbus Film Distribution.

"We have been owed the money since October," he said.

"The last information that I had was that [Helkon] had said they had no money, but they were going to raise it in the next few days.

"It has been exactly the same comment for months."

The writ alleges that Helkon's withholding of payments has put Redbus Film Distribution at risk of running short of capital, and has already caused it to lose a number of key employees.

But Helkon chief executive Mark Ramaker yesterday refuted allegations that the company had told Redbus it could not make the payments. He said the money had been withheld because of a number of unresolved issues Helkon had with Redbus Film Distribution.

Mr Ramaker described the payment delay as a "technical detail" but said he could not discuss his misgivings over the deal because it would damage Helkon's position. "It is not serious, and it will not come to court," he said.

Asked if Helkon could make the payments, he said: "That is not an issue for us."

He said Helkon's finances were in good health, and that the company had recently celebrated a number of successes, including securing the German distribution rights for The Mexican, a feature film starring Julia Roberts and Brad Pitt.

Helkon acquired its stake in Redbus Film Distribution as part of a plan to create a pan-European production and distribution network.

webTitle: British way of death 'in sway of consumerism'

fields.headline: British way of death 'in sway of consumerism'
fields.trailText: Seventeen of the country's hottest young artists and fashion designers plan to "put a bomb" under the British way of death tomorrow with a show of caskets which glow in the dark, balloons to catch a dying breath and - most poignant of all - tiny girl and boy jewel-box foetal coffins.
fields.body:
Seventeen of the country's hottest young artists and fashion designers plan to "put a bomb" under the British way of death tomorrow with a show of caskets which glow in the dark, balloons to catch a dying breath and - most poignant of all - tiny girl and boy jewel-box foetal coffins.

Dead - An End to Conveyor Belt Funerals, at the Roundhouse in north London, is as much a challenge to the £1bn funeral industry - which the artists accuse of ripping off the public and robbing them of the choice to celebrate a life well lived - as it is an attempt to update grave goods and bring them out of the grip of maudlin Victoriana.

The show, organised by the radical art activists Welfare State International, ranges in content from Hussein Chalayan's lavish funeral boat and Owen Gaster's crocheted diamante shroud to Bob and Roberta Smith's budget DIY coffins made from fruit boxes.

Linder Sterling, the artist notorious for her Menstrual Eggtimer, spent days roaming Manchester's gothic graveyards with the death-obsessed pop star Morrisey before composing her new non-denominational requiem.

Most unusual of all is the Last Gasp Balloons, officially called Memento Kit: Final Breath, created by the artists Dunne and Raby to record the moment of transcendence.

The organiser, John Fox, said some might find the show a little chilling, but part of the idea was to get people to think creatively about their own death. "If people thought about their own death a little more, I don't think they would bother with much of the consumerist rubbish that clutters up our lives now," he said.

It was up to artists, Fox argued, to take death "out of the hands of the multinational corporations" by coming up with objects and ceremonies which were both celebratory and practical. "People really have very little choice about what sort of a send-off their loved ones get unless they do it themselves, and very few people, for obvious reasons, feel able to do that. We want to open up a debate and to show there is a better way."

Andrew Davies, operations director of CSI, the US-owned conglomerate that is Britain's biggest undertaker, said yesterday that the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, had changed attitudes to death and funerals.

"People saw there that funerals could be done differently and that it was possible to introduce an element of celebration that may have been missing from more traditional ceremonies. There is a new openness among our clients to having more personal rituals, like releasing doves at the grave, or balloons at children's funerals."

fields.headline: Cost warning on missile shield
fields.trailText: Admiral Sir Michael Boyce, the new chief of defence staff, warned last night that Britain could not afford to participate in a missile defence system without a significant increase in the defence budget.
fields.body:
Admiral Sir Michael Boyce, the new chief of defence staff, warned last night that Britain could not afford to participate in a missile defence system without a significant increase in the defence budget.

He told the Commons defence committee that while it would be "silly" not to look at ways to counter the threat of missile attack, it must not be at the expense of existing roles undertaken by Britain's armed forces.

"I think this would have to be an add-on to our expeditionary capability," he told the committee. "My concern, if we were ever to invest in it, is that the money should be given in addition to the defence budget and not found from the defence budget.

"On the present defence budget, we could not maintain an effective expeditionary capability and a national defence system as well."

His comments came after Tony Blair's weekend talks with President George Bush, when the US's proposals for a national missile defence system - the so-called Son of Star Wars - was high on the agenda.

Sir Michael acknowledged the potential threat of a missile attack by a "rogue" state was growing. "What we have to worry about is that countries are developing ballistic missile systems that are soon going to have a capability that is close to what was previously held in Russia," he said.

"We would be very silly," he added, "not to look to see how we could counter that threat. If there is a way of doing it without mutually assured destruction, we should give it serious thought."

His comments reflect scepticism in both the Ministry of Defence and the Foreign Office about the need for and technological effectiveness of a missile defence shield.

Sir Michael also said the MoD would have to think "very, very carefully indeed" before deciding whether to allow women soldiers to serve in close combat roles. But he emphasised that any decision would have to be taken on the grounds of combat effectiveness, not because of concerns about exposing women to danger. Women in the forces were already serving in roles where they could be killed in fighting.

"The distinction is lost on me whether you are going to die horribly in a fireball in a ship hit by an Exocet or in a muddy field," he said.

He was not prepared to drop his opposition to women serving in nuclear submarines, however. He said medical evidence showed that, since nuclear submarines could remain underwater for two to three months without any change of air, there was a danger that, if a woman was pregnant, the foetus could be damaged.

It would be "irresponsible" to send women to sea in such circumstances when they could be pregnant without knowing it.

Sir Michael also said the MoD would have to think "very, very carefully indeed" before deciding whether to allow women soldiers to serve in close combat roles. But he emphasised that any decision would have to be taken on the grounds of combat effectiveness, not because of concerns about exposing women to danger. Women in the forces were already serving in roles where they could be killed in fighting. "The distinction is lost on me whether you are going to die horribly in a fireball in a ship hit by an Exocet or in a muddy field," he said. He was not prepared to drop his opposition to women serving in nuclear submarines, however. He said medical evidence showed that, since nuclear submarines could remain underwater for two to three months without any change of air, there was a danger that, if a woman was pregnant, the foetus could be damaged. It would be "irresponsible" to send women to sea in such circumstances when they could be pregnant without knowing it.

fields.headline: Wembley to ditch name
fields.standfirst: Stadium pioneer aims at new goals
fields.trailText: Wembley, the entertainment and events company, is to change its name following the sale of its remaining interests in the eponymous north London development.
fields.body:
Wembley, the entertainment and events company, is to change its name following the sale of its remaining interests in the eponymous north London development.

Finance director Mark Elliott said that the profile of the company - which sold Wembley stadium two years ago - had been hit by negative publicity surrounding the troubled development of a new national stadium. "When we read headlines in the Sun like 'Wembley shambles', it really hurt us," he said.

The company hopes to ac celerate its withdrawal from the London suburb by selling the 50-acre site surrounding English football's leading stadium without securing approval for redevelopment. The company had previously said it would be involved in the planning application process before selling the site, which includes Wembley arena and conference centre.

Mr Elliott said that while the corporate name had served the company well, an alternative would better reflect the company's present interests. About 90% of Wembley PLC's profits come from the US, while more than 95% comes from its greyhound race tracks and around 13,000 trackside slot machines.

Mr Elliott said: "Wembley has been home for us for 70-odd years, and there is a strong historical link. But we do not judge shareholder value on history."

Analysts said a sale of the company's remaining Wembley interests was unlikely while uncertainty over the redevelopment of the stadium dragged on. Property developers interested in the site are likely to want to see Brent council's development plan for the area before committing to the sale. The plan is due to be published in November.

The site is valued at £50m in Wembley's accounts, but could fetch double that amount if the prospects for redevelopment remain favourable. Possible buyers include Lend Lease, the Australian firm behind Bluewater Park shopping centre, and British Land.

Peter Joseph, an analyst at broker Peel Hunt, said: "The only reason for getting rid of the brand name is if the company can get more from it by selling it."

The company yesterday posted pre-tax profits for 2000 of £32m - a 20% increase on the previous year - on a turnover of £115m.

webTitle: Comment, Martin Woollacott: the countryside's crisis

fields.headline: Farmers learn the lie of the land
fields.standfirst:
Recent crises in agriculture are driving the young from the fields

Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: The agricultural crises of recent years do, alas, show the town leading the farmer by the nose.
fields.body:
Never tell the farmer how good his pears are with his cheese is an Italian saying which nicely parodies the townsman's notion that the farmer can easily be duped, even about the things he knows best. Yet the agricultural crises of recent years do, alas, show the town leading the farmer by the nose - into greater debt, into greater reliance on machinery and chemicals, into greater dependence on distant markets, and, as we have just learned once again, into greater vulnerability to plant and livestock disease.

The resulting changes threaten not only the supply of healthy food but the essential character of our societies, shaped as they have been since the Greeks by the wisdom, experience, and political style of farmers. "There is something sweet in the bitterness of farming," the Greek playwright Menander wrote, touching on that mixture of discipline and fatalism, of acceptance of misfortune tempered by an ever renewed optimism, of respect for the land and a determination to bend it to human needs that farming at its best brings to a civilisation.

But, in an extraordinary process that was at first imperceptible and then moved with bewildering speed, the agricultural tradition in the developed world has been jolted and battered in the past 50 years as in no other period in history. Some would say it is close to extinction.

The Dutch journalist Geert Mak, in his sad and eloquent account of the decline of the Frisian village of Jorwerd, muses on "four remarkable decades in which all the farm hands and the milkmaids had suddenly disappeared from the farmyard; in which, after thousands of years, the cooperation between man and beast was severed by the arrival of the tractor; in which the interests of agriculture were superseded by other interests; in which the dynamism of the village melted away..."

The European Union, founded in part to protect small farmers as well as workers in the basic heavy industries of coal and steel, has ironically succeeded in turning both groups into threatened and ever smaller minorities. That is what connects the disasters of BSE and foot and mouth disease with the disaster of the Newport closure. But if the old kind of industrial worker has his back to the wall, the farmer is an even worse case. EU figures suggest that half of north European agriculture will disappear within a generation. As is well known, farmers are leaving the land in unprecedented numbers.

It is worth remembering, when considering these statistics that, as Mak says: "Almost every farmer who stops feels that he has failed." He has an account of one farmer standing up at a meeting which was being addressed by the Dutch minister of agriculture and saying: "I am going to have to stop, because I just can't make ends meet." "That is good," the minister replied, "that will give us more space. Next question." In Sussex country pubs, men talk of a plot to concentrate farming in eastern Europe and northern France and a few other places, while England's land will go to more and more housing. Looking at some of John Prescott's plans, one can hardly blame them.

In the town of Leeuwarden a sculpture of a black and white Frisian cow was erected in the 50s. It was named "Us Mem" - "Our Mother" - in honour of the animal upon whom the prosperity of the province had long depended. But the Netherlands at the turn of the new century, as Mak pictures it, is a place where small farmers can no longer afford to keep cows. At night, illegal loads of milk and manure clank down country roads, as those larger farmers who can still afford to keep cows, "rearrange" their quotas. In charting the recent history of his adopted village - the end of many of its farms, the disappearance of its shops, the migration of its young people - Mak notes a process "reminiscent of the way ghettos are formed in cities", in which the proportion of unemployed, illpaid, elderly, and disabled gradually creeps up.

Similar studies have shown the same process of decline at work all across western Europe, even if moving at a different pace in different places. Most countries have programmes to deal with these problems, like that recently proposed by the British government. Too often the result is a mixture of acceptable welfare measures and schemes for rural development which, as Mak says, have something of "a whiff" about them. They are rarely aimed at restoring the primacy of agriculture in communities whose tone was once set by farmers, whose calendar was that of the farming year, and whose reason for being was summed up by symbols like "Us Mem". Eastern Europe may appear to be in a different position, but that is not likely to remain the case. Timothy Garton Ash, in one of his reports from Poland before the changes, described a peasant farmer showing off his pigs and then adding with grim satisfaction that not one kilo of his pork would ever go to the communists. But the tradition of small farming that resisted the old ideology so stoutly may not fare so well under the new one. The future of east European farmers may be to benefit for some years from access to, and then incorporation in the union, only to suffer the same fate, in the end, as farmers in western Europe.

What is at risk here is not just what does or does not get on to our plates or what happens to hedgerows and songbirds. The American farmer and classicist Victor Hanson, writing in a California where there are three times as many people on food stamps as there are farmers, wonders: "My fear is not whether we will have a sizable presence of family farmers but whether we are to have any farmers at all!" If that happens, he continues, " where will be the needed counterpoint?...What other profession is there now ... where the individual fights against nature, lives where he works, invests hourly for the future and never for the mere present, succeeds or fails by his own intellect, physical strength, bodily endurance, and sheer nerve?" Some of today's harassed and slovenly farmers may not well fit this portrait, but it remains true of the best, and it remains true that this farming experience is, as Hanson says, a "needed counterpoint" to less grounded kinds of work and thinking.

The English word "landscape", Mak says, comes from the Dutch word lanschap, implying something shaped but not made by man and thus carrying within it an inherent notion of limits. Describing the sky over around Jorwerd, he writes: "The light above this flatness determines everything. It is eternal and ever changing, it sets the colour of each day, it threatens and consoles, it frightens and pleases." Unfortunately, it is a light not as often seen in the Hague, in Amsterdam, in London, in Paris or in Brussels as it is in Jorwerd.

 Jorwerd by Geert Mak, the Harvill Press; The Other Greeks by Victor Davis Hanson, the Free Press.

webTitle: Body blow to two regional theatres

fields.headline: Body blow to two regional theatres
fields.standfirst: Tough line from minister as he insists status quo is no longer an option  Director quits in frustration over 'endless second-guessing'
fields.trailText: Two regional theatres are in effect being condemned to a slow death, and a third is having its budget cut in real terms, despite the government's much-hyped £70m rejuvenation of live drama, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
Two regional theatres are in effect being condemned to a slow death, and a third is having its budget cut in real terms, despite the government's much-hyped £70m rejuvenation of live drama, the Guardian has learned.

The Swan theatre in Worcester, which gets little or no help from its local council, and the trouble-hit Gateway in Chester will only get standstill funding next year when the first £15m slice of the windfall secured by the culture secretary, Chris Smith, is due to kick in.

The revelation comes as Mr Smith, in a hardline speech, warned that theatre must reinvent itself to survive. "The status quo is no longer an option," he told the Theatre 2001 conference in London yesterday, stressing that attitudes must change too, and not all of the problems were financial.

The Theatre Royal in York - already reeling from November's floods - will only get a 1% rise, a blow given the acclaim its adaptation of Kate Atkinson's Whitbread-winning novel, Behind the Scenes at the Museum, set in York, attracted.

Last night its executive director, Elizabeth Jones, who brought the theatre back from the brink of closure and cleared its debts during her 10 years in charge, said she was now stepping down in frustration.

She blamed the strain of having "to try to meet and second-guess the ever-changing targets that the funding systems require. It is very, very hard to be adventurous and developmental without risking the strength and stability we have worked so hard to achieve".

The leaks, a week before the arts council is to announce the results of its radical review of theatre funding, has raised fears that the "big 10" regional producing houses will win out at the cost of smaller theatres.

Last month there was dismay when it became clear that the arts council intended to spent the money recommended by the Boyden report into the problems of regional producing theatres on the "wider theatre ecology" rather than just the reps.

However, the arts council chairman Gerry Robinson assured them that regional theatre would get the "lion's share" of the cash.

An arts council spokesman yesterday refused confirm or deny that some theatres would lose out on the bonanza intended to make up for two decades of chronic underfunding.

"Next week will announce huge increases in funding for a great many threatres and companies, and over 270 will get increases in their funding. More than 170 of those will be getting increase in excess of 25%, so the outcome will be more productions across a wider area of England.

"The extra £12m for theatres in 2002, and the £25m a year from 2003 was always intended to support the wider theatre sector, not just building-based threatres, and was always going to be about change and innovation to support those organisations that are doing new and exciting things."

Mr Smith, in his speech to theatre managers and producers, acknowledged that while the recent past has meant surviving rather than thriving, the extra money he had set aside would not solve all their problems. "The status quo is no longer an option," he said. "It will need a significant change in attitudes and practices, and greater collaboration across the theatre sector, including commercial theatre ... if a vibrant, accessible sector is to created and maintained".

His comment came after Sir Richard Eyre, former head of the National Theatre, urged the arts council to encourage impresarios and not the plethora of "arts managers, planning executives, development managers or project co-ordinators" which had proliferated as subsidy dwindled.

Calling for root-and-branch reform of the way theatre is regarded and funded, he challenged the government to help make tickets as cheap as those for the cinema and to push theatre in the schools.

But if theatre was to shake off the tag of being "the cricket of the performing arts - meaning archaic, quaint, thinly attended, and not done as well as it used to be" - artistic directors should be given index-linked funding for four years.

Sir Richard admitted that theatre could sometimes be "head-burningly, ball-breakingly, bowel-churningly bad. But it can make you elated when it's good, and in an age that seeks to make all experience virtual, there's a powerful case for an art form which can never dissolve the scale of the human figure, the sound of the human voice, and our desire to tell each other stories."

webTitle: Nurses head for first union action

fields.headline: Nurses head for first union action
fields.trailText: The Royal College of Nursing was last night heading for its first industrial action after staff at the John Radcliffe hospital in Oxford said overcrowding of the accident and emergency department was putting patients' lives at risk.
fields.body:
The Royal College of Nursing was last night heading for its first industrial action after staff at the John Radcliffe hospital in Oxford said overcrowding of the accident and emergency department was putting patients' lives at risk.

A union committee agreed to recommend a ballot of the 70 nurses working in the unit. Industrial action could include working to rule, a ban on overtime or refusing to treat patients in places nurses consider unsuitable.

The full RCN council is expected to support the proposal within the next 10 days. If the hospital does not move quickly to solve the problem, it could be the first to be targeted since the RCN changed its rules in 1995 to permit limited industrial action that did not affect patient care.

Patricia Marquis, the union's regional officer, said: "For several years, conditions have become more and more difficult [at John Radcliffe]. There have been increasing numbers of patients and, partly because of the nurse shortages, fewer beds."

It was common for every corridor to be full of people waiting on trolleys, but the overcrowding reached crisis proportions 10 days ago when the unit held three times the approved maximum number of patients. "This means the nurses cannot give patients the best care, or even privacy and dignity, and safety is being compromised."

Last year the nurses made a formal complaint to the trust management and a panel upheld their complaints, Ms Marquis said. But an action plan was not fully implemented and problems continued. "The nurses are at the end of their tether and now feel this ballot is their only course," Ms Marquis said.

David Highton, the hospital's chief executive, said: "I understand the frustrations of our accident and emergency staff and am deeply concerned about the difficulties they face.

"It is no great secret that the emergency care system in Oxfordshire has been very stretched recently.

"I will continue to talk to the RCN and to our own staff about how we can work together to relieve some of the pressures and improve the system as a whole."

The hospital serves more than 600,000 people in the Oxford area. A report last year on its heart unit criticised a "culture of cronyism" that left the centre in chaos. Personality clashes between doctors left the unit "on its knees" and threatened its future, the report said.

webTitle: New doubts cast on Chinook crash cause

fields.headline: New doubts cast on Chinook crash cause
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence was aware that technical problems with the helicopter type involved in the RAF's worst peacetime accident could have endangered aircraft safety, two leaked documents reveal.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence was aware that technical problems with the helicopter type involved in the RAF's worst peacetime accident could have endangered aircraft safety, two leaked documents reveal.

Ministers now face fresh accusations that, albeit inadvertently, they misled MPs over the crash of the Chinook helicopter on the Mull of Kintyre in June 1994. Four aircrew and 25 senior members of the Northern Ireland anti-terrorism community were killed in Chinook Zulu Delta 576 on their way to a high-level security conference near Inverness.

Two air marshals blamed the experienced special forces pilots, Flight Lieutenants Jonathan Tapper and Rick Cook - finding them guilty of gross negligence.

Since then, ministers and officials have doggedly stuck by the line that a catalogue of technical problems in the newly-upgraded Chinook fleet were "trivial" and could not have endangered an aircraft.

But the latest leaked documents, obtained by Computer Weekly magazine and passed to the Guardian, contradict this claim.

One, dated 1997, stated explicitly that one of the problems - the computerised engine control system misinterpreting an air pressure signal and limiting the engine power available - could have jeopardised an aircraft.

The second leaked document referred to upgrades to the control system carried out in late 1994 - within months of the ZD576 crash - to correct nine software anomolies.

In August 1999, the armed forces ministers, John Spellar, listed the modifications in reply to a parliamentary question from Desmond Swayne, Tory MP for New Forest West.

Last night, Mr Swayne said he was "outraged" by the new evidence. He is considering raising a point of order on the floor of the Commons to establish whether he was misled.

On Monday, the Lords is to vote on a motion by the former Labour foreign affairs minister, Lord Chalfont, to set up a select committee to investigate the crash.

The MoD repeated its insistence that the Chinook fleet's technical problems were trivial.
