Ministers now face fresh accusations that, albeit inadvertently, they misled MPs over the crash of the Chinook helicopter on the Mull of Kintyre in June 1994. Four aircrew and 25 senior members of the Northern Ireland anti-terrorism community were killed in Chinook Zulu Delta 576 on their way to a high-level security conference near Inverness. Two air marshals blamed the experienced special forces pilots, Flight Lieutenants Jonathan Tapper and Rick Cook - finding them guilty of gross negligence. Since then, ministers and officials have doggedly stuck by the line that a catalogue of technical problems in the newly-upgraded Chinook fleet were "trivial" and could not have endangered an aircraft. But the latest leaked documents, obtained by Computer Weekly magazine and passed to the Guardian, contradict this claim. One, dated 1997, stated explicitly that one of the problems - the computerised engine control system misinterpreting an air pressure signal and limiting the engine power available - could have jeopardised an aircraft. The second leaked document referred to upgrades to the control system carried out in late 1994 - within months of the ZD576 crash - to correct nine software anomolies. In August 1999, the armed forces ministers, John Spellar, listed the modifications in reply to a parliamentary question from Desmond Swayne, Tory MP for New Forest West. Last night, Mr Swayne said he was "outraged" by the new evidence. He is considering raising a point of order on the floor of the Commons to establish whether he was misled. On Monday, the Lords is to vote on a motion by the former Labour foreign affairs minister, Lord Chalfont, to set up a select committee to investigate the crash. The MoD repeated its insistence that the Chinook fleet's technical problems were trivial.

fields.headline: 'Saddam spies' arrested
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Two Iraqis suspected of spying were last night being held in a German jail after reportedly being caught near the United State's army headquarters in Europe.
fields.body:
Two Iraqis suspected of spying were last night being held in a German jail after reportedly being caught near the United State's army headquarters in Europe.

Their arrests raised fears that Baghdad might be planning to make good on Saddam Hussein's threat earlier this week to retaliate against US and British air strikes which killed two civilians on February 16.

German police and intelligence officers are hunting for other members of a spy ring which is thought to have been cracked.

The two Iraqis were picked up by police on the orders of Germany's chief prosecutor, Kay Nehm. A brief statement from his office said that one of the suspected agents was detained on Sunday and the other on Tuesday.

"They are suspected of carrying out missions for an Iraqi intelligence service in a number of German towns since the beginning of 2001," a statement said.

A federal judge ordered the two men to be held on "urgent suspicion" of espionage.

A spokesman for the federal prosecutors would not comment on a television report that the Iraqis had been held in the south-western university town of Heidelberg, which houses the headquarters of the US army in Europe.

webTitle: Labour ignoring north-south divide, says MP

fields.headline: Labour ignoring north-south divide, says MP
fields.standfirst: Regeneration
fields.trailText: A former Labour defence minister last night accused the government of advancing a regional development policy akin to a local raj, imposing Whitehall's will. Peter Kilfoyle, the MP for Liverpool Walton, told a Guardian North debate that Whitehall saw the regions through a departmental prism.
fields.body:
A former Labour defence minister last night accused the government of advancing a regional development policy akin to a local raj, imposing Whitehall's will. Peter Kilfoyle, the MP for Liverpool Walton, told a Guardian North debate that Whitehall saw the regions through a departmental prism.

Pockets of extreme deprivation and unemployment continued to separate the north from the south, despite the hundreds of millions of pounds spent on renewal schemes. The only way to stop them was with regional devolution.

Speaking in Salford at the debate, The Regeneration Game: Are Northern Cities Losing Out? he said: "I view the government officers as local raj set out to impose Whitehall's will. They have departmental agendas.

"They do not look holistically at the region. The government has to develop policies with local people. It has to establish local ownership of these projects." Tenants associations might have better ideas for their development than civil servants.

A report commissioned by the Guardian this week found economic divisions between north and south had widened over the past four years and showed little sign of narrowing despite government money on urban schemes.

Brian Robson, head of the centre for urban policy at Manchester University and a government adviser who wrote the report, highlighted the extent of deprivation on Humberside and in the north-west.

"There have been dramatic changes in the centre of Manchester and Liverpool but unless we bridge the gulf between the centres of cities and the doughnut ring of deprivation around the edge, we haven't solved the problem."

Tom Bloxham, whose Urban Splash group, has made millions by renovating decaying areas of Manchester and Liverpool, said money from central urban development had not reached the peripheries of the cities.

Anthony Wilson, founder of Factory Records and the Hacienda club, said the success of French cities like Lille proved regional cities could be regenerated with devolved government.

fields.headline: Survivors relive last desperate hours as 58 illegal immigrants suffocated around them
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: The two survivors of the Dover lorry tragedy in which 58 Chinese illegal immigrants died spoke yesterday for the first time of the panic that gripped the 60 people packed into the airtight container as they began to suffocate.
fields.body:
The two survivors of the Dover lorry tragedy in which 58 Chinese illegal immigrants died spoke yesterday for the first time of the panic that gripped the 60 people packed into the airtight container as they began to suffocate.

Speaking on the fourth day of the trial of Perry Wacker, a Dutch lorry driver charged with 58 counts of manslaughter and conspiracy to smuggle illegal immigrants, Ke Su Di and Ke Shi Guang, the only survivors of the doomed human cargo, described the scenes in the lorry.

Wacker, 32, and a translator, Ying Guo, 29, of South Woodford, London, who is charged with conspiracy to facilitate the entry of illegal immigrants, deny the charges.

The survivors, who are under police protection, told how a vent, the only source of oxygen, was closed before the lorry boarded a Zeebrugge to Dover ferry last year.

Speaking behind a screen and through an interpreter, Ke Shi Guang, 22, broke down as he described how they pounded the side of the lorry and screamed for help as they gasped for breath.

"Did there come a time when those in the container started to become distressed?" he was asked by Victor Temple QC for the Crown.

"Yes."

"Others were having great difficulty breathing?"

"Yes."

"Did all of you bang on the side of the container, shout and ask for help?"

"Yes," he said, sobbing.

Ke Su Di, 20, told the court that within two or three hours of the vent being closed some people began to pass out in the darkness.

"People began to panic because the window was shut and there was no air," he said.

He had been one of the last people loaded on to the lorry in the Netherlands and so was close to the load of tomatoes used to conceal their presence at the back of the container.

"I wanted to breathe air so I got close to the tomatoes but I do not think they were any use."

He said other people in the container also tried getting close to the tomatoes, but when this did not work everyone started screaming and shouting for help.

"Some people removed tomatoes and wanted to kick open the doors.

"There was also a lot of shouting and screaming but nobody came to help."

He passed out and the next thing he recalled was being dragged from the lorry at Dover by customs officials around four hours later.

Both survivors had paid up to 230,000RMB (£20,000) to a Snakehead gang to be transported to Britain. On June 18 they began the final leg of their journey.

The group of 60 gathered at a warehouse in Rotterdam after spending around three days in two safe houses in the city. They were driven in two small vans, one resembling an ambulance, which had the windows blacked out with paper.

The group were loaded aboard the lorry and four containers of water were passed up to them. The tomatoes were then loaded and the doors sealed.

The group had been told that at some point on the journey the air vent would be closed to prevent them being heard by customs or police, the jury at Maidstone crown court was told.

"We were told if this window is open you can speak in very low voices, but if it is closed then you do not speak."

Both survivors were carrying a piece of paper bearing Ms Ying's name and her telephone number. A man in the warehouse told the group that she was the person to contact when they got to the UK.

"He said everyone should write down this telephone number and we all took down the number. He said if you were arrested over there [the UK] you call this number. This person will come to bail you," Ke Shi Guang said.

Ke Su Di told the court that his journey to Britain had begun 11 days previously on June 7 when he travelled to Beijing from his home province of Fujian and boarded a plane bound for Moscow.

His parents paid a local Snakehead gang a downpayment of 10,000RMB, the equivalent of 10 months' pay. The remaining payment of 220,000RMB was payable on his arrival in the UK. If it was not made, the court heard, he would be locked up by the Snakeheads and retribution would follow.

"If the money was not paid then I'm in the hands of the Snakeheads, I'm the one in real danger," he said.

He had been told to wear a grey t-shirt and black trousers so the Snakeheads would recognise him, and was given a code number to prevent the wrong Snakehead gang picking him up. He met Ke Shi Guang when he picked up his passport and they started the journey together.

Travelling with a group of 15 others and a Snakehead minder they flew on to Yugoslavia from Moscow and then passed into Hungary by road and on foot. The group then moved through Austria to France where they caught a train to Rotterdam. Ke Su Di said he travelled for the first part of the journey on his own passport and therefore did not think he was acting illegally. When he arrived in Hungary this passport was taken from him and replaced with a forged Korean passport which was taken away when he got to the Netherlands.

Both men attempted to describe the men who loaded the lorry at the Rotterdam warehouse but struggled because they were not familiar with seeing foreigners.

The court heard that Ke Su Di's application for political asylum had been refused, but when he agreed to give evidence he was granted exceptional leave to remain for the next four years by the home secretary, Jack Straw.

fields.headline: West's lure
fields.standfirst:
Dreams of money and freedom

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: The two men dragged barely alive from Perry Wacker's lorry at Dover last June were tempted to the west by the promise of high wages and the prospect of religious freedom, Maidstone crown court was told.
fields.body:
The two men dragged barely alive from Perry Wacker's lorry at Dover last June were tempted to the west by the promise of high wages and the prospect of religious freedom, Maidstone crown court was told.

Ke Su Di, 20, earned the equivalent of between £50 and £70 a month working as a delivery driver in his home village in the rural province of Fujian, and his father earned just a little more to support his wife and two other children.

"In China life is not too good," Mr Ke said. "I didn't have a good life at home and the Snakehead [gang member] told me there would not be any risk.

"He told me we would travel by air."

Many people in his village wanted to come to the UK because of the hardship and lack of religious freedom in China, the court heard.

He said some of his friends belonged to the Falun Gong sect, which is outlawed by Beijing and its members subject to persecution.

Everyone knew that it was possible to get to the UK as long as you could meet the Snakeheads' price, he said.

"They [the Snakeheads] helped us to arrive in England, then we paid them. They help these people who want to go abroad to go abroad. Then you pay them for their service."

The full cost could be as much as 10 years' wages. He said his parents had spent all their savings and borrowed more money to pay for his passage.

Ke Shi Guang said everyone in the village knew the local Snakehead who could arrange passage."He was known as the little Snakehead," he said.

The attraction of Europe was simple: "You can get salaries there."

The Dover disaster has not tarnished the lustre of the west. Ke Su Di said he had tried to persuade his aunt to tell her eldest son, who is considering coming to Britain, to come only by air.

Even now Snakeheads want the full payment from his family. He has asked them to say he is dead in an attempt to help them avoid having to meet the debt.

webTitle: Abuse claim in internet twins case

fields.headline: Abuse claim in internet twins case
fields.standfirst:
Man who first adopted girls accused in US of molesting babysitters

Special report: babies for sale
fields.trailText: The American husband of one of the couples caught up in the battle for custody of eight-month-old twin girls adopted over the internet has been arrested after claims that he sexually abused two teenagers.
fields.body:
The American husband of one of the couples caught up in the battle for custody of eight-month-old twin girls adopted over the internet has been arrested after claims that he sexually abused two teenagers.

Richard Allen, who originally adopted the babies with his wife Vickie, has been detained by police in southern California amid claims that he molested two babysitters at his family's home in Highland.

A hearing will take place at the San Bernardino county district attorney's office today. A spokesman for the sheriff's department said Mr Allen, 49, a father of one, had been charged with lewd and lascivious behaviour towards two minors.

"It was learned the incident occurred in November 2000 at Allen's home when the [13-year-old] victim babysat for the Allens," said the police spokesman. "As a result of investigative interviews, detectives learned of a second female victim aged 14. The second female had been sexually molested by Allen.

"He was arrested at his home on February 28 at 3.53pm and was subsequently booked into the West Valley detention centre. Bail is set at $100,000."

The 13-year-old is believed to have contacted police with a complaint against Mr Allen on February 20. Investigators then questioned her 14-year-old sister, who had also babysat for the Allens.

The Allens paid £4,000 to adopt the twin baby girls late last year, but after two months of caring for them they were tricked into handing them back to their natural mother, Tranda Wecker, for an access visit.

Ms Wecker gave the babies to Tina Johnson, an adoption broker from the Caring Heart adoption agency. They were then adopted by a second couple - Judith and Alan Kilshaw from north Wales, who paid £8,200 for them.

The Kilshaws named the babies Belinda and Kimberley and brought them home to the UK. The twins travelled to the country as visitors on American passports.

After the Kilshaws became caught up in a media circus in January, social workers in Flintshire took the twins into custody and a judge later ruled that they should remain in the care of the local authority while the courts were considering the case.

Lawyers acting for the Allens served a writ on the Kilshaws shortly after they appeared on the Oprah Winfrey show in Chicago last month. The writ claimed the twins had been abducted from them and alleged that the Kilshaws had deceived officials in Britain and America.

Mr Allen's arrest comes a week after police in north Wales questioned Mrs Kilshaw on suspicion of stealing travellers' cheques before she travelled to America to adopt the babies. She has been released without charge.

Yesterday the Kilshaws could barely contain their delight after learning of Mr Allen's arrest.

Mr Kilshaw said he was surprised and disgusted by the allegations, but emphasised that nothing had been proven. "I would hope that people will now take a very serious look at these charges," he said. "Obviously this reflects on their ability to provide a home for the children."

He said the doubts that were beginning to emerge about the Allens proved that Ms Wecker had been right to take the twins away from the couple.

webTitle: Fiji regime is illegal, says court after battle of QCs

fields.headline: Fiji regime is illegal, says court after battle of QCs
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Fiji coup
fields.trailText: The Fiji court of appeal yesterday declared that the South Pacific nation's military-backed government illegal, after a court battle which pitted two of Britain's leading human rights lawyers against each other.
fields.byline: Clare Dyer in London and  Patrick Barkham in Sydney
fields.body:
The Fiji court of appeal yesterday declared that the South Pacific nation's military-backed government illegal, after a court battle which pitted two of Britain's leading human rights lawyers against each other.

Nicholas Blake QC, who is, with Cherie Booth QC, a founder member of the Matrix chambers which specialises in human rights cases, drew media fire for taking a fee to represent the interim regime, installed after a coup.

The democratically elected government of Mahendra Chaudhry, Fiji's first ethnic Indian prime minister, was overturned last May.

Geoffrey Robertson QC, from the rival Doughty Street chambers, acted free of charge on behalf of Chandrika Prasad, an ethnic Indian peasant farmer challenging the legality of the regime.

Mr Blake, who has an impeccable record defending vulnerable groups like asylum seekers against the state, yesterday accused his critics of misunderstanding the issues.

He said his clients had promised before the appeal was heard that they would abide by the result, and the legal process in which he had played a part had hastened the likely return of democracy to Fiji, through fresh elections.

Both Ratu Josefa Iloilo, the acting president, and Laisenia Qarase, the interim prime minister, made public pledges to work towards a return to constitutional rule after the judgment.

"Let us proceed to deal calmly and quietly with the court's decision," Mr Iloilo said in a televised address. Mr Qarase appealed for "time and space" in which to manage the "delicate" transition.The military also promised to uphold the court's judgment.

The court of five senior Commonwealth judges instructed Mr Iloilo to recall the parliament toppled in the coup led by the Fijian nationalist George Speight. But the president, who must stand down by 15 March, can also dissolve that parliament and call new elections under the 1997 constitution.

If the parliament is recalled then swiftly dismissed by the president, observers believe that Mr Qarase's government will continue, with the inclusion of some new faces to give it an appearance of national unity, until a general election is held.

Mr Chaudhry, who was held hostage by Mr Speight for 56 days and deposed by the military's declaration of martial law, yesterday declared he was still the prime minister of Fiji. Mr Chaudhry, now in exile, will return to the Fijian capital Suva by the weekend, but analysts said he lacked support within his party for a return to power.

The 1997 constitution allows for the creation of a government of national unity, with all parties commanding more than 10% support entitled to join the cabinet.

Mr Chaudhry has said he would not serve with any politicians linked to the coup, ruling out his participation in any national coalition.

The 1997 constitution gave ethnic Indians the same political rights as Fijians. Most ethnic Indians, who constitute 44% of the islands' 800,000 population, are descendants of the sugar plantation workers who arrived in the late 19th century.

Conflict between the two groups triggered two coups in 1987, when an Indian-dominated government was ousted.

Land ownership has proved an increasingly contentious issue. Native Fijians own 83% of all land in Fiji and in the last three years have moved to evict ethnic Indians, who previously worked cane plantations under relatively secure 30-year leases.

Mr Blake, clearly stung by press criticism of his role in the case, said the regime should be given credit for bringing the appeal and promising to abide by the judges' ruling.

He added: "The government was entitled to seek legal advice from lawyers outside Fiji on the constitutional and human rights implications of its proposals. To participate in this process on behalf of the interim civilian administration was not dishonourable or reprehensible.

"It is never healthy for the rule of law for lawyers to be criticised for doing their job: whether on the grounds of a supposed identity of interest between the aims of advocate and client, or the alternative suggestion currently promoted by the home secretary that lawyers are only interested in earning huge fees without any sense of social responsibility.

"Either approach serves to undermine the principle that the client has a right to representation, however unpopular or unattractive the cause may appear to be. Rumours of a six-figure brief fee are an absurd exaggeration."

The democratically elected government of Mahendra Chaudhry, Fiji's first ethnic Indian prime minister, was overturned last May. Mr Blake, who has an impeccable record defending vulnerable groups like asylum seekers against the state, yesterday accused his critics of misunderstanding the issues. He said his clients had promised before the appeal was heard that they would abide by the result, and the legal process in which he had played a part had hastened the likely return of democracy to Fiji, through fresh elections. Both Ratu Josefa Iloilo, the acting president, and Laisenia Qarase, the interim prime minister, made public pledges to work towards a return to constitutional rule after the judgment. "Let us proceed to deal calmly and quietly with the court's decision," Mr Iloilo said in a televised address. Mr Qarase appealed for "time and space" in which to manage the "delicate" transition.The military also promised to uphold the court's judgment. The court of five senior Commonwealth judges instructed Mr Iloilo to recall the parliament toppled in the coup led by the Fijian nationalist George Speight. But the president, who must stand down by 15 March, can also dissolve that parliament and call new elections under the 1997 constitution. If the parliament is recalled then swiftly dismissed by the president, observers believe that Mr Qarase's government will continue, with the inclusion of some new faces to give it an appearance of national unity, until a general election is held. Mr Chaudhry, who was held hostage by Mr Speight for 56 days and deposed by the military's declaration of martial law, yesterday declared he was still the prime minister of Fiji. Mr Chaudhry, now in exile, will return to the Fijian capital Suva by the weekend, but analysts said he lacked support within his party for a return to power. The 1997 constitution allows for the creation of a government of national unity, with all parties commanding more than 10% support entitled to join the cabinet. Mr Chaudhry has said he would not serve with any politicians linked to the coup, ruling out his participation in any national coalition. The 1997 constitution gave ethnic Indians the same political rights as Fijians. Most ethnic Indians, who constitute 44% of the islands' 800,000 population, are descendants of the sugar plantation workers who arrived in the late 19th century. Conflict between the two groups triggered two coups in 1987, when an Indian-dominated government was ousted. Land ownership has proved an increasingly contentious issue. Native Fijians own 83% of all land in Fiji and in the last three years have moved to evict ethnic Indians, who previously worked cane plantations under relatively secure 30-year leases. Mr Blake, clearly stung by press criticism of his role in the case, said the regime should be given credit for bringing the appeal and promising to abide by the judges' ruling. He added: "The government was entitled to seek legal advice from lawyers outside Fiji on the constitutional and human rights implications of its proposals. To participate in this process on behalf of the interim civilian administration was not dishonourable or reprehensible. "It is never healthy for the rule of law for lawyers to be criticised for doing their job: whether on the grounds of a supposed identity of interest between the aims of advocate and client, or the alternative suggestion currently promoted by the home secretary that lawyers are only interested in earning huge fees without any sense of social responsibility. "Either approach serves to undermine the principle that the client has a right to representation, however unpopular or unattractive the cause may appear to be. Rumours of a six-figure brief fee are an absurd exaggeration."

fields.headline: 'Today it's me, tomorrow it's you'
fields.standfirst:
Bomb blast rocks Galilee as Sharon puts finishing touches to coalition government

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Bomb blast rocks Galilee as Sharon puts finishing touches to coalition government
fields.body:
A taxi van that had unwittingly carried a Palestinian bomber and his lethal cargo of explosives across a swath of Israel blew up at a road block in Galilee yesterday, killing one person and injuring nine.

Israeli television said the taxi had been boarded by at least one Palestinian bomber near Tel Aviv, and that its other passengers - who were Jews as well as Arabs - had no idea they were riding alongside a 2kg bomb.

It was not immediately clear whether the dead man was one of the bombers.

Police said they had been hunting a Palestinian militant cell for 24 hours, after sappers defused an explosive device planted on a busy street in central Tel Aviv.

The bomb, like yesterday's, was designed to be detonated by a mobile phone.

The bomber is believed to have detonated yesterday's bomb after the taxi was pulled over at a roadblock near the Arab town of Umm al-Fahim in northern Galilee.

The force of the blast blew the roof off the white taxi van and shattered the windscreens of passing vehicles.

It also sheared the legs off one suspected militant, who police said was a Palestinian man from the town of Jenin, in the West Bank. He had confessed to plotting Wednesday's thwarted attack, police said, which was claimed by the previously unknown group, called the "Return Brigades".

"I heard a loud explosion .. I saw body parts, someone's hand," David Grosser, a lorry driver at the scene, said.

"Everyone was in shock. I cried myself for half an hour. Today it's me, tomorrow it's you."

No one claimed responsibility for the blast, but as in past attacks inside the borders of the Jewish state during this five-month Palestinian uprising, Israeli officials accused Yasser Arafat of indirect responsibility.

The outgoing deputy defence minister, Efraim Sneh, said Mr Arafat's Palestinian Authority had failed to rein in Islamic Jihad militants, who have claimed some of the bombings during the past five months, or Hamas.

"As long as activists of Hamas and the Jihad are walking around free in the West Bank and Gaza, the responsibility is on those who let them walk around freely," Mr Sneh said. "We see the Palestinian Authority as responsible for the situation."

Yesterday's attack comes as Israel's hardline prime minister-elect, Ariel Sharon, enters the final stages of assembling a national unity government which is expected to act even more harshly against the Palestinian uprising.

In recent days, Mr Sharon's advisers have called for an acceleration of the assassination of Palestinian leaders, and for deepening the siege on the West Bank and Gaza. Their demands grew even more strident yesterday.

"We can not talk English here, this is the Middle East," said Meir Sheetrit, a senior leader of Mr Sharon's Likud party, yesterday. "Here we have to talk Arabic."

On Wednesday, Israel's army chief, Shaul Mofaz, said the military would even consider reoccupying the areas of the West Bank and Gaza now under Palestinian rule.

Gen Mofaz's statements to visiting Jewish leaders met an angry response from Palestinian security officials yesterday.

"He should know that the worst kind of terrorism and violence is the occupation," said Jibril Rajoub, the leader of the Palestinian security apparatus in the West Bank.

webTitle: Farms crisis will not delay election

fields.headline: Farms crisis will not delay election - Blair
fields.standfirst:
Special report: election countdown
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is determined not to be thwarted in his plans to stage the general election on May 3 by what ministers regard as premature and unnecessary alarm about the nationwide restrictions on movements caused by foot and mouth disease.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is determined not to be thwarted in his plans to stage the general election on May 3 by what ministers regard as premature and unnecessary alarm about the nationwide restrictions on movements caused by foot and mouth disease.

In the face of growing protests by farmers, countryside activists and MPs that the local and general elections should be postponed until the crisis is definitely over, No 10 is refusing to blink. "There are no plans to move the date of the local elections and there is no contingency planning going on," said the Downing Street spokesman Godric Smith.

Behind that decision lie two calculations. One is that, unlike in the BSE crisis, "no people are dying". The other is that electoral rules have changed to allow anyone to apply to vote by post, including farmers confined to their farms.

A week after the outbreak was confirmed in Northumberland, and rapidly spread via markets across Britain, Mr Blair's officials and ministers do not even admit that the issue is being discussed, because all efforts are being focused on containing the outbreak.

To admit contingency planning would make it harder to stick to May 3, officials admit privately, and would get William Hague off a strategic hook - one in which he constantly demands an election which he is all but universally expected to lose.

"The Tories are desperate not to have an election in May. Equally we are determined to hold it in May," insisted one Labour official. A member of the shadow cabinet confirmed that verdict. "We are pretty anxious not to have a May election," he admitted yesterday.

Nick Brown, the minister of agriculture, came as close as any insider has to admitting that events may still force a postponement. The significance of his remarks on Radio 2's Jimmy Young Show was immediately discounted by colleagues as "over-interpreted".

Mr Brown said: "MPs have made representations saying that it would be unfair to hold an election in circumstances where a part of our community is constrained from taking part. I've actually asked [them] and other political activists to stay away from farms while we get this disease under control. And clearly the implications of that are not lost on anyone."

Mr Blair's scheduled visit to a party question and answer session in the Forest of Dean in Gloucestershire had to be rerouted last night, even though the nearest outbreak of foot and mouth is 30 miles away. He was harried by pro-hunting agricultural students.

One consequence of a post ponement to June or October would be that ministers would have the time to push through the bill to ban hunting with dogs, a confrontation with the countryside lobby that most ministers are not keen to stage in the current climate.

Behind Labour's reluctance to delay the election lie partly the months of preparation focused on May 3 and the buoyant opinion polls. Until the foot and mouth outbreak Labour HQ in Millbank was gearing up for a possible April 5 poll if the prime minister so decided. That is now out of the question. The 14-day incubation period for sheep, dating from last week's ban on animal movements, expires only on March 9, though additional cases, the result of local contact or airborne viruses, may occur later.

A further three weeks must pass before the outbreak is deemed to be over and movement restrictions are lifted. Exports will be banned for six more months. But Labour planners are thinking "in people terms, not animal terms" and believe the current mood of crisis will subside. One cab inet minister insisted: "Talk of postponing the election is very premature until we get an outbreak we can't contain. And postal voting changes the rules of the game." Postal voting restrictions are now less tight with no reasons needed.

The last legal date for dissolving parliament in time for a May 3 election is April 5 after an announcement around March 30. In theory the Home Office could postpone the local elections to June 7 or 14 - and stage both polls on that date.

webTitle: Swiss confirm trail of Serbian gold

fields.headline: Swiss confirm trail of Serbian gold
fields.standfirst:
Pressure mounts on Slobodan Milosevic over his role in export from mine

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: An international legal net began closing on Slobodan Milosevic yesterday after it was confirmed that £730,000 of gold was shipped from a state-run mine in Serbia to Switzerland as the former Yugoslav leader was being toppled last year.
fields.body:
An international legal net began closing on Slobodan Milosevic yesterday after it was confirmed that £730,000 of gold was shipped from a state-run mine in Serbia to Switzerland as the former Yugoslav leader was being toppled last year.

The Swiss authorities said that import-export companies based in Greece and Cyprus exported 173kg of unrefined gold bars from the state-run Bor mines between September 21 and November 2 last year. The gold was sold to a Swiss firm for resale on the open market.

Earlier press reports had prompted Serbian prosecutors to take their first direct legal steps against Mr Milosevic on Wednesday by ordering a police inquiry into allegations that he had profited from the gold transaction.

Othmar Wyss, the head of trade sanctions at the Swiss economics ministry, admitted yesterday that it was unusual that the gold sale was not made by the Yugoslav central bank, which effectively owns the mine. "We are investigating if the Swiss company violated sanctions," he said.

The gold was checked by Swiss customs when it arrived, in Zürich in four shipments, on regular Swissair flights, and was taken to a reprocessing plant in southern Switzerland.

Mr Wyss said the exports were not illegal and the gold deal would only have fallen foul of an embargo in force in western Europe at the time if the proceeds were paid to Yugoslav state-run enterprises, including the central bank, Mr Milosevic or about 600 Serbs on a European blacklist.

No formal link has been established with the former Yugoslav regime but there are strong suspicions that Mr Milosevic and his associates used Cyprus as a base for millions siphoned from their country's economy.

About a hundred bank accounts were frozen in Switzerland last spring under the Europe-wide embargo, although none were in Mr Milosevic's name, Swiss officials said.

Greece has rejected claims that funds from the sale allegedly linked to Mr Milosevic were deposited in the country. "As far as Greece is concerned, I want to categorically refute this," foreign ministry spokesman Panagiotis Beglitis said. "All the investigations do not indicate this."

Bank accounts of people connected with the Milosevic regime containing "a very low amount of money" have already been frozen, Mr Beglitis said.

As legal moves against Mr Milosevic in Serbia gathered steam, an associate said he would ignore any summons to appear for questioning.

"Milosevic told me personally that he'll never answer to any court subpoena," Sinisa Vucinic, an official of the Yugoslav neo-communist party led by Mr Milosevic's wife, Mirjana Markovic, said.

Dozens of diehard supporters near Mr Milosevic's house in Belgrade yesterday, vowing to protect the ex-president.

"We will protect our supreme commander and hero with all available means," Mr Vucinic said. "From Kosovo alone, 50,000 rifles and heavy weapons were transferred and distributed to citizens."

The investigation ordered by the Belgrade prosecutor's office could lead to charges ranging from corruption to war crimes, but the new democratic Yugoslav government has refused to hand Mr Milosevic to the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague, claiming that the court is biased.

The US has given the new authorities in Belgrade until the end of the month to start cooperating with the war crimes tribunal, or risk losing millions of dollars in aid, as well as membership of international financial organisations.

The chief war crimes prosecutor, Carla del Ponte, said European aid to Yugoslavia should also be linked to cooperation with her court.

fields.headline: Competition forces Psion into rethink
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Psion yesterday cast a shadow over the future of its eponymous personal organiser products by announcing a radical shift in strategy which appeared to end its hopes of dominating the market for mobile internet devices.
fields.body:
Psion yesterday cast a shadow over the future of its eponymous personal organiser products by announcing a radical shift in strategy which appeared to end its hopes of dominating the market for mobile internet devices.

Shares in Psion slumped by up to 33% and closed at 115p as investors digested details of a restructuring that will lead to the merger of the handheld computer, modem and digital radio divisions and the loss of around 100 jobs.

Psion has faced increasing competition in the personal organiser market from competitors such as Palm, Handspring and Microsoft.

Chief executive David Levin said that after "a huge amount of soul searching", Psion had decided it was "a computer company, not a phone company", and would concentrate on other areas.

Last month's surprise an nouncement that mobile phone manufacturer Motorola was pulling out of the "ODIN" joint venture to build the first combined internet phone and personal organiser forced Psion to rethink its strategy.

"The result is a simplified group structure, with reduced costs and a focus on Psion Teklogix as our key operating division," said chairman David Potter. Analysts say that Teklogix - which makes wireless devices that help employees at big industrial units manage supply chains and was acquired for £250m - is a solid growth business with a strong market position.

It already accounts for around 45% of group revenues. In the year to December, Psion made a pre-tax loss of £1.4m, compared with a profit of £4.7m previously. Turnover climbed from £150m to £213m.

Psion's hopes of having an influence over the emerging market for handheld internet devices now rest on its 28% shareholding in Symbian, a joint venture with some of the world's biggest handset manufacturers to develop a new operating platform for smart mobile phones.

Dr Potter warned that the volume roll-out of devices requiring Symbian products may be slower than expected due to "handset production and wireless funding issues".

Nomura analyst Keith Woolcock said the comments made a flotation of Symbian unlikely this year and raised questions over its valuation. Symbian was said to be worth £5bn at one stage, but based on the price of Psion's shares it could now be worth less than £850m, he said.

A year ago Psion was riding high in the FTSE 100 index of Britain's biggest companies as investors bet on it cornering a big chunk of the emerging market for a new generation of personal organisers which would double as internet-enabled mobile phones.

fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Durlacher, the stockbroker that became one of the wonder stocks of the dot.com boom, yesterday underlined the dramatic change in fortunes for technology companies by confirming record losses - and as a consequence seeing its shares fall to their lowest point since June 1999.
fields.body:
Durlacher, the stockbroker that became one of the wonder stocks of the dot.com boom, yesterday underlined the dramatic change in fortunes for technology companies by confirming record losses - and as a consequence seeing its shares fall to their lowest point since June 1999.

Despite acknowledging that bleak trading conditions were likely to continue in the short-term, chief executive Geoffrey Chamberlain remained in an upbeat mood about the company's mid- to long-term prospects, and detailed figures showing a £32m improvement in the value of its portfolio of investments.

Durlacher shares have fallen 97% from the levels they rose to a year ago, and now trade at 13.75p, following a further fall in price yesterday.

In the year to December, Durlacher recorded a pre-tax loss of £13.2m due to a £13m provision it was forced to take before Christmas against investments that failed to make the grade.

Durlacher has not coordinated a stock market flotation for more than six months - the subsequent reduction in professional fees saw turnover fall from £11.6m to £6.7m. Mr Chamberlain admitted that when Durlacher shares peaked last year, the firm was "almost certainly overvalued" at £2.2bn, "but equally we've seen an excessive downward turn since," he added.

"At some stage, we'll see a more sane attitude.

"With continuing uncertainty about the health of the US economy and the growing prospect of a spring election at home, it would be unrealistic to anticipate anything other than unsettled trading conditions for some months to come," he said.

The investment portfolio of almost 30 companies has been revalued and is worth £60.7m - compared to a book value of £28.5m. Stakes in storage specialist kVault Software and media firm Popworld seem to be some of the most promising, research director Andy Bottomley said.

365 Corporation, the telecoms and content firm in which Durlacher has a 5% stake, yesterday reported revenues of £35.6m for the nine months to December 30 but a pre-tax loss of £26.7m. The shares were unchanged at 35p.

webTitle: Making a film about New York's subway dwellers

fields.headline: My seven years with the mole men
fields.standfirst: They blagged a camera, made a dolly from old track and plugged their lights right into the city's  power supply. Marc Singer reveals how he helped New York's subway dwellers make an award-winning film about life in the tunnels
fields.trailText: They blagged a camera, made a dolly from old track and plugged their lights right into the city's power supply. Marc Singer reveals how he helped New York's subway dwellers make an award-winning film about life in the tunnels
fields.body:
In the spring of 1994, I met a man by the name of John Murphy, who was homeless on the streets of New York. He would always talk about the tunnels under the city, and how he wanted to go and live down there because he was sick of the situation up top - the nights that he spent in the parks and on the pavements of the city, he would get almost no rest. The cops would wake him up and tell him to move on, or it would rain and he would get wet, or he was afraid of the kids who might come along and set him on fire, or he was afraid of losing his things to thieves. He was tired. He was tired of being tired. He told me that, in the tunnels, you could build yourself a house and have electricity. He heard that you could be left alone to be homeless in peace. But he had never gone there.

The idea of there being tunnels underneath the city where people were living fascinated me. It was deep in the realms of urban myth, and I wanted to know the reality I knew must be lurking behind it. I decided to go exploring. I went into just about every type of tunnel imaginable: train tunnels, both active and abandoned, steam tunnels, electric tunnels and subway tunnels. If there was a hole in the ground, I went into it. People would see me jumping down on the tracks and watch me disappear into the darkness.

After a month of this, I came across a long stretch of tunnel that belonged to Amtrak. It had around 100 people living in it. This tunnel was very different to the others. After stumbling around in the darkness for a bit, I decided I would come back the next day and try to get to know some of the people living there.

I never had any intention of making a film. It wasn't even my idea to do Dark Days. It really happened one night when a group of us were sitting around a fire in the tunnel. We were laughing at something that had happened that day, when one of the guys turned around and said: "Man, someone should be making a film about this." Someone laughed. "Why don't we do it?" I said. It was that simple. What I proposed is that we would make a film, sell it, and the money would get everyone out of the tunnel. I had never touched a movie camera. I had never even seen one. Asking around, it seemed that everyone in the tunnel had even less of an idea about film-making than I did. Where do you start?

The tunnel stretched more than 50 blocks, about three miles. During the day, it is very dark, as almost no daylight squeezes through the iron gratings set high in the ceiling. At night it is pitch black. I knew we would need power for the lights, if there was going to be any filming. We needed to run a lot of electric cable. Miraculously, we did manage to "find" 40 blocks' worth of the stuff in one of the many construction sites we scoured each night. Under the cover of darkness, we carried it back to the tunnel.

My electrician and chief builder was Henry. He was 62, had lived in the tunnel for five years and knew one or two things about getting by on the town's supply. With no apparent regard for the dangers of massive voltage, he prised open a largesilver box which ticked sinisterly, and set about splicing our cable into the two-inch wires that lay within. Sparks flew everywhere. Henry didn't flinch. We had tapped into the city's power.

There was a set of abandoned train tracks that lay parallel to some of the houses that were built along the tunnel. I wanted to build something to roll smoothly along the tracks holding the camera, two people and all the lights. In the business, they call it a dolly; it's big, heavy and very expensive. I mentioned this to Henry and he told me it shouldn't be too much of a problem.

The next day I woke up and stepped out of my house to clean my teeth (being in the tunnel is like camping - it is easier to spit the toothpaste on the ground outside). Looking down the track, I noticed a small fire burning in the distance. It was Henry. He had cut a few pieces of wood to length and was heating up a couple of metal rods in the fire. When the rods were red hot, he took them out and, pushing them through the wood, he burnt holes, tooling the basic components of my dolly. He then took the wheels from a shopping cart and bolted them to the base he had constructed. Within hours we were ready to roll.

We needed a camera. I had found a little yellow book that listed all the different production facilities in New York. I looked up cameras. The first place on the list was called Cinevision. Being close to my apartment, I decided to walk over there and check it out. When I walked into the place, a man came over and introduced himself as Laurie Drake. He asked me what I needed. I told him about the people I had met in the tunnel and what I wanted to do, and that I needed to get a film camera. He picked a camera out of a glass case and started to show me, step by step, how to operate it. He taught me the basics of what it would take to put an image on film, and then watched me walk out of his building dragging $40,000 worth of camera and lenses. We had only known each other for about three hours but, for some reason, Laurie trusted me and believed in what I was trying to do. I kept a Cinevision camera on and off for the next two and a half years, and I have still never seen a bill.

Back in the tunnel, everybody got given film jobs according to their area of expertise. In any group of homeless people, each one has often worked at some kind of a trade. Henry had worked on the railroad, he knew electricity, he was the builder, dolly wrangler and lighting guy. Ralph was the soundman, rigging the mike boom and so on. I started as the only one to do anything that involved the camera, but after a few weeks the crew was so good that they would ask me where I wanted to shoot that day. I would tell them. By the time I arrived, they had set up the lights, loaded the camera and would be standing around impatiently waiting to start. We all got the hang of it pretty fast.

After a while, Ralph mentioned that although we had been shooting for ages, nobody knew if we had captured a single image on film. Looking around Ralph's house I saw what he was talking about - there were cans of exposed film everywhere, people were sitting on stacks of them while they sipped their coffee. We had to bite the bullet and see what we had got.

I pulled out the yellow production guide and fingered the first lab on the list. We went over. They talked us through the steps. It was going to take a few days to process all the film, and those were anxious days. I eventually went up to screen the footage - alone, terrified we were going to have nothing. What would I tell the guys? To begin with there were muddy, underexposed images crossing the screen, then harsh overexposures. Suddenly we locked in. The pictures were clean, crisp and looked luminescent, otherworldly. It was pure jubilation. I ran back to the tunnel, shouting as I stumbled along in the darkness: "We did it! It's beautiful! We have a movie!"

I look back now and I see that that was really only the beginning. After that there were more good times and some really tough times as well. There were times when we didn't shoot film for weeks: we would regularly run out of cash, and so there was no way of buying film stock to shoot. In the beginning, I had been using credit cards, maxing out as many as they would send me. After that, I sold off all the contents of my apartment. The last thing to go was the bed. During editing, we ran out of money and couldn't touch the film for 18 months. I found myself homeless, eating out of the garbage. The process took me to places inside myself that I never knew were there.

When we sat around the fire fantasising about our movie seven years ago, we never dreamed it would travel over the ocean to the big screen in Britain. Who would have thought it? But here it is - and, from the bottom of my heart, I hope you like it.

Dark Days is released next Friday.

fields.headline: Romantic Cruz
fields.standfirst: First she was linked with Matt Damon. Then it was Nic Cage. And then it was Tom Cruise. Maybe that's why Penelope Cruz, the star of Captain Corelli's Mandolin, has decided to stay single for a while. She talks to  Sean M Smith
fields.trailText: First she was linked with Matt Damon. Then it was Nic Cage. And then it was Tom Cruise. Maybe that's why Penelope Cruz, the star of Captain Corelli's Mandolin, has decided to stay single for a while. She talks to Sean M Smith
fields.body:
I t's late July on the Cephallonia set of Captain Corelli's Mandolin, and Penelope Cruz is sitting in her trailer trying to set fire to a cigarette, with little success. She is wearing a peasant dress, her hair pinned under a matching cream scarf dappled with faded pink flowers. She's talking about Matt Damon and Ben Affleck, and the nickname they have given her, and she is laughing. "It started because Ben speaks Spanish and so does Matt," she says. "So we were talking Spanish and Ben was correcting me in Spanish. He was saying, "No, no! The word for 'problem', is not problema; it's troublé .' And I was like, 'Ben, I was born in Madrid. The word troublé does not exist.' She laughs again. "So now they call me troublé . But it fits me, also."

At 26, Cruz is poised to become one of the few European actresses since Sophia Loren - and the first Spanish actress ever - to attain enduring American stardom. The odds are stacked against this of course. Only an elite handful - Garbo, Dietrich, Bergman and Hepburn among them - have accomplished this. But if Cruz's current run of high-profile projects - Captain Corelli, the forthcoming adaptation of All the Pretty Horses, opposite Damon - she has no intention of leaving quietly. "Sometimes, somebody comes along who has such a magic, it doesn't matter if she has an accent," says Billy Bob Thornton, who directed All the Pretty Horses. "She's going to have a very, very long career. She's too strong to hold down."

When it comes to managing the ordinary details of her life, Cruz is, well, kind of a mess. "If I would have all of my papers tied up, I would get dizzy. I would throw up," she says. "But I think you find your own order in that craziness. Like, the way I travel? I don't know how I do it! I'm always late. I hear the flight is leaving, and I just sit on the floor and listen to my music." She laughs, and then shrugs. "You find your own rhythm."

It would be easy to think that this laissez-faire attitude is simply the by-product of fame. It's not difficult to operate on "your own rhythm" when an assistant packs your bags and finds your passport, when planes actually wait for you. So has she always been so... "Flaky?" suggests her agent of six years, Brandt Joel. "Always. A couple of times she was late for meetings I was taking her to. So one time I said, "I'll pick you up at one o'clock. She doesn't drive. And I picked her up at 1.30. I said, 'See how it feels?' She got it."

She is not, however, lackadaisical about her career. Hollywood didn't exactly come panting to Cruz's door. "I looked for it," she says, finally getting her cigarette lighter to work. "It was not about finishing one career (in Spain) and starting a new one. It's a continuation of what I started: to find more possibilities, more interesting characters, more stories." But the transition proved difficult. Joel says she spoke three words of English when she auditioned for the lead opposite Keanu Reaves in 1995's A Walk In The Clouds. (The role eventually went to Aitana Sanchez-Gijon). Lesson learned, she hit the books and found, oddly, that acting in a foreign language has its benefits. "It gives you an additional kind of freedom because you don't hear yourself so much," she says. "With that freedom, I can take more risks. There is not so much self-criticism, which can destroy a performance."

Cruz is the eldest of three children (her sister is 23; her brother 15), raised in a house about 15 minutes outside Madrid. Her mother ran a beauty salon. "I grew up observing women," she says, "all those different women, different attitudes, coming there to be pretty. I used to sit there and observe how they related to each other, to my mother. It was very interesting. It was like a good acting school."

Although her English has improved over the years, she still speaks in Spanish cadences, and her consonants are so soft that every word sounds whispered. "I had some very happy periods," she says. "I am happier now because I don't have so many fears. My first fear was about the devil, when I was around fire, something I saw in a movie. I think it's about pain, in whichever form it comes. I had a lot of energy as a child - sometimes too much - and I didn't know how to channel it. It was making me suffer. It was bigger than myself, and I was very young." She sighs and puts her chin in her hand. "It was a difficult time, no?"

Her parents signed her up for ballet classes when she was four. But by the time she reached early adolescence, the endless hours of being on her toes had lost their charm. "It's a very sadistic thing," she says. "You get used to bleeding and smiling at the same time." She had been studying theatre for a few years, and as the dancing faded out, acting took centre stage. Almost instantly, at 14, Cruz began working in films. "I found a lot of magic in it, a lot of order to that chaos," she says. "I felt like a child. I was completely in love with it. I still feel like that. You can always keep learning with acting, because the school is life and yourself and your friends and your relationships. I'm fascinated by it! Its infinito!"

The 1992 release of Jamon Jamon proved to be the only dark spot in her bright new world. A hypersexual hit in her native Spain, the film transformed her into a national fantasy - a tousled, naked, writhing minx. She was 17, suddenly a star, and she was scared. "There was some strong energy around me, and I didn't know how to handle it," Cruz says. And so she decided to sever the symbol of her eroticism. "I had a strong rejection of anything sexual or sensual for a while. I cut my hair very, very short. I didn't do any love scenes, not even kisses, for many years. I was told by everyone, 'You are risking your career.' But I followed my heart, and I never regret that." She sighs. "No one forced me to [make the movie]. I felt very happy doing it. But I also suffered for it."

When Cruz speaks like this, it's as if she's reliving the pain and fear. This ability to recall her emotional past imbues her acting with a raw immediacy. The problem is that she can't switch it off when the cameras stop rolling. "When I first start a movie, the first day, I feel like a duck," she says. "I feel clumsy, like I don't belong to it. I have fear every day, every night when I go to sleep and I have to do a scene that I'm scared of. I don't think that goes away." And than there are the recurring dreams - the one where she is running but can't move; the ones where someone is hitting her again and again in the kidneys.

"I don't think her life is that easy," Thornton says. "She cares so much about things, and she stresses herself out constantly and stays in a state of nerves all the time... She and I share a lot of the same fears and phobias. Matt, too, for that matter."

While Cruz was filming Captain Corelli, the rumor that she and Damon had forged an on-set romance during the making of Horses was new, and at the time it seemed amusing to her. Asked about Damon, she batted her eyelashes with exaggerated innocence. "I have no idea what you're talking about," she said. "He's amazing, but those things are not true. What is amazing is the way some people ask you sometimes..." She dropped her voice to an intense whisper. "'Tell me the truth. It is true?' Who cares? Because we have this job, we are to say to everybody what we do, or with whom we sleep?" She shrugged and smiled. "It's a bit absurd, but that's why everybody lies so much."

Five months later, when I caught up with her in New York, it was not funny anymore. She had become protective of her privacy. The Damon rumours had been replaced by reports that she and Cage were an item - about him, she said only that "he gives so much as an actor. Every day is a surprise." Last month, she had to deny emphatically that she was having an affair with Tom Cruise after he announced his separation from Nicole Kidman.

F or years now, Cruz has been quietly assisting Mother Teresa's charity work in Calcutta, through a Spanish organisation called the Sabera Foundation. Last year, in her brief time off between movies, Cruz travelled from LA to India to make a documentary about the housing that has been built for homeless children. (The proceeds from the documentary will then be used to build more homes.) "Calcutta is like another world," she says. "People there are very special and grateful. It was an amazing experience." She pauses. "I feel it is dangerous to talk about these things in interviews because they can be misunderstood. I want to make it clear that it's not about me." Perhaps, but her empathy exacts a heavy toll on her nonetheless. "This time in India, I was only there for two days, and there was no time to digest it," she says. "You see things that..." Her voice breaks. "When I come back, I come down like a I had a big crisis."

"She'll travel anywhere to help people," Thornton says. "I mean, she'll run herself into the ground to go someplace for somebody. Look, we're making the movies we want to make: we're making money to support our families; we're the luckiest people in the world. But she just cares so deeply that I think it'll be her downfall. This is a long-winded way of saying that she's co-dependent. And it makes life pretty tough sometimes."

She has spent most of her adult life being someone's girlfriend - presumably arguing part of the time - and so, recently, Cruz says, she decided to step off the relationship track and come to terms with herself. "I think it will be better when I get involved with someone again, because I made this time for me," she says. "I haven't really been single for a while, and I think it's been good for me, to lose the fear to be like this."

Of course, as always with Cruz, as one anxiety dissolves another emerges. "But what if I get used to it?" she asks, her dark eyes widening. "That's the danger."

From Premiere magazine © 2001 Hachette Filipacchi. Captain Corelli's Mandolin is out on May 11. All the Pretty Horses opens in June.

She doesn't drive. And I picked her up at 1.30. I said, 'See how it feels?' She got it." She is not, however, lackadaisical about her career. Hollywood didn't exactly come panting to Cruz's door. "I looked for it," she says, finally getting her cigarette lighter to work. "It was not about finishing one career (in Spain) and starting a new one. It's a continuation of what I started: to find more possibilities, more interesting characters, more stories." But the transition proved difficult. Joel says she spoke three words of English when she auditioned for the lead opposite Keanu Reaves in 1995's A Walk In The Clouds. (The role eventually went to Aitana Sanchez-Gijon). Lesson learned, she hit the books and found, oddly, that acting in a foreign language has its benefits. "It gives you an additional kind of freedom because you don't hear yourself so much," she says. "With that freedom, I can take more risks. There is not so much self-criticism, which can destroy a performance." Cruz is the eldest of three children (her sister is 23; her brother 15), raised in a house about 15 minutes outside Madrid. Her mother ran a beauty salon. "I grew up observing women," she says, "all those different women, different attitudes, coming there to be pretty. I used to sit there and observe how they related to each other, to my mother. It was very interesting. It was like a good acting school." Although her English has improved over the years, she still speaks in Spanish cadences, and her consonants are so soft that every word sounds whispered. "I had some very happy periods," she says. "I am happier now because I don't have so many fears. My first fear was about the devil, when I was around fire, something I saw in a movie. I think it's about pain, in whichever form it comes. I had a lot of energy as a child - sometimes too much - and I didn't know how to channel it. It was making me suffer. It was bigger than myself, and I was very young." She sighs and puts her chin in her hand. "It was a difficult time, no?" Her parents signed her up for ballet classes when she was four. But by the time she reached early adolescence, the endless hours of being on her toes had lost their charm. "It's a very sadistic thing," she says. "You get used to bleeding and smiling at the same time." She had been studying theatre for a few years, and as the dancing faded out, acting took centre stage. Almost instantly, at 14, Cruz began working in films. "I found a lot of magic in it, a lot of order to that chaos," she says. "I felt like a child. I was completely in love with it. I still feel like that. You can always keep learning with acting, because the school is life and yourself and your friends and your relationships. I'm fascinated by it! Its infinito!" The 1992 release of Jamon Jamon proved to be the only dark spot in her bright new world. A hypersexual hit in her native Spain, the film transformed her into a national fantasy - a tousled, naked, writhing minx. She was 17, suddenly a star, and she was scared. "There was some strong energy around me, and I didn't know how to handle it," Cruz says. And so she decided to sever the symbol of her eroticism. "I had a strong rejection of anything sexual or sensual for a while. I cut my hair very, very short. I didn't do any love scenes, not even kisses, for many years. I was told by everyone, 'You are risking your career.' But I followed my heart, and I never regret that." She sighs. "No one forced me to [make the movie]. I felt very happy doing it. But I also suffered for it." When Cruz speaks like this, it's as if she's reliving the pain and fear. This ability to recall her emotional past imbues her acting with a raw immediacy. The problem is that she can't switch it off when the cameras stop rolling. "When I first start a movie, the first day, I feel like a duck," she says. "I feel clumsy, like I don't belong to it. I have fear every day, every night when I go to sleep and I have to do a scene that I'm scared of. I don't think that goes away." And than there are the recurring dreams - the one where she is running but can't move; the ones where someone is hitting her again and again in the kidneys. "I don't think her life is that easy," Thornton says. "She cares so much about things, and she stresses herself out constantly and stays in a state of nerves all the time... While Cruz was filming Captain Corelli, the rumor that she and Damon had forged an on-set romance during the making of Horses was new, and at the time it seemed amusing to her. Asked about Damon, she batted her eyelashes with exaggerated innocence. "I have no idea what you're talking about," she said. "He's amazing, but those things are not true. What is amazing is the way some people ask you sometimes..." She dropped her voice to an intense whisper. "'Tell me the truth. It is true?' Who cares? Because we have this job, we are to say to everybody what we do, or with whom we sleep?" She shrugged and smiled. "It's a bit absurd, but that's why everybody lies so much." Five months later, when I caught up with her in New York, it was not funny anymore. She had become protective of her privacy. The Damon rumours had been replaced by reports that she and Cage were an item - about him, she said only that "he gives so much as an actor. Every day is a surprise." Last month, she had to deny emphatically that she was having an affair with Tom Cruise after he announced his separation from Nicole Kidman. F or years now, Cruz has been quietly assisting Mother Teresa's charity work in Calcutta, through a Spanish organisation called the Sabera Foundation. Last year, in her brief time off between movies, Cruz travelled from LA to India to make a documentary about the housing that has been built for homeless children. (The proceeds from the documentary will then be used to build more homes.) "Calcutta is like another world," she says. "People there are very special and grateful. It was an amazing experience." She pauses. "I feel it is dangerous to talk about these things in interviews because they can be misunderstood. I want to make it clear that it's not about me." Perhaps, but her empathy exacts a heavy toll on her nonetheless. "This time in India, I was only there for two days, and there was no time to digest it," she says. "You see things that..." Her voice breaks. "When I come back, I come down like a I had a big crisis." "She'll travel anywhere to help people," Thornton says. "I mean, she'll run herself into the ground to go someplace for somebody. Look, we're making the movies we want to make: we're making money to support our families; we're the luckiest people in the world. But she just cares so deeply that I think it'll be her downfall. This is a long-winded way of saying that she's co-dependent. And it makes life pretty tough sometimes." She has spent most of her adult life being someone's girlfriend - presumably arguing part of the time - and so, recently, Cruz says, she decided to step off the relationship track and come to terms with herself. "I think it will be better when I get involved with someone again, because I made this time for me," she says. "I haven't really been single for a while, and I think it's been good for me, to lose the fear to be like this." Of course, as always with Cruz, as one anxiety dissolves another emerges. "But what if I get used to it?" she asks, her dark eyes widening. "That's the danger." From Premiere magazine © 2001 Hachette Filipacchi. Captain Corelli's Mandolin is out on May 11. All the Pretty Horses opens in June.

webTitle: The night Moira got it wrong and was almost killed

fields.headline: The night Moira got it wrong and was almost killed
fields.trailText: Moira has been working the streets of Glasgow for four years to feed her drug habit. She has had her share of bad clients but last Friday she met the worst yet and she pulls back her hair to show the bruises on her forehead.
fields.body:
Moira has been working the streets of Glasgow for four years to feed her drug habit. She has had her share of bad clients but last Friday she met the worst yet and she pulls back her hair to show the bruises on her forehead.

"I almost got killed. I went down the alley with a guy and I was just about to do business when he put his arm round my neck and tried to choke me. It was like he was trying to break my neck. He was shouting, 'someone's going to get killed tonight and it's going to be you'.

"He got me on the deck and started banging my head off the ground. I thought I was going to black out. He had his hand over my mouth and I bit his finger. Then I got him by the balls but he kicked me back down and started banging my head again and I was just out of it then. I think I was concussed. He kicked me again, then he ran off.

"I reported it and the police liaison team were quite good. I had his blood on my cheek and I got some of his hair. But a couple of nights before that a wee lassie got done and they think it's the same guy. After he did me he ran straight past one of the CCTV cameras, but they're false ones so they won't have the picture of him. You've really just got to look out for yourself. No one else is going to do it for you."

Ann works from a flat in Edinburgh with another girl. She thinks its the safest way, even though it does not guarantee protection. She has had experience of saunas and she knows girls who have been forced into "carnal interviews" with sauna owners and others forced to forgo condoms.

"We've been lucky. Flat clients and sauna clients are completely different. In the flats we have a nicer client. It's done discreetly. Yes, there are clients that leave a lot to be desired, who get verbally abusive. But we have a security camera and a very good back-up. If a girl is in a room and it's not going right it's easy for her to let us know. A lot of the saunas don't have enough security. If you are in a cabin and a client turns on you what chance do you have?

"Flats are the safest way to go. The police are good in Edinburgh too. They know where every one of the flats is and they are approachable.

"Even with the violence, girls are scared to come forward. People still imagine that prostitutes are terrible, the scum of the earth, but I know some nice office workers that come up the town every weekend and drop their knickers, and you wouldn't say they don't deserve the same protection as everyone else, would you?"

fields.headline: Prostitutes 'left at risk of attack'
fields.standfirst: First study into sex industry violence calls for overhaul of social and legal attitudes with 80% of street workers suffering assaults
fields.trailText: Two-thirds of all prostitutes had experienced violence and more than a third had been attacked within the last six months, according to new research. Only 34%, however, had ever reported the assaults to police.
fields.body:
Two-thirds of all prostitutes had experienced violence and more than a third had been attacked within the last six months, according to new research. Only 34%, however, had ever reported the assaults to police.

The findings, in the first study in the UK, have led to calls for a major overhaul of social and judicial attitudes towards prostitution in the UK.

More than 80% of street prostitutes had experienced violence while they were working and half of them had been attacked within the last six months. Street prostitutes in Glasgow were six times more likely to have been attacked than those working indoors in Edinburgh. Indoor workers were not immune to violence, however. A total of 48% had been attacked, 26% within the last six months, says the study which focused on prostitutes in Glasgow, Edinburgh and Leeds and will be published today in the British Medical Journal.

The most common assault was punching and kicking, but 37% of street prostitutes had been robbed, 24% threatened with a weapon, 25% held against their will, 20% had been kidnapped and 22% raped. A total of 15% of indoor workers had been held against their will, 17% subject to attempted rape and 10% robbed.

The author, Marina Barnard of Glasgow University's centre for drug misuse research, said the findings were alarming and suggested that nothing short of legislation and a major shift in public attitudes would make prostitution safer.

"This study is the first look in this country at the levels of violence that women are confronting," she said. "If you are going to address it you need to look at ways of making sex work safer and ultimately there seems to be no way around legal change.

"We need to look at ways of minimising the risk of attack that are not just about pushing prostitution indoors. We need to encourage the perception that client violence against prostitutes is wrong and clients who perpetrate this violence will be brought to book."

The problem is particularly acute in Glasgow where six prostitutes have been murdered and a seventh has died violently since 1991. There are around 1,000 women working the streets and roughly 90% are on drugs, mostly heroin. The city recently adopted a radical scheme to take women off the streets and stop others entering the profession.

"We see prostitution as survival, not sexual behaviour," said Liz Curran of the Routes Out partnership. "At a social and political level, prostitution, like slavery and apartheid, is unacceptable. We had an option to try and manage it better but we wanted to dismantle it as something that is damaging to women."

Since October, 30 women have been persuaded to enter the programme, but street workers say more are starting every week.

In Edinburgh, city officials operate a policy of liaison and "discretionary prosecution", which prostitutes say offers better protection. There are 23 licensed saunas and 90% of prostitutes work in them.

"What we have done in Edinburgh is not rocket science," said Tom Wood, deputy chief constable of Lothian and Borders police. "We have recognised that the sex industry will always be there and that it is dangerous and we have worked along with the local authority and the health authority to reduce the risk as far as we can."

Ruth Morgan-Thomas, a leading campaigner for prostitutes, said the study was highly significant. "I think this shows up some very serious issues that society should look at about the sex industry and how it operates.

"The Scottish parliament and the UK parliament need to start examining the reality. Too often we pretend it does not exist because people are uncomfortable about looking at this. We need to look at it in all its complexities.

"We need a cultural shift because our attitude at the moment continues to disempower those working as prostitutes and make them extremely vulnerable."

The night Moira got it wrong and was almost killed

Moira has been working the streets of Glasgow for four years to feed her drug habit. She has had her share of bad clients but last Friday she met the worst yet and she pulls back her hair to show the bruises on her forehead.

"I almost got killed. I went down the alley with a guy and I was just about to do business when he put his arm round my neck and tried to choke me. It was like he was trying to break my neck. He was shouting, 'someone's going to get killed tonight and it's going to be you'.

"He got me on the deck and started banging my head off the ground. I thought I was going to black out. He had his hand over my mouth and I bit his finger. Then I got him by the balls but he kicked me back down and started banging my head again and I was just out of it then. I think I was concussed. He kicked me again, then he ran off.

"I reported it and the police liaison team were quite good. I had his blood on my cheek and I got some of his hair. But a couple of nights before that a wee lassie got done and they think it's the same guy. After he did me he ran straight past one of the CCTV cameras, but they're false ones so they won't have the picture of him. You've really just got to look out for yourself. No one else is going to do it for you."

Ann works from a flat in Edinburgh with another girl. She thinks its the safest way, even though it does not guarantee protection. She has had experience of saunas and she knows girls who have been forced into "carnal interviews" with sauna owners and others forced to forgo condoms.

"We've been lucky. Flat clients and sauna clients are completely different. In the flats we have a nicer client. It's done discreetly. Yes, there are clients that leave a lot to be desired, who get verbally abusive. But we have a security camera and a very good back-up. If a girl is in a room and it's not going right it's easy for her to let us know. A lot of the saunas don't have enough security. If you are in a cabin and a client turns on you what chance do you have?

"Flats are the safest way to go. The police are good in Edinburgh too. They know where every one of the flats is and they are approachable.

"Even with the violence, girls are scared to come forward. People still imagine that prostitutes are terrible, the scum of the earth, but I know some nice office workers that come up the town every weekend and drop their knickers, and you wouldn't say they don't deserve the same protection as everyone else, would you?"
