fields.headline: Canon Susan Cole-King
fields.trailText: One of the first English women to be ordained as a priest, Susan Cole-King, who has died on holiday in Australia aged 66, combined that role with her skills as a doctor. She was a champion of peace and justice, and a pioneer of primary healthcare in developing countries.
fields.body:
One of the first English women to be ordained as a priest, Susan Cole-King, who has died on holiday in Australia aged 66, combined that role with her skills as a doctor. She was a champion of peace and justice, and a pioneer of primary healthcare in developing countries.

Born in Eighton Banks, County Durham, where her father, the Rev Leonard Wilson, was vicar, Susan moved to the Far East when he was appointed Bishop of Singapore. The family escaped to Australia in the face of the Japanese invasion, though Bishop Wilson stayed behind and was tortured in the notorious Changai jail.

She qualified as a doctor at St Thomas's hospital, London, in 1962, and, while a student, married Paul Cole-King, a teacher. In 1964, they moved with their children to Malawi, where Susan helped set up a national primary healthcare programme, and successfully campaigned for better maternal and child care in the villages. Returning to England in 1973, she joined a research project at Sussex University on health planning in developing countries. By this time, her marriage had been dissolved and, in 1980, she took a job at the World Health Organisation in Geneva.

A year later, she joined Unicef in New York as senior health adviser, and began a period of extensive travelling, developing maternal and child healthcare policies, and initiating health projects in many countries.

In 1984, she enrolled at the General Theological Seminary, New York, to study for the priesthood of the Episcopal Church, which has acc- epted women priests since 1978. She was ordained in May 1987, at All Angels, Manhattan, the parish where she was running a project for homeless people.

Susan decided, in 1988, to return to England - "where I needed to be part of the struggle". She went to the Oxford diocese, and, after two years as a deacon at Dorchester, was appointed deacon-in-charge of Drayton. Her priesthood was recognised in 1994, when women were finally ordained in the Church of England. In 1995, she was made an honorary canon of Christ Church Cathedral, Oxford.

She was elected in 1990 to the general synod, where she served for eight years, for some time as vice-chair of the board for social responsibility and a member of the international and development affairs committee. In 1997, she retired to Salisbury, although she remained in great demand to lead retreats and to preach. She continued to be deeply involved in international issues, campaigning tirelessly for social justice for the world's poor.

During the 1998 Lambeth Conference, when the Japanese bishops - on Hiroshima Day - celebrated the Eucharist for the whole conference, they invited Susan to preach on their behalf. She spoke with passion about her father's torture and the reconciliation he later achieved, and about her own belief in peace and reconciliation.

Last year, with the Aids crisis escalating in Africa, the Bishop of Southern Malawi invited her to return and help "find the link between Aids and spirituality". She spent four months in Malawi, organising workshops for priests, headteachers, parents and local leaders, and acting as a catalyst for these groups of key people to discuss the then unspoken subject of Aids. Her medical and pastoral skills worked together to find a breakthrough in an impenetrable situation. She had planned to go back this year to continue this vital work.

Susan was a talented painter and gardener; she read poetry, walked and was a wonderful conversationalist. She is survived by her daughter and three sons.

 Susan Cole-King, doctor and priest, born April 23 1934; died February 8 2001

fields.headline: Andy Mulligan
fields.standfirst: Polymath rugby international whose world embraced journalism and business
fields.trailText: Many occupations are listed by Andy Mulligan in Who's Who, including businessman, diplomat, foreign correspondent, broadcaster, publisher and public relations consultant, but he curiously omits the activity for which he will be chiefly remembered: scrum-half for Cambridge University, Ireland and the British Lions.

Many occupations are listed by Andy Mulligan in Who's Who, including businessman, diplomat, foreign correspondent, broadcaster, publisher and public relations consultant, but he curiously omits the activity for which he will be chiefly remembered: scrum-half for Cambridge University, Ireland and the British Lions.

Mulligan, who has died aged 65, won three blues at Cambridge, 22 caps for Ireland between 1956 and 1961, three of them as captain, and starred in the Lions' historic victory over the All Blacks at Auckland in 1959. He was not an original selection for that tour, but seized his chance when the two chosen scrum-halves, Dickie Jeeps and Stan Coughtrie, were injured, creating a memorable blind-side try in the final Test for his great friend, Tony O'Reilly.

He and O'Reilly were the life and soul of the tour party, O'Reilly with his mimicry and Mulligan with his guitar. O'Reilly said: "He had real pace, a lancing break, a superb pass and was a fine reader of the game. But most important, he was a joyful character, a vaudevillian."

Mulligan is described in an official rugby history as "a slim, willowy figure who developed into a fine attacking player, and whose elegant running and passing made him one of the outstanding scrum-halves of the late-1950s". In his first game for Ireland, a week before he was 20, he played at Stade Colombes, in Paris, alongside the legendary fly-half Jackie Kyle. He took part in Ireland's first victory over a touring team from the southern hemisphere when they beat Australia 9-6 at Lansdowne Road in 1958.

Mulligan's playing career was nearly ended at its peak when he became a professional rugby writer. This was in contravention of the rules at the time, and there were cries from diehards for him to be banned. In the end, the Irish Rugby Union decided that, since journalism was then his fulltime occupation, he should be allowed to continue playing - a decision that opened the door for the many players who write about the game today.

Mulligan played at club level for London Irish and Wanderers, the Dublin team, but gave up international rugby at the age of 25 because of his burgeoning business interests. Although quintessentially Irish, with his easy manner, his stories, his quick wit and his gift for making friends and enjoying life - his clubs were Annabel's, the Hawks and the Kildare Street in Dublin - he lived his life mostly overseas, in Paris, Brussels and Washington.

Born in India to Irish parents, Mulligan was educated in England at Gresham's school, Holt, and Magdalene College, Cambridge, where he read geography and anthropology. After a brief time with the Irish Export Board, mostly looking up old rugby pals in Australia and New Zealand, he spent six years as a Paris correspondent for the Observer and the Daily Telegraph. He was not a notable success in this role, a contemporary recalling that "rugby opened many doors for him, but he didn't always know what to ask when he got inside them".

He also had a spell at ITN and worked for four years on the BBC Panorama programme, where his pale good looks and lilting accent made him a natural for television. He then went to Brussels as head of the general reports division of the European Community, publisher of Europe magazine and, later, director of the commission's press and information delegation to the United States.

After leaving this role in unclear circumstances in 1982, he stayed on in Washington, setting up his own company, Mulligan Communications, which utilised his many contacts around the world. He was also involved in European Satellite Radio and the EuroMedia group, and was director for 25 years of the American-Ireland Fund.

Mulligan was a gregarious man, whose interests included tennis, skiing, sailing and a special skill at landscape painting. He moved to Portland, Oregon, with his wife Pia and son Finn six months ago. They survive him, together with another son and two daughters.

 Andrew Armstrong Mulligan, businessman, Eurocrat and rugby player, born February 4 1936; died February 24 2001

webTitle: Foot and mouth: wildlife cull considered

fields.headline: Wildlife cull considered in battle for containment
fields.standfirst:
Extermination could do more harm than good

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The possible extermination of wild boar, deer, foxes and even hedgehogs has been considered by Ministry of Agriculture vets in a bid to prevent the further spread of food and mouth disease, the chief vet Jim Scudamore said yesterday.
fields.body:
The possible extermination of wild boar, deer, foxes and even hedgehogs has been considered by Ministry of Agriculture vets in a bid to prevent the further spread of food and mouth disease, the chief vet Jim Scudamore said yesterday.

So far Mr Scudamore has ordered that no action be taken on a working party report which fingered wild boar as the most likely animal to pose a threat

Although both deer and boar get the disease the problem for the ministry is that they are difficult to track and shoot, particularly boar, which is "extremely secretive". Mr Scudamore said attempting to shoot the deer, even if they were known to have the disease, might make matters worse. "Shooting the deer would be bound to frighten them, dispersing the animals over an even wider area possibly spreading the disease rather than containing it."

Some officials have been keen to exterminate wild boar because the growing population has been seen as a potential threat to the health of domestic pigs. They are the most difficult case of wild animals spreading the disease, he said. Like the domestic pig once infected they "shed" large quanitities of virus into the air increasing the risk of cross infection.

This problem had been considered during the recent classical swine fever epidemic in East Anglia and the possibility of shooting feral pigs and wild boar was considered. "We simply could not find any," so the idea was abandoned, he said. Although there is a small wild boar population in Essex the main stronghold of the animal is south of London in Kent and Sussex where foot and mouth is so far absent.

The only danger that foxes pose is carrying infected meat from once farm to another but the risk from hedgehogs carrying mud on their feet, was so slight that it was not worth considering, he said.

In the 1967 outbreak bird droppings were considered to be a risk of spreading infection but this is now known not to be true. The spread was caused by virus carried drops of water from herds of infected pigs. Currently a cull of wild ani mals was bottom of the list of priorities, he said.

"Cross contamination between farm animals in contact with each other is our main concern, and that is where we will continue to concentrate our efforts. We want to leave wild animals alone. If there is any threat from wild animals we would deal with it much later, if there is a threat at all."

Derek Gow, director of the Wildwood centre in Kent, a leading ecologist, who has been spearheading calls for the reintroduction of wild boar and other animals said: "This possible attack on wild animals smacks of paranioa. They are keen to find an excuse to kill these animals although MAFF knows that it could worsen the crisis.

"Trying to kill them only disperses family groups moving them into areas where there is disease and so spreading it further."

webTitle: BPP to sit out slide in profits

fields.headline: BPP to sit out slide in profits
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: BPP, the education company, yesterday warned that its investments in the internet would hit profits for the year.
fields.body:
BPP, the education company, yesterday warned that its investments in the internet would hit profits for the year.

Investors took fright and its shares, which have halved in value since last November, dropped nearly 19%.

The firm, which focuses on professional training, said it would invest £2.5m in e-learning - making its professional qualification courses available on the internet - and on developing interactive training.

"E-learning is a huge opportunity. It is something that we must do," Richard Price, BPP's chairman, said.

BPP, which trains 80% of investment bankers and stock brokers as well as accountants, is also planning to expand its legal training division.

"While our investment in the future of the business will hold back profits in the current year, we believe the prospects for BPP, in 2002 and beyond, are bright," said Mr Price, who sold some £2m worth of stock last October.

The company posted underlying pretax profits before exceptionals of £14.4m, compared to £14.1m for the previous year. Turnover rose to £105.9m from £95.7m.

Analysts said BPP, which issued a profits warning in December saying it had seen signs of slowing turnover, reported results in line with revised expectations.

"It is an amazing jam tomorrow story," one analyst said.

"They are running costs in every part of business they have."

The shares fell 58.5p to 396.5p. The company raised its total dividend from 19p to 20.25p.

webTitle: Aides begged Clinton not to pardon Rich

fields.headline: Aides begged Clinton not to pardon Rich
fields.standfirst:
International lobbying blitz 'overcame White House advice'

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton's top White House lieutenants all opposed his decision to grant a pardon to the fugitive financier Marc Rich but Mr Clinton himself granted the pardon after a last minute lobbying blitz by world leaders including Israel's prime minister Ehud Barak and King Juan Carlos of Spain, it was claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton's top White House lieutenants all opposed his decision to grant a pardon to the fugitive financier Marc Rich but Mr Clinton himself granted the pardon after a last minute lobbying blitz by world leaders including Israel's prime minister Ehud Barak and King Juan Carlos of Spain, it was claimed yesterday.

Mr Clinton's former chief of staff John Podesta told a congressional committee yesterday that both he and "the entire White House counsel's office" opposed the Rich pardon in the weeks leading up to January 20 this year, when Mr Rich was among 141 beneficiaries of presidential pardons issued on Mr Clinton's last morning in the White House.

Mr Podesta told the House of Representatives government reform committee how he had repeatedly told Mr Rich's lawyers during December and January that a pardon was unlikely, adding that he himself "strongly opposed" it.

But Mr Podesta then went on to give a glimpse of the force of the international lobbying effort on Mr Rich's behalf, coordinated from the top of the Israeli government, implying that it was this pressure which led to the former president's controversial decision.

A few days before Mr Clinton left office, the Israeli foreign minister Schlomo Ben-Ami lobbied King Juan Carlos during a visit to Madrid, who then contacted the White House through an intermediary. Mr Clinton was also lobbied by Mr Barak and the veteran Israeli leader Shimon Peres on the eve of his departure.

"These were men he respected and they were asking him to look at it," Mr Podesta said yesterday. "One could disagree with his reasoning, as many have. One can say that he did not adequately consult with justice department officials before issuing the pardons, as the president himself acknowledged in his statement [in the New York Times last month]. But I believe that President Clinton considered the legal merits of the argument for the pardon and he rendered his judgement, wise or unwise, on the merits of the case."

One of Mr Clinton's most faithful lieutenants, former White House counsel Bruce Lindsey, and his legal colleague Beth Nolan, also gave evidence. All three aides denied under oath that there had been any "quid pro quo" in the decision to pardon Mr Rich.

The evidence came amid fresh evidence of behind-the-scenes lobbying efforts for pardons by Hillary Clinton's brothers, and in a markedly more partisan political atmosphere, with Democrats charging congressional Republicans with double standards and selective indignation.

A week after revelations that Hillary Clinton's brother Hugh Rodham had returned $400,000 that he received for lobbying for two January 2001 pardons, it emerged yesterday that her other brother, Tony Rodham, had successfully lobbied for pardons for a Tennessee couple convicted of bank fraud in 1982, who were major campaign contributors - notably to Mrs Clinton's Senate campaign.

The increasingly partisan tone of the Capitol Hill hearings into the Clinton pardons was underlined yesterday when Republicans insisted that Mrs Rich's friend Beth Dozoretz, a close Clinton friend, should make a public show of her refusal to testify before the committee yesterday.

Unlike Mrs Rich, who two weeks ago pleaded her "fifth amendment" right not to testify through her lawyer, Ms Dozoretz faced a media scrum as she formally refused to answer any questions. The senior Democrat on the committee accused Republicans of "creating a media spectacle" out of yesterday's hearings.

fields.headline: And the toad lived happily ever after
fields.standfirst: Special report: parliament
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo has a lean and hungry look these days. His hair is sleek and black. His lips are full and lustrous. Now that he has come out as a Spaniard, he carries the air of a bullfighter, or perhaps I mean a bullfrog fighter.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo has a lean and hungry look these days. His hair is sleek and black. His lips are full and lustrous. Now that he has come out as a Spaniard, he carries the air of a bullfighter, or perhaps I mean a bullfrog fighter.

For the chancellor looks more and more like a toad. He even stands like an actor playing the part in The Wind in the Willows, legs astride, tummy sticking out, the head arched over the body. He would look wonderful dressed as a washerwoman.

I see Gordon Brown as a mythic figure, possibly from the 1001 Arabian Nights. There is a cave in the mountains, filled with sacks of gold and bushels of jewellery. But anyone who would seize this treasure must first get past the gigantic toad that guards the mouth of the cave.

And as ministers have known for years, the toad has the eyes of a basilisk, the sting of a scorpion, and the determination of a mule. Nobody has got past the toad into the Treasury, and probably nobody ever will.

So what we had yesterday at question time was a duel between the monster and the bold new hero. Young Portillo lost, of course, but that doesn't matter. The Tories have given up hope of winning the general election. What he has to do now is to prove his valiant qualities and to be offered the magical sword that will finally destroy the toad.

(I may have let this image run away with me. If so, I apologise. But I think I'm right about the toad guarding the treasure.)

It's a measure of how desperate the Tories have become that there was almost nothing the shadow chancellor could throw at him. With most economic indicators looking good, he was reduced to admitting that unemployment has fallen under Labour, but more slowly than it did under the Tories. "Will he admit that there were more jobs created in the last three years of the Conservative government than in the first three years of this government?"

This is thin stuff, indeed, delivered not because it might make anyone change their vote, but because it will impress a few Tory MPs. Here is a man, they might think, who can not only make bricks without straw, but concrete without cement.

Of course, it was not a problem for the toad. The world's most majestic specimen of bufo bufo smiled. Even the IMF, he said, had praised his new deal policy for unemployment. So had others. "Name them!" yelled the toad's supporters, the goblins who dance attendance on him from the backbenches.

"I am reluctant to name people," he barked. (Is that what toads do? I suspect that big, legendary toads make a mighty belching noise, like Nicholas Soames after lunch.) "But the shadow chancellor, before he returned to parliament, said 'the new deal appears to be working well'. "

The toad's toadies laughed and roared at that. But Mr Portillo returned to combat. He tried again, this time over taxes. Even if the toad were to cut income tax in next week's Budget, he would be known as "the 10p on, 2p off chancellor". (I doubt that soubriquet will catch on)

Rather tragically, he then went through a list of all the benison the Tories would bring us: lower taxes on savings, more assistance for families, bags of cash for pensioners. He can promise it all because he will not have to make it happen.

The toad rose again and, with one last "ullllp" noise, pointed out that unemployment had fallen by 51% in Mr Portillo's constituency alone. Toad had swallowed him whole, but that doesn't matter: like all true heroes, he will clamber out and live to fight again.

fields.headline: Chief vet hopes that ban will slow disease
fields.standfirst:
Officials say 1967 outbreak was different

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The government's chief vet, Jim Scudamore, was yesterday cautiously optimistic that the foot and mouth virus would not spread too far and there would be no repeat of the last major outbreak in 1967.
fields.body:
The government's chief vet, Jim Scudamore, was yesterday cautiously optimistic that the foot and mouth virus would not spread too far and there would be no repeat of the last major outbreak in 1967.

He expected the number of outbreaks in sheep to rise at the rate of six-eight a day for the next week and then to tail off because the ban on the movement of livestock a week ago should have prevented further spread of the disease.

Mr Scudamore said: "With disease this virulent it is was impossible to tell what will happen but we think we have done all the right things.

"The key was to stop animals being moved to prevent further cross infection, but there will be secondary infections, say to cattle or sheep on nearby farms across the fence or in damp air conditions [by tiny droplets of water containing the virus], but we hope they will be few and easy to isolate."

But in 1967 numbers exploded in week two, with 104 separate outbreaks, followed by 222 in the third week, rising to a peak of 490 in seven days at the end of November. From then on there was a slow decline over several months.

Mr Scudamore said he was cautiously optimistic because none of the newer outbreaks have been in pigs. They may have been the cause of the outbreak and the reason it spread so rapidly but they may also be the first group of animals to be free of the disease.

The incubation period for foot and mouth is thought to be 48 hours for pigs, four to five days for cattle, and 11 to 12 days for sheep. The hopes of the Ministry of Agriculture are pinned on a steady decline after March 9 - two weeks after the ban on movement of all farm animals.

There are other significant differences between 1967 and 2001 which suggest that the disease will not spread so far. In 1967, most of the outbreaks were in cattle herds, with 211,825 cows slaughtered and just over 100,000 pigs and sheep. This time, the disease has been mostly found in sheep.

The ministry has been sur prised by the number of sheep movements, mixing of flocks, and distances dealers took the animals in the days between the probable beginning of the outbreak two weeks ago and animal movements being stopped last Friday.

These movements, say the aiuthorities, have been the key to the spread of the virus. Hundreds of potential cross infections took place in the few days before the ban was introduced, caused by the frenetic trading in fat lambs in markets up and down the country.

Because the first outbreak, at Heddon-on-the-Wall in Northumberland, had been infectious for around 14 days before it was discovered last Thursday, a number of infected sheep had been in the market chain for some days and carried hundreds of miles before anyone realised there could be a danger of infection.

Lambs with foot and mouth are known to have been mixed with healthy sheep and sold in batches at markets in Hexham, Northumberland, Darlington, Co Durham, Longtown in Cumbria, Welshpool in Powys, and Holsworthy in Devon. fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst:
As our diarist's friends await test results on their animals, a cyclist ignores pleas to keep away
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: As our diarist's friends await test results on their animals, a cyclist ignores pleas to keep away
fields.body:
Two more inches of snow fell overnight. After the partial thaw yesterday and hard overnight frost, we now have a firm crust of solid snow, which is much harder to clear.

We found one of the two lost sheep this morning. We rescued her from the burn and she is now convalescing in a clean, dry stable. The other is still missing. Compared with what many farmers are coping with, one lost sheep is not serious, but we keep looking anyway.

I spoke to one farmer's wife this morning and her whole family is suffering. A few of their cattle are suspected of having the dreaded foot and mouth. The test result is due this morning. She has two small children and one of them has been very ill for two weeks with E coli 157. The child is recovering but has to attend the hospital 20 miles away. Their farm is sealed up completely - no one is allowed in or out - so she can only get to the hospital under a strict movement licence from Maff.

Only the mother and child as named on the licence may leave. First they have to walk to the car, parked some way from the farm; then disinfect themselves and the vehicle and follow the exact route as mapped by the ministry. She says the waiting for the final confirmation is the worst thing. They have accepted that the livestock will probably go, but the children have a pet pig each and she doesn't know, should the worst happen, how she will tell them.

The fear levels in this area, especially the nearer you get to the centre of Infected Area 2, are nearly off the Richter scale today. Telephone helplines of all types have reported a tenfold increase in calls. It is not just the fear of losing your own livestock. The rising levels of terror are often compounded by the uneasy feeling that any movement from the farm risks bringing back the disease - not just to our animals, but to neighbours' also.

Some farmers fear they would never be forgiven if that happened, but there should be no blame or shame attached to anyone who becomes the next confirmed case. The whole industry, and each individual livestock holding, remains in great danger.The only way to cope is to follow all the precautions rigorously and call in the ministry if you are even slightly suspicious.

I've just had to break off from writing today's entry to deal with a potentially serious development. My husband Peter came rushing in, reeking of disinfectant and in a total fury. The coast-to-coast cycle route runs through here and we have just had someone passing through, despite pleas to keep away.

Peter has cleared the mile-long route to the main road, but other access is limited. He can see from the footprints that the cyclist stopped to read the notices at the end of the road but ignored our polite request to keep away. Peter's anxiety, like everyone else's on the cycle route, is that it runs through the infected and restricted area.

He has gone to look for the culprit, who pushed his or her way through our outdoor cows who were standing at the closed gate. Whoever it was must have been close enough to our cows, due to calve any day, to feel the warmth of their steamy breath.

I've rung the council, the police and the NFU. Hopefully between us we can get a temporary access ban. No locals use the road as it doesn't really go anywhere except to the church, which is closed until the crisis is over. The next house in that direction is three miles away.

Another financial loser in all this is the local chimney sweep. He has lost two-thirds of his bookings: no farmer will allow him to enter their premises, just in case.

It is no surprise to learn from the Corbridge butcher that British meat supplies are diminishing and that small shops are hardest hit. Jimmy Higginson has five shops in the region and he has been hit by the closure of the Witton-le-Wear abattoir. He collected some frozen belly pork this morning from County Durham to make sausages. The wholesale price had risen from 30p to 75p a pound.

Tynedale council's tourism office has just rung me back about the cyclist. They have talked to the police, who told them to ring Maff, who told them to ring its animal health section . . . We'll await the answer. In the meantime, the next neighbour down the route has gone to look for the culprit.

I need to go out for fresh supplies for the humans and animals. I need a haircut, too, but that is a luxury which will have to wait.

 The writer and her husband run a livestock farm near Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland. She is writing a daily diary during the foot and mouth crisis.

fields.headline: Suicide pact girls were homesick for South Africa
fields.trailText: A South African teenager who gassed herself in an apparent suicide pact with a lifelong friend admitted to her mother in an email four days before she died that she was homesick.
fields.body:
A South African teenager who gassed herself in an apparent suicide pact with a lifelong friend admitted to her mother in an email four days before she died that she was homesick, an inquest heard yesterday.

Jennifer Prinn, 17, was found dead with her friend Elizabeth Gold, 16, in a car at a friend's house in Crawley, West Sussex, with Miss Gold's teddy bear and a duvet sandwiched between them. The pair had grown up together in Pretoria, South Africa, but had parted when their parents emigrated.

The inquest heard that Miss Gold, who had also suffered depression after she left South Africa, had tried to kill herself with paracetamol 10 days before she was found in the gas-filled car. She had spoken to friends of killing herself by carbon monoxide poisoning.

David Kimp, the deputy coroner for West Sussex, said he had no doubt that the girls had intended to kill themselves together. "I think it's tragic for the families that two young ladies with everything, so much potential, found there were no answers for them in this life apart from taking their lives." Dr Skimp recorded a verdict of suicide on both girls with the cause of death as carbon monoxide poisoning.

The inquest at Crawley hospital heard that Miss Prinn left her home in Ballincollig, Co Cork, last December without telling her parents that she was going to visit Miss Gold in Crawley.

She emailed her mother two days later saying that she had to get away for a while. The email said: "I feel I'm being pushed into a society where everyone goes with the flow and I got sick of being a puppet. We left South Africa so we could get a good education and good jobs ... at the moment I'd say I know about as much as I did when we left, and I work in a nightclub. Doesn't sound too good to me."

fields.headline: £330,000 for Hillsborough officer's late stress onset
fields.standfirst: Retired policeman's payout is 100 times greater than victims' award
fields.trailText: Relatives of victims of the Hillsborough football disaster yesterday criticised South Yorkshire police for awarding a retired officer £330,000 compensation for a "late onset" of post traumatic stress.
fields.body:
Relatives of victims of the Hillsborough football disaster yesterday criticised South Yorkshire police for awarding a retired officer £330,000 compensation for a "late onset" of post traumatic stress.

Martin Long, 39, a former sergeant in the South Yorkshire police force, entered the Sheffield stadium pens as more than 96 fans were crushed to death in an FA cup semi-final between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest almost 12 years ago.

Mr Long did not suffer post traumatic stress until nine years later, when he went back to the stadium on another job. He retired the following year on medical grounds and with an enhanced pension.

South Yorkshire police yesterday awarded Mr Long an out-of-court settlement before the case reached Sheffield high court. The force recognised Mr Long's symptoms of depression, nightmares and anxiety after putting himself at risk of being crushed in the crowd.

Phil Hammond, vice-chairman of the Hillsborough Family Support Group said he was surprised and disgusted by the sum, which was 100 times more than relatives and victims had received.

Mr Hammond, who received £3,500 for the death of his 14-year-old son, Philip, said: "I find it offensive. We all thought too much time had passed for claims like this. I am not saying he doesn't deserve something if he was in the thick of it. But he has received more than people who were in the crowd and were badly injured and will never work again.

"We still blame police for their role in the disaster and we are no nearer to finding out the truth of what happened. The police are just covering up the truth and they will take it to their graves. In that light, the pay-out is just ridiculous."

Trevor Hicks, chairman of the group, who lost two daughters in the 1989 tragedy, said: "Many of the people who lost members of their family have received nothing. Yet here we are seeing very large amounts awarded to people who perhaps shouldn't have taken the job in the first place.

"If police officers can't stand the heat, then maybe they shouldn't be in the kitchen. While we sympathise with the officer and his family, there is a very important principle here. When the first officers were paid out we said it would open the floodgates and it has."

Fourteen officers were earlier awarded a combined £1.2m after suffering post-traumatic stress disorder within weeks or months of the disaster - which occurred after intense crowding at the terrace turnstiles led to supporters at the front of the pens being crushed to death. But in December 1998, the law lords ruled against compensation for other officers, unless they had suffered direct physical risk at Hillsborough. They ruled that officers were expected to cope with traumatic events in the line of duty.

Many relatives of victims received up to £6,000 in compensation after courts decided fans would have died within minutes and not suffered "pre-death trauma". This was later questioned by medical experts.

Simon Allen, Mr Long's solicitor said his client had suffered physical risk when he had waded into the pen to rescue dying fans. "Mr Long was trying to extract the injured and the dying from the crush and in doing so was involved in the crush himself. He has suffered from a breakdown as a result, is still affected by it and will never return to employment as a police officer."

Ian Daines, assistant chief constable of South Yorkshire police, said: "We are pleased that another chapter of the Hillsborough disaster has now been closed."

webTitle: Boeing enters air traffic control fray

fields.headline: Boeing enters air traffic control fray
fields.trailText: Boeing, the world's biggest aircraft manufacturer, is backing the bid launched by a group of airlines to run Britain's air traffic control service.
fields.body:
Boeing, the world's biggest aircraft manufacturer, is backing the bid launched by a group of airlines to run Britain's air traffic control service.

Sources at Boeing confirmed last night that the company has written to Lord Macdonald, the transport minister, saying that it will provide technical support.

Boeing believes the bid is sensible, and sees the oppor tunity for a private company to supply air traffic services around the world.

This late entry by Boeing offers the airlines' group - which includes British Airways and Virgin Atlantic - a clear advantage over its nearest rival, management utilities group Serco.

The government's favoured bidder, Serco has been struggling since losing one of its main backers, Eads, the European aerospace and defence company. A more telling blow has been the refusal of a safety group appointed by the national air traffic control service, Nats, to approve the bid.

Government sources last night said that Lord Macdonald will make a statement on the future of the sale to peers later this month. Time is running out for a sale, with the approach of an election.

More than 3,000 air traffic controllers and engineers voted by a majority of 91% to take industrial action to protect the safety ethos of Nats.

Paul Noon, leader of the controllers' union, IPMS, said last night that it would seek meetings with ministers to obtain further assurances over the two bidders on the government's shortlist, Serco and the airlines' group.

Privatisation was an "unnecessary gamble, with no public support, and must not jeopardise safety in the way that has happened on the railways".

fields.trailText: Royal & Sun profits slip
fields.body:
Royal & Sun profits slip

Bob Mendelsohn, the American brought in to revive Royal & Sun Alliance after a troubled merger, will be denied his performance-related bonus for a second year after the insurer reported profits for 2000 down 16% to £476m from £566m.

Losses of £180m from last autumn's floods sliced into profits, preventing Mr Mendelsohn claiming a performance bonus, believed to worth about £250,000, on top of his £600,000-plus salary.

The company said its underlying financial position strengthened as general insurance premiums such as motor and household insurance rose 17% to £8.4bn and life and pensions business grew 21%.

ECB dampens rate cut hopes

The European Central Bank yesterday sought to damp down market expectations of an early cut in interest rates despite the worsening outlook for the global economy.

The governing council left interest rates in the eurozone on hold at 4.75%, and ECB president Wim Duisenberg indicated that the central bank was no more inclined to cut rates than it had been the previous months.

webTitle: BAE threatens to pull out of warship work

fields.headline: BAE threatens to pull out of warship work
fields.trailText: BAE Systems, Britain's largest defence group, yesterday warned that it might pull out of naval shipbuilding altogether if the Ministry of Defence continued to place orders at yards around the country for "political reasons".
fields.body:
BAE Systems, Britain's largest defence group, yesterday warned that it might pull out of naval shipbuilding altogether if the Ministry of Defence continued to place orders at yards around the country for "political reasons".

The threat comes as BAE is seeking MoD orders for two naval support vessels and three submarines.

Sir Richard Evans, BAE's chairman, said: "If the MoD continues to drip-feed ship orders around the country, I do not know if we would want to stay in the business."

BAE believes there is too much naval shipbuilding capacity in Britain, especially with merchant yards competing for MoD orders.

Sir Richard confirmed that BAE had put a national strategy for naval shipbuilding to the government which would strengthen the company's position, possibly at the expense of Vosper Thornycroft, the country's other traditional warship builder.

BAE employs about 90% of the country's naval shipbuilding workforce at its yards at Barrow-in-Furness, and at Scotstoun and Govan on Clydeside. The Scottish yards are reported to be losing up to £3m a month.

BAE, which ranks as the world's third largest defence contractor, yesterday reported that pre-tax profits declined from £459m to £179m last year, largely as a result of an al ready announced £300m provision in connection with its £2bn fixed price contract to upgrade the RAF's Nimrod aircraft.

British European yesterday signed a £415m order to buy 12 of BAE's new 112 seat Avro RJX-100 regional jets, with an option for a further eight.

 General Sir Roger Wheeler, the former chief of the UK general staff, has been appointed a non-executive director of Thales, the French defence group.

fields.headline: Corbett in Woolworths coup
fields.standfirst: £500,000 a year role in Kingfisher break-up for Railtrack chief who quit
fields.trailText: Gerald Corbett, the chief executive of Railtrack forced to quit after last October's Hatfield train crash, has walked straight into a new job as chairman of Woolworths.
fields.body:
Gerald Corbett, the chief executive of Railtrack forced to quit after last October's Hatfield train crash, has walked straight into a new job as chairman of Woolworths.

The appointment, likely to pay at least £500,000 a year, comes ahead of structural changes at Woolworths' parent group, Kingfisher.

The group plans to split in the spring, hiving off its Woolworths, Superdrug and video entertainment "general merchandise" division to focus on electrical and DIY stores, including Comet and B&Q.

Mr Corbett, who was approached by headhunters three weeks ago, will now direct the separation. He described the job as "an exciting opportunity" at a company with "a great heritage, a place at the heart of the community and strong market positions".

Woolworths is unloved by City analysts and investors. Margin pressure means profits will dip this year, but the 800-store chain is still the UK's biggest CD and video retailer.

An associate of Mr Corbett said he had been surprised at the approach. "He didn't expect to be heaved out of Railtrack and there's a bit of him that is sad not to be still running the railways. But he has now put it behind him."

News of Mr Corbett's arrival was accompanied by the departure of the two senior Woolworths executives and confirmation from Kingfisher that it is now likely to sell Superdrug.

The departing executives are Martin Toogood and Philip Rowley. Mr Toogood was previously managing director of B&Q and Mr Rowley the Kingfisher group finance director, but the duo were named as chief and deputy chief executive of the general merchandise division last autumn when Kingfisher planned to float the entire business.

Those plans have since changed. Up to four companies are thought to be interested in Superdrug, with Dutch health retailer Kruidvat the most likely suitor.

It has also emerged that Woolworths and the video businesses might be sold to venture capitalists.

Mr Toogood and Mr Rowley, who were anticipating running their own company, were unhappy at the turn of events and made clear they wanted to depart. Their payoffs are likely to be up to £500,000 each.

Kingfisher now intends to prepare for a demerger while simultaneously holding discussions that could lead to a leveraged buyout. Analysts believe the underlying value of the business may be only £500m and that debt-laden Kingfisher favours a cash sale.

In the event of a buyout Mr Corbett could once again lose his job, as financiers usually want to install their own management. Kingfisher's shares closed down 4p at 490p.

The move to Woolworths takes Mr Corbett back to his retailing roots. In the mid-1980s he was finance director at Dixons and squared up to Sir Geoff Mulcahy, the chief executive of Kingfisher, when the electrical goods retailer made a bid for Woolworths which failed by a whisker. He then moved on to building materials group Redland, drinks combine Grand Metropolitan and, in 1997, to Railtrack.

He tendered his resignation immediately after the Hatfield crash, which claimed four lives, but his fellow directors refused the offer.

A month later, after it became clear that poor track maintenance caused the accident and following a tense meeting with Tony Blair, Mr Corbett resigned for a second time.

fields.headline: TV review
fields.standfirst: A shot in the dark
fields.trailText: EastEnders | Ballykissangel
fields.body:
In the words of the great Frankie Howerd, "I blame Dot." And why not Dot? While the devout Mrs Cotton is not the obvious suspect for the shooting of Phil Mitchell in EastEnders (BBC 1), perhaps she heard voices. As we all did. There was enough said at Mel's wedding to inflame a saint. The groom was murderous, the bride tearful and the bridesmaid suicidal. Their footsteps rang hollow in the register office like a bad comic going off stage.

However, Mrs Owen, the groom's estranged mother (Sheila Hancock), carrying a load of roses on her head like the muffin man who lives in Drury Lane, and Phil Mitchell, the bride's ex-lover (Steve McFadden), carrying a load of booze, arrived uninvited and got on together like a pub on fire. Of the whole doom-laden wedding party, they seemed to be having much the best time. "She's long been an inspiration to me", said Mrs Owen, gazing mistily at a portrait of the Queen in her blue garter. "The Mother of the Nation", said Phil, who was just asking for a good slap. "What a very nice boy you are", said the groom's mother, much moved.

Their happy association continued unabated at the reception. "What a gentleman you are! One recognises a gentleman by his capacity to distinguish between a great Chablis and a cheap plonk", she said, darting a basilisk eye at the bride and stubbing out her fag end in the wedding cake.

The odd thing is that quite recently she would have been right. The Mitchell brothers were loosely based on the Krays. Grant created charismatic mayhem and Phil swept up after him like a small, industrious dustcart. If not precisely nice, at least nicer. But ever since Grant left, Phil has morphed into the man who makes the mess. As Mel said this week, "When exactly did you turn into your brother?"

For the benefit of those of you who are looking vacant, Phil enjoyed a Christmas tryst with Mel and ever since has been looking at her longingly, like a bull terrier spotting a tree in Bow. As he is short and fat and she is tall and willowy, their confrontations have to be carefully staged to avoid a tasteless note of comedy. Mel chose, as they will, to marry Steve, who is tall and willowy too. At her wedding Phil took spectacularly to the bottle and put the boot in with some brio. It was now that one felt the lack of a swimming pool. In Dallas, where weddings were conducted on the patio, malcontents were cooled off by being thrown into the bijou pool. I tell you frankly that a flood in the gents, requiring a swift evacuation of the wedding party to the Queen Vic, is not the same thing at all.

Phil was running the Queen Vic. So the legendary Curse of the Queen Vic, which puts Tutankhamen firmly in his place, has struck again. Landlords of the Vic are routinely murdered. There was "Dirty" Den Watts, shot with a bunch of daffodils as he strolled beside the canal, Eddie Royle, stabbed in Albert Square by, it is widely believed, Nick Cotton, and Grant Mitchell, driven into the Thames by his brother.

Phil's last words just before he was shot were tantalisingly "I know who you are!" No relation of Bing Crosby being in sight, that leaves us with the usual suspects: Ian, the bride's ex-husband; Steve, the current incumbent; Lisa, Phil's ex-girlfriend; Mark, who loves her hopelessly; and Dan, who appeared from nowhere to make up the numbers. Or you could ask Christopher Reason, who wrote the script.

What a shock for Phil's dinky Mum (Barbara Windsor) on her return from Lanzarote! Let us hope the Queen will, as ever, be an inspiration and comfort to her.

Ballykissangel (BBC 1) is back in fine form with Father "Call me Vincent" Sheahan (real name, implausibly enough, Robert Taylor), a craggy new Australian priest, who looks as if roughly hewn from a coolabah tree, and a changed but charming cast, not one of whom could walk from a to b in a straight line. And that even before Fitzgerald's opens. The outer habiliments of the late Brian Quigley, the rogue with the brogue, are found folded tidily on the shore, topped by his trilby like a cherry. It's the consensus at Fitzgerald's that he's done a bunk and the arrival of a number of large cheques drawn on the aptly named Banco Sinistre de Rio confirms it. Tony Doyle, who played Quigley, is, in fact, dead but we don't have to believe it if we don't want to.

fields.headline: Turkey brings in experts
fields.trailText: The main opposition party in the Turkish parliament filed a censure motion against the government yesterday, accusing it of bringing the economy to the brink of collapse.
fields.body:
The main opposition party in the Turkish parliament filed a censure motion against the government yesterday, accusing it of bringing the economy to the brink of collapse.

With markets struggling to recover from a week of financial upheaval sparked by a row between the prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, and the president about the pace of corruption investigations, Mr Ecevit, has said he is seeking billions of pounds in new international loans.

A senior Turkish economist from the World Bank, Kemal Dervis, arrived in Ankara yesterday at the request of Mr Ecevit. Mr Dervis is expected to become a pivotal figure in a new economic team designed to restore the confidence of sceptical investors. Two teams from the International Monetary Fund are also locked in talks with the government.

Large parts of the economy have ground to a halt, with some companies not paying wages because they are short of hard cash, and others laying off staff. Banks have frozen loans and many small businesses are stretched to the limit.

A group of leading unions and business organisations has threatened widespread popular protests after next week's Eid holiday if they are not consulted about economic policy.

webTitle: Briton's cipher talk feeds suspicions of US cyber spying

fields.headline: Briton's cipher talk feeds suspicions of US cyber spying
fields.trailText: A British official at the European Commission was at the centre of a bizarre cyber-spying row yesterday after he appeared to suggest that the US National Security Agency (NSA) had unfettered access to the EU's system for dispatching encoded confidential messages all over the world.
fields.body:
A British official at the European Commission was at the centre of a bizarre cyber-spying row yesterday after he appeared to suggest that the US National Security Agency (NSA) had unfettered access to the EU's system for dispatching encoded confidential messages all over the world.

In an episode certain to refuel French suspicions that Washington is engaged in industrial espionage on a gigantic scale, Desmond Perkins, 65, a senior official who works in the commission's cipher unit, said: "I have always had very good contacts with the NSA in Washington, and they usually check our systems to see that they are being well looked after and not being misused for me."

Asked during a hearing at the European parliament why the NSA should be involved, he answered: "Because I have relatives working in there, that is why. It is as simple as that. You have got to remember .. that the Americans read everything, no matter what is going on inside here, they read everything with their satellites lined up.

"And after two weeks they could not break it [the cipher], so I'm quite happy with that," he said, adding that the information he dealt with was in any case "very short-term political stuff".

Mr Perkins was addressing a hearing in February which was only publicised yesterday, by the French daily Libération.

The commission yesterday rejected any suggestion that its communications system - used to convey information about defence matters - had been penetrated by Washington.

"This was a major misunderstanding," a commission spokesman, Jonathan Faull, said. "This is not a system which was cracked by the NSA and there was no situation where the EC opened its system up to third parties."

Mr Faull said the encryption system's manufacturer, the German engineering firm Siemens, had boasted that the NSA had tried and failed to crack it before it was installed by the commission 10 years ago.

"When they delivered it they explained that it had been tested by the NSA who had tried to get in and failed. It was a sales pitch. The system is good but it's not perfect."

The communications system is similar to that used by national governments and Nato, Mr Faull added.

Another official said: "There is no American agency charged with checking our systems. And the codes used are changed every 24 hours so it would be a new challenge every day."

The two cipher systems used by the commission are Savil, for "top secret" communications, and Cryptofax, for "secret" ones.

Officials also said yesterday that the commission knew Mr Perkins had a relative working for the NSA before they took him on in 1976.

Mr Perkins has apologised to his boss, saying his words have been misconstrued.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 We are intrigued by leaked minutes from the parliamentary committee, Labour's ruling body at Westminster. "The chair and chief whip in the Lords reported back on discussions with a colleague about her conduct," it reads. "It was noted that satisfactory assurances had been received." That colleague is Ann Mallalieu, doyenne of the Leave Country Sports Alone campaign and, it seems, a very naughty baroness. The horsy barrister organised and held a 5,000-strong rally just 200 yards from the Leamington office of anti-hunt Labour MP James Plaskitt, who furiously complained that she pitched up without the usual prior notice and denounced him for encouraging class war and pitting town against country. Another Labour MP with a tiny majority, Falmouth's Candy Atherton, was also targeted, but Lady M insists that going for vulnerable MPs was her last desire, and struggles to recall accusing anyone of waging class war. "It's my fault, I made an error; I should have told James in advance," she says. "The last thing I want is to embarrass a Labour MP. I've now had some helpful guidance". Mm.

 That latter day Archimedes Conrad Black takes two pages of his Spectator to cry "Eureka! Taki-George is a racist!" and who on earth would believe it? The catalyst for this discovery, as reported elsewhere today, was a recent anti-Israel rant, of which Mr Black writes: "In both its venomous character and its unfathomable absurdity, this farrago of lies is almost worthy of Goebbels." Blimey. With Mr Black distressed that his old friend "should use a publication of ours for such malignant purposes," the bullet seems close. Whether we will find him any Diary work seems unlikely on current form (his riposte to Mr Black suggests that this summer's Berlitz School fortnight won't be his last), and a return to full-time waitering is favourite.

 Diary pundit Steptoe is obliged to clip the odds on Turncoat contender Margaret Hodge, the Trot who left Islington council in a fantastic mess and then mutated into an ultra-Blairite minister. When the list of election candidates was put on the Labour web-site yesterday, everyone omitted any honours (even Sir Ray Powell excluded his knighthood) ... except Margaret who included her MBE. For this act of petty vanity - one worthy of Baroness Jay herself - Margaret is in from 25-1 to 20-1.

fields.headline: Taxing his critics
fields.standfirst:
The chancellor can ignore the IMF's admonishments and produce a Budget that will invest in later generations without future fiscal pain

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: The chancellor can ignore the IMF's admonishments and produce a Budget that will invest in later generations without future fiscal pain.
fields.body:
Compared to the discipline adminstered to developing countries over the years, the International Monetary Fund's criticism of Gordon Brown is a light rap over the knuckles. But coming from the world's leading financial authority, it hit a raw nerve, especially since the IMF critique echoes that from from European Union finance ministers a couple of weeks ago.

Like the EU, the IMF agrees with Mr Brown's strategy, "particularly the need to enhance public infrastructure and human capital". Its latest health check on the UK praises the priority placed by Labour on investment and education. It does not call for any spending cuts. This is a far cry from 1976, when the IMF laid down the law to the Labour government led by Jim Callaghan during a sterling crisis, insisting on painful belt-tightening.

However, the IMF does not like the way Labour's investment plans should be paid for. The chancellor, who chairs the IMF's policy-making committee, wants to double capital spending to £18bn a year by 2003-04. The chart, based on Institute for Fiscal Studies-Goldman Sachs' "modest" assumptions, shows how investment will start to exceed the surplus generated from taxes.

Mr Brown believes it is financially sound to borrow in order to invest, as long as the borrowing is kept within strict guidelines preventing the ratio of government debt to GDP rising above 40%. The recent strong performance of the economy combined with the chancellor's tight (some would say over-rigid) control of the public finances means there is no danger of that happening.

The IMF on the other hand says public investment should be paid entirely from the revenue raised from taxation. Since current tax receipts are continually overshooting Treasury projections, there is ample scope to fund investment spending without resorting to borrowing. The result would be a balanced budget, a key tenet of the IMF's faith.

There are arguments in favour of both sides. The point at issue is quite a narrow one and in any case will have absolutely no bearing on what the Treasury actually does.

The IMF's argument is that a higher contribution from the public sector to national saving would boost investment and thereby address the achilles heel of the British economy - poor productivity growth. Although the weakness of productivity growth has many causes, nearly everyone including Mr Brown believes that under-investment is one of them.

The chancellor disagrees with the IMF's assessment of who should pay when, believing the Washington-based organisation's hair-shirt approach to public borrowing is old-fashioned and unfair. While he thinks it is right to keep the revenue budget in balance over the economic cycle, he argues that investment on new schools and hospitals falls into a different category from nurses and teachers' pay.

Unlike current expenditure, which only benefits those alive at the time, investment benefits both existing and future generations. Those alive in the future should help pay the bill and borrowing, which is in effect deferred taxation, is a way of spreading the cost over time.

Carl Emmerson of the IFS sides with Mr Brown. He likens his position to that of an individual buying a house. No one in their right mind would save up the entire costs before purchasing when they can get a mortgage to enjoy the benefit now.

However, Mr Emmerson says that neither fiscal norm, the IMF's yen for balance or the chancellor's so called golden rule, is perfect. While both are reasonable rules of thumb to ensure the public finances do not get out of control, they do not necessarily ensure the public gets best value for money from public services.

Ultimately it comes down to public - political - choice. Mr Brown's golden rule permitting borrowing for investment is sensible if the benefit to society of that investment is greater than the extra interest costs incurred in borrowing. The Treasury believes there is good reason for believing that this is the case now, when years of under-investment in public services has left them threadbare. With a huge backlog of investment to clear, it is unreasonable to expect the current generation to shoulder all of the costs. We think the IMF is being too fiscally conservative, says the Treasury.

On the other hand, it is not always easy to distinguish between current and capital expenditure. Who is to say, for example, whether teachers' pay is one or the other? It is surely both. Moreover, there is nothing sacrosanct about investment spending. As the dome has illustrated, it is perfectly possible to spend millions on public in frastructure and not get value for money.

Just ahead of the Budget, the IMF's intervention could not have been more politically awkward but it will make absolutely no difference to the contents of next Wednesday's statement. On top of the £1.7bn already set aside to placate disgruntled motorists, Mr Brown is expected to announce that the health of the public finances means he can introduce targeted tax cuts and spending increases worth just over £2bn without breaching his rules. The IMF would rather he eschewed what it calls "piecemeal" tax breaks and pay off debt, but with debt already falling rapidly Mr Brown will no doubt feel fully justified, both economically and politcally, in spreading some extra pre-election cheer.

 Mark Atkinson is the Guardian's economics correspondent.

fields.headline: Naming the day
fields.standfirst:
Should foot and mouth delay the election?

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Should the general election, reputedly pencilled into Tony Blair's diary for May 3, now be postponed because of the outbreak of foot and mouth disease?
fields.body:
When should it be? Should the general election, reputedly pencilled into Tony Blair's diary for May 3, now be postponed because of the outbreak of foot and mouth disease? Should the local elections in England, already scheduled for that same day, also be delayed?

The arguments for such a move appear persuasive. As areas of the countryside are sealed off into total exclusion zones - with farmers holed up inside their homes, their movements heavily restricted - it would surely be a violation of rural voters' rights to hold a ballot now, when so many could not take part. They could attend no rallies and would hear canvassers only through the distant cry of a megaphone. As for turnout, surely that would plunge as rural voters simply stayed at home.

Even if the situation was as dire as that, a postponement to June or October would still not be necessary. For this is not the 1950s. These days canvassing happens chiefly by telephone and email, with door-knocking a minority sport. Old-fashioned hustings are a thing of the past for most voters, too - replaced by the phone-in show on local radio. Even voting itself has changed, with postal balloting an easy solution for those reluctant to head outdoors on polling day.

Moreover, as luck would have it, the situation is not as dire as some have depicted. The countryside is not paralysed: there are just over 30 cases of F&M, a fraction of the 2,300 outbreaks which struck in 1967-68. Only those farmers are genuinely cut off; others can move, so long as they disinfect their vehicles as they come and go. Just look at the official tally of children who have had to stay away from school because of F &M: zero.

So Mr Blair should keep a cool head. Since the British system - wrongly in our view - still gives the PM the power to set the date, he should not be panicked into changing his mind. And he should remember: when it comes to delaying the day, Labour's history is not lucky.

fields.headline: Frances Lincoln
fields.standfirst: A much-loved independent publisher, she brought originality, literary flair and commercial wisdom to the world of books
fields.trailText: A much-loved independent publisher, she brought originality, literary flair and commercial wisdom to the world of books.
fields.body:
In 1975, the senior executives of the American firm Collier Macmillan, returning from a good lunch to their London office in Red Lion Square, were astounded to find the greater part of their staff assembled outside the office. They had walked out in protest at the decision to make 40 redundancies. Leading the strike, in a billowing skirt of black and brilliant red, was their brightest and youngest executive, Frances Lincoln.

She had come to them six years earlier, aged 23, had commissioned her first book (by her future husband) in her first fortnight, and, within a few years, had been appointed managing director of Studio Vista, the English firm which Collier Macmillan had taken over.

The strike lasted 10 days, and was gratifyingly successful. Management made a series of improving offers, each of which was calmly rejected by Frances - until she got what she wanted for the staff, and moved on to a better job with the publishers Marshall Cavendish.

The black and red outfit she wore for the occasion was far from typical. Frances, who has died aged 55, was usually dramatically self- effacing. Her voice was precise, but very soft and low, her clothes inconspicuous, though often expensive. Her skirts were long, and so was the hair, partly concealing her face, which was further hidden by broad-brimmed hats and large round glasses, usually dark. From behind this protective screen emerged her gentle little voice - not all that often, for she was never talkative.

It was a remarkably effective ensemble for someone who became one of the most successful publishers of her generation, knew exactly what she was doing and what she wanted, was a formidable and relentless businesswoman, kept her cards close to her chest, and never lost her cool or her commitment to producing books of the highest standard.

She could be baffling and elusive, and yet she inspired great fondness, because we knew that she was not just steel inside velvet, but a loyal friend, a loving wife and mother, a tolerant and gentle companion, and a person of strong feeling behind the reticence and reserve. She had, too, the charming ability of suddenly becoming giggly.

Frances was born the eldest of two children of liberal, middle-class Hampstead parents. Her father had been a clever grammar-school boy, her mother's immediate forebears included a Ceylon tea-planter and a Manchester solicitor. The family moved to Hertfordshire, and she went unhappily to school in Bedford. After a year, she moved to St George's, Harpenden, a co-educational boarding school, where she was fulfilled and successful, and ended up as head girl.

In 1964, she moved on to Oxford, to read greats at Somerville College. At university, she was to become a glamorous and admired figure, but, for her first year, she was once again lonely and unhappy, until she deliberately set out to recreate herself. The big hats, long hair and dark glasses were part of the new, successful and, as it turned out, permanent image.

From Marshall Cavendish, she was head-hunted in 1977 by George Weidenfeld, initially with the intention of putting her in charge of Weidenfeld and Nicolson's illustrated books, an offer which soon changed to one to set her up under her own imprint. The ebullient, flamboyant and talkative Weidenfeld was intrigued by the silent, reticent and hard-bargaining Lincoln, and she, although excited by a wonderful opening for a young publisher, coolly played hard to get, and went to the best and most expensive solicitor available to draw up a contract which eased her path when she later detached herself and went independent.

She became one of the few independent publishers to have survived the traumas of modern publishing. Her firm echoed her personality, from the "Frances Lincoln Publishing" barely visible in the glass of a small door in a Kentish Town mews, behind which sheltered her 43 staff, list of around 70 books a year and turnover of around £5.5m.

Inability to find a book to answer her own gardening needs led to the commissioning (in Marshall Cavendish days) of her first big seller, John Brookes's The Small Garden, and her ultimate establishment as a leading publisher of books on gardening. Similarly, it was the needs of her children that led to the children's book department, which became another of her main lines.

The firm flourished on the basis of low profile, good judgment, high standards of production, modest salaries, skilful promotion of co-editions and steady, unspectacular growth. Although she expected much from her staff, Frances could be a tolerant and understanding employer, and was a pioneer in making part-time arrangements for those with young children.

She, herself, worked long hours six days a week, but always found time for her family and regular visits to their home in the Lake District. It was there, during half-term, that she contracted pneumonia and died after a few days.

She leaves her husband John Nicoll, head of Yale University Press in England, whom she married in 1972, a son and twin daughters.

 Erica Hunningher writes: Frances Lincoln became a colleague and friend in 1970, when we were assistant editors at Studio Vista. I joined the company that bore her name in 1987, and worked for her for 11 years. She was a dedicated and inspired publisher, a pioneer with a grasp on life that was reflected in the illustrated books that her independent company produced over 24 years.

Early on, there were titles on pregnancy and twins. The children's list began with books on the big machines that fascinated her toddler son. A burgeoning gardening list was born of a desire to transform her own patch. With the family growing up in north London, she published groundbreaking children's fiction that, in 1995, earned her the award of Woman of the Year for Services to Multicultural Publishing.

Frances published with enormous care; she took a personal interest in every book, and no marketing, financial or strategy stone was left unturned. She was inscrutable in public and protected her tender feelings, and her vulnerability, by powerful pauses and a very elegant index finger. This she stroked up and down across her mouth, only saying anything when it was really worth saying, and ensuring that her emotions were never on display. But she would forgive us, her friends and colleagues, for showing ours.

 Frances Elisabeth Rosemary Lincoln, publisher, born March 20 1945; died February 26 2001

fields.headline: Outlook fades for permatan boys
fields.trailText: Cruise ship operators are as optimistic as their glossy brochures which show the sun shining day in, day out.
fields.body:
Cruise ship operators are as optimistic as their glossy brochures which show the sun shining day in, day out.

But even the executives of market leaders such as Carnival Corp and P&O Princess Cruises have lost their permatans of late.

Increased competition forced P&O Princess to report an embarrassing fourth quarter loss. This was only three months after the company was demerged from Lord Sterling's P&O group.

In the full year P&O Princess reported a fall in pre-tax profits from $357.8m to $318m. The period started on a high, with expensive millennium cruises heavily booked and onboard spending at record levels.

But the euphoria died fast, with large numbers of new vessels amounting to an extra 10% of capacity coming into the key north American market. For P&O Princess this led to falling passenger prices, a problem compounded by higher fuel costs and disruption in cruises to Israel due to political violence.

Carnival, the cruise market leader, saw its annual net income dip 5% from $1.3bn to $965.5m and took a hammering in the last three months of the year.

Share prices had a tough 2000, with Carnival starting the year at $46.87 but plunging to $18.31 by August. The outlook has since improved. Carnival's price has gone back up to the $30 mark after a reduction in prices triggered a resurgence in 2001 passenger demand.

But there are still worries that there are 52 vessels with 100,000 extra berths on order to arrive in the next five years while the US economy is slowing down. Jim Winchester, transport analyst at Lazard Freres in New York, says the outlook is positive. "The biggest blow was taken last year and the situation has now stabilised although the issue of [excess] capacity never goes away."

Mark McVicar, transport analyst with Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein in London, is similarly wary. "Yields fell between 3% and 5% during 2000 but today's forward bookings on a lower pricing base are quite encouraging," he says.

But even the executives of market leaders such as Carnival Corp and P&O Princess Cruises have lost their permatans of late. Increased competition forced P&O Princess to report an embarrassing fourth quarter loss. This was only three months after the company was demerged from Lord Sterling's P&O group. In the full year P&O Princess reported a fall in pre-tax profits from $357.8m to $318m. The period started on a high, with expensive millennium cruises heavily booked and onboard spending at record levels. But the euphoria died fast, with large numbers of new vessels amounting to an extra 10% of capacity coming into the key north American market. For P&O Princess this led to falling passenger prices, a problem compounded by higher fuel costs and disruption in cruises to Israel due to political violence. Carnival, the cruise market leader, saw its annual net income dip 5% from $1.3bn to $965.5m and took a hammering in the last three months of the year. Share prices had a tough 2000, with Carnival starting the year at $46.87 but plunging to $18.31 by August. The outlook has since improved. Carnival's price has gone back up to the $30 mark after a reduction in prices triggered a resurgence in 2001 passenger demand. But there are still worries that there are 52 vessels with 100,000 extra berths on order to arrive in the next five years while the US economy is slowing down. Jim Winchester, transport analyst at Lazard Freres in New York, says the outlook is positive. fields.headline: Punters check in to Hilton
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Hilton, the hotels and gaming group, made a rare appearance near the top of the FTSE leader board yesterday as two unrelated stories sparked heavy buying.
fields.body:
Hilton, the hotels and gaming group, made a rare appearance near the top of the FTSE leader board yesterday as two unrelated stories sparked heavy buying.

First, there was renewed talk of a strike from Bass, the cash-rich leisure outfit.

According to these market whispers, Hilton's portfolio of upmarket hotels, and the recent slide in its share price, have caught Bass's eye.

After selling its brewing operation to Belgian group Interbrew for £2.3bn and offloading nearly 1,000 pubs to Japanese bank Nomura for £625m, the refocused Bass is under pressure to do a deal.

Following these disposals over half of Bass's profits come from its hotel operations - Holiday Inn, Crowne Plaza, and Inter-Continental. But analysts reckon Bass needs to bulk up in hotels if it is to be a serious player. Having a pop at Hilton would be one way to solve the problem.

The second story suggested that Hilton, via its Ladbrokes gaming division, would be one of the biggest beneficiaries of next week's Budget.

It is widely expected that the chancellor will replace tax on betting, whereby a 9% levy is charged directly to the punter, with a 15% tax on bookmakers' gross profits.

And if the punters do not see the tax - so the theory goes - they are likely to spend more money at places such as Ladbrokes' outlets.

Analysts at WestLB Panmure estimate that the tax on gross profits would cost Hilton £55m but will be more than offset by increased turnover. When the Irish government reduced its betting tax there was an immediate 30% surge in turnover. Hilton shares closed 7p higher at 230p, while Bass eased 7p to 716p.

The day's other juicy story centred on IT services outfit FI Group. Three directors, including John Pocock, head of marketing, have cashed in some chips as the company's share price continues to head south. Yesterday they revealed that they had sold a total of 887,440 shares for 380p each. Angered by the sales, traders marked FI shares, 705p a year ago, down 31.5p to 347.5p.

Choking on another dose of profits warnings from North America, the FTSE 100 ended a gloomy session 9.3 points lower at 5,908.6 - its lowest close since October 1999. Telecom stocks BT, down 35p to 535p, and Vodafone, off 4.25p to 183.5p, did most of the damage.

But things could have been a lot worse. Heading into the last hour of trading the FTSE was in real trouble, falling below the 5,900 level for the first time in 16 months.

However, sparkling performances from Royal Bank of Scotland, up 139p to £16.59 after forecast busting figures, and Barclays, 91p higher at £21.94, together with a late rally in the closing auction, helped blue chip shares recover their dignity.

The same could not be said of the FTSE Techmark 100, which fell 50.95 points to 2,252.42, rocked by warnings from Gateway and 3Com.

Handheld computer maker Psion, off 39p to 115p, lead the rout in the after another set of ghastly figures that shareholders stunned. Elsewhere, ARC International slipped 30.5p to 128.5p, BATM lost 11p to 101p and Kewill Systems retreated 23.5p to 238.5p, all for no other reason than the Nasdaq moved lower yesterday.

Back among the blue chips Amvescap dropped 138p to £12.37, hit by rumours that its US fund management operation, AIM, is experiencing a massive outflow of client money. 90% of Amvescap's profits are generated in North America. British Airways was not far behind, diving 27.75p to 374.5p after poor figures from US Airways.

But it was not all doom and gloom. British Energy, up 32p to 282p, finished top of the pile in the mid-cap universe after Merrill Lynch added the stock to its Europe-1 list and set a 400p target price.

Construction group YJL added 3.5p to 27.25 on bid speculation and rumours of a major contract win.

fields.headline: IMI keeps them guessing
fields.trailText: With interests from drinks dispensing to "hydronic" controls, IMI is the one of the remaining traditional engineering conglomerates. But the question dealers are asking themselves is for how much longer?
fields.body:
With interests from drinks dispensing to "hydronic" controls, IMI is the one of the remaining traditional engineering conglomerates. But the question dealers are asking themselves is for how much longer?

Yesterday, one punter spent £16.5m, buying 5.5m shares for 300p each. IMI shares closed 14p higher at 282.5p.

Although a break-up bid for the company is a possibility, gossips reckon its new chief executive, Martin Lamb, will announce a disposal programme with full-year figures on March 12.

Some believe Mr Lamb is looking to refocus the group by selling off its smallest divisions - energy controls and fluid power - and investing the proceeds in expanding the hydronic controls and drinks businesses.

Such focus would be welcomed by investors, who are sick of seeing the share price bump along at under the 300p level.
