webTitle: Miami mogul makes waves on the Mersey

fields.headline: Miami mogul makes waves on the Mersey
fields.standfirst: Cammell Laird would like to stop the Carnival which threatens the renaissance in British shipbuilding
fields.trailText: The Florida cruise market is not for the faint-hearted. Konstantinos "Gus" Boulis, the former owner of the SunCruz company, was shot dead as he drove home to Fort Lauderdale a few days ago but the strife is normally confined to the water, where cutthroat commercial competition separates the top three operators in the world - Carnival, Royal Caribbean Cruises and P&O Princess.
fields.body:
The Florida cruise market is not for the faint-hearted. Konstantinos "Gus" Boulis, the former owner of the SunCruz company, was shot dead as he drove home to Fort Lauderdale a few days ago but the strife is normally confined to the water, where cutthroat commercial competition separates the top three operators in the world - Carnival, Royal Caribbean Cruises and P&O Princess.

Carnival is the biggest of the pack and its chairman, Micky Arison, is revered in Miami, the cruise capital of the world. He owns the Miami Heat basketball team as well as controlling a maritime empire of 35 ships.

His company likes to market itself as "the most popular cruise line in the world". But across the Atlantic on Merseyside, thousands of shipyard workers do not celebrate Carnival. They lay the blame on it for potentially snuffing out a British shipbuilding renaissance.

A decision by Italian Carnival subsidiary Costa Crociere to cancel a £50m conversion contract - even as the vessel was on its way to Birkenhead - has placed in doubt the future of the Cammell Laird shipbuilding group. The official reason for the cancellation was that the work undertaken by Cammell was behind schedule, but the shipyard management rejects this.

British shipbuilding union officials argue that the formerly convivial atmosphere between Costa and Cammell began to change as Carnival bought a controlling stake in the Italian group last year. They also believe it significant that the entire cruise market went into a nosedive due to overcapacity, encouraging operators to look for savings in their fleets.

Instead of lengthening the Costa Classica, Carnival lent its Italian subsidiary one of its own vessels, the Tropicale, to provide extra capacity. The British unions see this as the main reason why the conversion contract was shelved.

Egos to blame

They also point to an announcement by RCCL that it planned to start southern Mediterranean cruises out of Genoa with a start date a few weeks ahead of a lengthened Costa Classica being back in action.

But Kevin Curran, northern regional secretary for the GMB union, says Miami egos were ultimately at the centre of the dispute that has cost Cammell so dearly.

He explained: "Cammell Laird employees were already on the Costa Classica after they set sail for Merseyside. If Carnival had concerns about the work on the mid-section, they would have expressed them before.

"These theatricals - recalling the vessel halfway - were just to play a negotiating card to try to knock the price down - which Cammell Laird refused to do. Their bluff was called and they were too macho to back down."

Carnival denies all of this, insisting that all Costa decisions - from the appointment of technical directors to yard contracts - were solely in the hands of Costa itself. Mr Arison, in typically forthright style, has accused Cammell of putting out "ridiculous statements" and peddling "inaccurate propaganda"about the cancellation.

He says the vessel set sail because Costa was sure it would obtain guarantees on a new delivery timetable and was only halted when it realised this was not going to happen.

Carnival says the dispute has led to Costa losing money because it has been unable to market the vessel due to the uncertainty. The Tropicale has only been brought in to plug a gap because of the problems with the lengthening. What is clear is that in any vessel contract of this nature it is common for both sides to make changes along the way. Normally the resulting impact on cost and delivery times are settled mutually. But not always.

Harland & Wolff has lost millions of pound and, like Cammell, has come close to closure because an American shipowner - in this case Global Marine - refused to make final payments on a contract in a similar dispute.

Carnival's negotiating style was described by one US cruise ship specialist as "very aggressive, almost mean". But British-based cruise industry consultant GP Wild says it has never known Carnival pull out completely from a deal.

Peter Wild, who runs GP, admits the cruise ship market suffered badly last year with Carnival's share price being more than halved, but adds: "Whatever has happened Carnival will have very strong reasons for refusing to take delivery. It will not be because of market conditions."

Carnival was established by Ted Arison. But under his son Micky, the group has been turned into a ruthless competitor that has gobbled up weaker opposition such as Cunard, Seabourne and Costa. The Miami group has won plaudits from the financial community for its tight discipline and rigorous cost cutting. As one seasoned industry expert put it: "You could lose your job there for mislaying a paper clip."

And each paper clip could be counted by the boss because Mr Arison is said to take a personal interest in absolutely everything that goes on.

He is described by supporters as charming and fun but by critics as shrewd and controlling - which is why everyone was interested to see what changes Mr Arison would bring, having taken over Costa Crociere, which had warmly embraced Cammell the preceding February.

The Genoese-based shipowner, with Carnival then as a minority shareholder, had awarded Cammell the biggest con version contract for a cruise ship ever seen. This offered a springboard for the UK to again become a centre of cruise ship excellence, the like of which it has not seen since the glory days of the Queen Mary and QE1 and II's construction.

A second Italian contract to lengthen by 45 metres and insert 352 new passenger cabins was expected for a sister ship, the Costa Romantica. Cammell was cock-a-hoop. The company had been a state-owned "basket case" in the 1970s best known for disastrous industrial relations and late delivery.

It was privatised first under the mantle of Vickers Shipbuilding and Engineering and then the name was bought by John Stafford, who incorporated into it his own Coastline Shiprepairer firm.

Mr Stafford knew the ship repair sector inside out, and it was not long before he expanded to take in yards on Tyneside and Teeside before floating Cammell on the stock market in 1997. City analysts loved the stock and, flushed with success, Stafford began to move overseas - buying repair yards in Gibraltar, Marseilles and Portland Oregon.

Costa naivety

The Costa conversion contracts were meant to launch Cammell into the lucrative world of specialist cruise ship conversion and then on to full construction.

Cammell is in the middle of talks with the Department of Trade and Industry about help for a £360m order for two cruise ships from a new US-based company, Luxus. This deal, too, appears close to collapse, with some experts worried that the problems with Carnival have soiled Cammell's reputation in the eyes of the British government.

The debacle over the Costa Classica has taken a heavy toll on the ship-building company, which at the least seems guilty of naivety in spending £40m on the Italian contract before it was secured.

Last month, Cammell reported a £3.5m interim pre-tax loss compared with a £7.7m profit during the comparable period last year, and says worse is to come in the full-year results.The yard is now dependent on the Royal Bank of Scotland coming up with the equivalent of a bridging loan to keep the company afloat.

A lot of workers have already been laid off, and if the Luxus deal falls through a further 1,500 jobs will have to go.

Mr Stafford himself has fallen on his sword and resigned as chief executive. Last night, the rest of the company's 2,500 UK staff were hoping the wave that started in Miami would not sweep the rest of them away.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: Cries of outrage were echoing around the City yesterday morning after a bit of forked tongue Treasury naughtiness over a mildly critical IMF report. The FT had a nibble of the IMF's annual economic "health check" on Wednesday, provoking a furious response from HM Treasury and some frothing at the mouth on Great George Street, complete with selective quotes from the document
fields.body:
 Cries of outrage were echoing around the City yesterday morning after a bit of forked tongue Treasury naughtiness over a mildly critical IMF report. The FT had a nibble of the IMF's annual economic "health check" on Wednesday, provoking a furious response from HM Treasury and some frothing at the mouth on Great George Street, complete with selective quotes from the document. Inquirers as to when the full report would be published were told by the Treasury that it was up to the IMF, and not before the end of the week at the earliest. Then - gosh! - the IMF goes and publishes the full report ... with a note saying it was "at the request of the UK government". Now only an extreme cynic would suggest the Treasury gave the green light to release the report at 9pm, when news deadlines had long passed, on a day when a big rail tragedy would take up all the room on the front pages. Such a thing is very, very unlikely given Gordon Brown's well-known commitment to transparency and openness.

 Speaking of the Treasury, hats off to them for their logical and easy to administer proposals requiring some financial journalists to declare an interest in any shares they are tipping to buy or sell. I intend to go along with these perfectly reasonable demands. (Disclaimer: I have an interest in sucking up to the Treasury for career purposes.)

 Happy news that Gerald Corbett has put that Railtrack business behind him and found a new job as head of Woolworth (and it's safer for the rest of us too, since department stores very rarely suffer signals passed at danger). Well done, Gerald, but perhaps it would have been diplomatic for you not to refer to Woolworth's "excellent track record". It just draws attention. (Disclaimer: I once stole sweets from Woolworth's pick'n'mix as a child, and now feel guilty every time I pass one. Sorry.)

 You have to feel sorry for BP Amoco. Actually, no you don't. The company has rejected four environmental and human rights resolutions due to be heard at its AGM for piffling technical reasons. "In no way do we want to choke off legitimate debate," said a BP official ... which doesn't explain why BP chairman John Browne turned down the offer of a legitimate debate on the environment last night at Oxford University, where the great man was giving a speech.

 The ISA selling season is in full swing. All the newspapers are pumping out their own ISA guides, including the Sunday Times, which invited its readers to ring 0800 9150097 for a free copy, sponsored for a hefty sum by Best Invest financial advisers. That hefty sum may turn out to have been a bit of a waste ... the phone number is answered by a voice saying, "Hello, this is AXA ..." who just happened to have sponsored (for a less hefty sum) The Times ISA guide. As a result AXA have picked up an extra 6,000 addresses. For those of you wanting the correct number, it is 0870 9090264. Oops, that's the Guardian's ISA guide line. (Disclaimer: I'm employed by the Guardian. Work it out for yourself.)

 The National Film Theatre's programme for the 15th Lesbian and Gay Film Festival arrives, and is full of fascinating stuff. The eye is especially caught by the April 7 screening of a film intriguingly titled The Euro. Sadly, it's not a passionate account behind closed doors at the European Central Bank.

 You have to wonder about BT sometimes. To celebrate BTinternet signing up its one millionth customer, staff at the in-debt-up-to-its-eyeballs telecoms operator were each given ... a lollypop. As The Register news website succinctly put it: "BT employees suck". (Disclaimer: I ditched BT as my phone operator after too many annoying cold calls offering Friends and Family discounts.)

That hefty sum may turn out to have been a bit of a waste ... the phone number is answered by a voice saying, "Hello, this is AXA ..." who just happened to have sponsored (for a less hefty sum) The Times ISA guide. As a result AXA have picked up an extra 6,000 addresses. For those of you wanting the correct number, it is 0870 9090264. Oops, that's the Guardian's ISA guide line. (Disclaimer: I'm employed by the Guardian. Work it out for yourself.)  The National Film Theatre's programme for the 15th Lesbian and Gay Film Festival arrives, and is full of fascinating stuff. The eye is especially caught by the April 7 screening of a film intriguingly titled The Euro. Sadly, it's not a passionate account behind closed doors at the European Central Bank.  You have to wonder about BT sometimes. To celebrate BTinternet signing up its one millionth customer, staff at the in-debt-up-to-its-eyeballs telecoms operator were each given ... a lollypop. As The Register news website succinctly put it: "BT employees suck". (Disclaimer: I ditched BT as my phone operator after too many annoying cold calls offering Friends and Family discounts.) richard.adams@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Radio review
fields.standfirst: The people have spoken
fields.trailText: Nicky Campbell | Tommy Boyd | Little Britain
fields.body:
Rhodri Morgan's mother-in-law found the Prime Minister in the kitchen early one morning. "You're that Lionel Blair", she said, by way of greeting, unaware of the crushing disappointment to come. Nicky Campbell (Radio 5 Live) begged Morgan to tell this story on the first of his outside broadcasts from around the UK in the weeks leading up to the general election, Snapshot Britain.

The snapshot we got was one of strangeness. Campbell referred to Tony as Lionel for the rest of the show, while Morgan was in top cam paigning mode. "I enjoy meat and I enjoy vegetables - I enjoy all kinds of food", he said, stirringly. One caller declared Labour a bunch of "arrogant SOBs" who are "taking the biscuit" (though not from Morgan's mum-in-law, one hopes); another called Rhodri "Roger". But Morgan was clear on one thing in this sea of mistaken identities: "Denial is not just a big river in Egypt."

If Campbell offers a daytime Polaroid of modern Britain, Tommy Boyd (TalkSPORT) offers a nightmarish vision - think Hieronymus Bosch - in the wee small hours. His Sunday night phone-in, The Human Zoo, is, Boyd says with hefty understatement, "bedlamish".

Unscreened calls are taken at random: it might be an IRA song, it might be a fellow yelling, "do you like currants? beetroot? pickled BLOOD!". Someone calls in to discuss the merits of meat paste; a son phones up to apologise for his father, cut off a few weeks back for "using obletives". Lots of people get through with audio clips; one woman called Agnes wanted us to hear "a native American honouring the horse". Cue five minutes of clippity-clop noises.

Agnes apart, it's a man's world. Compliments are rare and relative - "you're not a verbal wanker", Boyd is told.

With such stiff competition from reality, Little Britain (Radio 4), a new comedy series written by Matt Lucas and David Williamson, had an uphill struggle given its target: oddball Britain. A spoof of the grandiloquent survey series, this was a nonsense thing of surreal joy sonorously narrated by Tom Baker. Subjects included a rubbish transvestite, a bad witch who's got the builders in, Dennis Waterman in tears with his agent, and Lucas as a slimming-club leader.

The series has a hard edge too, with lines like "fat people - they get in the way, and in summer they smell". A retired policeman turned driving instructor can't leave his old lines behind. "Get out of the car, you black bastard", he tells a first-time, white driver. After The Human Zoo, it all felt mighty real.

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: Jazz Legends | The Friday Play - 23 Years | Night Waves
fields.body:
Bud Powell is the subject of today's Jazz Legends (Radio 3, 4pm). Lots of favourite recordings, including the pianist playing with Charlie Parker, and his performance at the 1960 Essen Jazz Festival.

When Patrick Nicholls was released from prison in 1998 after serving 23 years for murder, he joined a shamefully long list of victims of miscarriage of justice. The Friday Play - 23 Years (Radio 4, 9pm) is Mike Walker's dramatisation of Nicholls's fight to clear his name. "Joseph Kaye" is an ordinary Joe until the old lady he visits happens to die. An investigation begins and the pathologist concludes that the woman died from a blow to her face. It is a quick step from courtroom to prison cell, and once there the Kafka-esque scenario all prisoners who maintain their innocence must face - if you don't admit your guilt then you won't be considered for parole; you must sit inside and campaign to get your conviction overturned. Alun Armstrong plays Joseph Kaye, Danny Webb is DI Brunner and Pip Torrens is the pathologist, Dr Priest.

If you are one of those people who perfect strangers tell to "cheer up, love. It'll never happen" then Night Waves (Radio 3, 9.30pm) might give you some comfort. Presenter Sarah Dunant wonders why we pursue happiness, and explores the cultural history of melancholy - a much richer depository than that devoted to being blissfully happy.

fields.headline: At this price? Argonaut
fields.trailText: In a scene that could have come straight out of one of its computer games, Argonaut came crashing down to earth yesterday with disappointing half-year results.
fields.body:
In a scene that could have come straight out of one of its computer games, Argonaut came crashing down to earth yesterday with disappointing half-year results.

Investors took fright as the company reported a depressing £1.6m loss on the back of a reduced turnover figure - down to just £1.5m, compared with £2.5m in the same period last year.

The dismay was reflected in the share price. By the close, the stock has slumped 24% to 45.5p. This is way off its 113p year high and heading towards the 33p low.

Since it floated on the stock market last year, the value of Argonaut has more than halved, and the company is now worth less than £46m.

But the company's situation must be viewed against the backdrop of a games industry in transit to the next generation consoles - a fact not overlooked in Argonaut's announcement to the stock market yesterday morning.

There have been substantial delays in the production of hardware associated with the new generation move and this, it is clear, has played a key role in Argonaut's downward spiral in recent months.

The turnover decline is being blamed on a serious reduction in royalties. The first half of 2000 was bolstered by the launch of Croc 2 in August 1999 and a full six months selling both Croc and Croc 2 games. This year, however, income from these games has dropped away as they are classed as being at a "mature stage" of their life.

Unfortunately three new titles released in the run-up to Christmas - Alien Resurrection, Aladdin and The Emperor's New Groove - have been disappointing so far.

But the future certainly does not all consist of doom and gloom predictions for London-based Argonaut. The company's showcase title, Malice, has been well received and was given its first public demonstration by Bill Gates of Microsoft during the first week of January and development continues on new generation games. Hold.

fields.headline: TV pick of the day
fields.trailText: Plunkett And Macleane | Out Of Sight | The Witches Of Eastwick | Bad Lieutenant | Live rugby league
fields.body:
Films

Plunkett And Macleane (Jake Scott, 1999)
8pm, Sky Premier

Jake Scott directs this tale of 18th-century highwaymen as though it were one of his dad Ridley's sci-fi forays: Blade Riders, perhaps, full of exotic visuals and pumping dance music. But unlike his father's films, there's not much else to enjoy beyond the sheer elan: the chaotic plot has Robert Carlyle's lowly Plunkett teaming up with Jonny Lee Miller's gentlemanly Macleane to steal from the rich - and keep it. Liv Tyler is underemployed as Macleane's wench and Ken Stott is a pantomime baddy.

Out Of Sight (Steven Soderbergh, 1998)
10pm, Sky Premier

This hip and witty thriller brought indie star Soderbergh storming into the mainstream. Scriptwriter Scott "Get Shorty" Frank plots an intricate path through Elmore Leonard's twisty novel, and hangs on to the master's snappy dialogue. Meanwhile George Clooney's bank robber and Jennifer Lopez's federal marshal fizz with odd-couple chemistry; Ving Rhames is dead cool as Clooney's partner in crime, and Michael Keaton and Samuel L Jackson appear unannounced.

The Witches Of Eastwick (George Miller, 1987)
10pm, Sky Cinema

Jack Nicholson is Daryl Van Horne, "a horny little devil" dreamed up by sultry trio Cher, Susan Sarandon and Michelle Pfeiffer to banish their Eastwick ennui; but he proves rather too stimulating. A spellbinding, sexy comedy, retaining the latent threat of John Updike's clever novel, though the overheated finale is disappointing.

Bad Lieutenant (Abel Ferrara, 1992)
12.10am, FilmFour

Harvey Keitel's detective is not the guy you want to call when you've been burgled: he's up to his eyes in heroin, booze and gambling debts, and inclined to sexually humiliate teenage girls. He's a walking composite of human degradation, wriggling in a putrid New York. He's not nice. And then, astonishingly, the case of the raped nun offers a chance of redemption. Uncompromising, bravura work from director and star.

The Violent Cop (Takeshi Kitano, 1989)
1.50am, FilmFour

Admirers of Kitano's sublime Hana Bi will see similarities in this cruder, more violent treatment of familiar themes: paint splashed on walls rather than Hana Bi's fine calligraphy. Kitano, a silent, monolithic screen presence, plays the cop, Azume, who takes on the yakuza and his own corrupt bosses with maximum force, while caring tenderly for his ailing, addicted sister. A relentless, very stylish thriller.

Paul Howlett

Others

Live rugby league
7.30pm Sky Sports 1

Rugby League simply never stops. As the winter leagues wind down, the new Super League season kicks off at Valley Parade where Bradford Bulls face last year's champions St Helens. The Saints are joint favourites with big-spending Wigan to repeat their feat this year, with Bradford not far behind, so a fiercely contested encounter between these two local rivals looks almost certain.

Simon Burnton

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Flower power
fields.trailText: Flower power
fields.body:
Northumberland

Lambing has already started here. Ewes are grouped in hemmels, and once their offspring are feeding and tottering about, the families are turned out for exercise. The majority of cattle are also inside, until the spring grass comes through - which seems to be later every year, especially when it has been as wet as this winter has been.

"I've not been out of my wellies since Christmas", sighed one farmer's wife, who was helping her husband sell lamb from their stall at our local farmers' market. I am glad to say they were doing a brisk trade.

Later, I took the dogs for a walk, on their leads (much to my dachshund's disgust) through the beautiful Belsay Hall quarry gardens, now an English Heritage property. The gardens were fashioned from the void left after stone had been mined for the hall, providing a sheltered microclimate which has allowed tender introductions to survive.

Some of the plants and trees here were brought back from all corners of the world by intrepid 19th and early 20th-century collectors. Many men died on expeditions, others survived avalanches or horrendous chases from hostile natives. Most were going into uncharted territory. David Douglas's Douglas fir tree brought from North America to Belsay in 1827 still lives, but he was gored to death after falling into a buffalo pit. William Lobb successfully introduced the monkey puzzle tree in the mid-19th century. The early collectors brought back many thousands of rare plant varieties, sometimes sponsored by nurseries who then charged high prices to gardeners and estates who wanted the latest exotic novelties.

webTitle: Puff Daddy has his day in court

fields.headline: Puff Daddy has his day in court
fields.standfirst: Facing the rap
fields.trailText: The rap star Sean "Puffy" Combs - aka Puff Daddy - who is accused of possessing a firearm and bribery, told a court yesterday how a night of champagne and dancing on the tables of a New York nightclub was transformed by gunfire and ended in a police chase.
fields.body:
The rap star Sean "Puffy" Combs - aka Puff Daddy - who is accused of possessing a firearm and bribery, told a court yesterday how a night of champagne and dancing on the tables of a New York nightclub was transformed by gunfire and ended in a police chase.

"I thought I was being shot at," said the 31-year-old head of a $250m business empire. "I had felt the shots were for me. As fast as I could get down there, I was just trying to get away from danger."

He said that he heard four shots ring out as he and his entourage, including his then girlfriend, the singer and actress Jennifer Lopez, left the VIP section of Club New York in Times Square on December 27 1999.

He had run up a $4,000 champagne bill preparing for a Caribbean cruise that he and Lopez were due to start the following day.

The prosecution says that Combs was illegally carrying a gun when there was a fracas in the club and that he tried to bribe his chauffeur with $50,000 to accept responsibility for a gun found in the car in which they fled from police. Three people were wounded in the shooting.

Combs told the state supreme court in Manhattan yesterday that he did not have a gun, believed he was the intended victim of the violence and that they fled the scene because he was worried about Lopez.

His bodyguard, Anthony "Wolf" Jones, 34, is also accused of possessing a gun and his protege, rapper Jamal "Shyne" Barrow, 21, is charged with attempted murder.

Combs said he did not see a man throwing money at him, an incident that the prosecution says sparked the clash. Asked whether he had offered his driver a bribe, he replied: "Absolutely not."

The star faces up to 15 years in jail if convicted.

The defence said that it might yet call Lopez to testify. "She categorically exonerates Mr Combs on a number of issues," Benjamin Brafman, Combs' lawyer, said.

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.standfirst: I think about suicide daily and no therapy seems to work. What can I do?
fields.trailText: I think about suicide daily and no therapy seems to work. What can I do?
fields.body:
Three-and-a-half years ago my surviving parent died. Two months later my partner of 18 years left me. I have lots of lovely people in my life - siblings, nieces, nephews, godchildren and good friends. I have switched to an interesting job, paid off debts I was left with and sorted out legal problems on our jointly owned flat. However, I still feel overwhelmed by depression. I've had counselling, bereavement counselling, psychotherapy, drug therapy and hypnotherapy. I have taken holidays and spent money on nice things to do. But I think about suicide almost daily. I have no interest in my appearance, finding a new partner, sex, making new friends or planning for the future. I have become forgetful about other people and their needs. How can I recover from this unhappy existence?

You're doing well

In three-and-a-half years you have switched jobs, paid off your debts and solved your accommodation troubles despite everything that happened to you. You're doing well. It is hardly surprising that your appearance, finding a new partner and making new friends have taken a back seat. Thank goodness for your old friends - if they're still supportive and loyal you're really blessed. And how could you possibly have planned for the future with so much "past" to sort out?

I had a more or less identical experience at the same time as you. You don't mention children, so we possibly have this in common. Have you thought about a dog? The discipline of walking a dog every day helps cut through the chaotic thoughts, the exercise is good for you and you meet really nice people.

I can also highly recommend the Samaritans for dark moments. Your awareness that you are forgetful about other people and their needs surely indicates that this situation is not irreversible. Give yourself a pat on the back and think about the huge benefits of living without the fear of debt and a feckless partner.

Name and address withheld

Try group therapy

The counselling you have received all seems very "self" centred. My first piece of advice is to try group therapy. In group therapy you are given permission to explore the way you feel without "owing" anything. The people in the group are not your friends but in time they do know you and are accepting of you. And you can draw on your own experiences to offer something back.

There is a generosity in group therapy that transcends one-to-one therapies where you are the centre of attention, which, in my experience, can exacerbate one's unhappiness. Over a period of time you can come to understand that your feelings, whatever the individual circumstances, are common to us all. I believe this is where the healing process starts.

My second piece of advice is to turn to literature for help. Read the great novels dealing with the human condition. War and Peace and Thomas Hardy come to mind. Through these novels you do get a perspective on your place in the world. Or try "think yourself lucky" novels such as Grapes of Wrath, where again you are confronted with the human capacity for struggle. The message is that you are going to have to get on with it and wait for things to get better... and if you are lucky they will.

Name and address withheld

Talk to a GP and a friend

You can see life is worth having but your sickness is poisoning every perception you have. You will have heard this before but: depression is a dangerous illness. You need a GP and a clinical psychologist who will take time with you to find the right drug. Your self-obsession, guilt and lack of concern about your appearance are symptoms of the illness, as are the suicidal thoughts.

You need a friend who you can open up to for long periods. They are the best therapy along with the right pill. You are not weak or to blame; there is just a small chemical change to be rectified and the world is still there to enjoy if you can just clear your vision.

Chris Hardy, London

Follow your dreams

I too have endured depression and thoughts of suicide for many years. Society expects us to "snap out of" these situations too quickly. Knowing that you might be forgetful of others' needs shows you have more awareness of people around you than most. So what if you don't feel inclined to worry about your appearance or pursue a new partner? You will when you're ready.

My tip for moving forward: dig in your memory for ambitions and follow one. Mine was the decision to go and watch whales in the wild. Rekindling one or two special dreams will bring back the smiles.

Cathy Jones, Essex

Homeopathy may help

As a therapist of several disciplines and a student of homeopathy, I would recommend that you consider consulting a homeopath. Homeopathy does not separate the mental, emotional and physical. Get a register from the Society of Homeopaths at 4a Artizan Road, Northampton, NN1 4HU or phone 01604 621400. Good luck.

Name and address withheld

Next week

Shortly before Christmas, my husband of four years announced, by email, that he intended to leave me. He was working overseas, and when he got back he left the family home offering little explanation. I've tried to persuade him to change his mind but there is little chance of reconciliation. I live where I do because we moved here for my husband's job a year-and-a-half ago. My family and all my friends are 500 miles away, but my husband says he wants to spend equal time with our son, who is two-and-a-half. He also has a daughter overseas whom he does not see for months on end. Do I return to where my family is so I can get reliable support for me and my son, or do I stick it out here, where I have few friends, so my son and his father can have regular contact?

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. fields.bodyText: Three-and-a-half years ago my surviving parent died. Two months later my partner of 18 years left me. I have lots of lovely people in my life - siblings, nieces, nephews, godchildren and good friends. I have switched to an interesting job, paid off debts I was left with and sorted out legal problems on our jointly owned flat. However, I still feel overwhelmed by depression. I've had counselling, bereavement counselling, psychotherapy, drug therapy and hypnotherapy. I have taken holidays and spent money on nice things to do. But I think about suicide almost daily. I have no interest in my appearance, finding a new partner, sex, making new friends or planning for the future. I have become forgetful about other people and their needs. How can I recover from this unhappy existence? You're doing well In three-and-a-half years you have switched jobs, paid off your debts and solved your accommodation troubles despite everything that happened to you. You're doing well. It is hardly surprising that your appearance, finding a new partner and making new friends have taken a back seat. Thank goodness for your old friends - if they're still supportive and loyal you're really blessed. And how could you possibly have planned for the future with so much "past" to sort out? I had a more or less identical experience at the same time as you. You don't mention children, so we possibly have this in common. Have you thought about a dog? The discipline of walking a dog every day helps cut through the chaotic thoughts, the exercise is good for you and you meet really nice people. I can also highly recommend the Samaritans for dark moments. Your awareness that you are forgetful about other people and their needs surely indicates that this situation is not irreversible. Give yourself a pat on the back and think about the huge benefits of living without the fear of debt and a feckless partner. Name and address withheld Try group therapy The counselling you have received all seems very "self" centred. My first piece of advice is to try group therapy. In group therapy you are given permission to explore the way you feel without "owing" anything. The people in the group are not your friends but in time they do know you and are accepting of you. And you can draw on your own experiences to offer something back. There is a generosity in group therapy that transcends one-to-one therapies where you are the centre of attention, which, in my experience, can exacerbate one's unhappiness. Over a period of time you can come to understand that your feelings, whatever the individual circumstances, are common to us all. I believe this is where the healing process starts. My second piece of advice is to turn to literature for help. Read the great novels dealing with the human condition. War and Peace and Thomas Hardy come to mind. Through these novels you do get a perspective on your place in the world. Or try "think yourself lucky" novels such as Grapes of Wrath, where again you are confronted with the human capacity for struggle. The message is that you are going to have to get on with it and wait for things to get better... and if you are lucky they will. Name and address withheld Talk to a GP and a friend You can see life is worth having but your sickness is poisoning every perception you have. You will have heard this before but: depression is a dangerous illness. You need a GP and a clinical psychologist who will take time with you to find the right drug. Your self-obsession, guilt and lack of concern about your appearance are symptoms of the illness, as are the suicidal thoughts. You need a friend who you can open up to for long periods. They are the best therapy along with the right pill. You are not weak or to blame; there is just a small chemical change to be rectified and the world is still there to enjoy if you can just clear your vision. Chris Hardy, London Follow your dreams I too have endured depression and thoughts of suicide for many years. Society expects us to "snap out of" these situations too quickly. Knowing that you might be forgetful of others' needs shows you have more awareness of people around you than most. So what if you don't feel inclined to worry about your appearance or pursue a new partner? You will when you're ready. My tip for moving forward: dig in your memory for ambitions and follow one. Mine was the decision to go and watch whales in the wild. Rekindling one or two special dreams will bring back the smiles. Cathy Jones, Essex Homeopathy may help As a therapist of several disciplines and a student of homeopathy, I would recommend that you consider consulting a homeopath. Homeopathy does not separate the mental, emotional and physical. Get a register from the Society of Homeopaths at 4a Artizan Road, Northampton, NN1 4HU or phone 01604 621400. Good luck. Name and address withheld Next week Shortly before Christmas, my husband of four years announced, by email, that he intended to leave me. He was working overseas, and when he got back he left the family home offering little explanation. I've tried to persuade him to change his mind but there is little chance of reconciliation. I live where I do because we moved here for my husband's job a year-and-a-half ago. My family and all my friends are 500 miles away, but my husband says he wants to spend equal time with our son, who is two-and-a-half. He also has a daughter overseas whom he does not see for months on end. Do I return to where my family is so I can get reliable support for me and my son, or do I stick it out here, where I have few friends, so my son and his father can have regular contact?  Private Lives appears every Friday. fields.headline: Making enemies
fields.trailText: Many teachers like myself must have wondered if the enemy of my enemy is my friend. The conundrum is now solved (Woodhead lays into Blair and Blunkett, March 1). They all remain my enemy and it's a great joy to see them snapping at each other instead of the poor bloody infantry. More please.
fields.body:
Many teachers like myself must have wondered if the enemy of my enemy is my friend. The conundrum is now solved (Woodhead lays into Blair and Blunkett, March 1). They all remain my enemy and it's a great joy to see them snapping at each other instead of the poor bloody infantry. More please.
Dennis Charman
London

 So Maff may be considering slaughtering Britain's wildlife to combat foot and mouth disease (Eco-soundings, February 28)? I, for one, would never vote for a government that allowed the slaughter of rare wild animals to deal with a non-fatal "economic" disease.
James O'Donoghue
London

 If our retailers can buy meat from abroad more cheaply than from home producers, how are we able to export meat? Surely those foreigners could buy it cheaper in their own countries?
Raymond Cobbett
Billericay, Essex

 What has happened to Guardian North reviews? During the last few months of last year we had regular reviews from the likes of Messrs Simpson and Hopkin (in Manchester) but recently all we seem to get is obscure jazz bands playing in Yorkshire. What's going on?
Dr Richard Milk
Manchester

 John O'Farrell is right in his analogy of a marriage to the Labour party (Letters, February 28). But this union is a bigamous one to a parsimonious, violent transvestite partner. Who could have guessed before the veil was removed? Thank goodness divorce is possible.
Leslie Dalton
Eastbourne, E Sussex

 Bill Gates heckled by an earthquake (Report, March 1)? Maybe there is a god after all.
Jason Hazeley
London

webTitle: Leader: Zimbabwe's chief justice needs support

fields.headline: Illegal and immoral
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe's chief justice needs support

Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Chief justice Anthony Gubbay's brave stand against Robert Mugabe's attempt to emasculate Zimbabwe's independent judiciary deserves the strongest support. But will he get it?
fields.body:
Chief justice Anthony Gubbay's brave stand against Robert Mugabe's attempt to emasculate Zimbabwe's independent judiciary deserves the strongest support. But will he get it? In refusing to be sacked by ministerial diktat, Mr Gubbay is well within his rights in terms of his contract of employment (which runs until April next year), Zimbabwe's constitution (which says a chief justice may only be removed once an independent tribunal has proved misconduct), the 1991 Commonwealth Harare declaration on democratic governance, the UN basic principles on the independence of the judiciary (1985), and UN international covenant on civil and political rights (1976).

Article 17 of this latter document, to which Zimbabwe is a party, states that "no one shall be subjected to arbitrary or unlawful attacks on his honour and reputation". Mr Gubbay, who is British-born, white and Jewish, faces such attacks on all three counts. That is how illegal - and how disgustingly immoral - the assault on the chief justice actually is.

In drawing the line, Mr Gubbay acts, ex parte, for all the many victims of Mr Mugabe's misrule, a long list that includes fellow judges, opposition MPs and their supporters, the farming community (black and white), the church, and the independent media. His persecutors appreciate his symbolic importance and it enrages them. Integrity always infuriates scoundrels. But while they wonder what to do about Mr Gubbay, what will the world do about them?

Britain's decision yesterday to withdraw its military trainers is welcome for the signal it sends. But this, the latest in a series of minor punishments, highlights how little leverage London really has. Robin Cook's announcement last week of an urgent Commonwealth "fact-finding team" also sounds more impressive than it is.

The mission (not his to command) was in fact proposed some time ago, is limited to land reform, and has as yet been given no date for its visit. Like the UN, the Commonwealth has had scant success in modifying Mr Mugabe's behaviour; suspension threats produce only scorn. And as for South Africa's Thabo Mbeki, his recently toughened stance looks like more hot air. Perhaps the best way to apply additional pressure is through the EU, which, at Mr Cook's behest, has begun a "critical dialogue", a possible prelude to sanctions. But this, sadly, is of little help now to Zimbabwe's people - and none at all to Mr Gubbay.

webTitle: Letters: Missives from the mayor's office

fields.headline: Missives from the mayor's office
fields.trailText: I know that the Guardian political staff believes that nothing happens in London other than by the agency of the mayor, but in the case of the New Year's Eve files, I feel that I need to protect him from any unnecessary recriminations by government ministers (Livingstone defies Prescott in row over Whitehall papers, February 24).
fields.body:
I know that the Guardian political staff believes that nothing happens in London other than by the agency of the mayor, but in the case of the New Year's Eve files, I feel that I need to protect him from any unnecessary recriminations by government ministers (Livingstone defies Prescott in row over Whitehall papers, February 24).

The decision to open 82 files in the possession of the GLA was taken entirely by leading members of the London assembly. At present, the assembly is conducting an inquiry into the decision to cancel last year's event, in order to ensure that future plans for major events do not suffer the same fate, and that the capital can mount celebrations worthy of a great world city. Any government documents on the GLA files were handed over to the GLA last year. Assembly members will naturally need to study them as part of the inquiry, and there is no basis for an attempt to deny the assembly access to what are now the GLA's own files. If any papers are found to be subject to any legal obligations on the GLA regarding confidentiality that will be respected.

The mayor should be in no danger of joining us behind bars, though he clearly relishes the prospect of my being "carted off to gaol". Should that happen, I look forward to his visits and his food parcels with as much enthusiasm as I would a visit from that other prisoners' champion, Lord Longford.
Trevor Phillips
Chair of the London assembly

 The reason Catherine Bennett cannot work out how I managed to do so many speaking engagements in one year is because I didn't (Need a party entertainer? Hire an MP, G2, March 1). Her article repeats the common pattern of coverage of this issue by merging several years' earnings into one year. In doing so it grossly inflates the reader's impression of my annual earnings.

Since the mayoral election campaign began, I have not accepted any new paid after-dinner speeches and have merely completed a handful of outstanding ones from before the election. I will not be accepting any paid after-dinner speeches during the course of my mayoralty.
Ken Livingstone
Mayor of London

fields.headline: We're trying
fields.trailText: You say culturally sensitive mental health care is an issue that does not easily get on the NHS agenda (Society, February 21). In fact it is a top priority.
fields.body:
You say culturally sensitive mental health care is an issue that does not easily get on the NHS agenda (Society, February 21). In fact it is a top priority. The mental health task force, set up after publication of the NHS plan, is developing a strategy for services for ethnic minorities, drawing on the experiences of service users, voluntary organisations, clinicians and research.

When I took up the post of national director for mental health last year, I called for training for psychiatrists in cultural competence. The Royal College of Psychiatrists responded positively and is now completing a report.

We have known for years ethnic minorities do not see our current services as appropriate. We are committed to developing services nationally that respect cultural diversity.
Prof Louis Appleby
National director, mental health services

fields.headline: Labour's act of terror
fields.trailText: We note that the DHKP-C (Revolutionary People's Liberation Party-Front) has been placed on the "draft order" of organisations to be banned under the Terrorism Act (21 groups banned under new terror law, March 1).
fields.body:
We note that the DHKP-C (Revolutionary People's Liberation Party-Front) has been placed on the "draft order" of organisations to be banned under the Terrorism Act (21 groups banned under new terror law, March 1). Although the authorities deny there are diplomatic reasons for banning groups, the government of Turkey has been trying to get Britain to ban our and other organisations for many years. A Labour government purporting to have an "ethical" foreign policy has levied a ban on freedom of assembly and expression not even the Conservatives got round to. And it has done it to please a regime in Turkey guilty of torture, murder, rape and disappearances; which systematically represses minorities such as the Kurds, and even makes it a criminal offence to read a press statement in public without prior permission from the police.

The struggle for democracy and revolution in Turkey will continue; the support for this in Britain will continue, whatever the cost and the efforts made to criminalise it.
Name supplied
DHKC Information Bureau
dhkcbureau@netscapeonline.co.uk

 Terrorism is a major problem and governments have an obligation to tackle it to protect the rights of us all. But a distinction should be made between actions which promote violence and the expression of views, however offensive they may be. Criminalising activities which in no way constitute direct (or even indirect) incitement to violence, either here or abroad, is dubious in the extreme.

For example, if I "arouse reasonable suspicion" by wearing an item of clothing or wearing, carrying or displaying an article that might indicate support for one of the 21 organisations on the proscribed list, I could be imprisoned for six months, fined, or both. If the Norwegians were to transfer attempts to broker a peace deal between the LTTE and Sri Lankan government to London, their representative would be liable to imprisonment for up to 10 years for "arranging or managing a meeting which he knows is ... to be addressed by a person who belongs or professes to belong to a proscribed organisation", even if held in private.

It is debatable whether UK judges will interpret the Terrorism Act in the light of the standards of the Human Rights Act. What is certain is that the European court of human rights will take a tough view of attempts to limit legitimate rights to freedom of expression and opinion under the guise of preventing terrorism.
Andrew Puddephatt
Executive director, Article 19
press@article19.org

fields.headline: Prison isn't for children
fields.trailText: As yet another inspection report condemns conditions in young offender institutions (Youth jail seen as stain on prison system, March 1), surely it is time for a fundamental rethink about the way we deal with young people who offend?
fields.body:
As yet another inspection report condemns conditions in young offender institutions (Youth jail seen as stain on prison system, March 1), surely it is time for a fundamental rethink about the way we deal with young people who offend? Locking up children is a failed policy. It abjectedly fails to prevent reoffending - 88% of children released from prison are reconvicted within two years - and it is a dangerous and damaging environment for children to live in.

Children in prison are an extremely needy group. Most have had chaotic lives, characterised by neglect, and a large number have been victims of physical and/or sexual abuse. A third have a recognised psychiatric disorder. By incarcerating children in large prisons, with poor supervision, inadequately trained staff and high levels of violence, we too, are guilty of neglect. The acute anguish experienced by young people in prison is apparent in shocking levels of self-harm and suicide. In a typical month at Feltham there are 10 attempted hangings and, since 1990, 19 children aged under 18 have killed themselves in English and Welsh prisons.

It is time to stop ploughing resources into an institutional approach which has been shown to be both ineffective and damaging, and instead focus on developing programmes in the community. Only then will we be acting in accordance with the UN convention on the rights of the child, which states that "detention or imprisonment of a child shall be used only as a measure of last resort and for the shortest appropriate period of time".
Charlotte Day
Howard League for Penal Reform
howardleague@ukonline.co.uk

fields.headline: The lessons of Selby
fields.trailText: You join in the labelling of the Selby rail disaster as a "freak" accident (Leader, March 1). In the chances of timing it was, but not in a wider sense.
fields.body:
You join in the labelling of the Selby rail disaster as a "freak" accident (Leader, March 1). In the chances of timing it was, but not in a wider sense. You report that there have been 29 cases of road vehicles plunging off bridges over railways in three years, two of which involved collisions with trains. Only this week, an elderly driver turned on to the railway at a level crossing. And almost every day the National Rail website reports disruption of services as a result of a vehicle damaging a road bridge.

Surely such events are symptomatic of a failure to apply comprehensive risk assessment to roads? If Mr Prescott is serious about "a level playing field" in transport and if the terrible scourge of road accidents is to be addressed, Selby should be the catalyst for a radical evaluation of the road system.

If a railway experienced an equipment fault as serious in its potential consequences as a tyre-burst as often as road vehicles do, it would soon take drastic preventative action. Are high speeds compatible with a system in which each vehicle is independently controlled? And so on. The answers may challenge the so-called freedoms of the road, but we owe nothing less to yesterday's victims.
Jonathan Tyler
Passenger Transport Networks
jtyler@ptn.globalnet.co.uk

 Twenty years ago my father and a friend both died in their car as they crossed the railway on the A19 at Selby. Their car was hit by a goods train at 70mph. The accident occurred minutes from Wednesday's crash. Fortunately the driver of the train that killed my father was not injured and the train was not derailed. My father was believed, for some reason, to have driven around a half-barrier. The accident was caused not by a "unique set of circumstances", but by an entirely preventable situation.

I can't help wondering if those half barriers have been replaced with full barriers. I hope Railtrack will take action to prevent another train being derailed in preventable circumstances.
Usha Kar
Oxford

 The Selby tragedy was not a rail accident. Rather, it was just one out of a normal day's quota of road accidents, unusual only in that this time the innocent bystanders who were killed happened to be rail passengers, rather than the more usual - and acceptable? - children, pedestrians, cyclists, and other motorists.
Paul Smee
Bristol

 Had Railtrack performed a proper risk assessment in conjunction with the highways agency, it would have come up with the conclusion that high-speed road traffic running across a high-speed rail line, only a few feet away, was a potential danger zone. We should now have motorway speed restrictions near all rail bridges until adequate precautions are in place.
Mark Hellen
London

 I am writing this whilst travelling on a GNER train out of Kings Cross just hours after the latest disaster - another blow to rail travel that brings both a terrible recognition of our common vulnerability and private grief about lost and injured colleagues and customers. In the face of this, GNER staff have produced a standard of customer service which has been quite extraordinary: the swift reallocation of travellers to alternative routes, a huge input of staff seeking to answer queries rather than waiting to be asked: an atmosphere of calm courtesy and kindness.
Catherine Shea
Newcastle upon Tyne

 If high-speed trains were fitted with seat belts, is it possible that lives might have been saved?
Very Rev Michael Sadgrove
Dean, Sheffield Cathedral

 Why was 1,000 tonnes of coal imported at Immingham travelling across the largest and most productive coalfield in Europe?
Neil Hanson
Huddersfield, W Yorks

The accident was caused not by a "unique set of circumstances", but by an entirely preventable situation. I can't help wondering if those half barriers have been replaced with full barriers. I hope Railtrack will take action to prevent another train being derailed in preventable circumstances. Usha Kar Oxford  The Selby tragedy was not a rail accident. Rather, it was just one out of a normal day's quota of road accidents, unusual only in that this time the innocent bystanders who were killed happened to be rail passengers, rather than the more usual - and acceptable? - children, pedestrians, cyclists, and other motorists. Paul Smee Bristol  Had Railtrack performed a proper risk assessment in conjunction with the highways agency, it would have come up with the conclusion that high-speed road traffic running across a high-speed rail line, only a few feet away, was a potential danger zone. We should now have motorway speed restrictions near all rail bridges until adequate precautions are in place. In the face of this, GNER staff have produced a standard of customer service which has been quite extraordinary: the swift reallocation of travellers to alternative routes, a huge input of staff seeking to answer queries rather than waiting to be asked: an atmosphere of calm courtesy and kindness. Catherine Shea Newcastle upon Tyne  If high-speed trains were fitted with seat belts, is it possible that lives might have been saved? Very Rev Michael Sadgrove Dean, Sheffield Cathedral  Why was 1,000 tonnes of coal imported at Immingham travelling across the largest and most productive coalfield in Europe? Neil Hanson Huddersfield, W Yorks

fields.headline: Reluctant judge defies Mugabe
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe's chief justice spurns 'illegal' order to leave office and make way for compliant successor

Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's chief justice spurns 'illegal' order to leave office and make way for compliant successor.
fields.body:
As Zimbabwe's white chief justice steered his Mercedes towards the gates of the supreme court yesterday he did not know if the policeman on guard would admit him or arrest him.

As it turned out, the officer saluted, the gates swung open and Anthony Gubbay - a Manchester-born lawyer described as quiet and even timid by colleagues - reluctantly found himself leading the struggle to defend the last arm of state prepared to defy President Robert Mugabe.

The government tried to sack Mr Gubbay as the supreme court's chief justice earlier this week after months of vilifying him as a racist because he oversaw rulings which found Mr Mugabe's wholesale redistribution of white-owned farms, and other misuses of power, illegal.

Mr Gubbay had already agreed to take early retirement in June but the government wants him out of the way before then.

He stands in the way of a grand plan to purge the hierarchy of Zimbabwe's judiciary - including the entire supreme court and much of the high court - to ensure that the government gets its way over the land seizures and that the ruling party, Zanu-PF, retains power.

Zimbabwe's justice minister, Patrick Chinamasa, had told Mr Gubbay to vacate his office by yesterday. But the chief justice went to work anyway, and forced Mr Mugabe to seek another way to seize control of the judiciary.

In parliament this week, the ruling party derided Mr Gubbay as a man who "thinks and behaves as if he is the last British governor in Zimbabwe".

A Zanu-PF MP, Christopher Mushowe, alleged that the chief justice was "infiltrated into Zimbabwe by British intelligence to overthrow the government" even though he arrived in 1958 when it was the colony of Southern Rhodesia.

The chief justice's supporters dismiss the allegations of racism as preposterous. Mr Gubbay gained a distinguished reputation as a lawyer for defending black opponents of Ian Smith's illegal regime. And it was Mr Mugabe who elevated Mr Gubbay to the position of chief justice, having described him as a "nice man". Would Zimbabwe's president have chosen an avowed racist for such a role?

"Gubbay would not have chosen to take on Mugabe like this," one of the chief justice's colleagues said. "To him, it's all a terrible mistake. But he's been put into a position where they have so humiliated a decent man that he has had to fight back. It was all an accident, really."

The accident came from a meeting Mr Gubbay held with Zimbabwe's vice-president, Simon Muzenda, to demand better security for all judges after public death threats by "war veterans" unhappy with court rulings about the land seizures.

Mr Muzenda said the government had little faith in the judges, and Mr Gubbay said that if that was the case, and if the police were not prepared to protect them, perhaps he should resign.

At a second meeting, the justice minister said the government would not protect the judges and reminded Mr Gubbay of his threat to quit.

The chief justice was cornered. He agreed to take early retirement in June and to go on leave from yesterday.

The government had what it wanted. But Mr Mugabe's men were greedy.

Perhaps they wanted everything immediately, or perhaps they felt the need to humiliate Mr Gubbay.

Either way, on Tuesday the chief justice read in the paper of a letter from the justice minister ordering him out of his office and announcing that a designated successor was ready to move in.

Mr Gubbay said that the appointment of a replacement was illegal, and withdrew his offer to take early retirement.

The battle for control of the courts might be brief if the government resorts to the methods used to occupy the farms. But it may also decide to fight it out in the very courts it is seeking to control, without any assurance of success.

There is much at stake. For a start, the courts are deciding whether to overturn the government's slender majority in parliament because of vote-rigging in June's election.

The government is also apparently laying the legal ground to bar the principal opposition candidate, Morgan Tsvangirai, from running in the presidential election.

It will ultimately be the supreme court that decides that case.

If Mr Gubbay is still chief justice with his present colleagues around him, there is little prospect of the government pulling off that particularly dirty trick.

webTitle: Seattle quake will cost state billions

fields.headline: Seattle quake will cost state billions
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: One woman died of a heart attack and more than 250 injuries have so far been reported as a result of Wednesday's earthquake near Seattle.
fields.body:
One woman died of a heart attack and more than 250 injuries have so far been reported as a result of Wednesday's earthquake near Seattle.

Billions of dollars worth of damage was caused throughout Washington state by the 6.8 magnitude earthquake and the state governor, Gary Locke, has declared a state of emergency.

There were two small aftershocks in the area early yesterday morning but no damage or injuries were reported. "We're just really, really lucky," Mr Locke said after surveying the region by helicopter. It was the biggest earthquake to hit the Pacific Northwest for 52 years.

"We believe the damage could go into the billions of dollars when you calculate not only property damage and the cost of repair but also the economic impact of lost wages, people who aren't working, businesses not in operation," he added.

Although some roads were still closed, the Seattle-Tacoma airport was almost back to normal after being closed in the wake of the earthquake. Power has now been restored for some 200,000 users throughout the state who had been cut off.

Experts said that one of the reasons for the lack of deaths and serious injuries was that the earthquake's epicentre was 33 miles underground, in solid rock. The area has also spent a lot of money in the last 20 years to ensure that buildings could withstand major shocks.

One of the city's best known landmarks, the Space Needle, was built to handle a 9.1 magnitude earthquake. It shuddered violently during the tremor and 30 people were briefly stranded at the top.

The earthquake, which was felt as far away as Portland, Oregon, and British Columbia, also caused a landslide in Renton, Washington.

The 66-year-old woman who died lived in Burien, south of Seattle, although it was not confirmed that her death had been directly caused by the earthquake.

Six people, including an 84-year-old man with pelvic fractures and another man whose back was broken, remain seriously ill.

George Bush ordered Joe Allbaugh, the head of the federal emergency management agency, to visit the area and assess the damage.

fields.headline: Rant or rave
fields.standfirst:
Exit one Woodhead, enter another

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Until yesterday there were two Chris Woodheads struggling with each other.
fields.body:
Until yesterday there were two Chris Woodheads struggling with each other. As chief inspector of schools, he was required to report fairly on progress as well as reverses behind the school gate. This he dutifully did in his annual reports, but was far from dismayed when the media concentrated on the bad bits.

The other Chris Woodhead revelled in his media role as the teachers' bogeyman. From yesterday, the first Chris Woodhead exited right stage. Released from his contractual requirement to remain silent about Ofsted for the first three months, following his resignation last November, the second Chris Woodhead emerged yesterday full of undiluted bile and bitterness towards ministers and teachers in his new role as a Daily Telegraph columnist and leader writer.

So which Chris Woodhead should be believed? Should it be the measured Mr Woodhead, who in his last annual review noted "the quality of teaching has improved in all types of schools, in all subjects and in all year groups". More headteachers were raising expectations and supporting their staff; more were monitoring teaching in a more systematic way.

Then there was the spectacular rise in primary pupil achievements in English and maths tests. Secondary school progress was still disappointing and the gaps between the best and worst were worrying, but most schools were tackling the weaknesses identified by inspectors. And looking to the future, "government initiatives such as educational action zones and excellence in cities may have a profound impact".

Or should it be the Telegraph's new columnist, who in a full-page report entitled: Woodhead: the final report, was only able to concede four lines to progress and 2,500 words on what was wrong with teachers, schools and ministers. Apart from the rise in primary literacy and numeracy skills, everything else was wrong, from excessive bureaucratic interference, through an excess of government initiatives, to the concentration on inculcating labour skills.

David Blunkett's immediate response was absolutely right. Unlike his former chief inspector, he refused to indulge in personal abuse and impressively paid tribute to Chris Woodhead's work as chief inspector. Mr Woodhead has demeaned himself.

All good columnists need to be opinionated and each should be allowed the occasional rant, but his opening tirade exposes a naivety (in believing he could expect prime ministers to get involved in detailed educational change), an unattractive callowness in allowing abuse to replace rigorous argument, and a wooden style (including a "therefore" in his intro for goodness sake) which does not augur well for his journalistic future.

Mr Blunkett can relax. His record at education is safe. It was the education secretary who insisted on a nationwide literacy and numeracy hour, not the chief inspector. It was Mr Blunkett who pushed this through against much initial opposition, but which is now both popular with teachers and parents for the dramatic improvement in primary school standards. There was no mention of Labour's bold targets, smaller primary classes, wider access to nursery education, or new vocational package.

Mr Woodhead denies he is a conservative. Yesterday's rant more than qualifies him to join an opposition which dares not concede any success to the current government. His abrasive term helped lift education standards, but his successor looks set to overshadow him by shifting Ofsted's focus on to a more urgent priority: getting more funds into schools.

fields.trailText: Apologies for including among the celebrities who live in Muswell Hill in London (yesterday's Space, page 22) the actor Gary Olsen. He died in Australia last year.
fields.body:
Apologies for including among the celebrities who live in Muswell Hill in London (yesterday's Space, page 22) the actor Gary Olsen. He died in Australia last year.

In an article about gap years, Education, pages 12 and 13, February 27, we included in a survival guide for students working abroad the advice to "get vaccinated against illnesses like TB and malaria". There is no vaccination against malaria.

An editing slip in a report, page 7, February 28, about Harrison Ford's $1m-a-day role in K-19: The Widow maker, made it appear that Ford went to Moscow to meet Captain Zateyev, the hero of the K-19 submarine incident. In fact, he went to meet his widow, Antonina.

In an article about Kentucky, pages 14 and 15, Travel, February 24, we said the Kentucky Derby in Louisville took place in early June. In fact, it happens on the first Saturday in May.

In our notes on the week's best films on television, page 54, the Guide, February 24, we mentioned Gordon Parry's film Sailor Beware, 1956, with Peggy Mount, based on the stage farce of the same name, but illustrated it with a still of Hal Walker's Sailor Beware of 1951, with Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Deadly fruit | Praise for bomb | Sect jailings | Dustbin death
fields.body:
Deadly fruit

At least 38 people, mostly children, have died in Haiti's northern province after eating unripened fruit, radio reports said yesterday. The fruit that envelops the seeds of ackee is only edible when the 7-10cm pods are allowed to open naturally.
AP, Port-au-Prince

Praise for bomb

The world's most wanted Islamic militant, Osama bin Laden, yesterday praised the bombing of a US destroyer in Yemen last year, saying it was a ship of injustice that sailed to its doom. Two suicide bombers detonated a small boat of explosives alongside the USS Cole in Aden harbour on October 12, killing 17 sailors.
AP, Dubai

Sect jailings

China said yesterday 37 members of the banned Falun Gong movement had been sentenced to jail, with one receiving seven years for downloading and distributing internet material, the official Xinhua news agency said.
AFP, Beijing

Dustbin death

A student died yesterday when the wheelie bin she had climbed into to race down the world's steepest street crashed into a trailer. Ana Louise North, 19, died instantly after the collision on Baldwin Street, Dunedin, on New Zealand's South Island.
Patrick Barkham

fields.headline: Asian anger at war history
fields.trailText: The South Korean president, Kim Dae-jung, told the Japanese government yesterday that it needed a history lesson, as a row escalated over a new school textbook that glosses over Japan's role in the second world war.
fields.body:
The South Korean president, Kim Dae-jung, told the Japanese government yesterday that it needed a history lesson, as a row escalated over a new school textbook that glosses over Japan's role in the second world war.

The book has provoked protests in South Korea, North Korea and China since it was submitted to the Japanese education ministry for approval last year.

According to a draft, Japan's victories over western powers in south-east Asia filled independence movements in the region with "courage and inspiration". The 1939-1945 conflict is called the "Greater East Asian War", a term used by the military regime of the time to justify Japan's military adventurism as a crusade against white imperialists.

The authors say they want to counter the excessively "masochistic" view of history imposed on Japan by the US.

On Wednesday, the South Korean parliament called on Japan to halt textbooks that "distort history" and "give rise to new conflicts" in the region.

Meanwhile, a Chinese foreign ministry spokesman, Zhu Bangzao, said: "The rightist group in Japan concocted the history textbook to further the historical concept of imperialist Japan and to deny and whitewash the history of aggression."

North Korea's state news agency said the book was "an insult" to Koreans and other Asian peoples.
