fields.headline: 80 years on, hope of reparation for race riot victims
fields.standfirst: Inquiry finds for 121 survivors of Tulsa rampage by white mob, but governor fears it may open door to wider claims
fields.trailText: Inquiry finds for 121 survivors of Tulsa rampage by white mob, but governor fears it may open door to wider claims.
fields.body:
George Monroe can still recall vividly the summer night in Tulsa, Oklahoma, nearly 80 years ago. "My mother saw four men with torches coming towards our house,"

Mr Monroe, now 85 and a slim, dignified war veteran, said: "Everything was burning outside and you could hear gunshots. She told us kids - I was five - to get under the bed and hide."

He can still remember peering from under the bed at the men's boots as they stomped in and set fire to the curtains.

False rumours that a black shoe-shiner called Dick Rowland had molested a white lift operator called Sarah Page had swept Tulsa that week and on May 31 1921 - as the local newspaper, the Tulsa Tribune, ran the headline "To Lynch Negro Tonight" - a white mob, including the Ku Klux Klan, rampaged through the middle-class Greenwood area, known at the time as the "black Wall Street".

Rowland escaped. It is not known what happened to him later, but one rumour is that he eloped to Kansas with Page.

Many of the people of Greenwood were not so fortunate. At the end of the night's mayhem at least 40 members of the thriving black community had been killed in one of the worst race riots the US has seen.

Now a panel officially appointed to investigate the Tulsa riot has recommended that Mr Monroe and the other 120 remaining survivors be paid reparations in some form, a decision seen as highly significant for the reparations movement in the US, which has argued for African Americans to receive compensation for slavery and discrimination.

The Tulsa Race Riot Commission, appointed by the state legislature, delivered its final 200-page report this week to the governor of Oklahoma, Frank Keating. It says reparations "will stand as symbols that fully acknowledge and finally discharge a collective responsibility".

At least 40 died in the riots although researchers suggest that the number killed could be as high as 300, as many were buried in mass graves,. The commission has concluded that the true death toll will probably never be known.

"Not one of these criminal acts was then or ever has been prosecuted or punished by the government at any level, municipal, county, state or federal," the report said.

The commission has recommended five forms of reparation: cash payments to the 121 survivors, cash payments to authenticated descendants of survivors, a scholarship fund in memory of those who died, business incentives to revive the Greenwood area where the riot took place and a memorial. The state has already agreed to a $5m memorial and support for the revitalisation of the area.

However, reactions to the recommendation of reparations varied."Some com pensation may be in order," the state house speaker, Larry Adair, said, but added: "I think we need to be very cautious on making any commitments on how money is spent in the state of Oklahoma."

Governor Keating said that he favoured raising money for a suitable memorial for the victims but does not support specific financial reparations for the descendants of the survivors. "If you can show liability on the part of the state, city and county, I do support reparations to survivors," he added.The issue will now be debated in the state legislature.

Eddiefaye Gates, the chairwoman of the survivors' committee and a member of the commission, said yesterday that resistance to the idea of compensation was unsurprising.

"There is something about this whole nation when it comes to black people," said Ms Gates. "We did it for the native Americans whose land had been taken, we did it for the Japanese Americans who were interned during the war and had their property taken but when it comes to black people, we don't do it."

Plans for the memorial have already been approved but Ms Gates said that legislators were obliged to do this because a memorial has already been completed for the victims of the much more recent Oklahoma City bombing.

Ms Gates, whose committee has tracked down 121 survivors so far, said that she was still finding more all over the US. The furthest away survivor she had located was a jazz musician in Paris called Hal Singer, who was a baby at the time.

The Oklahoma representative Don Ross, whose bill in the state legislature set up the inquiry and who has been the most active figure in seeking recompense, said that he still believes that repar- ations should be paid. Mr Ross wants public recognition of what had happened: "We were taught nothing about it as children. It wasn't until I was in high school that I heard about it."
fields.bodyText: George Monroe can still recall vividly the summer night in Tulsa, Oklahoma, nearly 80 years ago. "My mother saw four men with torches coming towards our house," Mr Monroe, now 85 and a slim, dignified war veteran, said: "Everything was burning outside and you could hear gunshots. She told us kids - I was five - to get under the bed and hide." He can still remember peering from under the bed at the men's boots as they stomped in and set fire to the curtains. False rumours that a black shoe-shiner called Dick Rowland had molested a white lift operator called Sarah Page had swept Tulsa that week and on May 31 1921 - as the local newspaper, the Tulsa Tribune, ran the headline "To Lynch Negro Tonight" - a white mob, including the Ku Klux Klan, rampaged through the middle-class Greenwood area, known at the time as the "black Wall Street". Rowland escaped. It is not known what happened to him later, but one rumour is that he eloped to Kansas with Page. Many of the people of Greenwood were not so fortunate. At the end of the night's mayhem at least 40 members of the thriving black community had been killed in one of the worst race riots the US has seen. Now a panel officially appointed to investigate the Tulsa riot has recommended that Mr Monroe and the other 120 remaining survivors be paid reparations in some form, a decision seen as highly significant for the reparations movement in the US, which has argued for African Americans to receive compensation for slavery and discrimination. The Tulsa Race Riot Commission, appointed by the state legislature, delivered its final 200-page report this week to the governor of Oklahoma, Frank Keating. It says reparations "will stand as symbols that fully acknowledge and finally discharge a collective responsibility". At least 40 died in the riots although researchers suggest that the number killed could be as high as 300, as many were buried in mass graves,. The commission has concluded that the true death toll will probably never be known. "Not one of these criminal acts was then or ever has been prosecuted or punished by the government at any level, municipal, county, state or federal," the report said. The commission has recommended five forms of reparation: cash payments to the 121 survivors, cash payments to authenticated descendants of survivors, a scholarship fund in memory of those who died, business incentives to revive the Greenwood area where the riot took place and a memorial. The state has already agreed to a $5m memorial and support for the revitalisation of the area. However, reactions to the recommendation of reparations varied."Some com pensation may be in order," the state house speaker, Larry Adair, said, but added: "I think we need to be very cautious on making any commitments on how money is spent in the state of Oklahoma." Governor Keating said that he favoured raising money for a suitable memorial for the victims but does not support specific financial reparations for the descendants of the survivors. "If you can show liability on the part of the state, city and county, I do support reparations to survivors," he added.The issue will now be debated in the state legislature. Eddiefaye Gates, the chairwoman of the survivors' committee and a member of the commission, said yesterday that resistance to the idea of compensation was unsurprising. "There is something about this whole nation when it comes to black people," said Ms Gates. "We did it for the native Americans whose land had been taken, we did it for the Japanese Americans who were interned during the war and had their property taken but when it comes to black people, we don't do it." Plans for the memorial have already been approved but Ms Gates said that legislators were obliged to do this because a memorial has already been completed for the victims of the much more recent Oklahoma City bombing. Ms Gates, whose committee has tracked down 121 survivors so far, said that she was still finding more all over the US. The furthest away survivor she had located was a jazz musician in Paris called Hal Singer, who was a baby at the time. The Oklahoma representative Don Ross, whose bill in the state legislature set up the inquiry and who has been the most active figure in seeking recompense, said that he still believes that repar- ations should be paid. webTitle: One in 10 suffers knock-on harm in hospital

fields.headline: One in 10 suffers knock-on harm in hospital
fields.trailText: More than one patient in every 10 admitted to hospital for treatment will suffer some sort of harm while they are there, according to the first study of its kind in the UK.
fields.body:
More than one patient in every 10 admitted to hospital for treatment will suffer some sort of harm while they are there, according to the first study of its kind in the UK.

The toll of what are known as "adverse events", ranging from picking up a minor infection on the ward to the recent tragedies when patients have died through drugs being injected in the wrong part of the body, costs the NHS around £1bn a yearin extra treatment, says the study, published today in the British Medical Journal.

That is besides the high cost of litigation - £77m compensation was paid to patients last year - and the human cost in suffering for patients and their relatives.

Although there have been studies in the US and Australia to establish how many patients suffer unexpected harm in hospital, the exercise by Charles Vincent, professor of psychology, and colleagues in the clinical risk unit of University College London has never been undertaken before in the UK.

They found that the rate of adverse events in their pilot study of 1,014 patients in two London hospitals was 10.8%. Since some patients suffered more than one event, the percentage of medical misadventures was still higher, at 11.7%.

This is considerably higher than the 3.7% recorded by a Harvard study in the US, but lower than the Australian figure of 16.6%. The team found that half the adverse events in the UK were preventable. "I strongly suspected there was a problem of this magnitude," said Professor Vincent. "I don't think we have faced up to the scale of it or the economic consequences of it."

Prof Vincent was a member of the panel put together by the chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, which last year launched a blueprint for the NHS to report mistakes and learn from them.

The document, An Organisation With a Memory, promised confidential phone lines for medical staff to report mistakes anonymously and central databases which would reveal common and preventable mistakes.

But little appears to have happened so far, and without precise data for the rates and numbers of mistakes being made by doctors and nurses, it will be impossible to tell whether the confidential reporting system is aware of more than the tip of the iceberg.

"Reporting is not going to tell you what is going on where, and how much it is costing," Prof Vincent said.

He and his team want to carry out a large-scale study to provide a picture of the rate and cost of adverse events nationwide.

In an editorial in the BMJ, Sir George Alberti, president of the Royal College of Physicians, concurs. "Only a full-scale study can substantiate this estimate, and if the NHS is serious about learning about and reducing errors it should fund such a study," he writes.

But Prof Vincent has tried without success to get financial backing for the work, which raises questions as to how eager the NHS is to know the truth about medical error.

The mistakes that are made in hospital were "much more often an accumulation of small things rather than one big blunder, such as problems in record-keeping and delays", he said. Some were barely preventable, such as bedsores, but others could certainly have been avoided, such as infections picked up after surgery by patients who should have been given antibiotics as a preventative measure.

In his editorial, Sir George points out that there are things that can be done to prevent errors happening, once it is clear what is going on. Better surgical training is needed.

"Fewer operations and procedures during the night may also help," he says.

Drugs errors remain a problem, but Birmingham has a computer linked pharmacology system, which sends out warnings when drugs that could be dangerous in combination are prescribed.

"The introduction of such a system nationwide could prevent hundreds, indeed thousands, of errors," he writes.

There may be more mistakes made by doctors than even this study suggests, Sir George says, because not every error leads to harm to the patient. "A pilot study by the Royal College of Physicians into deaths after admission for medical emergencies suggests that some error occurred in as many as one in five cases.. These data should be interpreted cautiously, but do suggest that actual recorded adverse events are the tip of the iceberg."

webTitle: Hollywood reporter: Don't make me go back

fields.headline: Don't make me go back
fields.standfirst: The new extended version of Apocalypse Now shows that Coppola's talent is burnt out
fields.trailText: The new extended version of Apocalypse Now shows that Coppola's talent is burnt out
fields.body:
Francis Ford Coppola must be feeling the pinch these days. Why else is he releasing an expanded version of the 21-year-old Apocalypse Now? The last time he dug this deeply into his back catalogue he came up with the dreadful Godfather 3, a movie erected as mere scaffolding for a global marketing campaign. Godfather 3 blighted the memory of its two predecessors, which, taken together, represent Coppola's greatest achievement and one of the greatest American films since the second world war. Coppola later admitted that the three-quel paid his back taxes, and that admission - as well as the film itself - proved what had long been suspected: the Emperor of Zoetrope had no clothes and was clad only in the ashes of his former glory.

By releasing an expanded Apocalypse Now, Coppola is turning the clock back to 1979, the last time he could seriously be called an outstanding American film-maker. The past 20 years have been hard on those of us who once expected of him a great and distinguished career. Instead, we have realised that two Godfathers, one Conversation, bits of The Rain People and about two-thirds of Apocalypse were all he really had in him. There have been blips in his decline: parts of Rumble Fish, One from the Heart and even The Cotton Club are marvellous, but have we any serious takers for Jack, Bram Stoker's Dracula, The Rainmaker, or Life Without Zoe - his toe-curling contribution to New York Stories?

The impression one gets from collaborators and biographers is that Coppola was creatively bankrupted by Apocalypse Now's five-year production schedule, which included a harrowing 238-day shoot in Marcos's Philippines and 18 months in the editing suite. Accounts of the shoot refer to monsoons destroying whole sets, adultery, a prodigious collective intake of posh Hollywood narcotics, stars having heart attacks, and a director becoming increasingly messianic. Co-screenwriter John Milius, a self-described "right-wing anarchist" fond of martial metaphors, says that "All the veterans on Apocalypse Now look back on it exactly as veterans look back on the war". Strange - I don't recall GIs at the siege of Khe Sahn asking for fresh lobsters and caviar to be airlifted to them.

So why now? And why not five years ago, when a micro-magazine named Film Threat, which I worked for at the time, got hold of a version fully two hours longer than the forthcoming "expanded cut"? FT detailed its contents in an extensive article in April 1996, and called upon Coppola to release a version containing this extra footage, which he had once told Rolling Stone didn't exist. We put it on the cover, with hints of what it contained: "The five-hour version you must see! See Sheen stabbing children! Hopper's death scene! Brando blabbing!"

We'd been given an nth-generation video dub of an assembly print that included almost all the workably coherent material. About seven more Doors songs appeared on the rudimentary soundtrack, which still lacked Michael Herr's narration (we all agreed we didn't miss it). The Playboy bunnies sequence was much longer: the bunny-copter has run out of fuel, but Sheen offers them some from his boat if his crew can boff the bunnies. There's an interlude at a French rubber plantation (which has been restored to the "expanded" version), and a sexual encounter between the lady of the house and Martin Sheen's stone-hearted Willard. Dennis Hopper's blitzed photo-journalist is murdered by Scott Glenn (who's only in two shots of the '79 cut), and Glenn is almost immediately killed by Sheen. Willard is altogether more psychopathic. On the way to execute Brando's Kurtz, he stabs three more people to death, including a father and child whom he skewers on the same spear. Sheen also shows flashes of humour, including a JFK impersonation he uses to soften up Duvall's more human Kilgore.

Among the less welcome additions are endless shots of helicopters and a bloated, more Charles Manson-like Brando reading the New York Times to the captive Willard. The cut also lacked certain scenes, marked with "scene missing" title cards, so it's possible to imagine a version lasting up to six hours.

Film Threat didn't say where the rough-cut had come from ("We found it. In our office. Over behind that chair," was what we printed); but when we called Coppola's office to hassle him about releasing an expanded cut, his people pinpointed our source in one guess. The Zoetrope lawyers were on the phone pronto, demanding the return of the tape and all dubs and generally crying blue murder. That's the last anyone heard about the matter until Coppola's announcement this week.

I've come to think that Apocalypse Now is a film you finally grow out of. As Coppola said in 1979: "It's less of a movie and more of an experience." It's a theme-park movie, each bravura sequence a different thrill-ride, the parts greater than the whole, the ending almost wilfully incoherent and unintegrated. The borrowings from Werner Herzog's Aguirre: Wrath of God (just as spectacular and more intellectually rigorous - on a budget of $300,000) are innumerable. The final sequence, in which Willard sacrifices Kurtz, is almost a shot-for-shot remake of The Host, a film-school graduation short by Coppola's UCLA classmate, Corman B-director Jack Hill.

A few years ago, Hill told me that The Host's cameraman was on the crew of Apocalypse when Coppola crowed about his new ending: "We're remaking Jack Hill's graduation movie!" The affable Hill said he didn't mind a bit, though he would have liked some acknowledgment. Funny - that's what we Film Threat vets all said this week.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: The Luzhin Defence | Me, Myself & Irene | There's Only One Jimmy Grimble
fields.trailText: The Luzhin Defence | Me, Myself & Irene | There's Only One Jimmy Grimble
fields.body:
The Luzhin Defence
Rental and DVD rental EV Cert 12

Kubrick's Lolita apart, Vladimir Nabokov has not translated well to the screen, but this is an honourable attempt to reproduce his book's feverish obsessiveness. John Turturro is the chess fanatic incapable of any other life. He is tongue-tied when he meets Emily Watson, until she asks him how long he's been playing chess. "Nine thousand, two hundred and sixty-three days, four hours" is the response. Will Watson become a pawn in his game or vice-versa? The two relationships in Turturro's life, with his new girlfriend and his embittered ex- mentor (Stuart Wilson) mirror those of difficult talents in Shine and The Color of Money. Turturro is a master of oddball roles, and his pale, distracted bundle of nerves is another believable creation, as is Watson's protective lover. It's elegantly filmed by Dutch director Marleen Gorris, though Boaz Yakin's Fresh still beats it to the title of best chess-as-metaphor-for-life film.

Me, Myself & Irene
Rental and DVD rental Fox Pathé Cert 15

The Farrelly brothers' comedies show no sign of progression and the law of diminishing returns is setting in fast. Dumb & Dumber and Kingpin had cherishable moments, but these came from ensemble playing . Here, to all intents and purposes, Jim Carrey's co-star is himself, which is a lot more Carrey than is good for the film. His official co-star is René e Zellweger, a good dramatic actress who shows no flair for comedy (which doesn't bode well for her forthcoming Bridget Jones). Carrey is the Rhode Island policeman "trapped behind a wall of politeness" who discovers his other self. In other words it's The Mask without a mask, and much less fun. The comedy is based, as ever, on scatology and mental illness, but it is also the most sentimental Farrelly outing yet. It was condemned by mental health groups for muddling schizophrenia and split personality. It should also offend cows, chickens, black and short people: about par for the course, then.

There's Only One Jimmy Grimble
Rental Fox Pathé Cert 12

As believable as Billy the Fish and as convincing as the Bradford City attack, this is one more dismal British football film. Robert Carlyle is an ex-Manchester City striker who once scored a hat-trick against United but goes unrecognised as a local school football coach. If you can believe that, you are asked to swallow Ray Winstone as a diehard City fan. Mancunian, my arse, as the great philosopher Jim Royle might say. It's full of sentimental homilies and clunky scripting. I felt most sorry for Lewis McKenzie, very likable as the aspiring kid footballer of the title.

fields.headline: The Tao of Steve
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: First feature from director Jenniphr Goodman with a pleasing touch of John Sayles in its unshowy, yet adroit handling of quietly intelligent performances.
fields.body:
An amiable, aimless slacker-ish movie about how to make it with women, based on the time-honoured idea of a guy with fiendishly cunning rules of seduction whose cosy world is upended when he really does fall for someone. It's a slightly windblown indie feature set in Santa Fe with un-pretty actors who look startlingly like real people. It is a first feature from director Jenniphr Goodman with a pleasing touch of John Sayles in its unshowy, yet adroit handling of quietly intelligent performances.

Donal Logue plays Dex, who comes to his 10-year college reunion, shocking (and secretly delighting) his contemporaries with the fact that he has become fat and does not have a high-flying job. But this former womaniser and straight-A philosophy student still has the old magic and has in fact fused his two enthusiasms into what he calls "The Tao of Steve".

This turns out to be a quasi-Buddhist approach to getting women into bed, named after Steve because of Dex's belief that this is the male name that most transcendentally captures the quintessence of sexual attractiveness, or Steve-ness, and involves entering a kind of mystical state of non-desiring, so that the women do all the work of chasing and seducing.

Dex's philosophy often looks like nothing so much as a Gen-X version of Stephen Potter's lifemanship classes. Inevitably, Dex finds himself warily hung up on a female ex-classmate, Syd (Greer Goodman, sister of the director). The effect is a shrugging sort of emotional reticence, in a breezy, likable film.

fields.headline: Proof of Life
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: The movie is supposedly inspired by a Vanity Fair article about the world of the counter-kidnap professionals, but by the final laughable reel it is about as genuine as Trumpton.
fields.body:
He's back. He might not be rubbing his hands in the dirt before a martial encounter, and he's doing the low sexy growl in his native Australian accent rather than American. But he's still showing off his manly bulk in a military outfit, and he has the same gallant, courtly, undemonstrative regard for a lady. Russell Crowe is Terry, an ex-SAS hombre and one of the new anti-kidnapping professionals hired by big corporations whose executives get snatched in the far-flung godless countries whose mineral resources they are there to exploit.

Meg Ryan is Alice, wife of Peter (David Morse) an engineer working in a Latin American country, building a dam to facilitate an oil pipeline. Peter gets kidnapped; Terry is called in to work with Alice and one thing leads to another.

The movie is supposedly inspired by a Vanity Fair article about the world of the counter-kidnap professionals, but by the final laughable reel it is about as genuine as Trumpton. This is because real-life ransom negotiation is essentially about the inglorious business of paying off kidnappers. There is no question of Russ doing this, naturally. So he ends up going in for a 21st-century, post-Rambo all-out rescue mission, in which the foreigners don't get a penny; they get their asses kicked and precisely none of Terry's guys get killed. And of course Peter himself is not allowed to be just a passive hostage: to be a red-blooded US male worthy of Meg Ryan's love he has to shoot a kidnapper and even lead a temporarily blinded Russ to safety.

It's all just fantasy, needless to say, for all the magazine-article "research". A complete no-brainer. Ryan does her usual routine of being on the verge of tears by wrinkling up her nose, and looking as if she is being tickled with a giant invisible feather. And there is a good deal of falling into Crowe's manly, dependable arms and sobbing. Though you keep expecting her to throw back her head and howl: "I'm gonna be 40."

fields.headline: Chocolat
fields.standfirst:
Even Juliette Binoche cannot redeem Lasse
Hallstrom's sickly, soft-centred confection,
says Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Like a two-hour version of one of those TV ads targeted patronisingly at the female consumer, coyly suggesting that chocolate is the new sex, or maybe that sex is the new chocolate.
fields.body:
This is a gooey, sticky, mushy, sickly-sweet confection of a movie; it tastes much more like the dairy milk chocolate proffered to the uneducated Gump-ish palates of Britain and America than the dark, bitter substance preferred by the discerning French. Watching this very self-conscious comedy-romance is a bit like being forced to eat a Thornton's factory out of business.

Chocolat is directed by Lasse Hallstrom, the man who in The Cider House Rules took the themes of racial prejudice and sexual abuse and suffused them in a weirdly benign glow. Hallstrom turns the feelgood bestseller by British author Joanne Harris into what looks like a two-hour version of one of those TV ads targeted patronisingly at the female consumer, coyly suggesting that chocolate is the new sex, or maybe that sex is the new chocolate. It certainly suggests that filling your face with chocolate is a richly joyous, warmly sensual, life-affirming and above all giving experience - and in itself a devastating rebuke to the tyrannies of the Roman Catholic church.

It's got a strong cast doing their best. Only a churl would not feel his heart lift at the sight of the star, Juliette Binoche. Her grace, beauty and intelligence are subjects on which I have descanted in the past, and to which I shall return when Michael Haneke's Code Unknown is released later this year. But here she is let down by having to play the ineffably smug part of Vianne, a free-spirited woman who turns up in an uptight French town in the late 1950s. It is here that a Clochemerlesque comedy unfolds.

Accompanied by her daughter Anouk (Victoire Thivisol), Binoche opens up a chocolaterie - presumably drawing upon a substantial reserve of capital - and mischievously yet adorably unlocks the sensuality of the townsfolk. This she does with her strangely saucy creations. She is aided and abetted by her elderly landlady Armande, played with vigour and poise by Judi Dench.

Unhappily, however, Binoche's heroine has chosen the beginning of Lent for this adventure and, worse, proposes a (preposterous) "chocolate festival" to coincide with Easter Sunday. The cut of her jib offends the Comte de Reynaud, aristocratic mayor and pillar of the church, a right old misery-guts who sets out to ruin her. This role is gamely played by the superb Alfred Molina, all tightly buttoned discomfiture and sweaty, pop-eyed self-denial, displaced into ill-humoured disapproval of anyone else enjoying themselves.

Molina is a heavyweight performer who can pack a real punch. But only a fraction of his power is uncoiled the way it was in such parts as Kenneth Halliwell and John Ogden. And this is because of the way that Hallstrom emphasises the movie's whole naughty-but-nice ethos. Molina is supposed to be an unpleasant bigot, and when we fleetingly see Africans delivering the raw material for Binoche's shop, a racial dimension to the comte's loathing of the chocolaterie is, perhaps, subliminally suggested.

Furthermore, he refers in passing to his forebears having booted out the Huguenots. But Hallstrom presents us with an oddly flavourless, odourless, unhistorical sort of bigotry. The obvious subject, anti-semitism, is absent, and Molina has a line making it clear that he sincerely disapproved of collaborators during the war - hardly a convincing side for a reactionary Catholic toff to take, I suggest. No, the comte is obviously ripe for eventual redemption since, like everything in this film, he has a soft centre.

Bigotry is what brings us to the most groan-inducingly awful part of the film: Johnny Depp, playing a hunky riverboat traveller called Roux with a hunky ponytail and hunky facial hair. He is one of the Gypsies loathed by the comte. Roux is not on the screen for long, but it's quite long enough. Despite his character's name, Mr Depp has evidently decided that he is not comfortable with the 'Allo 'Allo Franglais voices imposed on everyone else, so he plays him as an Irishman with what is supposed to be an Irish accent. For this he ought to be shot at dawn, or preferably earlier. It's similar to the Gypsy he played in Sally Potter's The Man Who Cried, only much, much more embarrassing.

He's always to be found a-hummin' and a-strummin' on his guitar, a fascinating lone-wolf figure. Needless to say, Roux is the kindred spirit with whom Juliette elects to get it on for a rare bit of non-chocolate-oriented, off-camera loving. Then he is off, footloose force of nature that he is, taking with him our sincere good wishes and a heartfelt request that Mr Depp give the free-spirit Romany roles a miss from now on.

The sheer, unmitigated ickiness of the film is what gets you down in the end. That and the supercilious association of chocolate with sex. It's got all the taste and style of "erotic" chocolate body-paint kits on sale at British Home Stores.

fields.headline: The Gift
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Lots of people in the film have been taking what seems to be a Berlitz cassette-tape course in How to Speak Hollywood Blue-Collar.
fields.body:
A Simple Plan was director Sam Raimi's much-admired graduation from genre shlock to serious movie-making. Now, sadly, he has given us what can only be described as An Unnecessarily Complicated and Boring Plan, having already tried our patience last year with the sugary baseball movie For Love of the Game. The Gift is a garbled supernatural thriller set in down-home Georgia with a peculiar element of old-fashioned Cluedo-ish whodunnit.

Cate Blanchett is Annie, a widow with three boys, who is blessed with the "gift": second sight. (She is supposedly based on co-writer Billy Bob Thornton's mother.) With this sixth sense, she can see soon-to-be-dead people. One in particular: southern belle Jessica King, played by Dawson's Creek ex-teen star Katie Holmes. Despite being a wealthy daddy's girl, she is engaged to humble schoolteacher Greg Kinnear (one of the film's many implausibilities) but turns out to have been fooling around with most of Georgia's male population. After her violent fate is made known, we are tacitly invited to indulge in any number of Colonel-Mustard-with-the-candlestick speculations. And all the time, our Cate is assailed with lightning-flash visions of blood, mud, corpses, chains and who knows what else.

Lots of people in the film - Blanchett herself, Giovanni Ribisi as the local disturbed mechanic, Hilary Swank as the local battered wife - have been taking what seems to be a Berlitz cassette-tape course in How to Speak Hollywood Blue-Collar. They all do that very earnestly authentic actor's impression of trailer trash: "Ah wen day-un ter thuh stow-uh", etc.

The worst offender, I am sorry to say, is Keanu Reeves, an actor who regained his place in our hearts with The Matrix, but looks like losing it with his absurd and unpleasant performance as Donnie, a boorish redneck who raises his hay-und to his wife and threatens Cate and the kee-uds. His plump face is lumpen with malign stupidity, and an unwelcome change from the ingenuous perplexity of Neo. To paraphrase Margot Beste-Chetwynde in Evelyn Waugh: we like you puzzled, Keanu, but not absolutely cretinous.

fields.headline: Misadventures by Sylvia Smith
fields.standfirst:
Canongate, £9.99
Condensed in the style of the original
fields.trailText: Throughout my childhood my parents supplied me with a variety of pets. We once kept 24 goldfish outside in an old boiler; I've often wondered whether they minded swimming in the dark. Sadly they died when the water froze. I also had a tortoise; sadly that died, too.
fields.body:
Throughout my childhood my parents supplied me with a variety of pets. We once kept 24 goldfish outside in an old boiler; I've often wondered whether they minded swimming in the dark. Sadly they died when the water froze. I also had a tortoise; sadly that died, too.

Beth was a very pretty 14-year-old. She took me to see Mandy, her heavily pregnant sister. Unbeknownst to Mandy, Beth was having sex with her boyfriend.

Carol and I worked together. Each Christmas I would buy her some toiletries. She told her mum, "At least you know what Sylvie is going to give you."

My friend Gloria once caught the director sitting on the toilet with his trousers down; we all had a good laugh about that. My father and I once got piles at the same time. That wasn't so funny.

I saw a woman getting soaked by a passing car, but she carried on as if nothing untoward had happened.

My relationship with John lasted three dances. His chat-up line was, "I work for the BBC." It turned out he meant Barking Borough Council.

Hilary and I met at the social club. She told me that her daughter Francesca had shat herself in the swimming pool but she didn't think anyone else had noticed. John S and I also met at the social club; he used to arrange coach journeys to Europe and overcharge everyone so he could go free. Sadly he was going bald.

Malcolm and I met at a large social event. On one date he took me to the cinema and spent 20 minutes in the gentlemen's toilets. He never apologised when he came out. I also went out with Ghalib but was shocked to find he had amorous thoughts in another direction.

When I reached the age of 40, I decided I needed to make some money. I bought some premium bonds. Sadly I would have been better off keeping my money in the Post Office.

A little boy was hit by a car outside the doctor's surgery. Afterwards we all said that there couldn't be a better place to have an accident.

A flower seller once asked me to marry him after I smiled at him. I declined. I also saw a man with brown stains on his white shorts; I decided he must have a touch of diarrhoea.

And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested: The Diary of a Nobody for the 21st century

fields.headline: Zimbabwe's charismatic leader
fields.standfirst:
Oliver Mtukudzi
Barbican
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Oliver Mtukudzi
Barbican
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
"Are there any Zimbabweans in the house tonight?" called Oliver Mtukudzi, as he arrived on stage. He almost induced a standing ovation before producing a single note. Later, he tried to introduce a song with the words: "In Zimbabwe, where I come from ... " He got no further: the hall erupted. For the audience, many of whom had roots in Africa, this was a visit from royalty.

The man who has inspired what's known as "Tuku beat", drawing on both western and African influences, from pop to township jive, rumba to traditional Shona rhythms, took the audience by storm last year when he performed with fellow Zimbabwean Thomas Mapfumo in the Barbican's Africa Roots and Shoots festival. Here, despite the charged atmosphere, the band, Black Spirits, began in relaxed fashion with a simple piano intro, over which Mtukudzi laid a few uncomplicated ideas on guitar.

Mary Bell and Mwendakanyi Isabel Chibindi arrived to provide backing vocals along with Erick Kasamba, and the tune gently crescendoed with the aid of pipe organ sounds from the keyboard. Tendai Samson Mataure on drums introduced a smattering of heart-stopping cymbal smashes, and in one moment of vacuum, Mtukudzi stepped forward: "Good evening, ladies and gentlemen. Are you happy?" The audience's squeals told him he was on the right track.

The singer's first hit in Zimbabwe came more than 20 years ago with a group called the Wagon Wheels and his potent, throaty voice has since earned him the sobriquet of Africa's answer to Otis Redding. One of the evening's more moving moments was when Mtukudzi dedicated a song to a "brother" who had died of Aids in 1996, yet even in this slightly slower number the beat stayed breezy. The first half of the evening was brought to a humorous close by the Spirits departing one by one from the stage, leaving Takundwa Kennedy Neshamba, a conga player with an infectious grin, to round off the piece.

The evening got progressively more boppy, helped by the fact that many in the audience knew the lyrics. At first, enthusiasts filed neatly to the front of the hall to dance in a little cluster to one side. Soon the aisles were bustling, and by the second half, the melee of jiving fans on the stairs was so thick that ushers' attempts to shoo people back into seats went unheeded.

One fan was so anxious to get close to Mtukudzi that she climbed onto the stage and clung to the amplifier as two security guards tried to winkle her away. Moments later she was back, dancing happily behind the great man until forcibly removed. Mtukudzi, who later indulged in his own spot of dancing, to the delight of the audience, was like the Pied Piper - mesmerising, charismatic, the leader of the gang.

fields.headline: I want to be creative
fields.trailText: 2 March: I feel that I have made nothing but a succession of mistakes. All my life I have painted and being a painter is all I ever wanted to do. However, I am woefully unambitious.
fields.body:
The problem

Basically I am 27 and I feel that I have made nothing but a succession of mistakes. All my life I have painted and being a painter is all I ever wanted to do. However, I am woefully unambitious and in the current art world talent only counts for 20% of the big picture.

To shorten the story, I did not achieve the forecasted results for my degree and it ruined my future plans. In desperation I took a post-graduate teaching course and embarked on a teaching career, something that would have horrified me only a few years ago. I hate it and feel in a complete rut. How do I get out of this and pursue something creative.

The solution

I can't help feeling sad that at the tender age of 27 you feel that your life has been a 'succession of mistakes'. You have a degree in fine art, some experience of the world and a post-graduate teaching qualification - hardly indicative of a lifetime of mistakes. However, you have ended up in a place you never thought you would - an ordinary, uncreative job - and this is why you feel so desperately disappointed. You say that you are "woefully unambitious", but if you are to get yourself out of this rut, you will need to summon up all your enthusiasm and ambition, be and act positive and make the changes happen yourself.

With your background, the most obvious career that springs to mind is teaching art (you do not say what subject you currently teach). I know of people with arts degrees who teach art at secondary level either part or full-time in order to fund artistic pursuits in their own studio. Others teach adults in the evenings, or at further education colleges in order to fund their painting. If this does not sound challenging enough, what about using art to help disadvantaged children, or those with learning or other disabilities? Keep an eye on the Guardian job pages for ideas of jobs out there.

There are various alternative creative careers such as stage set design or window design (window dressing). Take a trip to the careers advice office at your nearest University to discover all the options and find out how to get an opening in them. The goal I believe you should be aiming for is a fulfilling, creative career that will also allow you to paint at home or in your own studio. But, you will need determination and drive to turn this goal into reality.

webTitle: Labour woos voters with budget spend

fields.headline: Labour woos voters with budget spend
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown is in a strong position, with an £18 billion tax surplus, as he prepares next Wednesday's budget.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown is in a strong position, with an £18 billion tax surplus, as he prepares next Wednesday's budget.

Experts are currently pondering how much he will give away in a budget that could put Labour in a strong position to win a likely May election.

That said, at a Labour pre-election rally last month, Mr Brown said there will be no return to the "irresponsible pre-election give-aways of the past."

Instead, his pre-election budget will "lock in the tough fiscal stance" set out in last year's budget and November's pre-budget report.

Brown will be keenly aware of a recent warning from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) that "it would be prudent to abstain from introducing significant new spending commitments or tax cuts in the March 2001 budget."

Despite this, he is already committed to helping pensioners and motorists as outlined in his November mini-budget. The Treasury estimates these measures will cost £2.6 billion in the coming financial year, with £1.7 billion set aside for motorists.

The chancellor has announced that the government would run a bigger surplus in 2001-02 than forecast in the 2000 budget since revenues were turning out to be higher than he had projected last March. It is estimated he has around £4 billion in tax breaks to give away according to the Institute of Fiscal Studies.

What is likely on Budget Day?

Pensioners
Actuaries Bacon & Woodrow say there will be sweeteners for pensioners in the budget. It believes there could be measures to level the playing field between traditional final salary pension schemes and the new stakeholder schemes, to be launched in April.

This could mean greater flexibility to take cash from additional voluntary contributions and buy investment-linked annuities.

It's been hinted the chancellor will reject calls to drop the pension annuity system. But, he may re-examine the strict rules governing annuities as part of a wider assessment of the pensions and savings industry. This review is likely to include poor performing "with-profits" policies such as those offered by the floundering Equitable Life.

Under annuity rules, 75% of money accumulated in a pension fund must be used to buy an annuity to provide a regular income. The Treasury is concerned this arrangement does not allow the best deal for those who want to use their funds more flexibly.

But, the stumbling block to scrapping the restriction altogether would be the cost to the exchequer. Payments from annuities are liable for income tax, whereas lump sums taken from pension funds are not.

Single OAPs will get £5 more from April 2001and an extra £3 in April 2002. Married couples will get £8, then £4.80. Personal allowances are to be increased by £240 more than inflation in 2003-4 says KPMG.

Income Tax
There is not expected to be any change in the basic rate of tax of 22%, but there should be a promise to reduce this to 20% over the next five years.

Mr Brown may widen the 10% income-tax band. When the chancellor first introduced this in 1999, it was billed as a measure that targeted low earners. But, a widening of the 10% band from £1,580 to £2,050-at a cost of £1.3 billion-would also benefit upper-middle-income households, says the Institute for Fiscal Studies.

PricewaterhouseCoopers predicts the starting point for the 40% income tax rate band to be marginally raised from its current level of £28,400.

Capital Gains Tax
The chancellor may increase Capital Gains Tax relief to promote an entrepreneurial culture, according to KPMG.

PricewaterhouseCoopers expects amendments, but nothing above the inflationary increase for the £7,200 gain you can make before paying tax.

Tax Credits
The main Budget focus will be on tax cuts for families with children - including a rise from £8.50 to £10 a week in the children's tax credit, an uprating of the working families' tax credit, a measure for parents of infants under one, and a rise in statutory maternity pay and paid maternity leave. Increases to the Working Families' Tax Credit are also likely. There could also be help for workplace nurseries and helping employers set these up and run them.

Share Options
Larger tax breaks for share options in small, high-risk companies are expected to be unveiled on Wednesday. The so-called enterprise management incentive gives tax relief on share options worth up to £100,000 per employee. Its aim is to help growing companies hold on to staff.

While the scheme was introduced last autumn, it is limited to 15 employees per company. Now it is expected to be extended to all employees up to a ceiling of £2.5 million of a company's shares - £1 million higher than the original limit.

KPMG predicts the chancellor will raise the long-standing £30,000 limit on company share option schemes to nearer £100,000. He may also relax the requirement for 3 years to lapse between approved exercises of these options, it says.

Shares
Although the investment industry wants to see a change to the way stamp duty is charged on buying shares, it is understood no change is planned.

Cigarettes
PricewaterhouseCoopers predict a modest increase in duty on cigarettes, the money raised to be set aside for the health service. A small percentage may also be earmarked for anti-smuggling strategies.

Alcohol
There is little change expected - duties will only rise by inflation. This would drive the price of beer up by 1p and the price of wine up by 3p.

Betting
The government is trying to find a way of dealing with the arrival of Internet betting. It could suggest a tax on bookmakers' gross profits, rather than turnover, in return for abolition of off-course betting duty.

Businesses
Labour wants to seen as a pro-business party that looks after the UK's entrepreneurs. He is likely to announce more generous tax relief on share options for employees in smaller, high-risk companies than the proposed £2.5m limit for an individual firm.

He will also announce plans for a research and development tax credit for larger companies, although this will require the agreement of the European Commission.

The national minimum wage, currently £3.70 an hour, is set to be increased by around 10%, the second rise since its introduction two years ago.

webTitle: Airtours to shut 120 high street shops

fields.headline: Airtours to shut 120 high street shops
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Airtours is closing 120 of its Going Places and Travelworld high street shops as a result of consumers increasingly booking holidays over the telephone.
fields.body:
Airtours is closing 120 of its Going Places and Travelworld high street shops as a result of consumers increasingly booking holidays over the telephone.

The move, which will reduce the group's number of high street stores to 720, will affect about 550 staff.

However, Richard Carrick, the chief executive of the group's UK Leisure Group division, said the firm hoped to redeploy all affected staff elsewhere in the group.

The majority of the shops to be closed are branded under the Going Places name. The fate of the above shop in Truro, Cornwall, is yet to be announced.

webTitle: Top pay for top performers only

fields.headline: Top pay for top performers only
fields.standfirst:
Notebook Byers should back ABI message
Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Big bosses' pay is back on the agenda, with new guidelines yesterday from the Association of British Insurers demanding that executive share incentive schemes show a clear link to performance.
fields.body:
Big bosses' pay is back on the agenda, with new guidelines yesterday from the Association of British Insurers demanding that executive share incentive schemes show a clear link to performance.

At the same time the ABI, which speaks for institutions managing over £1,000bn in total, has endorsed the growing trend towards phased annual grants of options or shares, which it believes do motivate executives to improve shareholder returns.

This potentially opens the door to much higher pay deals for Britain's corporate ruling class.

Expect to see more of the packages enjoyed by people such as Matt Barrett at Barclays and Martin Sorrell at WPP, where exceptional share price performance promises spectacular "compensation" packages.

The ABI has also made it clear that its new guidelines will only permit companies to adopt American-style pay deals - where options simply replace cash and are not performance driven - in the most exceptional of circumstances.

Firms would have to prove they were under true global pressure and unable to hire a particular executive to dodge the rules.

The ABI has avoided setting any sort of upper limit on pay, but says it only wants top money for top people, with sliding scales of performance always linked to the relative performance of peer companies. Bad managers should get nothing, it says.

This would all appear to be quite sensible and grown-up. But maintaining the fight against vulgar pay packets for shoddy corporate leadership will require the ABI to demonstrate clearly that it has little time for abuses of its code.

Understanding the pay deals being offered will be the first step.

There is a need to root out attempts to hide big packages behind legal jargon. Shareholders should be able to see the potential total and how it might be earned.

Meanwhile, 18 months of silence has passed since Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, promised to get tough on boardroom excesses.

Since he has clearly been struggling to find something to say on the issue, perhaps he should start by backing the ABI's message.

Bandit territory

The public, supported by the press, has long demanded that the financial services industry is stringently regulated. The pressure for clean money has been such that the City is now far and away the most closely monitored financial centre in Europe.

We have umpteen thousand bureaucrats sitting in the financial services authority at Canary Wharf. Every financial firm has a compliance officer to make sure rules are adhered to. Just about every telephone call made in the Square Mile is recorded. Anyone and everyone can be interviewed at a moment's notice by the financial police, without any proper right to silence, under the threat of jail and/or an unlimited fine.

It is positively Orwellian, and it also costs a fortune. So those in the financial industry must be faintly bemused by the response of the newspaper industry to secondary legislation now proposed by the Treasury which would make it mandatory for any journalist tipping a share or other investment to declare any interest, such as owning the share being tipped.

"Completely unworkable," bellowed Les Hinton, chairman of the newspaper industry's code of practice committee and executive chairman of News International. "Think again," instructed a Times leader column.

There are two main threads to the newspaper industry's response. One is that state regulation of the press of any kind is a no-no in peacetime. The other is that the proposed legislation does not take into account the complexities of newspaper production. Several people can be involved in a decision to tip a particular share and a tipsters' column will typically pass through several hands before reaching the printers. Where, it is asked, might the declarations of interest begin and end?

These are fair objections. But in marshalling its response the newspaper industry should remember that its City desks are quite lucky to be excluded from the regulatory dragnet which makes a misery of life in the City proper. If calls to this office were recorded, there would be a lot of blank space in these pages.

At the same time, it should also be noted that the Treasury and the FSA are not really gunning for the national press. The real problem lies with bandit tip sheets and alleged investment web-sites which claim journalistic privilege, but which are not tied to the industry code of practice. They have little need to maintain high professional standards.

In fact, the issue here is not about making sure readers as customers are fully informed. It is about stealing money from readers through insider dealing.

fields.headline: Pura Pasion
fields.standfirst:
Peacock Theatre
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Peacock Theatre
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
You can see why flamenco dancers in the year 2001 might be desperate for an alternative to spotted, flouncey dresses, fake carnations and the make-believe that they're a bunch of Gypsies gathered in an Andalusian village square. But Pura Pasion, the latest production headed by Cristobal Reyes (and co-produced by his superstar nephew Joaquin Cortes), doesn't come up with a very convincing future for the dance form.

The updated trappings of the show are mostly fine - moody, colour-drenched lighting, fashionably cut costumes and a band augmented by drums, keyboard, flute and heavy amplification. But the dancing itself, vaunted as the new fusion flamenco and segueing old-style flamenco with quasi-Riverdance routines, fake ballet and even faker Indian and African motifs, often looks a mess.

The truth is that any traditional dance form can be reinvented but it requires talent and vision from its choreographers and dancers. Reyes, who has created much of the movement for Pura Pasion, is certainly a powerful dancer. In his 16-minute solo, Saeta al Cachorro, there may be an irksome preponderance of preening and a sense of self-congratulation as much as concentration, but the lineaments of flamenco are fiercely instinctive. As he builds the solo to its climax, his famously fast, controlled footwork orchestrates a spectacular fantasy of pianissimo heel drumming and hail storms of stamping.

His choreography for the other dancers in the company is often less sure, though, especially when it pushes too hard against the familiar parameters of the dance. Straining after novelty, Reyes fumbles for contrasts, placing gauche slow-motion moves for the chorus against punchy solos, or having his women dancers cross-dressing with male flamenco. A more genuine reinterpretation appears in the dancing of Rafaela Carrasco, who performs solos in some of Reyes's credited pieces but I suspect also does her own thing. Like Reyes, she embodies many traditional elements of flamenco - and like him dances with a thrillingly driven edge. But she also possesses a sensuously full-bodied style that in the Solea: Desafio al Baile especially allows her to expand her moves into slow, languorous turns and vertiginous spirals, as well as articulating a witty syncopation. In Carrasco flamenco finds a natural fusion with jazz and modern dance.

The top female billing goes to Lola Greco, however, for reasons that I can't connect to her dancing. Along with her choreographer Dagmara Brown, Greco has concocted a style of new-age flamenco in which she floats around the stage, kicking up her legs, ballet style, and posing like some latterday Isadora Duncan. Sometimes, in a nod to flamenco's affiliations with African and Indian dance, Greco is accompanied by a harem-style chorus whose bare midriffs and crudely flexed limbs have all the oriental credentials of a Las Vegas cabaret show.

 Until March 17. Box office: 020-7863 8222.

fields.headline: Tommy Tiernan
fields.standfirst:
Gardner Arts Centre
Brighton
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Gardner Arts Centre
Brighton
Rating: ***
fields.body:
The people of Brighton must have Britain's smallest bladders. Either that, or the Gardner Centre's bar staff have put something in the beer. For most of Tommy Tiernan's show, someone is either walking across the front of the stalls in a can't-stop-or-I'm-gonna-wet-myself sort of way, then banging out through the swing doors, or making the return trip in that apologetic half-crouch perfected by fidgety cinema-goers.

Add in the usual idiots too idle to turn off their mobile phones, and you understand why so many stand-up comedians seek the more controllable world of television. Tiernan himself has parlayed his 1998 Perrier award into a string of TV jobs, including compere of BBC1's The Stand-Up Show and a lead role in Channel 4's limp sitcom Small Potatoes.

To Tiernan's credit, he does not let the interruptions rattle him. Instead he works his old shtick as the sweet-natured, self-deprecating Irish slacker, meditating on death, fatherhood, the screwed-upness of his compatriots and his alleged status as a "massive sex god". (He is, it's true, far less pasty-faced than he once was.) He doesn't rely on quick wit alone: more thoughtful than many comics, he has even talked seriously of standing for the Irish parliament.

At its best this show confirms how good traditional stand-up can be. At its worst ... well, there are a handful of crass, poorly thought-through jokes about the Paralympics and mental illness that should have been tied up in a sack and thrown off Beachy Head.

Overall, the evening never quite coheres. Tiernan tries in vain to Polyfilla the cracks between the longer routines with musings such as: "Are you familiar with the phrase, 'The mind boggles'? Does anything else boggle?" He looks tired, and the way he repeatedly calls Brighton Bristol suggests that touring is taking its toll. But the crowd love it, and if only 60 of the 90 minutes are inspiring, that's 45 more than many of his peers could manage.

 At the Gordon Craig Theatre, Stevenage (08700 131 030), tonight, the Corn Exchange, Cambridge (01223 357851), tomorrow, then touring.

fields.headline: Shoppers shrug off US contagion
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Retailers and manufacturers enjoyed increased sales in February, figures showed yesterday, easing fears that Britain is suffering from the slowdown in the US economy.
fields.body:
Retailers and manufacturers enjoyed increased sales in February, figures showed yesterday, easing fears that Britain is suffering from the slowdown in the US economy.

Bank of England officials warned earlier this week that the American downturn could hinder UK economic growth. But analysts said that in yesterday's data there were few signs of a slowdown.

Manufacturers reported the fastest rise in orders for more than a year in February, according to the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply (Cips).

A separate survey from the Confederation of British Industry showed that retail sales slowed slightly in February after a robust performance in January, but retailers were optimistic about the future.

"There is no evidence here of consumer demand slowing rapidly," said, Ross Walker, UK economist at Royal Bank of Scotland. "Expectations among retailers suggest things can get better still. It will take more than a bit of contagion [either from the US or from pigs] to dent the Great British public's appetite for spending money."

But other analysts warned that the manufacturing sector was still fragile despite the upbeat tone of the Cips survey.

House prices fell sharply last month, according to Nationwide, which will ease worries at the Bank that the market is overheating. Prices fell by 0.8%, taking the average property price to £83,314, the biggest monthly drop since June 1995. The annual rate of house price growth is now running at 8.1% compared with 17.5% last spring, according to the building society.

The fall followed a 2.5% rise in prices in January which was described as the biggest monthly increase since the boom days of 1988-89.

A Nationwide spokesman said that the February fall was partly linked to a slowdown in house buying activity in London, the region that has led the upturn in the property market.

fields.headline: English Touring Opera takes a gamble
fields.standfirst:
Manon
Arts Theatre
Cambridge
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Manon
Arts Theatre
Cambridge
Rating: **
fields.body:
Massenet's Manon is not an obvious choice for a company such as English Touring Opera, which has to produce robust, portable stagings that can be adapted to all shapes and sizes of theatres. To do it justice, the work needs a fairly lavish staging, complete with sizable chorus and decent choreography, so that at least the set pieces can go with a bit of a sparkle; otherwise an evening among all those wretched people - there are few operas with a less endearing line-up of characters - can seem a very long time indeed. Musically, it needs stylish performances by a top-notch cast and efficient orchestra, while sopranos who can successfully tackle the title role don't grow on trees.

It is good to report that ETO's new production by Gordon Anderson confounds at least some of those prejudices. A cast of just 18 singers (only Manon and Des Grieux are excused duty in the chorus line) work tremendously hard to bring this sprawling, infuriating piece to life. The contrast between public glitter and private amorality is certainly made; and they even manage a little bit of a dance routine for Manon's third-act gavotte. Jamie Vartan's birdcage set may be a slightly weary metaphor, but is adaptable enough to suggest the railway station at Amiens, Des Grieux's Paris apartment, a fairground by the Seine and the church of St Sulpice, though it can't cope with the final act on the road to Le Havre, which has to be played out before a plain cloth.

Within these parameters Anderson doesn't do much other than get everyone on and off the stage efficiently, but then ETO's brief isn't to take deconstructed opera around the country, just simple, practical shows, sung in English. It certainly provides an effective showcase for Kate Ladner's Manon, who shows she has the vocal agility and the top notes for the role, and makes a good stab at pinning down the ambiguity of the character, who is not so much a tragic heroine, more a pain in the arse. The rest of the cast is workmanlike rather than notable: Des Grieux is Andrew Burden, reportedly suffering from a cold on the first night; De Bretigny, Benjamin Bland; Lescaut, Howard Quilla Croft. The conductor Andrew Greenwood understands how the score goes, and should get better results from the orchestra when they know it properly; there is a long tour in prospect.

 Further performance tonight. Box office: 01223 503333. Then touring to Reading, Brighton, Poole and around Britain until June 1.

webTitle: Theatre review: Bambi - The Wilderness Years

fields.headline: Bambi versus the terrorists
fields.standfirst:
Bambi - The Wilderness Years
Lyric Studio
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Bambi - The Wilderness Years
Lyric Studio
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Forget Disney and the cute little creature with big watery eyes. In puppeteers Green Ginger's version of the story, based on Felix Saltern's original 1926 tale, Bambi becomes a young boy living in an urban jungle. Here the hunters are called Visors and ruthlessly hunt down the dispossessed such as Bambi and his family, who live on a car tip. Green Ginger's nightmarish vision is closer to Saltern's tale than Disney's 1942 film, which sanitised the story and omitted all reference to Bambi's handicapped brother Gobo, and his search for his dad.

This 80-minute descent into a world of fear, terrorist cells, haves and have-nots, hunters and hunted, isn't a pretty sight; nor is it what you'd call either an enjoyable or particularly coherent evening. But Green Ginger will make you gasp with the scale of its theatrical imagination, its highly developed sense of the bizarre and the brilliance of its puppetry technique.

Sometimes you are not sure whether you are watching a puppet or a live actor, and film is seamlessly spliced into the performance. The ingenuity is staggering, the unconventionality always poised at the point of freakishness. The skill involved is beyond doubt. Yet cleverly it also relates to a real world. Poised between future, present and past, the show succeeds in conveying some of the sense of terror, despair and horror of living under apartheid in South Africa or in the Balkans.

That is not to say that it all works. But this is so different from almost anything else that you're ever likely to see in the theatre that it deserves an audience. Failure with such flair is a rare and wonderful thing.

 Until March 10. Box office: 020-8741 2311.
